author: Grimms
sentence: In a certain mill lived an old miller who had neither wife nor child, and three apprentices served under him.

author: Grimms
sentence: As they had been with him several years, he one day said to them, "I am old, and want to sit in the chimney-corner, go out, and whichsoever of you brings me the best horse home, to him will I give the mill, and in return for it he shall take care of me till my death."

author: Grimms
sentence: The third of the boys was, however, the drudge, who was looked on as foolish by the others; they begrudged the mill to him, and afterwards he would not have it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then all three went out together, and when they came to the village, the two said to stupid Hans, "Thou mayst just as well stay here, as long as thou livest thou wilt never get a horse."

author: Grimms
sentence: Hans, however, went with them, and when it was night they came to a cave in which they lay down to sleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: The two sharp ones waited until Hans had fallen asleep, then they got up, and went away leaving him where he was.

author: Grimms
sentence: And they thought they had done a very clever thing, but it was certain to turn out ill for them.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the sun arose, and Hans woke up, he was lying in a deep cavern.

author: Grimms
sentence: He looked around on every side and exclaimed, "Oh, heavens, where am I?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he got up and clambered out of the cave, went into the forest, and thought, "Here I am quite alone and deserted, how shall I obtain a horse now?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Whilst he was thus walking full of thought, he met a small tabby-cat which said quite kindly, "Hans, where are you going?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Alas, thou canst not help me.

author: Grimms
sentence: I well know your desire, said the cat.

author: Grimms
sentence:
You wish to have a beautiful horse.
14:14	N:N	N:N	Come with me, and be my faithful servant for seven years long, and then I will give you one more beautiful than any you have ever seen in your whole life.

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, this is a wonderful cat! thought Hans, "but I am determined to see if she is telling the truth."

author: Grimms
sentence: So she took him with her into her enchanted castle, where there were nothing but cats who were her servants.

author: Grimms
sentence: They leapt nimbly upstairs and downstairs, and were merry and happy.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the evening when they sat down to dinner, three of them had to make music.

author: Grimms
sentence: One played the bassoon, the other the fiddle, and the third put the trumpet to his lips, and blew out his cheeks as much as he possibly could.

author: Grimms
sentence: When they had dined, the table was carried away, and the cat said, "Now, Hans, come and dance with me."

author: Grimms
sentence: No, said he, "I won"t dance with a pussy cat.

author: Grimms
sentence: I have never done that yet."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then take him to bed, said she to the cats.

author: Grimms
sentence: So one of them lighted him to his bed-room, one pulled his shoes off, one his stockings, and at last one of them blew out the candle.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next morning they returned and helped him out of bed, one put his stockings on for him, one tied his garters, one brought his shoes, one washed him, and one dried his face with her tail.

author: Grimms
sentence: That feels very soft! said Hans.

author: Grimms
sentence: He, however, had to serve the cat, and chop some wood every day, and to do that, he had an axe of silver, and the wedge and saw were of silver and the mallet of copper.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he chopped the wood small; stayed there in the house and had good meat and drink, but never saw anyone but the tabby-cat and her servants.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once she said to him, "Go and mow my meadow, and dry the grass," and gave him a scythe of silver, and a whetstone of gold, but bade him deliver them up again carefully.

author: Grimms
sentence: So Hans went thither, and did what he was bidden, and when he had finished the work, he carried the scythe, whetstone, and hay to the house, and asked if it was not yet time for her to give him his reward.

author: Grimms
sentence: No, said the cat, "you must first do something more for me of the same kind.

author: Grimms
sentence: There is timber of silver, carpenter"s axe, square, and everything that is needful, all of silver, with these build me a small house."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Hans built the small house, and said that he had now done everything, and still he had no horse.

author: Grimms
sentence: Nevertheless the seven years had gone by with him as if they were six months.

author: Grimms
sentence: The cat asked him if he would like to see her horses?

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said Hans.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she opened the door of the small house, and when she had opened it, there stood twelve horses, such horses, so bright and shining, that his heart rejoiced at the sight of them.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now she gave him to eat and drink, and said, "Go home, I will not give thee thy horse away with thee; but in three days" time I will follow thee and bring it."

author: Grimms
sentence: So Hans set out, and she showed him the way to the mill.

author: Grimms
sentence: She had, however, never once given him a new coat, and he had been obliged to keep on his dirty old smock-frock, which he had brought with him, and which during the seven years had everywhere become too small for him.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he reached home, the two other apprentices were there again as well, and each of them certainly had brought a horse with him, but one of them was a blind one, and the other lame.

author: Grimms
sentence: They asked Hans where his horse was.

author: Grimms
sentence: It will follow me in three days time."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they laughed and said, "Indeed, stupid Hans, where wilt thou get a horse?"

author: Grimms
sentence: It will be a fine one!

author: Grimms
sentence: Hans went into the parlour, but the miller said he should not sit down to table, for he was so ragged and torn, that they would all be ashamed of him if any one came in.

author: Grimms
sentence: So they gave him a mouthful of food outside, and at night, when they went to rest, the two others would not let him have a bed, and at last he was forced to creep into the goose-house, and lie down on a little hard straw.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the morning when he awoke, the three days had passed, and a coach came with six horses and they shone so bright that it was delightful to see them! and a servant brought a seventh as well, which was for the poor miller"s boy.

author: Grimms
sentence: And a magnificent princess alighted from the coach and went into the mill, and this princess was the little tabby-cat whom poor Hans had served for seven years.

author: Grimms
sentence: She asked the miller where the miller"s boy and drudge was?

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the miller said, "We cannot have him here in the mill, for he is so ragged; he is lying in the goose-house."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the King"s daughter said that they were to bring him immediately.

author: Grimms
sentence: So they brought him out, and he had to hold his little smock-frock together to cover himself.

author: Grimms
sentence: The servants unpacked splendid garments, and washed him and dressed him, and when that was done, no King could have looked more handsome.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the maiden desired to see the horses which the other apprentices had brought home with them, and one of them was blind and the other lame.

author: Grimms
sentence: So she ordered the servant to bring the seventh horse, and when the miller saw it, he said that such a horse as that had never yet entered his yard.

author: Grimms
sentence: And that is for the third millers boy," said she.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he must have the mill, said the miller, but the King"s daughter said that the horse was there, and that he was to keep his mill as well, and took her faithful Hans and set him in the coach, and drove away with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: They first drove to the little house which he had built with the silver tools, and behold it was a great castle, and everything inside it was of silver and gold; and then she married him, and he was rich, so rich that he had enough for all the rest of his life.

author: Grimms
sentence: After this, let no one ever say that anyone who is silly can never become a person of importance.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once on a time a princess who was extremely proud.

author: Grimms
sentence: If a wooer came she gave him some riddle to guess, and if he could not find it out, he was sent contemptuously away.

author: Grimms
sentence: She let it be made known also that whosoever solved her riddle should marry her, let him be who he might.

author: Grimms
sentence: At length, therefore, three tailors fell in with each other, the two eldest of whom thought they had done so many dexterous bits of work successfully that they could not fail to succeed in this also; the third was a little useless land-louper, who did not even know his trade, but thought he must have some luck in this venture, for where else was it to come from?

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the two others said to him, "Just stay at home; thou canst not do much with thy little bit of understanding."

author: Grimms
sentence: The little tailor, however, did not let himself be discouraged, and said he had set his head to work about this for once, and he would manage well enough, and he went forth as if the whole world were his.

author: Grimms
sentence: They all three announced themselves to the princess, and said she was to propound her riddle to them, and that the right persons were now come, who had understandings so fine that they could be threaded in a needle.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the princess, "I have two kinds of hair on my head, of what color is it?"

author: Grimms
sentence: If that be all, said the first, "it must be black and white, like the cloth which is called pepper and salt."

author: Grimms
sentence: The princess said, "Wrongly guessed; let the second answer."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the second, "If it be not black and white, then it is brown and red, like my father"s company coat."

author: Grimms
sentence: Wrongly guessed, said the princess, "let the third give the answer, for I see very well he knows it for certain."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the little tailor stepped boldly forth and said, "The princess has a silver and a golden hair on her head, and those are the two different colors."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the princess heard that, she turned pale and nearly fell down with terror, for the little tailor had guessed her riddle, and she had firmly believed that no man on earth could discover it.

author: Grimms
sentence: When her courage returned she said, "Thou hast not won me yet by that; there is still something else that thou must do.

author: Grimms
sentence: Below, in the stable is a bear with which thou shalt pass the night, and when I get up in the morning if thou art still alive, thou shalt marry me."

author: Grimms
sentence: She expected, however, she should thus get rid of the tailor, for the bear had never yet left any one alive who had fallen into his clutches.

author: Grimms
sentence: The little tailor did not let himself be frightened away, but was quite delighted, and said, "Boldly ventured is half won."

author: Grimms
sentence: When therefore the evening came, our little tailor was taken down to the bear.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bear was about to set at the little fellow at once, and give him a hearty welcome with his paws: "Softly, softly," said the little tailor, "I will soon make thee quiet."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then quite composedly, and as if he had not an anxiety in the world, he took some nuts out of his pocket, cracked them, and ate the kernels.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the bear saw that, he was seized with a desire to have some nuts too.

author: Grimms
sentence: The tailor felt in his pockets, and reached him a handful; they were, however, not nuts, but pebbles.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bear put them in his mouth, but could get nothing out of them, let him bite as he would.

author: Grimms
sentence: Eh! thought he, "what a stupid blockhead I am!

author: Grimms
sentence: I cannot even crack a nut!" and then he said to the tailor, "Here, crack me the nuts."

author: Grimms
sentence: There, see what a stupid fellow thou art! said the little tailor, "to have such a great mouth, and not be able to crack a small nut!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he took the pebble and nimbly put a nut in his mouth in the place of it, and crack, it was in two!

author: Grimms
sentence: I must try the thing again, said the bear; "when I watch you, I then think I ought to be able to do it too."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the tailor once more gave him a pebble, and the bear tried and tried to bite into it with all the strength of his body.

author: Grimms
sentence: But no one will imagine that he accomplished it.

author: Grimms
sentence: When that was over, the tailor took out a violin from beneath his coat, and played a piece of it to himself.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the bear heard the music, he could not help beginning to dance, and when he had danced a while, the thing pleased him so well that he said to the little tailor, "Hark you, is the fiddle heavy?"

author: Grimms
sentence:
Light enough for a child.

author: Grimms
sentence: So, said the bear; "fiddling is a thing I should like to understand too, that I might dance whenever I had a fancy.

author: Grimms
sentence: What dost thou think of that?

author: Grimms
sentence: Wilt thou give me lessons?

sentence: With all my heart, said the tailor, "if thou hast a talent for it.

author: Grimms
sentence: But just let me see thy claws, they are terribly long, I must cut thy nails a little."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then a vise was brought, and the bear put his claws in it, and the little tailor screwed it tight, and said, "Now wait until I come with the scissors," and he let the bear growl as he liked, and lay down in the corner on a bundle of straw, and fell asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the princess heard the bear growling so fiercely during the night, she believed nothing else but that he was growling for joy, and had made an end of the tailor.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the morning she arose careless and happy, but when she peeped into the stable, the tailor stood gaily before her, and was as healthy as a fish in water.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now she could not say another word against the wedding because she had given a promise before every one, and the King ordered a carriage to be brought in which she was to drive to church with the tailor, and there she was to be married.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: The princess heard him snorting and growling; she was terrified, and she cried, "Ah, the bear is behind us and wants to get thee!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The tailor was quick and stood on his head, stuck his legs out of the window, and cried, "Dost thou see the vise?

author: Grimms
sentence: If thou dost not be off thou shalt be put into it again."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the bear saw that, he turned round and ran away.

author: Grimms
sentence: Little brother took his little sister by the hand and said, "Since our mother died we have had no happiness; our step-mother beats us every day, and if we come near her she kicks us away with her foot.

author: Grimms
sentence: Our meals are the hard crusts of bread that are left over; and the little dog under the table is better off, for she often throws it a nice bit.

author: Grimms
sentence: May Heaven pity us.

author: Grimms
sentence: If our mother only knew!

author: Grimms
sentence: Come, we will go forth together into the wide world."

author: Grimms
sentence: They walked the whole day over meadows, fields, and stony places; and when it rained the little sister said, "Heaven and our hearts are weeping together."

author: Grimms
sentence: In the evening they came to a large forest, and they were so weary with sorrow and hunger and the long walk, that they lay down in a hollow tree and fell asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next day when they awoke, the sun was already high in the sky, and shone down hot into the tree.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the brother said, "Sister, I am thirsty; if I knew of a little brook I would go and just take a drink; I think I hear one running."

author: Grimms
sentence: The brother got up and took the little sister by the hand, and they set off to find the brook.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the wicked step-mother was a witch, and had seen how the two children had gone away, and had crept after them privily, as witches do creep, and had bewitched all the brooks in the forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now when they found a little brook leaping brightly over the stones, the brother was going to drink out of it, but the sister heard how it said as it ran, "Who drinks of me will be a tiger; who drinks of me will be a tiger."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the sister cried, "Pray, dear brother, do not drink, or you will become a wild beast, and tear me to pieces."

author: Grimms
sentence: The brother did not drink, although he was so thirsty, but said, "I will wait for the next spring."

author: Grimms
sentence: When they came to the next brook the sister heard this also say, "Who drinks of me will be a wolf; who drinks of me will be a wolf."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the sister cried out, "Pray, dear brother, do not drink, or you will become a wolf, and devour me."

author: Grimms
sentence: The brother did not drink, and said, "I will wait until we come to the next spring, but then I must drink, say what you like; for my thirst is too great."

author: Grimms
sentence: And when they came to the third brook the sister heard how it said as it ran, "Who drinks of me will be a roebuck; who drinks of me will be a roebuck."

author: Grimms
sentence: The sister said, "Oh, I pray you, dear brother, do not drink, or you will become a roebuck, and run away from me."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the brother had knelt down at once by the brook, and had bent down and drunk some of the water, and as soon as the first drops touched his lips he lay there a young roebuck.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now the sister wept over her poor bewitched brother, and the little roe wept also, and sat sorrowfully near to her.

author: Grimms
sentence: But at last the girl said, "Be quiet, dear little roe, I will never, never leave you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she untied her golden garter and put it round the roebuck"s neck, and she plucked rushes and wove them into a soft cord.

author: Grimms
sentence: With this she tied the little beast and led it on, and she walked deeper and deeper into the forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when they had gone a very long way they came at last to a little house, and the girl looked in; and as it was empty, she thought, "We can stay here and live."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she sought for leaves and moss to make a soft bed for the roe; and every morning she went out and gathered roots and berries and nuts for herself, and brought tender grass for the roe, who ate out of her hand, and was content and played round about her.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the evening, when the sister was tired, and had said her prayer, she laid her head upon the roebuck"s back: that was her pillow, and she slept softly on it.

author: Grimms
sentence: And if only the brother had had his human form it would have been a delightful life.

author: Grimms
sentence: For some time they were alone like this in the wilderness.

author: Grimms
sentence: But it happened that the King of the country held a great hunt in the forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the blasts of the horns, the barking of dogs, and the merry shouts of the huntsmen rang through the trees, and the roebuck heard all, and was only too anxious to be there.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, said he, to his sister, "let me be off to the hunt, I cannot bear it any longer;" and he begged so much that at last she agreed.

author: Grimms
sentence: But, said she to him, "come back to me in the evening; I must shut my door for fear of the rough huntsmen, so knock and say, "My little sister, let me in!" that I may know you; and if you do not say that, I shall not open the door."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the young roebuck sprang away; so happy was he and so merry in the open air.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King and the huntsmen saw the pretty creature, and started after him, but they could not catch him, and when they thought that they surely had him, away he sprang through the bushes and could not be seen.

author: Grimms
sentence: When it was dark he ran to the cottage, knocked, and said, "My little sister, let me in."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the door was opened for him, and he jumped in, and rested himself the whole night through upon his soft bed.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next day the hunt went on afresh, and when the roebuck again heard the bugle-horn, and the ho! ho! of the huntsmen, he had no peace, but said, "Sister, let me out, I must be off."

author: Grimms
sentence: His sister opened the door for him, and said, "But you must be here again in the evening and say your pass-word."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the King and his huntsmen again saw the young roebuck with the golden collar, they all chased him, but he was too quick and nimble for them.

author: Grimms
sentence: This went on for the whole day, but at last by the evening the huntsmen had surrounded him, and one of them wounded him a little in the foot, so that he limped and ran slowly.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then a hunter crept after him to the cottage and heard how he said, "My little sister, let me in," and saw that the door was opened for him, and was shut again at once.

author: Grimms
sentence: The huntsman took notice of it all, and went to the King and told him what he had seen and heard.

author: Grimms

sentence: Then the door opened, and the King walked in, and there stood a maiden more lovely than any he had ever seen.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: But the King looked kindly at her, stretched out his hand, and said, "Will you go with me to my palace and be my dear wife?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, indeed, answered the maiden, "but the little roe must go with me, I cannot leave him."

sentence: The King said, "It shall stay with you as long as you live, and shall want nothing."

author: Grimms
sentence: The King took the lovely maiden upon his horse and carried her to his palace, where the wedding was held with great pomp.

author: Grimms
sentence: She was now the Queen, and they lived for a long time happily together; the roebuck was tended and cherished, and ran about in the palace-garden.

sentence: The daughter also was close by; so they carried the weakly Queen into the bath-room, and put her into the bath; then they shut the door and ran away.

sentence: But in the bath-room they had made a fire of such deadly heat that the beautiful young Queen was soon suffocated.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the King could not restrain himself; he sprang towards her, and said, "You can be none other than my dear wife."

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she told the King the evil deed which the wicked witch and her daughter had been guilty of towards her.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a man whose wife died, and a woman whose husband died, and the man had a daughter, and the woman also had a daughter.

author: Grimms
sentence: The girls were acquainted with each other, and went out walking together, and afterwards came to the woman in her house.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said she to the man"s daughter, "Listen, tell thy father that I would like to marry him, and then thou shalt wash thyself in milk every morning, and drink wine, but my own daughter shall wash herself in water and drink water."

author: Grimms
sentence: The girl went home, and told her father what the woman had said.

author: Grimms
sentence: The man said, "What shall I do?

author: Grimms
sentence: Marriage is a joy and also a torment."

author: Grimms
sentence: At length as he could come to no decision, he pulled off his boot, and said, "Take this boot, it has a hole in the sole of it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Go with it up to the loft, hang it on the big nail, and then pour water into it.

author: Grimms
sentence: If it hold the water, then I will again take a wife, but if it run through, I will not."

author: Grimms
sentence: The girl did as she was ordered, but the water drew the hole together, and the boot became full to the top.

author: Grimms
sentence: She informed her father how it had turned out.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he himself went up, and when he saw that she was right, he went to the widow and wooed her, and the wedding was celebrated.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next morning, when the two girls got up, there stood before the man"s daughter milk for her to wash in and wine for her to drink, but before the woman"s daughter stood water to wash herself with and water for drinking.

author: Grimms
sentence: On the second morning, stood water for washing and water for drinking before the man"s daughter as well as before the woman"s daughter.

author: Grimms
sentence: And on the third morning stood water for washing and water for drinking before the man"s daughter, and milk for washing and wine for drinking, before the woman"s daughter, and so it continued.

author: Grimms
sentence: The woman became bitterly unkind to her step-daughter, and day by day did her best to treat her still worse.

author: Grimms
sentence: She was also envious because her step-daughter was beautiful and lovable, and her own daughter ugly and repulsive.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once, in winter, when everything was frozen as hard as a stone, and hill and vale lay covered with snow, the woman made a frock of paper, called her step-daughter, and said, "Here, put on this dress and go out into the wood, and fetch me a little basketful of strawberries,---I have a fancy for some."

author: Grimms
sentence: Good heavens! said the girl, "no strawberries grow in winter!

author: Grimms
sentence: The ground is frozen, and besides the snow has covered everything.

author: Grimms
sentence: And why am I to go in this paper frock?

author: Grimms
sentence: It is so cold outside that one"s very breath freezes!

author: Grimms
sentence: The wind will blow through the frock, and the thorns will tear it off my body."

author: Grimms
sentence: Wilt thou contradict me again? said the stepmother, "See that thou goest, and do not show thy face again until thou hast the basketful of strawberries!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she gave her a little piece of hard bread, and said, "This will last thee the day," and thought, "Thou wilt die of cold and hunger outside, and wilt never be seen again by me."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the maiden was obedient, and put on the paper frock, and went out with the basket.

author: Grimms
sentence: Far and wide there was nothing but snow, and not a green blade to be seen.

author: Grimms
sentence: When she got into the wood she saw a small house out of which peeped three dwarfs.

author: Grimms
sentence: She wished them good day, and knocked modestly at the door.

author: Grimms
sentence: They cried, "Come in," and she entered the room and seated herself on the bench by the stove, where she began to warm herself and eat her breakfast.

author: Grimms
sentence: The elves said, "Give us, too, some of it."

author: Grimms
sentence: Willingly, she said, and divided her bit of bread in two and gave them the half.

author: Grimms
sentence: They asked, "What dost thou here in the forest in the winter time, in thy thin dress?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, she answered, "I am to look for a basketful of strawberries, and am not to go home until I can take them with me."

author: Grimms
sentence: When she had eaten her bread, they gave her a broom and said, "Sweep away the snow at the back door with it."

author: Grimms
sentence: But when she was outside, the three little men said to each other, "What shall we give her as she is so good, and has shared her bread with us?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the first, "My gift is, that she shall every day grow more beautiful."

author: Grimms
sentence: The second said, "My gift is, that gold pieces shall fall out of her mouth every time she speaks."

author: Grimms
sentence: The third said, "My gift is, that a king shall come and take her to wife."

author: Grimms
sentence: The girl, however, did as the little men had bidden her, swept away the snow behind the little house with the broom, and what did she find but real ripe strawberries, which came up quite dark-red out of the snow!

author: Grimms
sentence: In her joy she hastily gathered her basket full, thanked the little men, shook hands with each of them, and ran home to take her step-mother what she had longed for so much.

author: Grimms
sentence: When she went in and said good-evening, a piece of gold at once fell from her mouth.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon she related what had happened to her in the wood, but with every word she spoke, gold pieces fell from her mouth, until very soon the whole room was covered with them.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now look at her arrogance, cried the step-sister, "to throw about gold in that way!" but she was secretly envious of it, and wanted to go into the forest also to seek strawberries.

author: Grimms
sentence: The mother said, "No, my dear little daughter, it is too cold, thou mightest die of cold."

author: Grimms
sentence: However, as her daughter let her have no peace, the mother at last yielded, made her a magnificent dress of fur, which she was obliged to put on, and gave her bread-and-butter and cake with her.

author: Grimms
sentence: The girl went into the forest and straight up to the little house.

author: Grimms
sentence: The three little elves peeped out again, but she did not greet them, and without looking round at them and without speaking to them, she went awkwardly into the room, seated herself by the stove, and began to eat her bread-and-butter and cake.

author: Grimms
sentence: Give us some of it, cried the little men; but she replied, "There is not enough for myself, so how can I give it away to other people?"

author: Grimms
sentence: When she had done eating, they said, "There is a broom for thee, sweep all clean for us outside by the back-door."

author: Grimms
sentence:
Humph!

author: Grimms
sentence: When she saw that they were not going to give her anything, she went out by the door.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the little men said to each other, "What shall we give her as she is so naughty, and has a wicked envious heart, that will never let her do a good turn to any one?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The first said, "I grant that she may grow uglier every day."

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: The third said, "I grant that she may die a miserable death."

author: Grimms
sentence: The maiden looked for strawberries outside, but as she found none, she went angrily home.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the step-mother was still more enraged, and thought of nothing but how to do every possible injury to the man"s daughter, whose beauty, however, grew daily greater.

author: Grimms
sentence: At length she took a cauldron, set it on the fire, and boiled yarn in it.

author: Grimms
sentence: When it was boiled, she flung it on the poor girl"s shoulder, and gave her an axe in order that she might go on the frozen river, cut a hole in the ice, and rinse the yarn.

author: Grimms
sentence: She was obedient, went thither and cut a hole in the ice; and while she was in the midst of her cutting, a splendid carriage came driving up, in which sat the King.

author: Grimms
sentence: The carriage stopped, and the King asked,"My child, who are thou, and what art thou doing here?"

author: Grimms
sentence: I am a poor girl, and I am rinsing yarn.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the King felt compassion, and when he saw that she was so very beautiful, he said to her, "Wilt thou go away with me?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, yes, with all my heart, she answered, for she was glad to get away from the mother and sister.

author: Grimms
sentence: So she got into the carriage and drove away with the King, and when they arrived at his palace, the wedding was celebrated with great pomp, as the little men had granted to the maiden.

author: Grimms
sentence: When a year was over, the young Queen bore a son, and as the step-mother had heard of her great good-fortune, she came with her daughter to the palace and pretended that she wanted to pay her a visit.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once, however, when the King had gone out, and no one else was present, the wicked woman seized the Queen by the head, and her daughter seized her by the feet, and they lifted her out of the bed, and threw her out of the window into the stream which flowed by.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the ugly daughter laid herself in the bed, and the old woman covered her up over her head.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the King came home again and wanted to speak to his wife, the old woman cried, "Hush, hush, that can"t be now, she is lying in a violent perspiration; you must let her rest to-day."

author: Grimms
sentence: The King suspected no evil, and did not come back again till next morning; and as he talked with his wife and she answered him, with every word a toad leaped out, whereas formerly a piece of gold had fallen out.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he asked what that could be, but the old woman said that she had got that from the violent perspiration, and would soon lose it again.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon the King was full of great joy, but he kept the Queen hidden in a chamber until the Sunday, when the baby was to be christened.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when it was christened he said, "What does a person deserve who drags another out of bed and throws him in the water?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The wretch deserves nothing better, answered the old woman, "than to be taken and put in a barrel stuck full of nails, and rolled down hill into the water."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then, said the King, "Thou hast pronounced thine own sentence;" and he ordered such a barrel to be brought, and the old woman to be put into it with her daughter, and then the top was hammered on, and the barrel rolled down hill until it went into the river.

author: Grimms
sentence: Let no one ever say that a poor tailor cannot do great things and win high honors; all that is needed is that he should go to the right smithy, and what is of most consequence, that he should have good luck.

author: Grimms
sentence: A civil, adroit tailor"s apprentice once went out travelling, and came into a great forest, and, as he did not know the way, he lost himself.

author: Grimms
sentence: Night fell, and nothing was left for him to do, but to seek a bed in this painful solitude.

author: Grimms
sentence: He might certainly have found a good bed on the soft moss, but the fear of wild beasts let him have no rest there, and at last he was forced to make up his mind to spend the night in a tree.

author: Grimms
sentence: He sought out a high oak, climbed up to the top of it, and thanked God that he had his goose with him, for otherwise the wind which blew over the top of the tree would have carried him away.

author: Grimms
sentence: After he had spent some hours in the darkness, not without fear and trembling, he saw at a very short distance the glimmer of a light, and as he thought that a human habitation might be there, where he would be better off than on the branches of a tree, he got carefully down and went towards the light.

author: Grimms
sentence: It guided him to a small hut that was woven together of reeds and rushes.

author: Grimms
sentence: He knocked boldly, the door opened, and by the light which came forth he saw a little hoary old man who wore a coat made of bits of colored stuff sewn together.

author: Grimms
sentence: Who are you, and what do you want? asked the man in a grumbling voice.

author: Grimms
sentence: I am a poor tailor, he answered, "whom night has surprised here in the wilderness, and I earnestly beg you to take me into your hut until morning."

author: Grimms
sentence: Go your way, replied the old man in a surly voice, "I will have nothing to do with runagates; seek for yourself a shelter elsewhere."

author: Grimms
sentence: After these words he was about to slip into his hut again, but the tailor held him so tightly by the corner of his coat, and pleaded so piteously, that the old man, who was not so ill-natured as he wished to appear, was at last softened, and took him into the hut with him where he gave him something to eat, and then pointed out to him a very good bed in a corner.

author: Grimms
sentence: The weary tailor needed no rocking; but slept sweetly till morning, but even then would not have thought of getting up, if he had not been aroused by a great noise.

author: Grimms
sentence: A violent sound of screaming and roaring forced its way through the thin walls of the hut.

author: Grimms
sentence: The tailor, full of unwonted courage, jumped up, put his clothes on in haste, and hurried out.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then close by the hut, he saw a great black bull and a beautiful stag, which were just preparing for a violent struggle.

author: Grimms
sentence: They rushed at each other with such extreme rage that the ground shook with their trampling, and the air resounded with their cries.

author: Grimms
sentence: For a long time it was uncertain which of the two would gain the victory; at length the stag thrust his horns into his adversary"s body, whereupon the bull fell to the earth with a terrific roar, and was thoroughly despatched by a few strokes from the stag.

author: Grimms
sentence: The tailor, who had watched the fight with astonishment, was still standing there motionless, when the stag in full career bounded up to him, and before he could escape, caught him up on his great horns.

author: Grimms
sentence: He had not much time to collect his thoughts, for it went in a swift race over stock and stone, mountain and valley, wood and meadow.

author: Grimms
sentence: He held with both hands to the tops of the horns, and resigned himself to his fate.

author: Grimms
sentence: It seemed, however, to him just as if he were flying away.

author: Grimms
sentence: At length the stag stopped in front of a wall of rock, and gently let the tailor down.

author: Grimms
sentence: The tailor, more dead than alive, required a longer time than that to come to himself.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had in some degree recovered, the stag, which had remained standing by him, pushed its horns with such force against a door which was in the rock, that it sprang open.

author: Grimms
sentence: Flames of fire shot forth, after which followed a great smoke, which hid the stag from his sight.

author: Grimms
sentence: The tailor did not know what to do, or whither to turn, in order to get out of this desert and back to human beings again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Whilst he was standing thus undecided, a voice sounded out of the rock, which cried to him, "Enter without fear, no evil shall befall you thee."

author: Grimms
sentence: He hesitated, but driven by a mysterious force, he obeyed the voice and went through the iron-door into a large spacious hall, whose ceiling, walls and floor were made of shining polished square stones, on each of which were cut letters which were unknown to him.

author: Grimms
sentence: He looked at everything full of admiration, and was on the point of going out again, when he once more heard the voice which said to him, "Step on the stone which lies in the middle of the hall, and great good fortune awaits thee."

author: Grimms
sentence: His courage had already grown so great that he obeyed the order.

author: Grimms
sentence: The stone began to give way under his feet, and sank slowly down into the depths.

author: Grimms
sentence: When it was once more firm, and the tailor looked round, he found himself in a hall which in size resembled the former.

author: Grimms
sentence: Here, however, there was more to look at and to admire.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hollow places were cut in the walls, in which stood vases of transparent glass which were filled with colored spirit or with a bluish vapour.

author: Grimms
sentence: On the floor of the hall two great glass chests stood opposite to each other, which at once excited his curiosity.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he went to one of them he saw inside it a handsome structure like a castle surrounded by farm-buildings, stables and barns, and a quantity of other good things.

author: Grimms
sentence: Everything was small, but exceedingly carefully and delicately made, and seemed to be cut out by a dexterous hand with the greatest exactitude.

author: Grimms
sentence: He might not have turned away his eyes from the consideration of this rarity for some time, if the voice had not once more made itself heard.

author: Grimms
sentence: It ordered him to turn round and look at the glass chest which was standing opposite.

author: Grimms
sentence: How his admiration increased when he saw therein a maiden of the greatest beauty!

author: Grimms
sentence: She lay as if asleep, and was wrapped in her long fair hair as in a precious mantle.

author: Grimms
sentence: Her eyes were closely shut, but the brightness of her complexion and a ribbon which her breathing moved to and fro, left no doubt that she was alive.

author: Grimms
sentence: The tailor was looking at the beauty with beating heart, when she suddenly opened her eyes, and started up at the sight of him in joyful terror.

author: Grimms
sentence: Just Heaven! cried she, "my deliverance is at hand!

author: Grimms
sentence: Quick, quick, help me out of my prison; if thou pushest back the bolt of this glass coffin, then I shall be free."

author: Grimms
sentence: The tailor obeyed without delay, and she immediately raised up the glass lid, came out and hastened into the corner of the hall, where she covered herself with a large cloak.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she seated herself on a stone, ordered the young man to come to her, and after she had imprinted a friendly kiss on his lips, she said, "My long-desired deliverer, kind Heaven has guided thee to me, and put an end to my sorrows.

author: Grimms
sentence: On the self- same day when they end, shall thy happiness begin.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thou art the husband chosen for me by Heaven, and shalt pass thy life in unbroken joy, loved by me, and rich to overflowing in every earthly possession.

author: Grimms
sentence: Seat thyself, and listen to the story of my life:

author: Grimms
sentence:
I am the daughter of a rich count.

54:54	N:N	H:H	In our house there was no lack of company; neighbors and friends visited us often, and we showed the greatest hospitality to every one.
55:55	N:N	N:N	So it came to pass one evening that a stranger came riding to our castle, and, under pretext of not being able to get on to the next place, begged for shelter for the night.
56:56	N:N	N:N	We granted his request with ready courtesy, and he entertained us in the most agreeable manner during supper by conversation intermingled with stories.
57:57	N:H	N:H	My brother liked the stranger so much that he begged him to spend a couple of days with us, to which, after some hesitation, he consented.

61:61	N:N	-:S	I felt as if a mountain were weighing down my breast, and was unable to make the very slightest sound.
62:62	N:N	N:-	In the meantime, by the light of my night-lamp, I saw the stranger enter my room through two doors which were fast bolted.
63:63	N:N	N:-	He came to me and said, that by magic arts which were at his command, he had caused the lovely music to sound in order to awaken me, and that he now forced his way through all fastenings with the intention of offering me his hand and heart.
64:64	D:D	D:D	My repugnance to his magic arts was, however, so great, that I vouchsafed him no answer.
65:65	N:N	N:A	He remained for a time standing without moving, apparently with the idea of waiting for a favorable decision, but as I continued to keep silence, he angrily declared he would revenge himself and find means to punish my pride, and left the room.

67:67	N:N	N:F	When I awoke, I hurried to my brother, but did not find him in his room, and the attendants told me that he had ridden forth with the stranger to the chase by daybreak.
68:68	F:N	F:F	I at once suspected nothing good.

author: Grimms
sentence: I dressed myself quickly, ordered my palfrey to be saddled, and accompanied only by one servant, rode full gallop to the forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: The servant fell with his horse, and could not follow me, for the horse had broken its foot.

author: Grimms
sentence: I pursued my way without halting, and in a few minutes I saw the stranger coming towards me with a beautiful stag which he led by a cord.

author: Grimms
sentence: I asked him where he had left my brother, and how he had come by this stag, out of whose great eyes I saw tears flowing.

author: Grimms
sentence: Instead of answering me, he began to laugh loudly.

author: Grimms
sentence: I fell into a great rage at this, pulled out a pistol and discharged it at the monster; but the ball rebounded from his breast and went into my horse"s head.

author: Grimms
sentence: I fell to the ground, and the stranger muttered some words which deprived me of consciousness.

author: Grimms
sentence:
When I came to my senses again I found myself in this underground cave in a glass coffin.
77:77	N:N	-:S	The magician appeared once again, and said he had changed my brother into a stag, my castle with all that belonged to it, diminished in size by his arts, he had shut up in the other glass chest, and my people, who were all turned into smoke, he had confined in glass bottles.
78:78	N:N	N:S	He told me that if I would now comply with his wish, it was an easy thing for him to put everything back in its former state, as he had nothing to do but open the vessels, and everything would return once more to its natural form.
79:79	N:N	N:A	I answered him as little as I had done the first time.
80:80	N:N	N:S	He vanished and left me in my prison, in which a deep sleep came on me.
81:81	H:H	H:H	Amongst the visions which passed before my eyes, that was the most comforting in which a young man came and set me free, and when I opened my eyes to-day I saw thee, and beheld my dream fulfilled.
82:82	N:N	N:H	Help me to accomplish the other things which happened in those visions.

author: Grimms
sentence: As soon as the stone was laden, it began to rise up on high with the maiden and the young man, and mounted through the opening of the ceiling into the upper hall, from whence they then could easily reach the open air.

author: Grimms
sentence: Here the maiden opened the lid, and it was marvellous to behold how the castle, the houses, and the farm buildings which were enclosed, stretched themselves out and grew to their natural size with the greatest rapidity.

author: Grimms
sentence: After this, the maiden and the tailor returned to the cave beneath the earth, and had the vessels which were filled with smoke carried up by the stone.

author: Grimms
sentence: The maiden had scarcely opened the bottles when the blue smoke rushed out and changed itself into living men, in whom she recognized her servants and her people.

author: Grimms
sentence: Her joy was still more increased when her brother, who had killed the magician in the form of the bull, came out of the forest towards them in his human form, and on the self-same day the maiden, in accordance with her promise, gave her hand at the altar to the lucky tailor.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once on a time a poor man, who could no longer support his only son.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the son, "Dear father, things go so badly with us that I am a burden to you.

author: Grimms
sentence: I would rather go away and see how I can earn my bread."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the father gave him his blessing, and with great sorrow took leave of him.

author: Grimms
sentence: At this time the King of a mighty empire was at war, and the youth took service with him, and with him went out to fight.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when he came before the enemy, there was a battle, and great danger, and it rained shot until his comrades fell on all sides, and when the leader also was killed, those left were about to take flight, but the youth stepped forth, spoke boldly to them, and cried, "We will not let our fatherland be ruined!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the others followed him, and he pressed on and conquered the enemy.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the King heard that he owed the victory to him alone, he raised him above all the others, gave him great treasures, and made him the first in the kingdom.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King had a daughter who was very beautiful, but she was also very strange.

author: Grimms
sentence: She had made a vow to take no one as her lord and husband who did not promise to let himself be buried alive with her if she died first.

author: Grimms
sentence: If he loves me with all his heart, said she, "of what use will life be to him afterwards?"

author: Grimms
sentence: On her side she would do the same, and if he died first, would go down to the grave with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: This strange oath had up to this time frightened away all wooers, but the youth became so charmed with her beauty that he cared for nothing, but asked her father for her.

author: Grimms
sentence: But dost thou know what thou must promise? said the King.

author: Grimms
sentence: I must be buried with her, he replied, "if I outlive her, but my love is so great that I do not mind the danger."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the King consented, and the wedding was solemnized with great splendour.

author: Grimms
sentence: They lived now for a while happy and contented with each other, and then it befell that the young Queen was attacked by a severe illness, and no physician could save her.

author: Grimms
sentence: And as she lay there dead, the young King remembered what he had been obliged to promise, and was horrified at having to lie down alive in the grave, but there was no escape.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King had placed sentries at all the gates, and it was not possible to avoid his fate.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the day came when the corpse was to be buried, he was taken down into the royal vault with it and then the door was shut and bolted.

author: Grimms
sentence: Near the coffin stood a table on which were four candles, four loaves of bread, and four bottles of wine, and when this provision came to an end, he would have to die of hunger.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now he sat there full of pain and grief, ate every day only a little piece of bread, drank only a mouthful of wine, and nevertheless saw death daily drawing nearer.

author: Grimms
sentence: Whilst he thus gazed before him, he saw a snake creep out of a corner of the vault and approach the dead body.

author: Grimms
sentence: And as he thought it came to gnaw at it, he drew his sword and said, "As long as I live, thou shalt not touch her," and hewed the snake in three pieces.

author: Grimms
sentence: After a time a second snake crept out of the hole, and when it saw the other lying dead and cut in pieces, it went back, but soon came again with three green leaves in its mouth.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then it took the three pieces of the snake, laid them together, as they ought to go, and placed one of the leaves on each wound.

author: Grimms
sentence: Immediately the severed parts joined themselves together, the snake moved, and became alive again, and both of them hastened away together.

author: Grimms
sentence: The leaves were left lying on the ground, and a desire came into the mind of the unhappy man who had been watching all this, to know if the wondrous power of the leaves which had brought the snake to life again, could not likewise be of service to a human being.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he picked up the leaves and laid one of them on the mouth of his dead wife, and the two others on her eyes.

author: Grimms
sentence: And hardly had he done this than the blood stirred in her veins, rose into her pale face, and coloured it again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she drew breath, opened her eyes, and said, "Ah, God, where am I?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Thou art with me, dear wife, he answered, and told her how everything had happened, and how he had brought her back again to life.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he gave her some wine and bread, and when she had regained her strength, he raised her up and they went to the door and knocked, and called so loudly that the sentries heard it, and told the King.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King came down himself and opened the door, and there he found both strong and well, and rejoiced with them that now all sorrow was over.

author: Grimms
sentence: The young King, however, took the three snake-leaves with him, gave them to a servant and said, "Keep them for me carefully, and carry them constantly about thee; who knows in what trouble they may yet be of service to us!"

author: Grimms
sentence: A change had, however, taken place in his wife; after she had been restored to life, it seemed as if all love for her husband had gone out of her heart.

author: Grimms
sentence: After some time, when he wanted to make a voyage over the sea, to visit his old father, and they had gone on board a ship, she forgot the great love and fidelity which he had shown her, and which had been the means of rescuing her from death, and conceived a wicked inclination for the skipper.

author: Grimms
sentence: And once when the young King lay there asleep, she called in the skipper and seized the sleeper by the head, and the skipper took him by the feet, and thus they threw him down into the sea.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the shameful deed was done, she said, "Now let us return home, and say that he died on the way.

author: Grimms
sentence: I will extol and praise thee so to my father that he will marry me to thee, and make thee the heir to his crown."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the faithful servant who had seen all that they did, unseen by them, unfastened a little boat from the ship, got into it, sailed after his master, and let the traitors go on their way.

author: Grimms
sentence: He fished up the dead body, and by the help of the three snake-leaves which he carried about with him, and laid on the eyes and mouth, he fortunately brought the young King back to life.

author: Grimms
sentence: They both rowed with all their strength day and night, and their little boat flew so swiftly that they reached the old King before the others did.

author: Grimms
sentence: He was astonished when he saw them come alone, and asked what had happened to them.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he learnt the wickedness of his daughter he said, "I cannot believe that she has behaved so ill, but the truth will soon come to light," and bade both go into a secret chamber and keep themselves hidden from every one.

author: Grimms
sentence: Soon afterwards the great ship came sailing in, and the godless woman appeared before her father with a troubled countenance.

author: Grimms
sentence: He said, "Why dost thou come back alone?

author: Grimms
sentence: Where is thy husband?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, dear father, she replied, "I come home again in great grief; during the voyage, my husband became suddenly ill and died, and if the good skipper had not given me his help, it would have gone ill with me.

author: Grimms
sentence: He was present at his death, and can tell you all."

author: Grimms
sentence: The King said, "I will make the dead alive again," and opened the chamber, and bade the two come out.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the woman saw her husband, she was thunderstruck, and fell on her knees and begged for mercy.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King said, "There is no mercy.

author: Grimms
sentence: He was ready to die with thee and restored thee to life again, but thou hast murdered him in his sleep, and shalt receive the reward that thou deservest."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she was placed with her accomplice in a ship which had been pierced with holes, and sent out to sea, where they soon sank amid the waves.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a King"s son who was seized with a desire to travel about the world, and took no one with him but a faithful servant.

author: Grimms
sentence: One day he came to a great forest, and when darkness overtook him he could find no shelter, and knew not where to pass the night.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he saw a girl who was going towards a small house, and when he came nearer, he saw that the maiden was young and beautiful.

author: Grimms
sentence: He spoke to her, and said, "Dear child, can I and my servant find shelter for the night in the little house?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, yes, said the girl in a sad voice, "that you certainly can, but I do not advise you to venture it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Do not go in."

author: Grimms
sentence: Why not? asked the King"s son.

author: Grimms
sentence: The maiden sighed and said, "My step-mother practises wicked arts; she is ill-disposed toward strangers."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he saw very well that he had come to the house of a witch, but as it was dark, and he could not go farther, and also was not afraid, he entered.

author: Grimms
sentence: The old woman was sitting in an armchair by the fire, and looked at the stranger with her red eyes.

author: Grimms
sentence: Good evening, growled she, and pretended to be quite friendly.

author: Grimms
sentence: Take a seat and rest yourselves.

author: Grimms
sentence: She blew up the fire on which she was cooking something in a small pot.

author: Grimms
sentence: The daughter warned the two to be prudent, to eat nothing, and drink nothing, for the old woman brewed evil drinks.

author: Grimms
sentence: They slept quietly until early morning.

author: Grimms
sentence: When they were making ready for their departure, and the King"s son was already seated on his horse, the old woman said, "Stop a moment, I will first hand you a parting draught."

author: Grimms
sentence: Whilst she fetched it, the King"s son rode away, and the servant who had to buckle his saddle tight, was the only one present when the wicked witch came with the drink.

author: Grimms
sentence: Take that to your master, said she.

author: Grimms
sentence: But at that instant the glass broke and the poison spirted on the horse, and it was so strong that the animal immediately fell down dead.

author: Grimms
sentence: The servant ran after his master and told him what had happened, but would not leave his saddle behind him, and ran back to fetch it.

author: Grimms
sentence: When, however, he came to the dead horse a raven was already sitting on it devouring it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Who knows whether we shall find anything better to-day? said the servant; so he killed the raven, and took it with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now they journeyed onwards into the forest the whole day, but could not get out of it.

author: Grimms
sentence: By nightfall they found an inn and entered it.

author: Grimms
sentence: The servant gave the raven to the innkeeper to make ready for supper.

author: Grimms
sentence: They had, however, stumbled on a den of murderers, and during the darkness twelve of these came, intending to kill the strangers and rob them.

author: Grimms
sentence: Before they set about this work, they sat down to supper, and the innkeeper and the witch sat down with them, and together they ate a dish of soup in which was cut up the flesh of the raven.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hardly, however, had they swallowed a couple of mouthfuls, before they all fell down dead, for the raven had communicated to them the poison from the horse-flesh.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was no no one else left in the house but the innkeeper"s daughter, who was honest, and had taken no part in their godless deeds.

author: Grimms
sentence: She opened all doors to the stranger and showed him the heaped-up treasures.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the King"s son said she might keep everything, he would have none of it, and rode onwards with his servant.

author: Grimms
sentence: After they had traveled about for a long time, they came to a town in which was a beautiful but proud princess, who had caused it to be proclaimed that whosoever should set her a riddle which she could not guess, that man should be her husband; but if she guessed it, his head must be cut off.

author: Grimms
sentence: She had three days to guess it in, but was so clever that she always found the answer to the riddle given her, before the appointed time.

author: Grimms
sentence: Nine suitors had already perished in this manner, when the King"s son arrived, and blinded by her great beauty, was willing to stake his life for it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went to her and laid his riddle before her.

author: Grimms
sentence: What is this? said he, "One slew none, and yet slew twelve."

author: Grimms
sentence: She did not know what that was, she thought and thought, but she could not find out, she opened her riddle-books, but it was not in them---in short, her wisdom was at an end.

author: Grimms
sentence: As she did not know how to help herself, she ordered her maid to creep into the lord"s sleeping-chamber, and listen to his dreams, and thought that he would perhaps speak in his sleep and discover the riddle.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the clever servant had placed himself in the bed instead of his master, and when the maid came there, he tore off from her the mantle in which she had wrapped herself, and chased her out with rods.

author: Grimms
sentence: The second night the King"s daughter sent her maid-in-waiting, who was to see if she could succeed better in listening, but the servant took her mantle also away from her, and hunted her out with rods.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now the master believed himself safe for the third night, and lay down in his own bed.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then came the princess herself, and she had put on a misty-grey mantle, and she seated herself near him.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when she thought that he was asleep and dreaming, she spoke to him, and hoped that he would answer in his sleep, as many do, but he was awake, and understood and heard everything quite well.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she asked, "One slew none, what is that?"

author: Grimms
sentence: He replied, "A raven, which ate of a dead and poisoned horse, and died of it."

author: Grimms
sentence: She inquired further, "And yet slew twelve, what is that?"

author: Grimms
sentence: He answered, "That means twelve murderers, who ate the raven and died of it."

author: Grimms
sentence: When she knew the answer to the riddle she wanted to steal away, but he held her mantle so fast that she was forced to leave it behind her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next morning, the King"s daughter announced that she had guessed the riddle, and sent for the twelve judges and expounded it before them.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the youth begged for a hearing, and said, "She stole into my room in the night and questioned me, otherwise she could not have discovered it."

author: Grimms
sentence: The judges said, "Bring us a proof of this."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then were the three mantles brought thither by the servant, and when the judges saw the misty-grey one which the King"s daughter usually wore, they said, "Let the mantle be embroidered with gold and silver, and then it will be your wedding-mantle.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a poor woman who gave birth to a little son; and as he came into the world with a caul on, it was predicted that in his fourteenth year he would have the King"s daughter for his wife.

author: Grimms
sentence: It happened that soon afterwards the King came into the village, and no one knew that he was the King, and when he asked the people what news there was, they answered, "A child has just been born with a caul on; whatever any one so born undertakes turns out well.

author: Grimms
sentence: It is prophesied, too, that in his fourteenth year he will have the King"s daughter for his wife."

author: Grimms
sentence: The King, who had a bad heart, and was angry about the prophecy, went to the parents, and, seeming quite friendly, said, "You poor people, let me have your child, and I will take care of it."

author: Grimms
sentence: At first they refused, but when the stranger offered them a large amount of gold for it, and they thought, "It is a luck-child, and everything must turn out well for it," they at last consented, and gave him the child.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King put it in a box and rode away with it until he came to a deep piece of water; then he threw the box into it and thought, "I have freed my daughter from her unlooked-for suitor."

author: Grimms
sentence: The box, however, did not sink, but floated like a boat, and not a drop of water made its way into it.

author: Grimms
sentence: And it floated to within two miles of the King"s chief city, where there was a mill, and it came to a stand-still at the mill-dam.

author: Grimms
sentence: A miller"s boy, who by good luck was standing there, noticed it and pulled it out with a hook, thinking that he had found a great treasure, but when he opened it there lay a pretty boy inside, quite fresh and lively.

author: Grimms
sentence: He took him to the miller and his wife, and as they had no children they were glad, and said, "God has given him to us."

author: Grimms
sentence: They took great care of the foundling, and he grew up in all goodness.

author: Grimms
sentence: It happened that once in a storm, the King went into the mill, and he asked the mill-folk if the tall youth was their son.

author: Grimms
sentence: No, answered they, "he"s a foundling.

author: Grimms
sentence: Fourteen years ago he floated down to the mill-dam in a box, and the mill-boy pulled him out of the water."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the King knew that it was none other than the luck-child which he had thrown into the water, and he said, "My good people, could not the youth take a letter to the Queen; I will give him two gold pieces as a reward?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Just as the King commands, answered they, and they told the boy to hold himself in readiness.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the King wrote a letter to the Queen, wherein he said, "As soon as the boy arrives with this letter, let him be killed and buried, and all must be done before I come home."

author: Grimms
sentence: The boy set out with this letter; but he lost his way, and in the evening came to a large forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the darkness he saw a small light; he went towards it and reached a cottage.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he went in, an old woman was sitting by the fire quite alone.

author: Grimms
sentence: She started when she saw the boy, and said, "Whence do you come, and whither are you going?"

author: Grimms
sentence: I come from the mill, he answered, "and wish to go to the Queen, to whom I am taking a letter; but as I have lost my way in the forest I should like to stay here over night."

author: Grimms
sentence: You poor boy, said the woman, "you have come into a den of thieves, and when they come home they will kill you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Let them come, said the boy, "I am not afraid; but I am so tired that I cannot go any farther:" and he stretched himself upon a bench and fell asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: Soon afterwards the robbers came, and angrily asked what strange boy was lying there?

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, said the old woman, "it is an innocent child who has lost himself in the forest, and out of pity I have let him come in; he has to take a letter to the Queen."

author: Grimms
sentence: The robbers opened the letter and read it, and in it was written that the boy as soon as he arrived should be put to death.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the hard-hearted robbers felt pity, and their leader tore up the letter and wrote another, saying, that as soon as the boy came, he should be married at once to the King"s daughter.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they let him lie quietly on the bench until the next morning, and when he awoke they gave him the letter, and showed him the right way.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the Queen, when she had received the letter and read it, did as was written in it, and had a splendid wedding-feast prepared, and the King"s daughter was married to the luck-child, and as the youth was handsome and agreeable she lived with him in joy and contentment.

author: Grimms
sentence: After some time the King returned to his palace and saw that the prophecy was fulfilled, and the luck-child married to his daughter.

author: Grimms
sentence: How has that come to pass? said he; "I gave quite another order in my letter."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the Queen gave him the letter, and said that he might see for himself what was written in it.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King read the letter and saw quite well that it had been exchanged for the other.

author: Grimms
sentence: He asked the youth what had become of the letter entrusted to him, and why he had brought another instead of it.

author: Grimms
sentence: I know nothing about it, answered he; "it must have been changed in the night, when I slept in the forest."

author: Grimms
sentence: The King said in a passion, "You shall not have everything quite so much your own way; whosoever marries my daughter must fetch me from hell three golden hairs from the head of the devil; bring me what I want, and you shall keep my daughter."

author: Grimms
sentence: In this way the King hoped to be rid of him for ever.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the luck-child answered, "I will fetch the golden hairs, I am not afraid of the Devil;" thereupon he took leave of them and began his journey.

author: Grimms
sentence: The road led him to a large town, where the watchman by the gates asked him what his trade was, and what he knew.

author: Grimms
sentence: I know everything, answered the luck-child.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then you can do us a favour, said the watchman, "if you will tell us why our market-fountain, which once flowed with wine has become dry, and no longer gives even water?"

author: Grimms
sentence: That you shall know, answered he; "only wait until I come back."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went farther and came to another town, and there also the gatekeeper asked him what was his trade, and what he knew.

author: Grimms
sentence: I know everything, answered he.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then you can do us a favour and tell us why a tree in our town which once bore golden apples now does not even put forth leaves?

author: Grimms
sentence: You shall know that, answered he; "only wait until I come back."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went on and came to a wide river over which he must go.

author: Grimms
sentence: The ferryman asked him what his trade was, and what he knew.

author: Grimms
sentence: I know everything, answered he.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then you can do me a favour, said the ferryman, "and tell me why I must always be rowing backwards and forwards, and am never set free?"

author: Grimms
sentence: You shall know that, answered he; "only wait until I come back."

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had crossed the water he found the entrance to Hell.

author: Grimms
sentence: It was black and sooty within, and the Devil was not at home, but his grandmother was sitting in a large arm-chair.

author: Grimms
sentence: What do you want? said she to him, but she did not look so very wicked.

author: Grimms
sentence: I should like to have three golden hairs from the devils head," answered he, "else I cannot keep my wife."

author: Grimms
sentence: That is a good deal to ask for, said she; "if the devil comes home and finds you, it will cost you your life; but as I pity you, I will see if I cannot help you."

author: Grimms
sentence: She changed him into an ant and said, "Creep into the folds of my dress, you will be safe there."

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, answered he, "so far, so good; but there are three things besides that I want to know: why a fountain which once flowed with wine has become dry, and no longer gives even water; why a tree which once bore golden apples does not even put forth leaves; and why a ferry-man must always be going backwards and forwards, and is never set free?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Those are difficult questions, answered she, "but only be silent and quiet and pay attention to what the devil says when I pull out the three golden hairs."

author: Grimms
sentence: As the evening came on, the devil returned home.

author: Grimms
sentence: No sooner had he entered than he noticed that the air was not pure.

author: Grimms
sentence: I smell mans flesh," said he; "all is not right here."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he pried into every corner, and searched, but could not find anything.

author: Grimms
sentence: His grandmother scolded him.

author: Grimms
sentence: It has just been swept, said she, "and everything put in order, and now you are upsetting it again; you have always got man"s flesh in your nose.

author: Grimms
sentence: Sit down and eat your supper."

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had eaten and drunk he was tired, and laid his head in his grandmother"s lap, and before long he was fast asleep, snoring and breathing heavily.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the old woman took hold of a golden hair, pulled it out, and laid it down near her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh! cried the devil, "what are you doing?"

author: Grimms
sentence: I have had a bad dream, answered the grandmother, "so I seized hold of your hair."

author: Grimms
sentence: What did you dream then? said the devil.

author: Grimms
sentence: I dreamed that a fountain in a market-place from which wine once flowed was dried up, and not even water would flow out of it; what is the cause of it?

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, ho! if they did but know it, answered the devil; "there is a toad sitting under a stone in the well; if they killed it, the wine would flow again."

author: Grimms
sentence: He went to sleep again and snored until the windows shook.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she pulled the second hair out.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ha! what are you doing? cried the devil angrily.

author: Grimms
sentence: Do not take it ill, said she, "I did it in a dream."

author: Grimms
sentence: What have you dreamt this time? asked he.

author: Grimms
sentence:
I dreamt that in a certain kingdom there stood an apple-tree which had once borne golden apples, but now would not even bear leaves.

sentence: He went on and came to the town wherein stood the unfruitful tree, and there too the watchman wanted an answer.

sentence: Then the watchman thanked him, and gave him as a reward two asses laden with gold, which followed him.
