author: Grimms
sentence: The watchman thanked him, and also gave him two asses laden with gold.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last the luck-child got home to his wife, who was heartily glad to see him again, and to hear how well he had prospered in everything.

author: Grimms
sentence: To the King he took what he had asked for, the devil"s three golden hairs, and when the King saw the four asses laden with gold he was quite content, and said, "Now all the conditions are fulfilled, and you can keep my daughter.

author: Grimms
sentence: But tell me, dear son-in-law, where did all that gold come from? this is tremendous wealth!"

author: Grimms
sentence: I was rowed across a river, answered he, "and got it there; it lies on the shore instead of sand."

author: Grimms
sentence: Can I too fetch some of it? said the King; and he was quite eager about it.

author: Grimms
sentence: As much as you like, answered he.

author: Grimms
sentence: There is a ferry-man on the river; let him ferry you over, and you can fill your sacks on the other side.

author: Grimms
sentence: The greedy King set out in all haste, and when he came to the river he beckoned to the ferry-man to put him across.

author: Grimms
sentence: The ferry-man came and bade him get in, and when they got to the other shore he put the oar in his hand and sprang out.

author: Grimms
sentence: But from this time forth the King had to ferry, as a punishment for his sins.

author: Grimms
sentence: Perhaps he is ferrying still?

author: Grimms
sentence: If he is, it is because no one has taken the oar from him.

author: Grimms
sentence: A louse and a flea kept house together and were brewing beer in an egg-shell.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the little louse fell in and burnt herself.

author: Grimms
sentence: On this the little flea began to scream loudly.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the little room-door, "Little flea, why art thou screaming?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Because the louse has burnt herself.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the little door began to creak.

author: Grimms
sentence: On this a little broom in the corner said, "Why art thou creaking, little door?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Have I not reason to creak?

author: Grimms
sentence: The little louse has burnt herself, The little flea is weeping.

author: Grimms
sentence: So the little broom began to sweep frantically.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then a little cart passed by and said, "Why art thou sweeping, little broom?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Have I not reason to sweep?

author: Grimms
sentence:
The little louse has burnt herself, The little flea is weeping,
13:13	Su-:N	-:-	The little door is creaking.

author: Grimms
sentence: So the little cart said, "Then I will run," and began to run wildly.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the ash-heap by which it ran, "Why art thou running so, little cart?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Have I not reason to run?

author: Grimms
sentence:
The little louse has burnt herself, The little flea is weeping,
18:18	Su-:N	-:N	The little door is creaking, The little broom is sweeping.

author: Grimms
sentence: The ash-heap said, "Then I will burn furiously," and began to burn in clear flames.

author: Grimms
sentence: A little tree stood near the ash-heap and said, "Ash-heap, why art thou burning?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Have I not reason to burn?

author: Grimms
sentence:
The little louse has burnt herself, The little flea is weeping,
23:23	Su-:N	-:-	The little door is creaking, The little broom is sweeping,
24:24	Su-:N	-:-	The little cart is running.

author: Grimms
sentence: The little tree said, "Then I will shake myself," and began to shake herself so that all her leaves fell off; a girl who came up with her water-pitcher saw that, and said, "Little tree, why art thou shaking thyself?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Have I not reason to shake myself?

author: Grimms
sentence:
The little louse has burnt herself, The little flea is weeping,
28:28	Su-:N	-:N	The little door is creaking, The little broom is sweeping,
29:29	Su-:N	-:N	The little cart is running, The little ash-heap is burning.

author: Grimms
sentence: On this the girl said, "Then I will break my little water-pitcher," and she broke her little water-pitcher.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the little spring from which ran the water, "Girl, why art thou breaking thy water-jug?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Have I not reason to break my water-jug?

author: Grimms

The little louse has burnt herself, The little flea is weeping,

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, ho! said the spring, "then I will begin to flow," and began to flow violently.

author: Grimms
sentence: And in the water everything was drowned, the girl, the little tree, the little ash-heap, the little cart, the broom, the little door, the little flea, the little louse, all together.

author: Grimms
sentence: One very fine day it came to pass that the good God wished to enjoy himself in the heavenly garden, and took all the apostles and saints with him, so that no one stayed in heaven but Saint Peter.

author: Grimms
sentence: The Lord had commanded him to let no one in during his absence, so Peter stood by the door and kept watch.

author: Grimms
sentence: Before long some one knocked.

author: Grimms
sentence: Peter asked who was there, and what he wanted?

author: Grimms
sentence: I am a poor, honest tailor who prays for admission, replied a smooth voice.

author: Grimms
sentence: Honest indeed, said Peter, "like the thief on the gallows!

author: Grimms
sentence: Thou hast been light-fingered and hast snipped folks" clothes away.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thou wilt not get into heaven.

author: Grimms
sentence: The Lord hath forbidden me to let any one in while he is out."

author: Grimms
sentence: Come, do be merciful, cried the tailor.

author: Grimms
sentence:
Little scraps which fall off the table of their own accord are not stolen, and are not worth speaking about.
11:11	Sa:N	S:N	Look, I am lame, and have blisters on my feet with walking here, I cannot possibly turn back again.
12:12	Sa:N	S:N	Only let me in, and I will do all the rough work.
13:13	N:N	S:N	I will carry the children, and wash their clothes, and wash and clean the benches on which they have been playing, and patch all their torn clothes.

author: Grimms
sentence: Saint Peter let himself be moved by pity, and opened the door of heaven just wide enough for the lame tailor to slip his lean body in.

author: Grimms
sentence: He was forced to sit down in a corner behind the door, and was to stay quietly and peaceably there, in order that the Lord, when he returned, might not observe him and be angry.

author: Grimms
sentence: The tailor obeyed, but once when Saint Peter went outside the door, he got up, and full of curiosity, went round about into every corner of heaven, and inspected the arrangement of every place.

author: Grimms
sentence: At length he came to a spot where many beautiful and delightful chairs were standing, and in the midst was a seat all of gold which was set with shining jewels, likewise it was much higher than the other chairs, and a footstool of gold was before it.

author: Grimms
sentence: It was, however, the seat on which the Lord sat when he was at home, and from which he could see everything which happened on earth.

author: Grimms
sentence: The tailor stood still, and looked at the seat for a long time, for it pleased him better than all else.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last he could master his curiosity no longer, and climbed up and seated himself in the chair.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he saw everything which was happening on earth, and observed an ugly old woman who was standing washing by the side of a stream, secretly laying two veils on one side for herself.

author: Grimms
sentence: The sight of this made the tailor so angry that he laid hold of the golden footstool, and threw it down to earth through heaven, at the old thief.

author: Grimms
sentence: As, however, he could not bring the stool back again, he slipped quietly out of the chair, seated himself in his place behind the door, and behaved as if he had never stirred from the spot.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the Lord and master came back again with his heavenly companions, he did not see the tailor behind the door, but when he seated himself on his chair the footstool was missing.

author: Grimms
sentence: He asked Saint Peter what had become of the stool, but he did not know.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he asked if he had let anyone come in.

author: Grimms
sentence: I know of no one who has been here, answered Peter, "but a lame tailor, who is still sitting behind the door."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the Lord had the tailor brought before him, and asked him if he had taken away the stool, and where he had put it?

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, Lord, answered the tailor joyously, "I threw it in my anger down to earth at an old woman whom I saw stealing two veils at the washing."

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, thou knave, said the Lord, "were I to judge as thou judgest, how dost thou think thou couldst have escaped so long?

author: Grimms
sentence: I should long ago have had no chairs, benches, seats, nay, not even an oven-fork, but should have thrown everything down at the sinners.

author: Grimms
sentence: Henceforth thou canst stay no longer in heaven, but must go outside the door again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then go where thou wilt.

author: Grimms
sentence: No one shall give punishment here, but I alone, the Lord."

author: Grimms
sentence: Peter was obliged to take the tailor out of heaven again, and as he had torn shoes, and feet covered with blisters, he took a stick in his hand, and went to "Wait-a-bit," where the good soldiers sit and make merry.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hard by a great forest dwelt a wood-cutter with his wife, who had an only child, a little girl three years old.

author: Grimms
sentence: They were so poor, however, that they no longer had daily bread, and did not know how to get food for her.

author: Grimms
sentence: One morning the wood-cutter went out sorrowfully to his work in the forest, and while he was cutting wood, suddenly there stood before him a tall and beautiful woman with a crown of shining stars on her head, who said to him, "I am the Virgin Mary, mother of the child Jesus.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thou art poor and needy, bring thy child to me, I will take her with me and be her mother, and care for her."

author: Grimms
sentence: The wood-cutter obeyed, brought his child, and gave her to the Virgin Mary, who took her up to heaven with her.

author: Grimms
sentence: There the child fared well, ate sugar-cakes, and drank sweet milk, and her clothes were of gold, and the little angels played with her.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when she was fourteen years of age, the Virgin Mary called her one day and said, "Dear child, I am about to make a long journey, so take into thy keeping the keys of the thirteen doors of heaven.

author: Grimms
sentence: Twelve of these thou mayest open, and behold the glory which is within them, but the thirteenth, to which this little key belongs, is forbidden thee.

author: Grimms
sentence: Beware of opening it, or thou wilt bring misery on thyself."

author: Grimms
sentence: The girl promised to be obedient, and when the Virgin Mary was gone, she began to examine the dwellings of the kingdom of heaven.

author: Grimms
sentence: Each day she opened one of them, until she had made the round of the twelve.

author: Grimms
sentence: In each of them sat one of the Apostles in the midst of a great light, and she rejoiced in all the magnificence and splendour, and the little angels who always accompanied her rejoiced with her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the forbidden door alone remained, and she felt a great desire to know what could be hidden behind it, and said to the angels, "I will not quite open it, and I will not go inside it, but I will unlock it so that we can just see a little through the opening."

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh no, said the little angels, "that would be a sin.

author: Grimms
sentence: The Virgin Mary has forbidden it, and it might easily cause thy unhappiness."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she was silent, but the desire in her heart was not stilled, but gnawed there and tormented her, and let her have no rest.

author: Grimms
sentence: And once when the angels had all gone out, she thought, "Now I am quite alone, and I could peep in.

author: Grimms
sentence: If I do it, no one will ever know."

author: Grimms
sentence: She sought out the key, and when she had got it in her hand, she put it in the lock, and when she had put it in, she turned it round as well.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the door sprang open, and she saw there the Trinity sitting in fire and splendour.

author: Grimms
sentence: She stayed there awhile, and looked at everything in amazement; then she touched the light a little with her finger, and her finger became quite golden.

author: Grimms
sentence: Immediately a great fear fell on her.

author: Grimms
sentence: She shut the door violently, and ran away.

author: Grimms
sentence: Her terror too would not quit her, let her do what she might, and her heart beat continually and would not be still; the gold too stayed on her finger, and would not go away, let her rub it and wash it never so much.

author: Grimms
sentence: It was not long before the Virgin Mary came back from her journey.

author: Grimms
sentence: She called the girl before her, and asked to have the keys of heaven back.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the maiden gave her the bunch, the Virgin looked into her eyes and said, "Hast thou not opened the thirteenth door also?"

author: Grimms
sentence: No, she replied.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she laid her hand on the girl"s heart, and felt how it beat and beat, and saw right well that she had disobeyed her order and had opened the door.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she said once again, "Art thou certain that thou hast not done it?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said the girl, for the second time.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she perceived the finger which had become golden from touching the fire of heaven, and saw well that the child had sinned, and said for the third time "Hast thou not done it?"

author: Grimms
sentence: No, said the girl for the third time.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the Virgin Mary, "Thou hast not obeyed me, and besides that thou hast lied, thou art no longer worthy to be in heaven."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the girl fell into a deep sleep, and when she awoke she lay on the earth below, and in the midst of a wilderness.

author: Grimms
sentence: She wanted to cry out, but she could bring forth no sound.

author: Grimms
sentence: She sprang up and wanted to run away, but whithersoever she turned herself, she was continually held back by thick hedges of thorns through which she could not break.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the desert, in which she was imprisoned, there stood an old hollow tree, and this had to be her dwelling-place.

author: Grimms
sentence: Into this she crept when night came, and here she slept.

author: Grimms
sentence: Here, too, she found a shelter from storm and rain, but it was a miserable life, and bitterly did she weep when she remembered how happy she had been in heaven, and how the angels had played with her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Roots and wild berries were her only food, and for these she sought as far as she could go.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the autumn she picked up the fallen nuts and leaves, and carried them into the hole.

author: Grimms
sentence: The nuts were her food in winter, and when snow and ice came, she crept amongst the leaves like a poor little animal that she might not freeze.

author: Grimms
sentence: Before long her clothes were all torn, and one bit of them after another fell off her.

author: Grimms
sentence: As soon, however, as the sun shone warm again, she went out and sat in front of the tree, and her long hair covered her on all sides like a mantle.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thus she sat year after year, and felt the pain and the misery of the world.

author: Grimms
sentence: One day, when the trees were once more clothed in fresh green, the King of the country was hunting in the forest, and followed a roe, and as it had fled into the thicket which shut in this part of the forest, he got off his horse, tore the bushes asunder, and cut himself a path with his sword.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had at last forced his way through, he saw a wonderfully beautiful maiden sitting under the tree; and she sat there and was entirely covered with her golden hair down to her very feet.

author: Grimms
sentence: He stood still and looked at her full of surprise, then he spoke to her and said, "Who art thou?

author: Grimms
sentence: Why art thou sitting here in the wilderness?"

author: Grimms
sentence: But she gave no answer, for she could not open her mouth.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King continued, "Wilt thou go with me to my castle?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she just nodded her head a little.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King took her in his arms, carried her to his horse, and rode home with her, and when he reached the royal castle he caused her to be dressed in beautiful garments, and gave her all things in abundance.

author: Grimms
sentence: Although she could not speak, she was still so beautiful and charming that he began to love her with all his heart, and it was not long before he married her.

author: Grimms
sentence: After a year or so had passed, the Queen brought a son into the world.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon the Virgin Mary appeared to her in the night when she lay in her bed alone, and said, "If thou wilt tell the truth and confess that thou didst unlock the forbidden door, I will open thy mouth and give thee back thy speech, but if thou perseverest in thy sin, and deniest obstinately, I will take thy new-born child away with me."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the queen was permitted to answer, but she remained hard, and said, "No, I did not open the forbidden door;" and the Virgin Mary took the new-born child from her arms, and vanished with it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next morning when the child was not to be found, it was whispered among the people that the Queen was a man-eater, and had killed her own child.

author: Grimms
sentence: She heard all this and could say nothing to the contrary, but the King would not believe it, for he loved her so much.

author: Grimms
sentence: When a year had gone by the Queen again bore a son, and in the night the Virgin Mary again came to her, and said, "If thou wilt confess that thou openedst the forbidden door, I will give thee thy child back and untie thy tongue; but if you continuest in sin and deniest it, I will take away with me this new child also."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the Queen again said, "No, I did not open the forbidden door;" and the Virgin took the child out of her arms, and away with her to heaven.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next morning, when this child also had disappeared, the people declared quite loudly that the Queen had devoured it, and the King"s councillors demanded that she should be brought to justice.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King, however, loved her so dearly that he would not believe it, and commanded the councillors under pain of death not to say any more about it.

author: Grimms
sentence: The following year the Queen gave birth to a beautiful little daughter, and for the third time the Virgin Mary appeared to her in the night and said, "Follow me."

author: Grimms
sentence: She took the Queen by the hand and led her to heaven, and showed her there her two eldest children, who smiled at her, and were playing with the ball of the world.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the Queen rejoiced thereat, the Virgin Mary said, "Is thy heart not yet softened?

author: Grimms
sentence: If thou wilt own that thou openedst the forbidden door, I will give thee back thy two little sons."

author: Grimms
sentence: But for the third time the Queen answered, "No, I did not open the forbidden door."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the Virgin let her sink down to earth once more, and took from her likewise her third child.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next morning, when the loss was reported abroad, all the people cried loudly, "The Queen is a man-eater.

author: Grimms
sentence: She must be judged," and the King was no longer able to restrain his councillors.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon a trial was held, and as she could not answer, and defend herself, she was condemned to be burnt alive.

author: Grimms
sentence: The wood was got together, and when she was fast bound to the stake, and the fire began to burn round about her, the hard ice of pride melted, her heart was moved by repentance, and she thought, "If I could but confess before my death that I opened the door."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then her voice came back to her, and she cried out loudly, "Yes, Mary, I did it;" and straight-way rain fell from the sky and extinguished the flames of fire, and a light broke forth above her, and the Virgin Mary descended with the two little sons by her side, and the new-born daughter in her arms.

author: Grimms
sentence: She spoke kindly to her, and said, "He who repents his sin and acknowledges it, is forgiven."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she gave her the three children, untied her tongue, and granted her happiness for her whole life.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once upon a time, a certain King was hunting in a great forest, and he chased a wild beast so eagerly that none of his attendants could follow him.

author: Grimms
sentence: When evening drew near he stopped and looked around him, and then he saw that he had lost his way.

author: Grimms
sentence: He sought a way out, but could find none.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he perceived an aged woman with a head which nodded perpetually, who came towards him, but she was a witch.

author: Grimms
sentence: Good woman, said he to her, "Can you not show me the way through the forest?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, yes, Lord King, she answered, "that I certainly can, but on one condition, and if you do not fulfil that, you will never get out of the forest, and will die of hunger in it."

author: Grimms
sentence: What kind of condition is it? asked the King.

author: Grimms
sentence: I have a daughter, said the old woman, "who is as beautiful as any one in the world, and well deserves to be your consort, and if you will make her your Queen, I will show you the way out of the forest."

author: Grimms
sentence: In the anguish of his heart the King consented, and the old woman led him to her little hut, where her daughter was sitting by the fire.

author: Grimms
sentence: She received the King as if she had been expecting him, and he saw that she was very beautiful, but still she did not please him, and he could not look at her without secret horror.

author: Grimms
sentence: After he had taken the maiden up on his horse, the old woman showed him the way, and the King reached his royal palace again, where the wedding was celebrated.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King had already been married once, and had by his first wife, seven children, six boys and a girl, whom he loved better than anything else in the world.

author: Grimms
sentence: As he now feared that the step-mother might not treat them well, and even do them some injury, he took them to a lonely castle which stood in the midst of a forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: It lay so concealed, and the way was so difficult to find that he himself would not have found it, if a wise woman had not given him a ball of yarn with wonderful properties.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he threw it down before him, it unrolled itself and showed him his path.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King, however, went so frequently away to his dear children that the Queen observed his absence; she was curious and wanted to know what he did when he was quite alone in the forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: She gave a great deal of money to his servants, and they betrayed the secret to her, and told her likewise of the ball which alone could point out the way.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now she knew no rest until she had learnt where the King kept the ball of yarn, and then she made little shirts of white silk, and as she had learnt the art of witchcraft from her mother, she sewed a charm inside them.

author: Grimms
sentence: And once when the King had ridden forth to hunt, she took the little shirts and went into the forest, and the ball showed her the way.

author: Grimms
sentence: The children, who saw from a distance that some one was approaching, thought that their dear father was coming to them, and full of joy, ran to meet him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she threw one of the little shirts over each of them, and no sooner had the shirts touched their bodies than they were changed into swans, and flew away over the forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: The Queen went home quite delighted, and thought she had got rid of her step-children, but the girl had not run out with her brothers, and the Queen knew nothing about her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next day the King went to visit his children, but he found no one but the little girl.

author: Grimms
sentence: Where are thy brothers? asked the King.

author: Grimms
sentence: Alas, dear father, she answered, "they have gone away and left me alone!" and she told him that she had seen from her little window how her brothers had flown away over the forest in the shape of swans, and she showed him the feathers, which they had let fall in the courtyard, and which she had picked up.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King mourned, but he did not think that the Queen had done this wicked deed, and as he feared that the girl would also be stolen away from him, he wanted to take her away with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: But she was afraid of her step-mother, and entreated the King to let her stay just this one night more in the forest castle.

author: Grimms
sentence: The poor girl thought, "I can no longer stay here.

author: Grimms
sentence: I will go and seek my brothers."

author: Grimms
sentence: And when night came, she ran away, and went straight into the forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: She walked the whole night long, and next day also without stopping, until she could go no farther for weariness.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she saw a forest-hut, and went into it, and found a room with six little beds, but she did not venture to get into one of them, but crept under one, and lay down on the hard ground, intending to pass the night there.

author: Grimms
sentence: Just before sunset, however, she heard a rustling, and saw six swans come flying in at the window.

author: Grimms
sentence: They alighted on the ground and blew at each other, and blew all the feathers off, and their swan"s skins stripped off like a shirt.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the maiden looked at them and recognized her brothers, was glad and crept forth from beneath the bed.

author: Grimms
sentence: The brothers were not less delighted to see their little sister, but their joy was of short duration.

author: Grimms
sentence: Here canst thou not abide, they said to her.

author: Grimms
sentence: This is a shelter for robbers, if they come home and find thee, they will kill thee.

author: Grimms
sentence: But can you not protect me? asked the little sister.

author: Grimms
sentence: No, they replied, "only for one quarter of an hour each evening can we lay aside our swan"s skins and have during that time our human form; after that, we are once more turned into swans."

author: Grimms
sentence: The little sister wept and said, "Can you not be set free?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Alas, no, they answered, "the conditions are too hard!

author: Grimms
sentence: For six years thou mayst neither speak nor laugh, and in that time thou must sew together six little shirts of starwort for us.

author: Grimms
sentence: And if one single word falls from thy lips, all thy work will be lost."

author: Grimms
sentence: And when the brothers had said this, the quarter of an hour was over, and they flew out of the window again as swans.

author: Grimms
sentence: The maiden, however, firmly resolved to deliver her brothers, even if it should cost her her life.

author: Grimms
sentence: She left the hut, went into the midst of the forest, seated herself on a tree, and there passed the night.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next morning she went out and gathered starwort and began to sew.

author: Grimms
sentence: She could not speak to any one, and she had no inclination to laugh; she sat there and looked at nothing but her work.

author: Grimms
sentence: When she had already spent a long time there it came to pass that the King of the country was hunting in the forest, and his huntsmen came to the tree on which the maiden was sitting.

author: Grimms
sentence: They called to her and said, "Who art thou?"

author: Grimms
sentence: But she made no answer.

author: Grimms
sentence: Come down to us, said they.

author: Grimms
sentence: We will not do thee any harm.

author: Grimms
sentence: She only shook her head.

author: Grimms
sentence: As they pressed her further with questions she threw her golden necklace down to them, and thought to content them thus.

author: Grimms
sentence: They, however, did not cease, and then she threw her girdle down to them, and as this also was to no purpose, her garters, and by degrees everything that she had on that she could do without until she had nothing left but her shift.

author: Grimms
sentence: The huntsmen, however, did not let themselves be turned aside by that, but climbed the tree and fetched the maiden down and led her before the King.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King asked, "Who art thou?

author: Grimms
sentence: What art thou doing on the tree?"

author: Grimms
sentence: But she did not answer.

author: Grimms
sentence: He put the question in every language that he knew, but she remained as mute as a fish.

author: Grimms
sentence: As she was so beautiful, the King"s heart was touched, and he was smitten with a great love for her.

author: Grimms
sentence: He put his mantle on her, took her before him on his horse, and carried her to his castle.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he caused her to be dressed in rich garments, and she shone in her beauty like bright daylight, but no word could be drawn from her.

author: Grimms
sentence: He placed her by his side at table, and her modest bearing and courtesy pleased him so much that he said, "She is the one whom I wish to marry, and no other woman in the world."

author: Grimms
sentence: And after some days he united himself to her.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King, however, had a wicked mother who was dissatisfied with this marriage and spoke ill of the young Queen.

author: Grimms
sentence: Who knows, said she, "from whence the creature who can"t speak, comes?

author: Grimms
sentence: She is not worthy of a king!"

author: Grimms
sentence: After a year had passed, when the Queen brought her first child into the world, the old woman took it away from her, and smeared her mouth with blood as she slept.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she went to the King and accused the Queen of being a man-eater.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King would not believe it, and would not suffer any one to do her any injury.

author: Grimms
sentence: She, however, sat continually sewing at the shirts, and cared for nothing else.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next time, when she again bore a beautiful boy, the false step-mother used the same treachery, but the King could not bring himself to give credit to her words.

author: Grimms
sentence: He said, "She is too pious and good to do anything of that kind; if she were not dumb, and could defend herself, her innocence would come to light."

author: Grimms
sentence: But when the old woman stole away the newly-born child for the third time, and accused the Queen, who did not utter one word of defence, the King could do no otherwise than deliver her over to justice, and she was sentenced to suffer death by fire.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the day came for the sentence to be executed, it was the last day of the six years during which she was not to speak or laugh, and she had delivered her dear brothers from the power of the enchantment.

author: Grimms
sentence: The six shirts were ready, only the left sleeve of the sixth was wanting.

author: Grimms
sentence: When, therefore, she was led to the stake, she laid the shirts on her arm, and when she stood on high and the fire was just going to be lighted, she looked around and six swans came flying through the air towards her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she saw that her deliverance was near, and her heart leapt with joy.

author: Grimms
sentence: The swans swept towards her and sank down so that she could throw the shirts over them, and as they were touched by them, their swan"s skins fell off, and her brothers stood in their own bodily form before her, and were vigorous and handsome.

author: Grimms
sentence: The youngest only lacked his left arm, and had in the place of it a swan"s wing on his shoulder.

author: Grimms
sentence: They embraced and kissed each other, and the Queen went to the King, who was greatly moved, and she began to speak and said, "Dearest husband, now I may speak and declare to thee that I am innocent, and falsely accused."

author: Grimms
sentence: And she told him of the treachery of the old woman who had taken away her three children and hidden them.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then to the great joy of the King they were brought thither, and as a punishment, the wicked step-mother was bound to the stake, and burnt to ashes.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the King and the Queen with their six brothers lived many years in happiness and peace.

author: Grimms
sentence: The wolf had the fox with him, and whatsoever the wolf wished, that the fox was compelled to do, for he was the weaker, and he would gladly have been rid of his master.

author: Grimms
sentence: It chanced that once as they were going through the forest, the wolf said, "Red-fox, get me something to eat, or else I will eat thee thyself."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the fox answered, "I know a farm-yard where there are two young lambs; if thou art inclined, we will fetch one of them."

author: Grimms
sentence: That suited the wolf, and they went thither, and the fox stole the little lamb, took it to the wolf, and went away.

author: Grimms
sentence: The wolf devoured it, but was not satisfied with one; he wanted the other as well, and went to get it.

author: Grimms
sentence: As, however, he did it so awkwardly, the mother of the little lamb heard him, and began to cry out terribly, and to bleat so that the farmer came running there.

author: Grimms
sentence: They found the wolf, and beat him so mercilessly, that he went to the fox limping and howling.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thou hast misled me finely, said he; "I wanted to fetch the other lamb, and the country folks surprised me, and have beaten me to a jelly."

author: Grimms
sentence: The fox replied, "Why art thou such a glutton?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Next day they again went into the country, and the greedy wolf once more said, "Red-fox, get me something to eat, or I will eat thee thyself."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then answered the fox, "I know a farm-house where the wife is baking pancakes to-night; we will get some of them for ourselves."

author: Grimms
sentence: They went there, and the fox slipped round the house, and peeped and sniffed about until he discovered where the dish was, and then drew down six pancakes and carried them to the wolf.

author: Grimms
sentence: There is something for thee to eat, said he to him, and then went his way.

author: Grimms
sentence: The wolf swallowed down the pancakes in an instant, and said, "They make one want more," and went thither and tore the whole dish down so that it broke in pieces.

author: Grimms
sentence: This made such a great noise that the woman came out, and when she saw the wolf she called the people, who hurried there, and beat him as long as their sticks would hold together, till with two lame legs, and howling loudly, he got back to the fox in the forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: How abominably thou hast misled me! cried he, "the peasants caught me, and tanned my skin for me."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the fox replied, "Why art thou such a glutton?"

author: Grimms
sentence: On the third day, when they were out together, and the wolf could only limp along painfully, he again said, "Red-fox, get me something to eat, or I will eat thee thyself."

author: Grimms
sentence: The fox answered, "I know a man who has been killing, and the salted meat is lying in a barrel in the cellar; we will get that."

author: Grimms
sentence: Said the wolf, "I will go when thou dost, that thou mayest help me if I am not able to get away."

author: Grimms
sentence: I am willing, said the fox, and showed him the by-paths and ways by which at length they reached the cellar.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was meat in abundance, and the wolf attacked it instantly and thought, "There is plenty of time before I need leave off!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The fox liked it also, but looked about everywhere, and often ran to the hole by which they had come in, and tried if his body was still thin enough to slip through it.

author: Grimms
sentence: The wolf said, "Dear fox, tell me why thou art running here and there so much, and jumping in and out?"

author: Grimms
sentence: I must see that no one is coming, replied the crafty fellow.

author: Grimms
sentence: Dont eat too much!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the wolf, "I shall not leave until the barrel is empty."

author: Grimms
sentence: In the meantime the farmer, who had heard the noise of the fox"s jumping, came into the cellar.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the fox saw him he was out of the hole at one bound.

author: Grimms
sentence: The wolf wanted to follow him, but he had made himself so fat with eating that he could no longer get through, but stuck fast.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then came the farmer with a cudgel and struck him dead, but the fox bounded into the forest, glad to be rid of the old glutton.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once upon a time the little hen went with the little cock to the nut-hill, and they agreed together that whichsoever of them found a kernel of a nut should share it with the other.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the hen found a large, large nut, but said nothing about it, intending to eat the kernel herself.

author: Grimms
sentence: The kernel, however, was so large that she could not swallow it, and it remained sticking in her throat, so that she was alarmed lest she should be choked.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she cried, "Cock, I entreat thee to run as fast thou canst, and fetch me some water, or I shall choke."

author: Grimms
sentence: The little cock did run as fast as he could to the spring, and said, "Stream, thou art to give me some water; the little hen is lying on the nut- hill, and she has swallowed a large nut, and is choking."

author: Grimms
sentence: The well answered, "First run to the bride, and get her to give thee some red silk."

author: Grimms
sentence: The little cock ran to the bride and said, "Bride, you are to give me some red silk; I want to give red silk to the well, the well is to give me some water, I am to take the water to the little hen who is lying on the nut-hill and has swallowed a great nut-kernel, and is choking with it."

author: Grimms
sentence: The bride answered, "First run and bring me my little wreath which is hanging to a willow."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the little cock ran to the willow, and drew the wreath from the branch and took it to the bride, and the bride gave him some water for it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the little cock took the water to the hen, but when he got there the hen had choked in the meantime, and lay there dead and motionless.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the cock was so distressed that he cried aloud, and every animal came to lament the little hen, and six mice built a little carriage to carry her to her grave, and when the carriage was ready they harnessed themselves to it, and the cock drove.

author: Grimms
sentence: On the way, however, they met the fox, who said, "Where art thou going, little cock?"

author: Grimms
sentence: I am going to bury my little hen.

author: Grimms
sentence: May I drive with thee?

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, but seat thyself at the back of the carriage, for in the front my little horses could not drag thee.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the fox seated himself at the back, and after that the wolf, the bear, the stag, the lion, and all the beasts of the forest did the same.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the procession went onwards, and they reached the stream.

author: Grimms
sentence: How are we to get over? said the little cock.

author: Grimms
sentence: A straw was lying by the stream, and it said, "I will lay myself across, and you shall drive over me."

author: Grimms
sentence: But when the six mice came to the bridge, the straw slipped and fell into the water, and the six mice all fell in and were drowned.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they were again in difficulty, and a coal came and said, "I am large enough, I will lay myself across and you shall drive over me."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the coal also laid itself across the water, but unhappily just touched it, on which the coal hissed, was extinguished and died.

author: Grimms
sentence: When a stone saw that, it took pity on the little cock, wished to help him, and laid itself over the water.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the cock drew the carriage himself, but when he got it over and reached the other shore with the dead hen, and was about to draw over the others who were sitting behind as well, there were too many of them, the carriage ran back, and they all fell into the water together, and were drowned.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the little cock was left alone with the dead hen, and dug a grave for her and laid her in it, and made a mound above it, on which he sat down and fretted until he died too, and then every one was dead.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once upon a time there was a man who did nothing but gamble, and for that reason people never called him anything but Gambling Hansel, and as he never ceased to gamble, he played away his house and all that he had.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now the very day before his creditors were to take his house from him, came the Lord and St. Peter, and asked him to give them shelter for the night.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Gambling Hansel said, "For my part, you may stay the night, but I cannot give you a bed or anything to eat."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the Lord said he was just to take them in, and they themselves would buy something to eat, to which Gambling Hansel made no objection.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon St. Peter gave him three groschen, and said he was to go to the baker"s and fetch some bread.

author: Grimms
sentence: So Gambling Hansel went, but when he reached the house where the other gambling vagabonds were gathered together, they, although they had won all that he had, greeted him clamorously, and said, "Hansel, do come in."

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, said he, "do you want to win the three groschen too?"

author: Grimms
sentence: On this they would not let him go.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he went in, and played away the three groschen also.

author: Grimms
sentence: Meanwhile St. Peter and the Lord were waiting, and as he was so long in coming, they set out to meet him.

author: Grimms
sentence: When Gambling Hansel came, however, he pretended that the money had fallen into the gutter, and kept raking about in it all the while to find it, but our Lord already knew that he had lost it in play.

author: Grimms
sentence: St. Peter again gave him three groschen, and now he did not allow himself to be led away once more, but fetched them the loaf.

author: Grimms
sentence: Our Lord then inquired if he had no wine, and he said, "Alack, sir, the casks are all empty!"

author: Grimms
sentence: But the Lord said he was to go down into the cellar, for the best wine was still there.

author: Grimms
sentence: For a long time he would not believe this, but at length he said, "Well, I will go down, but I know that there is none there."

author: Grimms
sentence: When he turned the tap, however, lo and behold, the best of wine ran out!

author: Grimms
sentence: So he took it to them, and the two passed the night there.

author: Grimms
sentence: Early next day our Lord told Gambling Hansel that he might beg three favours.

author: Grimms
sentence: The Lord expected that he would ask to go to Heaven; but Gambling Hansel asked for a pack of cards with which he could win everything, for dice with which he would win everything, and for a tree whereon every kind of fruit would grow, and from which no one who had climbed up, could descend until he bade him do so.

author: Grimms
sentence: The Lord gave him all that he had asked, and departed with St. Peter.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now Gambling Hansel at once set about gambling in real earnest, and before long he had gained half the world.

author: Grimms
sentence: Upon this St. Peter said to the Lord, "Lord, this thing must not go on, he will win, and thou lose, the whole world.

author: Grimms
sentence: We must send Death to him."

author: Grimms
sentence: When Death appeared, Gambling Hansel had just seated himself at the gaming-table, and Death said, "Hansel, come out a while."

author: Grimms
sentence: But Gambling Hansel said, "Just wait a little until the game is done, and in the meantime get up into that tree out there, and gather a little fruit that we may have something to munch on our way."

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon Death climbed up, but when he wanted to come down again, he could not, and Gambling Hansel left him up there for seven years, during which time no one died.

author: Grimms
sentence: So St. Peter said to the Lord, "Lord, this thing must not go on.

author: Grimms
sentence: People no longer die; we must go ourselves."

author: Grimms
sentence: And they went themselves, and the Lord commanded Hansel to let Death come down.

author: Grimms
sentence: So Hansel went at once to Death and said to him, "Come down," and Death took him directly and put an end to him.

author: Grimms
sentence: They went away together and came to the next world, and then Gambling Hansel made straight for the door of Heaven, and knocked at it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Who is there?

author: Grimms
sentence: Gambling Hansel.

author: Grimms
sentence:
Ah, we will have nothing to do with him!
34:34	D:N	D:A	Begone!

author: Grimms
sentence: So he went to the door of Purgatory, and knocked once more.

author: Grimms
sentence: Who is there?

author: Grimms
sentence: Gambling Hansel.

author: Grimms
sentence:
Ah, there is quite enough weeping and wailing here without him.
39:39	N:N	D:S	We do not want to gamble, just go away again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went to the door of Hell, and there they let him in.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was, however, no one at home but old Lucifer and the crooked devils who had just been doing their evil work in the world.

author: Grimms
sentence: And no sooner was Hansel there than he sat down to gamble again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Lucifer, however, had nothing to lose, but his mis-shapen devils, and Gambling Hansel won them from him, as with his cards he could not fail to do.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now he was off again with his crooked devils, and they went to Hohenfuert and pulled up a hop-pole, and with it went to Heaven and began to thrust the pole against it, and Heaven began to crack.

author: Grimms
sentence: So again St. Peter said, "Lord, this thing cannot go on, we must let him in, or he will throw us down from Heaven."

author: Grimms
sentence: And they let him in.

author: Grimms
sentence: But Gambling Hansel instantly began to play again, and there was such a noise and confusion that there was no hearing what they themselves were saying.

author: Grimms
sentence: Therefore St. Peter once more said, "Lord, this cannot go on, we must throw him down, or he will make all Heaven rebellious."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they went to him at once, and threw him down, and his soul broke into fragments, and went into the gambling vagabonds who are living this very day.

author: Grimms
sentence: In olden times, when the Lord himself still used to walk about on this earth amongst men, it once happened that he was tired and overtaken by the darkness before he could reach an inn.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now there stood on the road before him two houses facing each other; the one large and beautiful, the other small and poor.

author: Grimms
sentence: The large one belonged to a rich man, and the small one to a poor man.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the Lord thought, "I shall be no burden to the rich man, I will stay the night with him."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the rich man heard some one knocking at his door, he opened the window and asked the stranger what he wanted.

author: Grimms
sentence: The Lord answered, "I only ask for a night"s lodging."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the rich man looked at the traveler from head to foot, and as the Lord was wearing common clothes, and did not look like one who had much money in his pocket, he shook his head, and said, "No, I cannot take you in, my rooms are full of herbs and seeds; and if I were to lodge everyone who knocked at my door, I might very soon go begging myself.

author: Grimms
sentence: Go somewhere else for a lodging," and with this he shut down the window and left the Lord standing there.

author: Grimms
sentence: So the Lord turned his back on the rich man, and went across to the small house and knocked.

author: Grimms
sentence: He had hardly done so when the poor man opened the little door and bade the traveler come in.

author: Grimms
sentence: Pass the night with me, it is already dark, said he; "you cannot go any further to-night."

author: Grimms
sentence: This pleased the Lord, and he went in.

author: Grimms
sentence: The poor man"s wife shook hands with him, and welcomed him, and said he was to make himself at home and put up with what they had got; they had not much to offer him, but what they had they would give him with all their hearts.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she put the potatoes on the fire, and while they were boiling, she milked the goat, that they might have a little milk with them.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the cloth was laid, the Lord sat down with the man and his wife, and he enjoyed their coarse food, for there were happy faces at the table.

author: Grimms
sentence: When they had had supper and it was bed-time, the woman called her husband apart and said, "Hark you, dear husband, let us make up a bed of straw for ourselves to-night, and then the poor traveler can sleep in our bed and have a good rest, for he has been walking the whole day through, and that makes one weary."

author: Grimms
sentence: With all my heart, he answered, "I will go and offer it to him;" and he went to the stranger and invited him, if he had no objection, to sleep in their bed and rest his limbs properly.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the Lord was unwilling to take their bed from the two old folks; however, they would not be satisfied, until at length he did it and lay down in their bed, while they themselves lay on some straw on the ground.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next morning they got up before daybreak, and made as good a breakfast as they could for the guest.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the sun shone in through the little window, and the Lord had got up, he again ate with them, and then prepared to set out on his journey.

author: Grimms
sentence: But as he was standing at the door he turned round and said, "As you are so kind and good, you may wish three things for yourselves and I will grant them."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the man said, "What else should I wish for but eternal happiness, and that we two, as long as we live, may be healthy and have every day our daily bread; for the third wish, I do not know what to have."

author: Grimms
sentence: And the Lord said to him, "Will you wish for a new house instead of this old one?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, yes, said the man; "if I can have that, too, I should like it very much."

author: Grimms
sentence: And the Lord fulfilled his wish, and changed their old house into a new one, again gave them his blessing, and went on.

author: Grimms
sentence: The sun was high when the rich man got up and leaned out of his window and saw, on the opposite side of the way, a new clean-looking house with red tiles and bright windows where the old hut used to be.

author: Grimms
sentence: He was very much astonished, and called his wife and said to her, "Tell me, what can have happened?

author: Grimms
sentence: Last night there was a miserable little hut standing there, and to-day there is a beautiful new house.

author: Grimms
sentence: Run over and see how that has come to pass."

author: Grimms
sentence: So his wife went and asked the poor man, and he said to her, "Yesterday evening a traveler came here and asked for a night"s lodging, and this morning when he took leave of us he granted us three wishes---eternal happiness, health during this life and our daily bread as well, and besides this, a beautiful new house instead of our old hut."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the rich man"s wife heard this, she ran back in haste and told her husband how it had happened.

author: Grimms
sentence: The man said, "I could tear myself to pieces!

author: Grimms
sentence: If I had but known that!

author: Grimms
sentence: That traveler came to our house too, and wanted to sleep here, and I sent him away."

author: Grimms
sentence: Quick! said his wife, "get on your horse.

author: Grimms
sentence: You can still catch the man up, and then you must ask to have three wishes granted to you."

author: Grimms
sentence: The rich man followed the good counsel and galloped away on his horse, and soon came up with the Lord.

author: Grimms
sentence: He spoke to him softly and pleasantly, and begged him not to take it amiss that he had not let him in directly; he was looking for the front-door key, and in the meantime the stranger had gone away, if he returned the same way he must come and stay with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said the Lord; "if I ever come back again, I will do so."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the rich man asked if might not wish for three things too, as his neighbor had done?

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said the Lord, he might, but it would not be to his advantage, and he had better not wish for anything; but the rich man thought that he could easily ask for something which would add to his happiness, if he only knew that it would be granted.

author: Grimms
sentence: So the Lord said to him, "Ride home, then, and three wishes which you shall form, shall be fulfilled."

author: Grimms
sentence: The rich man had now gained what he wanted, so he rode home, and began to consider what he should wish for.

author: Grimms
sentence: As he was thus thinking he let the bridle fall, and the horse began to caper about, so that he was continually disturbed in his meditations, and could not collect his thoughts at all.

author: Grimms
sentence: He patted its neck, and said, "Gently, Lisa," but the horse only began new tricks.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then at last he was angry, and cried quite impatiently, "I wish your neck was broken!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Directly he had said the words, down the horse fell on the ground, and there it lay dead and never moved again.

author: Grimms
sentence: And thus was his first wish fulfilled.

author: Grimms
sentence: As he was miserly by nature, he did not like to leave the harness lying there; so he cut it off, and put it on his back; and now he had to go on foot.

author: Grimms
sentence: I have still two wishes left, said he, and comforted himself with that thought.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now as he was walking slowly through the sand, and the sun was burning hot at noon-day, he grew quite hot-tempered and angry.

author: Grimms
sentence: The saddle hurt his back, and he had not yet any idea what to wish for.

author: Grimms
sentence: If I were to wish for all the riches and treasures in the world, said he to himself, "I should still to think of all kinds of other things later on, I know that, beforehand.

author: Grimms
sentence: But I will manage so that there is nothing at all left me to wish for afterwards."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he sighed and said, "Ah, if I were but that Bavarian peasant, who likewise had three wishes granted to him, and knew quite well what to do, and in the first place wished for a great deal of beer, and in the second for as much beer as he was able to drink, and in the third for a barrel of beer into the bargain."

author: Grimms
sentence: Many a time he thought he had found it, but then it seemed to him to be, after all, too little.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then it came into his mind, what an easy life his wife had, for she stayed at home in a cool room and enjoyed herself.

author: Grimms
sentence: This really did vex him, and before he was aware, he said, "I just wish she was sitting there on this saddle, and could not get off it, instead of my having to drag it along on my back."

author: Grimms
sentence: And as the last word was spoken, the saddle disappeared from his back, and he saw that his second wish had been fulfilled.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he really did feel warm.

author: Grimms
sentence: He began to run and wanted to be quite alone in his own room at home, to think of something really large for his last wish.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when he arrived there and opened the parlour-door, he saw his wife sitting in the middle of the room on the saddle, crying and complaining, and quite unable to get off it.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he said, "Do bear it, and I will wish for all the riches on earth for thee, only stay where thou art."

author: Grimms
sentence: She, however, called him a fool, and said, "What good will all the riches on earth do me, if I am to sit on this saddle?

author: Grimms
sentence: Thou hast wished me on it, so thou must help me off."

author: Grimms
sentence: So whether he would or not, he was forced to let his third wish be that she should be quit of the saddle, and able to get off it, and immediately the wish was fulfilled.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he got nothing by it but vexation, trouble, abuse, and the loss of his horse; but the poor people lived happily, quietly, and piously until their happy death.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once on a time a countryman had a son who was as big as a thumb, and did not become any bigger, and during several years did not grow one hair"s breadth.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once when the father was going out to plough, the little one said, "Father, I will go out with you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Thou wouldst go out with me? said the father.

author: Grimms
sentence: Stay here, thou wilt be of no use out there, besides thou mightest get lost!

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Thumbling began to cry, and for the sake of peace his father put him in his pocket, and took him with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he was outside in the field, he took him out again, and set him in a freshly-cut furrow.

author: Grimms
sentence: Whilst he was there, a great giant came over the hill.

author: Grimms
sentence: Do thou see that great bogie? said the father, for he wanted to frighten the little fellow to make him good; "he is coming to fetch thee."

author: Grimms
sentence: The giant, however, had scarcely taken two steps with his long legs before he was in the furrow.

author: Grimms
sentence: He took up little Thumbling carefully with two fingers, examined him, and without saying one word went away with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: His father stood by, but could not utter a sound for terror, and he thought nothing else but that his child was lost, and that as long as he lived he should never set eyes on him again.

author: Grimms
sentence: The giant, however, carried him home, suckled him, and Thumbling grew and became tall and strong after the manner of giants.

author: Grimms
sentence: When two years had passed, the old giant took him into the forest, wanted to try him, and said, "Pull up a stick for thyself."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the boy was already so strong that he tore up a young tree out of the earth by the roots.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the giant thought, "We must do better than that," took him back again, and suckled him two years longer.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he tried him, his strength had increased so much that he could tear an old tree out of the ground.

author: Grimms
sentence: That was still not enough for the giant; he again suckled him for two years, and when he then went with him into the forest and said, "Now just tear up a proper stick for me," the boy tore up the strongest oak-tree from the earth, so that it split, and that was a mere trifle to him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now that will do, said the giant, "thou art perfect," and took him back to the field from whence he had brought him.

author: Grimms
sentence: His father was there following the plough.

author: Grimms
sentence: The young giant went up to him, and said, "Does my father see what a fine man his son has grown into?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The farmer was alarmed, and said, "No, thou art not my son; I don"t want thee leave me!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Truly I am your son; allow me to do your work, I can plough as well as you, nay better.

author: Grimms
sentence: No, no, thou art not my son; and thou canst not plough go away!

author: Grimms
sentence: However, as he was afraid of this great man, he left go of the plough, stepped back and stood at one side of the piece of land.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the youth took the plough, and just pressed it with one hand, but his grasp was so strong that the plough went deep into the earth.

author: Grimms
sentence: The farmer could not bear to see that, and called to him, "If thou art determined to plough, thou must not press so hard on it, that makes bad work."

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth, however, unharnessed the horses, and drew the plough himself, saying, "Just go home, father, and bid my mother make ready a large dish of food, and in the meantime I will go over the field."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the farmer went home, and ordered his wife to prepare the food; but the youth ploughed the field which was two acres large, quite alone, and then he harnessed himself to the harrow, and harrowed the whole of the land, using two harrows at once.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had done it, he went into the forest, and pulled up two oak-trees, laid them across his shoulders, and hung on them one harrow behind and one before, and also one horse behind and one before, and carried all as if it had been a bundle of straw, to his parents" house.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he entered the yard, his mother did not recognize him, and asked, "Who is that horrible tall man?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The farmer said, "That is our son."

author: Grimms
sentence: She said, "No that cannot be our son, we never had such a tall one, ours was a little thing."

author: Grimms
sentence: She called to him, "Go away, we do not want thee!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth was silent, but led his horses to the stable, gave them some oats and hay, and all that they wanted.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had done this, he went into the parlour, sat down on the bench and said, "Mother, now I should like something to eat, will it soon be ready?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she said, "Yes," and brought in two immense dishes full of food, which would have been enough to satisfy herself and her husband for a week.

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth, however, ate the whole of it himself, and asked if she had nothing more to set before him.

author: Grimms
sentence: No, she replied, "that is all we have."

author: Grimms
sentence: But that was only a taste, I must have more.

author: Grimms
sentence: She did not dare to oppose him, and went and put a huge caldron full of food on the fire, and when it was ready, carried it in.

author: Grimms
sentence: At length come a few crumbs, said he, and ate all there was, but it was still not sufficient to appease his hunger.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said he, "Father, I see well that with you I shall never have food enough; if you will get me an iron staff which is strong, and which I cannot break against my knees, I will go out into the world."

author: Grimms
sentence: The farmer was glad, put his two horses in his cart, and fetched from the smith a staff so large and thick, that the two horses could only just bring it away.

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth laid it across his knees, and snap! he broke it in two in the middle like a bean-stalk, and threw it away.

author: Grimms
sentence: The father then harnessed four horses, and brought a bar which was so long and thick, that the four horses could only just drag it.

author: Grimms
sentence: The son snapped this also in twain against his knees, threw it away, and said, "Father, this can be of no use to me, you must harness more horses, and bring a stronger staff."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the father harnessed eight horses, and brought one which was so long and thick, that the eight horses could only just carry it.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the son took it in his hand, he broke off a bit from the top of it also, and said, "Father, I see that you will not be able to procure me any such staff as I want, I will remain no longer with you."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he went away, and gave out that he was a smith"s apprentice.

author: Grimms
sentence: He arrived at a village, wherein lived a smith who was a greedy fellow, who never did a kindness to any one, but wanted everything for himself.

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth went into the smithy and asked if he needed a journeyman.

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said the smith, and looked at him, and thought, "That is a strong fellow who will strike out well, and earn his bread."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he asked, "How much wages dost thou want?"

author: Grimms
sentence: I dont want any at all," he replied, "only every fortnight, when the other journeymen are paid, I will give thee two blows, and thou must bear them."

author: Grimms
sentence: The miser was heartily satisfied, and thought he would thus save much money.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next morning, the strange journeyman was to begin to work, but when the master brought the glowing bar, and the youth struck his first blow, the iron flew asunder, and the anvil sank so deep into the earth, that there was no bringing it out again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the miser grew angry, and said, "Oh, but I can"t make any use of you, you strike far too powerfully; what will you have for the one blow?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said he, "I will only give you quite a small blow, that"s all."

author: Grimms
sentence: And he raised his foot, and gave him such a kick that he flew away over four loads of hay.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he sought out the thickest iron bar in the smithy for himself, took it as a stick in his hand and went onwards.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had walked for some time, he came to a small farm, and asked the bailiff if he did not require a head-servant.

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said the bailiff, "I can make use of one; you look a strong fellow who can do something, how much a year do you want as wages?"

author: Grimms
sentence: He again replied that he wanted no wages at all, but that every year he would give him three blows, which he must bear.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the bailiff was satisfied, for he, too, was a covetous fellow.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next morning all the servants were to go into the wood, and the others were already up, but the head-servant was still in bed.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then one of them called to him, "Get up, it is time; we are going into the wood, and thou must go with us."

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, said he quite roughly and surlily, "you may just go, then; I shall be back again before any of you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the others went to the bailiff, and told him that the head-man was still lying in bed, and would not go into the wood with them.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bailiff said they were to awaken him again, and tell him to harness the horses.

author: Grimms
sentence: The head-man, however, said as before, "Just go there, I shall be back again before any of you."

author: Grimms
sentence: And then he stayed in bed two hours longer.

author: Grimms
sentence: At length he arose from the feathers, but first he got himself two bushels of peas from the loft, made himself some broth with them, ate it at his leisure, and when that was done, went and harnessed the horses, and drove into the wood.

author: Grimms
sentence: Not far from the wood was a ravine through which he had to pass, so he first drove the horses on, and then stopped them, and went behind the cart, took trees and brushwood, and made a great barricade, so that no horse could get through.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he was entering the wood, the others were just driving out of it with their loaded carts to go home; then said he to them, "Drive on, I will still get home before you do."

author: Grimms
sentence: He did not drive far into the wood, but at once tore two of the very largest trees of all out of the earth, threw them on his cart, and turned round.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he came to the barricade, the others were still standing there, not able to get through.

author: Grimms
sentence: Dont you see," said he, "that if you had stayed with me, you would have got home just as quickly, and would have had another hour"s sleep?"

author: Grimms
sentence: He now wanted to drive on, but his horeses could not work their way through, so he unharnessed them, laid them on the top of the cart, took the shafts in his own hands, and pulled it all through, and he did this just as easily as if it had been laden with feathers.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he was over, he said to the others, "There, you see, I have got over quicker than you," and drove on, and the others had to stay where they were.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the yard, however, he took a tree in his hand, showed it to the bailiff, and said, "Isn"t that a fine bundle of wood?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the bailiff to his wife, "The servant is a good one, if he does sleep long, he is still home before the others."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he served the bailiff for a year, and when that was over, and the other servants were getting their wages, he said it was time for him to take his too.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bailiff, however, was afraid of the blows which he was to receive, and earnestly entreated him to excuse him from having them; for rather than that, he himself would be head-servant, and the youth should be bailiff.

author: Grimms
sentence: No, said he, "I will not be a bailiff, I am head-servant, and will remain so, but I will administer that which we agreed on."

author: Grimms
sentence: The bailiff was willing to give him whatsoever he demanded, but it was of no use, the head-servant said no to everything.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the bailiff did not know what to do, and begged for a fortnight"s delay, for he wanted to find some way of escape.

author: Grimms
sentence: The head-servant consented to this delay.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bailiff summoned all his clerks together, and they were to think the matter over, and give him advice.

author: Grimms
sentence: The clerks pondered for a long time, but at last they said that no one was sure of his life with the head-servant, for he could kill a man as easily as a midge, and that the bailiff ought to make him get into the well and clean it, and when he was down below, they would roll up one of the mill-stones which was lying there, and throw it on his head; and then he would never return to daylight.

author: Grimms
sentence: The advice pleased the bailiff, and the head-servant was quite willing to go down the well.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he was standing down below at the bottom, they rolled down the largest mill-stone and thought they had broken his skull, but he cried, "Chase away those hens from the well, they are scratching in the sand up there, and throwing the grains into my eyes, so that I can"t see."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the bailiff cried, "Sh-sh," and pretended to frighten the hens away.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the head-servant had finished his work, he climbed up and said, "Just look what a beautiful neck-tie I have on," and behold it was the mill-stone which he was wearing round his neck.

author: Grimms
sentence: The head-servant now wanted to take his reward, but the bailiff again begged for a fortnight"s delay.

author: Grimms
sentence: The clerks met together and advised him to send the head-servant to the haunted mill to grind corn by night, for from thence as yet no man had ever returned in the morning alive.

author: Grimms
sentence: The proposal pleased the bailiff, he called the head-servant that very evening, and ordered him to take eight bushels of corn to the mill, and grind it that night, for it was wanted.

author: Grimms
sentence: So the head-servant went to the loft, and put two bushels in his right pocket, and two in his left, and took four in a wallet, half on his back, and half on his breast, and thus laden went to the haunted mill.

author: Grimms
sentence: The miller told him that he could grind there very well by day, but not by night, for the mill was haunted, and that up to the present time whosoever had gone into it at night had been found in the morning lying dead inside.

author: Grimms
sentence: He said, "I will manage it, just you go away to bed."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went into the mill, and poured out the corn.

author: Grimms
sentence: About eleven o"clock he went into the miller"s room, and sat down on the bench.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had sat there a while, a door suddenly opened, and a large table came in, and on the table, wine and roasted meats placed themselves, and much good food besides, but everything came of itself, for no one was there to carry it.

author: Grimms
sentence: After this the chairs pushed themselves up, but no people came, until all at once he beheld fingers, which handled knives and forks, and laid food on the plates, but with this exception he saw nothing.

author: Grimms
sentence: As he was hungry, and saw the food, he, too, place himself at the table, ate with those who were eating and enjoyed it.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had had enough, and the others also had quite emptied their dishes, he distinctly heard all the candles being suddenly snuffed out, and as it was now pitch dark, he felt something like a box on the ear.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he said, "If anything of that kind comes again, I shall strike out in return."

author: Grimms
sentence: And when he had received a second box on the ear, he, too struck out.

author: Grimms
sentence: And so it continued the whole night.

author: Grimms
sentence: He took nothing without returning it, but repaid everything with interest, and did not lay about him in vain.

author: Grimms
sentence: At daybreak, however, everything ceased.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the miller had got up, he wanted to look after him, and wondered if he were still alive.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the youth said, "I have eaten my fill, have received some boxes on the ears, but I have given some in return."

author: Grimms
sentence: The miller rejoiced, and said that the mill was now released from the spell, and wanted to give him much money as a reward.

author: Grimms
sentence: But he said, "Money, I will not have, I have enough of it."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he took his meal on his back, went home, and told the bailiff that he had done what he had been told to do, and would now have the reward agreed on.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the bailiff heard that, he was seriously alarmed and quite beside himself; he walked backwards and forwards in the room, and drops of perspiration ran down from his forehead.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he opened the window to get some fresh air, but before he was aware, the head-servant had given him such a kick that he flew through the window out into the air, and so far away that no one ever saw him again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the head-servant to the bailiff"s wife, "If he does not come back, you must take the other blow."

author: Grimms
sentence: She cried, "No, no I cannot bear it," and opened the other window, because drops of perspiration were running down her forehead.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he gave her such a kick that she, too, flew out, and as she was lighter she went much higher than her husband.

author: Grimms
sentence: Her husband cried, "Do come to me," but she replied, "Come thou to me, I cannot come to thee."

author: Grimms
sentence: And they hovered about there in the air, and could not get to each other, and whether they are still hovering about, or not, I do not know, but the young giant took up his iron bar, and went on his way.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once upon a time a rich King who had three daughters, who daily went to walk in the palace garden, and the King was a great lover of all kinds of fine trees, but there was one for which he had such an affection, that if anyone gathered an apple from it he wished him a hundred fathoms underground.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when harvest time came, the apples on this tree were all as red as blood.

author: Grimms
sentence: The three daughters went every day beneath the tree, and looked to see if the wind had not blown down an apple, but they never by any chance found one, and the tree was so loaded with them that it was almost breaking, and the branches hung down to the ground.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the King"s youngest child had a great desire for an apple, and said to her sisters, "Our father loves us far too much to wish us underground, it is my belief that he would only do that to people who were strangers."

author: Grimms
sentence: And while she was speaking, the child plucked off quite a large apple, and ran to her sisters, saying, "Just taste, my dear little sisters, for never in my life have I tasted anything so delightful."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the two other sisters also ate some of the apple, whereupon all three sank deep down into the earth, where they could hear no cock crow.

author: Grimms
sentence: When mid-day came, the King wished to call them to come to dinner, but they were nowhere to be found.

author: Grimms
sentence: He sought them everywhere in the palace and garden, but could not find them.
