author: Grimms
sentence: Then he was much troubled, and made known to the whole land that whosoever brought his daughters back again should have one of them to wife.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hereupon so many young men went about the country in search, that there was no counting them, for every one loved the three children because they were so kind to all, and so fair of face.

author: Grimms
sentence: Three young huntsmen also went out, and when they had travelled about for eight days, they arrived at a great castle, in which were beautiful apartments, and in one room a table was laid on which were delicate dishes which were still so warm that they were smoking, but in the whole of the castle no human being was either to be seen or heard.

author: Grimms
sentence: They waited there for half a day, and the food still remained warm and smoking, and at length they were so hungry that they sat down and ate, and agreed with each other that they would stay and live in that castle, and that one of them, who should be chosen by casting lots, should remain in the house, and the two others seek the King"s daughters.

author: Grimms
sentence: They cast lots, and the lot fell on the eldest; so next day the two younger went out to seek, and the eldest had to stay home.

author: Grimms
sentence: At mid-day came a small, small mannikin and begged for a piece of bread, then the huntsman took the bread which he had found there, and cut a round off the loaf and was about to give it to him, but whilst he was giving it to the mannikin, the latter let it fall, and asked the huntsman to be so good as to give him that piece again.

author: Grimms
sentence: The huntsman was about to do so and stooped, on which the mannikin took a stick, seized him by the hair, and gave him a good beating.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next day, the second stayed at home, and he fared no better.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the two others returned in the evening, the eldest said, "Well, how have you got on?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, very badly, said he, and then they lamented their misfortune together, but they said nothing about it to the youngest, for they did not like him at all, and always called him Stupid Hans, because he did not exactly belong to the forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: On the third day, the youngest stayed at home, and again the little mannikin came and begged for a piece of bread.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the youth gave it to him, the elf let it fall as before, and asked him to be so good as to give him that piece again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said Hans to the little mannikin, "What! canst thou not pick up that piece thyself?

author: Grimms
sentence: If thou wilt not take as much trouble as that for thy daily bread, thou dost not deserve to have it."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the mannikin grew very angry and said he was to do it, but the huntsman would not, and took my dear mannikin, and gave him a thorough beating.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the mannikin screamed terribly, and cried, "Stop, stop, and let me go, and I will tell thee where the King"s daughters are."

author: Grimms
sentence: When Hans heard that, he left off beating him and the mannikin told him that he was an earth mannikin, and that there were more than a thousand like him, and that if he would go with him he would show him where the King"s daughters were.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he showed him a deep well, but there was no water in it.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the elf said that he knew well that the companions Hans had with him did not intend to deal honourably with him, therefore if he wished to deliver the King"s children, he must do it alone.

author: Grimms
sentence: The two other brothers would also be very glad to recover the King"s daughters, but they did not want to have any trouble or danger.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hans was therefore to take a large basket, and he must seat himself in it with his hanger and a bell, and be let down.

author: Grimms
sentence: Below were three rooms, and in each of them was a princess, with a many-headed dragon, whose heads she was to comb and trim, but he must cut them off.

author: Grimms
sentence: And having said all this, the elf vanished.

author: Grimms
sentence: When it was evening the two brothers came and asked how he had got on, and he said, "pretty well so far," and that he had seen no one except at mid-day when a little mannikin had come and begged for a piece of bread, that he had given some to him, but that the mannikin had let it fall and had asked him to pick it up again; but as he did not choose to do that, the elf had begun to lose his temper, and that he had done what he ought not, and had given the elf a beating, on which he had told him where the King"s daughters were.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the two were so angry at this that they grew green and yellow.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next morning they went to the well together, and drew lots who should first seat himself in the basket, and again the lot fell on the eldest, and he was to seat himself in it, and take the bell with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he said, "If I ring, you must draw me up again immediately."

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had gone down for a short distance, he rang, and they at once drew him up again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the second seated himself in the basket, but he did just the same as the first, and then it was the turn of the youngest, but he let himself be lowered quite to the bottom.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had got out of the basket, he took his hanger, and went and stood outside the first door and listened, and heard the dragon snoring quite loudly.

author: Grimms
sentence: He opened the door slowly, and one of the princesses was sitting there, and had nine dragon"s heads lying upon her lap, and was combing them.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he took his hanger and hewed at them, and the nine fell off.

author: Grimms
sentence: The princess sprang up, threw her arms round his neck, embraced and kissed him repeatedly, and took her stomacher, which was made of pure gold, and hung it round his neck.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went to the second princess, who had a dragon with five heads to comb, and delivered her also, and to the youngest, who had a dragon with four heads, he went likewise.

author: Grimms
sentence: And they all rejoiced, and embraced him and kissed him without stopping.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he rang very loud, so that those above heard him, and he placed the princesses one after the other in the basket, and had them all drawn up, but when it came to his own turn he remembered the words of the elf, who had told him that his comrades did not mean well by him.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he took a great stone which was lying there, and placed it in the basket, and when it was about half way up, his false brothers above cut the rope, so that the basket with the stone fell to the ground, and they thought that he was dead, and ran away with the three princesses, making them promise to tell their father that it was they who had delivered them, and then they went to the King, and each demanded a princess in marriage.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the meantime the youngest huntsman was wandering about the three chambers in great trouble, fully expecting to have to end his days there, when he saw, hanging on the wall, a flute; then said he, "Why dost thou hang there, no one can be merry here?"

author: Grimms
sentence: He looked at the dragons, heads likewise and said, "You too cannot help me now."

author: Grimms
sentence: He walked backwards and forwards for such a long time that he made the surface of the ground quite smooth.

author: Grimms
sentence: But at last other thoughts came to his mind, and he took the flute from the wall, and played a few notes on it, and suddenly a number of elves appeared, and with every note that he sounded one more came.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he played until the room was entirely filled.

author: Grimms
sentence: They all asked what he desired, so he said he wished to get above ground back to daylight, on which they seized him by every hair that grew on his head, and thus they flew with him onto the earth again.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he was above ground, he at once went to the King"s palace, just as the wedding of one princess was about to be celebrated, and he went to the room where the King and his three daughters were.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the princesses saw him they fainted.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hereupon the King was angry, and ordered him to be put in prison at once, because he thought he must have done some injury to the children.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the princesses came to themselves, however, they entreated the King to set him free again.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King asked why, and they said that they were not allowed to tell that, but their father said that they were to tell it to the stove.

author: Grimms
sentence: And he went out, listened at the door, and heard everything.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he caused the two brothers to be hanged on the gallows, and to the third he gave his youngest daughter, and on that occasion I wore a pair of glass shoes, and I struck them against a stone, and they said, "Klink," and were broken.

author: Grimms
sentence: About a thousand or more years ago, there were in this country nothing but small kings, and one of them who lived on the Keuterberg was very fond of hunting.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once on a time when he was riding forth from his castle with his huntsmen, three girls were watching their cows upon the mountain, and when they saw the King with all his followers, the eldest girl pointed to him, and called to the two other girls, "If I do not get that one, I will have none."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the second girl answered from the other side of the hill, and pointed to the one who was on the King"s right hand, "Hilloa! hilloa!

author: Grimms
sentence: If I do not get him, I will have no one."

author: Grimms
sentence: These, however, were the two ministers.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King heard all this, and when he had come back from the chase, he caused the three girls to be brought to him, and asked them what they had said yesterday on the mountain.

author: Grimms
sentence: This they would not tell him, so the King asked the eldest if she really would take him for her husband?

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: The wife of a rich man fell sick; and when she felt that her end drew nigh, she called her only daughter to her bed-side, and said, "Always be a good girl, and I will look down from heaven and watch over you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Soon afterwards she shut her eyes and died, and was buried in the garden; and the little girl went every day to her grave and wept, and was always good and kind to all about her.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the snow fell and spread a beautiful white covering over the grave; but by the time the spring came, and the sun had melted it away again, her father had married another wife.

author: Grimms
sentence: This new wife had two daughters of her own, that she brought home with her; they were fair in face but foul at heart, and it was now a sorry time for the poor little girl.

author: Grimms
sentence: What does the good-for-nothing want in the parlour? said they; "they who would eat bread should first earn it; away with the kitchen-maid!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they took away her fine clothes, and gave her an old grey frock to put on, and laughed at her, and turned her into the kitchen.

author: Grimms
sentence: There she was forced to do hard work; to rise early before daylight, to bring the water, to make the fire, to cook and to wash.

author: Grimms
sentence: Besides that, the sisters plagued her in all sorts of ways, and laughed at her.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the evening when she was tired, she had no bed to lie down on, but was made to lie by the hearth among the ashes; and as this, of course, made her always dusty and dirty, they called her Ashputtel.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: Fine clothes, said the first; "Pearls and diamonds," cried the second.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: The first twig, dear father, that brushes against your hat when you turn your face to come homewards, said she.

sentence: Then he bought for the first two the fine clothes and pearls and diamonds they had asked for: and on his way home, as he rode through a green copse, a hazel twig brushed against him, and almost pushed off his hat: so he broke it off and brought it away; and when he got home he gave it to his daughter.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she took it, and went to her mother"s grave and planted it there; and cried so much that it was watered with her tears; and there it grew and became a fine tree.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: Now it happened that the king of that land held a feast, which was to last three days; and out of those who came to it his son was to choose a bride for himself.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ashputtel"s two sisters were asked to come; so they called her up, and said, "Now, comb our hair, brush our shoes, and tie our sashes for us, for we are going to dance at the king"s feast."

author: Grimms
sentence: A king and queen once upon a time reigned in a country a great way off, where there were in those days fairies.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now this king and queen had plenty of money, and plenty of fine clothes to wear, and plenty of good things to eat and drink, and a coach to ride out in every day: but though they had been married many years they had no children, and this grieved them very much indeed.

author: Grimms
sentence: But one day as the queen was walking by the side of the river, at the bottom of the garden, she saw a poor little fish, that had thrown itself out of the water, and lay gasping and nearly dead on the bank.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the queen took pity on the little fish, and threw it back again into the river; and before it swam away it lifted its head out of the water and said, "I know what your wish is, and it shall be fulfilled, in return for your kindness to me--you will soon have a daughter."

author: Grimms
sentence: What the little fish had foretold soon came to pass; and the queen had a little girl, so very beautiful that the king could not cease looking on it for joy, and said he would hold a great feast and make merry, and show the child to all the land.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he asked his kinsmen, and nobles, and friends, and neighbours.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the queen said, "I will have the fairies also, that they might be kind and good to our little daughter."

author: Grimms
sentence: Now there were thirteen fairies in the kingdom; but as the king and queen had only twelve golden dishes for them to eat out of, they were forced to leave one of the fairies without asking her.

author: Grimms
sentence: So twelve fairies came, each with a high red cap on her head, and red shoes with high heels on her feet, and a long white wand in her hand: and after the feast was over they gathered round in a ring and gave all their best gifts to the little princess.

author: Grimms
sentence: One gave her goodness, another beauty, another riches, and so on till she had all that was good in the world.

author: Grimms
sentence: Just as eleven of them had done blessing her, a great noise was heard in the courtyard, and word was brought that the thirteenth fairy was come, with a black cap on her head, and black shoes on her feet, and a broomstick in her hand: and presently up she came into the dininghall.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now, as she had not been asked to the feast she was very angry, and scolded the king and queen very much, and set to work to take her revenge.

author: Grimms
sentence: So she cried out, "The king"s daughter shall, in her fifteenth year, be wounded by a spindle, and fall down dead."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the twelfth of the friendly fairies, who had not yet given her gift, came forward, and said that the evil wish must be fulfilled, but that she could soften its mischief; so her gift was, that the king"s daughter, when the spindle wounded her, should not really die, but should only fall asleep for a hundred years.

author: Grimms
sentence: However, the king hoped still to save his dear child altogether from the threatened evil; so he ordered that all the spindles in the kingdom should be bought up and burnt.

author: Grimms
sentence: But all the gifts of the first eleven fairies were in the meantime fulfilled; for the princess was so beautiful, and well behaved, and good, and wise, that everyone who knew her loved her.

author: Grimms
sentence: It happened that, on the very day she was fifteen years old, the king and queen were not at home, and she was left alone in the palace.

author: Grimms
sentence: So she roved about by herself, and looked at all the rooms and chambers, till at last she came to an old tower, to which there was a narrow staircase ending with a little door.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the door there was a golden key, and when she turned it the door sprang open, and there sat an old lady spinning away very busily.

author: Grimms
sentence: Why, how now, good mother, said the princess; "what are you doing there?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Spinning, said the old lady, and nodded her head, humming a tune, while buzz! went the wheel.

author: Grimms
sentence: How prettily that little thing turns round! said the princess, and took the spindle and began to try and spin.

author: Grimms
sentence: But scarcely had she touched it, before the fairy"s prophecy was fulfilled; the spindle wounded her, and she fell down lifeless on the ground.

author: Grimms
sentence: However, she was not dead, but had only fallen into a deep sleep; and the king and the queen, who had just come home, and all their court, fell asleep too; and the horses slept in the stables, and the dogs in the court, the pigeons on the house-top, and the very flies slept upon the walls.

author: Grimms
sentence: Even the fire on the hearth left off blazing, and went to sleep; the jack stopped, and the spit that was turning about with a goose upon it for the king"s dinner stood still; and the cook, who was at that moment pulling the kitchen-boy by the hair to give him a box on the ear for something he had done amiss, let him go, and both fell asleep; the butler, who was slyly tasting the ale, fell asleep with the jug at his lips: and thus everything stood still, and slept soundly.

author: Grimms
sentence: A large hedge of thorns soon grew round the palace, and every year it became higher and thicker; till at last the old palace was surrounded and hidden, so that not even the roof or the chimneys could be seen.

author: Grimms
sentence: But there went a report through all the land of the beautiful sleeping Briar Rose (for so the king"s daughter was called): so that, from time to time, several kings" sons came, and tried to break through the thicket into the palace.

author: Grimms
sentence: This, however, none of them could ever do; for the thorns and bushes laid hold of them, as it were with hands; and there they stuck fast, and died wretchedly.

author: Grimms
sentence: After many, many years there came a king"s son into that land: and an old man told him the story of the thicket of thorns; and how a beautiful palace stood behind it, and how a wonderful princess, called Briar Rose, lay in it asleep, with all her court.

author: Grimms
sentence: He told, too, how he had heard from his grandfather that many, many princes had come, and had tried to break through the thicket, but that they had all stuck fast in it, and died.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the young prince said, "All this shall not frighten me; I will go and see this Briar Rose."

author: Grimms
sentence: The old man tried to hinder him, but he was bent upon going.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now that very day the hundred years were ended; and as the prince came to the thicket he saw nothing but beautiful flowering shrubs, through which he went with ease, and they shut in after him as thick as ever.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he came at last to the palace, and there in the court lay the dogs asleep; and the horses were standing in the stables; and on the roof sat the pigeons fast asleep, with their heads under their wings.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when he came into the palace, the flies were sleeping on the walls; the spit was standing still; the butler had the jug of ale at his lips, going to drink a draught; the maid sat with a fowl in her lap ready to be plucked; and the cook in the kitchen was still holding up her hand, as if she was going to beat the boy.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went on still farther, and all was so still that he could hear every breath he drew; till at last he came to the old tower, and opened the door of the little room in which Briar Rose was; and there she lay, fast asleep on a couch by the window.

author: Grimms
sentence: She looked so beautiful that he could not take his eyes off her, so he stooped down and gave her a kiss.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the moment he kissed her she opened her eyes and awoke, and smiled upon him; and they went out together; and soon the king and queen also awoke, and all the court, and gazed on each other with great wonder.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the horses shook themselves, and the dogs jumped up and barked; the pigeons took their heads from under their wings, and looked about and flew into the fields; the flies on the walls buzzed again; the fire in the kitchen blazed up; round went the jack, and round went the spit, with the goose for the king"s dinner upon it; the butler finished his draught of ale; the maid went on plucking the fowl; and the cook gave the boy the box on his ear.

author: Grimms
sentence: And then the prince and Briar Rose were married, and the wedding feast was given; and they lived happily together all their lives long.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a king, whose queen had hair of the purest gold, and was so beautiful that her match was not to be met with on the whole face of the earth.

author: Grimms
sentence: But this beautiful queen fell ill, and when she felt that her end drew near she called the king to her and said, "Promise me that you will never marry again, unless you meet with a wife who is as beautiful as I am, and who has golden hair like mine."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then when the king in his grief promised all she asked, she shut her eyes and died.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the king was not to be comforted, and for a long time never thought of taking another wife.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last, however, his wise men said, "this will not do; the king must marry again, that we may have a queen."

author: Grimms
sentence: So messengers were sent far and wide, to seek for a bride as beautiful as the late queen.

author: Grimms
sentence: But there was no princess in the world so beautiful; and if there had been, still there was not one to be found who had golden hair.

author: Grimms
sentence: So the messengers came home, and had had all their trouble for nothing.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now the king had a daughter, who was just as beautiful as her mother, and had the same golden hair.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when she was grown up, the king looked at her and saw that she was just like this late queen: then he said to his courtiers, "May I not marry my daughter?

author: Grimms
sentence: She is the very image of my dead wife: unless I have her, I shall not find any bride upon the whole earth, and you say there must be a queen."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the courtiers heard this they were shocked, and said, "Heaven forbid that a father should marry his daughter!

author: Grimms
sentence: Out of so great a sin no good can come."

author: Grimms
sentence: And his daughter was also shocked, but hoped the king would soon give up such thoughts; so she said to him, "Before I marry anyone I must have three dresses: one must be of gold, like the sun; another must be of shining silver, like the moon; and a third must be dazzling as the stars: besides this, I want a mantle of a thousand different kinds of fur put together, to which every beast in the kingdom must give a part of his skin."

author: Grimms
sentence: And thus she though he would think of the matter no more.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the king made the most skilful workmen in his kingdom weave the three dresses: one golden, like the sun; another silvery, like the moon; and a third sparkling, like the stars: and his hunters were told to hunt out all the beasts in his kingdom, and to take the finest fur out of their skins: and thus a mantle of a thousand furs was made.

author: Grimms
sentence: When all were ready, the king sent them to her; but she got up in the night when all were asleep, and took three of her trinkets, a golden ring, a golden necklace, and a golden brooch, and packed the three dresses--of the sun, the moon, and the stars--up in a nutshell, and wrapped herself up in the mantle made of all sorts of fur, and besmeared her face and hands with soot.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she threw herself upon Heaven for help in her need, and went away, and journeyed on the whole night, till at last she came to a large wood.

author: Grimms
sentence: As she was very tired, she sat herself down in the hollow of a tree and soon fell asleep: and there she slept on till it was midday.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now as the king to whom the wood belonged was hunting in it, his dogs came to the tree, and began to snuff about, and run round and round, and bark.

author: Grimms
sentence: Look sharp! said the king to the huntsmen, "and see what sort of game lies there."

author: Grimms
sentence: And the huntsmen went up to the tree, and when they came back again said, "In the hollow tree there lies a most wonderful beast, such as we never saw before; its skin seems to be of a thousand kinds of fur, but there it lies fast asleep."

author: Grimms
sentence: See, said the king, "if you can catch it alive, and we will take it with us."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the huntsmen took it up, and the maiden awoke and was greatly frightened, and said, "I am a poor child that has neither father nor mother left; have pity on me and take me with you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they said, "Yes, Miss Cat-skin, you will do for the kitchen; you can sweep up the ashes, and do things of that sort."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they put her into the coach, and took her home to the king"s palace.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they showed her a little corner under the staircase, where no light of day ever peeped in, and said, "Cat-skin, you may lie and sleep there."

author: Grimms
sentence: And she was sent into the kitchen, and made to fetch wood and water, to blow the fire, pluck the poultry, pick the herbs, sift the ashes, and do all the dirty work.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thus Cat-skin lived for a long time very sorrowfully.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah! pretty princess! thought she, "what will now become of thee?"

author: Grimms
sentence: But it happened one day that a feast was to be held in the king"s castle, so she said to the cook, "May I go up a little while and see what is going on?

author: Grimms
sentence: I will take care and stand behind the door."

author: Grimms
sentence: And the cook said, "Yes, you may go, but be back again in half an hour"s time, to rake out the ashes."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she took her little lamp, and went into her cabin, and took off the fur skin, and washed the soot from off her face and hands, so that her beauty shone forth like the sun from behind the clouds.

author: Grimms
sentence: She next opened her nutshell, and brought out of it the dress that shone like the sun, and so went to the feast.

author: Grimms
sentence: Everyone made way for her, for nobody knew her, and they thought she could be no less than a king"s daughter.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the king came up to her, and held out his hand and danced with her; and he thought in his heart, "I never saw any one half so beautiful."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the dance was at an end she curtsied; and when the king looked round for her, she was gone, no one knew wither.

author: Grimms
sentence: The guards that stood at the castle gate were called in: but they had seen no one.

author: Grimms
sentence: The truth was, that she had run into her little cabin, pulled off her dress, blackened her face and hands, put on the fur-skin cloak, and was Catskin again.

author: Grimms
sentence: When she went into the kitchen to her work, and began to rake the ashes, the cook said, "Let that alone till the morning, and heat the king"s soup; I should like to run up now and give a peep: but take care you don"t let a hair fall into it, or you will run a chance of never eating again."

author: Grimms
sentence: As soon as the cook went away, Cat-skin heated the king"s soup, and toasted a slice of bread first, as nicely as ever she could; and when it was ready, she went and looked in the cabin for her little golden ring, and put it into the dish in which the soup was.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the dance was over, the king ordered his soup to be brought in; and it pleased him so well, that he thought he had never tasted any so good before.

author: Grimms
sentence: At the bottom he saw a gold ring lying; and as he could not make out how it had got there, he ordered the cook to be sent for.

author: Grimms
sentence: The cook was frightened when he heard the order, and said to Cat-skin, "You must have let a hair fall into the soup; if it be so, you will have a good beating."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went before the king, and he asked him who had cooked the soup.

author: Grimms
sentence: I did, answered the cook.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the king said, "That is not true; it was better done than you could do it."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he answered, "To tell the truth I did not cook it, but Cat-skin did."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then let Cat-skin come up, said the king: and when she came he said to her, "Who are you?"

author: Grimms
sentence: I am a poor child, said she, "that has lost both father and mother."

author: Grimms
sentence: How came you in my palace? asked he.

author: Grimms
sentence: I am good for nothing, said she, "but to be scullion-girl, and to have boots and shoes thrown at my head."

author: Grimms
sentence: But how did you get the ring that was in the soup? asked the king.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she would not own that she knew anything about the ring; so the king sent her away again about her business.

author: Grimms
sentence: After a time there was another feast, and Cat-skin asked the cook to let her go up and see it as before.

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said he, "but come again in half an hour, and cook the king the soup that he likes so much."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she ran to her little cabin, washed herself quickly, and took her dress out which was silvery as the moon, and put it on; and when she went in, looking like a king"s daughter, the king went up to her, and rejoiced at seeing her again, and when the dance began he danced with her.

author: Grimms
sentence: After the dance was at an end she managed to slip out, so slyly that the king did not see where she was gone; but she sprang into her little cabin, and made herself into Cat-skin again, and went into the kitchen to cook the soup.

author: Grimms
sentence: Whilst the cook was above stairs, she got the golden necklace and dropped it into the soup; then it was brought to the king, who ate it, and it pleased him as well as before; so he sent for the cook, who was again forced to tell him that Cat-skin had cooked it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Cat-skin was brought again before the king, but she still told him that she was only fit to have boots and shoes thrown at her head.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when the king had ordered a feast to be got ready for the third time, it happened just the same as before.

author: Grimms
sentence: You must be a witch, Catskin, said the cook; "for you always put something into your soup, so that it pleases the king better than mine."

author: Grimms
sentence: However, he let her go up as before.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she put on her dress which sparkled like the stars, and went into the ball-room in it; and the king danced with her again, and thought she had never looked so beautiful as she did then.

author: Grimms
sentence: So whilst he was dancing with her, he put a gold ring on her finger without her seeing it, and ordered that the dance should be kept up a long time.

author: Grimms
sentence: When it was at an end, he would have held her fast by the hand, but she slipped away, and sprang so quickly through the crowd that he lost sight of her: and she ran as fast as she could into her little cabin under the stairs.

author: Grimms
sentence: But this time she kept away too long, and stayed beyond the half-hour; so she had not time to take off her fine dress, and threw her fur mantle over it, and in her haste did not blacken herself all over with soot, but left one of her fingers white.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she ran into the kitchen, and cooked the king"s soup; and as soon as the cook was gone, she put the golden brooch into the dish.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the king got to the bottom, he ordered Cat-skin to be called once more, and soon saw the white finger, and the ring that he had put on it whilst they were dancing: so he seized her hand, and kept fast hold of it, and when she wanted to loose herself and spring away, the fur cloak fell off a little on one side, and the starry dress sparkled underneath it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he got hold of the fur and tore it off, and her golden hair and beautiful form were seen, and she could no longer hide herself: so she washed the soot and ashes from her face, and showed herself to be the most beautiful princess upon the face of the earth.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the king said, "You are my beloved bride, and we will never more be parted from each other."

author: Grimms
sentence: And the wedding feast was held, and a merry day it was, as ever was heard of or seen in that country, or indeed in any other.

author: Grimms
sentence: A certain cat had made the acquaintance of a mouse, and had said so much to her about the great love and friendship she felt for her, that at length the mouse agreed that they should live and keep house together.

author: Grimms
sentence: But we must make a provision for winter, or else we shall suffer from hunger, said the cat; "and you, little mouse, cannot venture everywhere, or you will be caught in a trap some day."

author: Grimms
sentence: The good advice was followed, and a pot of fat was bought, but they did not know where to put it.

author: Grimms
sentence: At length, after much consideration, the cat said: "I know no place where it will be better stored up than in the church, for no one dares take anything away from there.

author: Grimms
sentence: We will set it beneath the altar, and not touch it until we are really in need of it."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the pot was placed in safety, but it was not long before the cat had a great yearning for it, and said to the mouse: "I want to tell you something, little mouse; my cousin has brought a little son into the world, and has asked me to be godmother; he is white with brown spots, and I am to hold him over the font at the christening.

author: Grimms
sentence: Let me go out today, and you look after the house by yourself."

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, yes, answered the mouse, "by all means go, and if you get anything very good to eat, think of me.

author: Grimms
sentence: I should like a drop of sweet red christening wine myself."

author: Grimms
sentence: All this, however, was untrue; the cat had no cousin, and had not been asked to be godmother.

author: Grimms
sentence: She went straight to the church, stole to the pot of fat, began to lick at it, and licked the top of the fat off.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she took a walk upon the roofs of the town, looked out for opportunities, and then stretched herself in the sun, and licked her lips whenever she thought of the pot of fat, and not until it was evening did she return home.

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, here you are again, said the mouse, "no doubt you have had a merry day."

author: Grimms
sentence: All went off well, answered the cat.

author: Grimms
sentence: What name did they give the child?

author: Grimms
sentence: Top off! said the cat quite coolly.

author: Grimms
sentence: Top off! cried the mouse, "that is a very odd and uncommon name, is it a usual one in your family?"

author: Grimms
sentence: What does that matter, said the cat, "it is no worse than Crumb-stealer, as your godchildren are called."

author: Grimms
sentence: Before long the cat was seized by another fit of yearning.

author: Grimms
sentence: She said to the mouse: "You must do me a favour, and once more manage the house for a day alone.

author: Grimms
sentence: I am again asked to be godmother, and, as the child has a white ring round its neck, I cannot refuse."

author: Grimms
sentence: The good mouse consented, but the cat crept behind the town walls to the church, and devoured half the pot of fat.

author: Grimms
sentence: Nothing ever seems so good as what one keeps to oneself, said she, and was quite satisfied with her day"s work.

author: Grimms
sentence: When she went home the mouse inquired: "And what was the child christened?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Half-done, answered the cat.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a man who had a daughter who was called Clever Elsie.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when she had grown up her father said: "We will get her married."

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said the mother, "if only someone would come who would have her."

author: Grimms
sentence: At length a man came from a distance and wooed her, who was called Hans; but he stipulated that Clever Elsie should be really smart.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, said the father, "she has plenty of good sense"; and the mother said: "Oh, she can see the wind coming up the street, and hear the flies coughing."

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, said Hans, "if she is not really smart, I won"t have her."

author: Grimms
sentence: When they were sitting at dinner and had eaten, the mother said: "Elsie, go into the cellar and fetch some beer."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Clever Elsie took the pitcher from the wall, went into the cellar, and tapped the lid briskly as she went, so that the time might not appear long.

author: Grimms
sentence: When she was below she fetched herself a chair, and set it before the barrel so that she had no need to stoop, and did not hurt her back or do herself any unexpected injury.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she placed the can before her, and turned the tap, and while the beer was running she would not let her eyes be idle, but looked up at the wall, and after much peering here and there, saw a pick-axe exactly above her, which the masons had accidentally left there.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Clever Elsie began to weep and said: "If I get Hans, and we have a child, and he grows big, and we send him into the cellar here to draw beer, then the pick-axe will fall on his head and kill him."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she sat and wept and screamed with all the strength of her body, over the misfortune which lay before her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Those upstairs waited for the drink, but Clever Elsie still did not come.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the woman said to the servant: "Just go down into the cellar and see where Elsie is."

author: Grimms
sentence: The maid went and found her sitting in front of the barrel, screaming loudly.

author: Grimms
sentence: Elsie why do you weep? asked the maid.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, she answered, "have I not reason to weep?

author: Grimms
sentence: If I get Hans, and we have a child, and he grows big, and has to draw beer here, the pick-axe will perhaps fall on his head, and kill him."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the maid: "What a clever Elsie we have!" and sat down beside her and began loudly to weep over the misfortune.

author: Grimms
sentence: After a while, as the maid did not come back, and those upstairs were thirsty for the beer, the man said to the boy: "Just go down into the cellar and see where Elsie and the girl are."

author: Grimms
sentence: The boy went down, and there sat Clever Elsie and the girl both weeping together.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he asked: "Why are you weeping?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, said Elsie, "have I not reason to weep?

author: Grimms
sentence: If I get Hans, and we have a child, and he grows big, and has to draw beer here, the pick-axe will fall on his head and kill him."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the boy: "What a clever Elsie we have!" and sat down by her, and likewise began to howl loudly.

author: Grimms
sentence: Upstairs they waited for the boy, but as he still did not return, the man said to the woman: "Just go down into the cellar and see where Elsie is!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The woman went down, and found all three in the midst of their lamentations, and inquired what was the cause; then Elsie told her also that her future child was to be killed by the pick-axe, when it grew big and had to draw beer, and the pick-axe fell down.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the mother likewise: "What a clever Elsie we have!" and sat down and wept with them.

author: Grimms
sentence: The man upstairs waited a short time, but as his wife did not come back and his thirst grew ever greater, he said: "I must go into the cellar myself and see where Elsie is."

author: Grimms
sentence: But when he got into the cellar, and they were all sitting together crying, and he heard the reason, and that Elsie"s child was the cause, and the Elsie might perhaps bring one into the world some day, and that he might be killed by the pick-axe, if he should happen to be sitting beneath it, drawing beer just at the very time when it fell down, he cried: "Oh, what a clever Elsie!" and sat down, and likewise wept with them.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bridegroom stayed upstairs alone for along time; then as no one would come back he thought: "They must be waiting for me below: I too must go there and see what they are about."

author: Grimms
sentence: When he got down, the five of them were sitting screaming and lamenting quite piteously, each outdoing the other.

author: Grimms
sentence: What misfortune has happened then? asked he.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, dear Hans, said Elsie, "if we marry each other and have a child, and he is big, and we perhaps send him here to draw something to drink, then the pick-axe which has been left up there might dash his brains out if it were to fall down, so have we not reason to weep?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Come, said Hans, "more understanding than that is not needed for my household, as you are such a clever Elsie, I will have you," and seized her hand, took her upstairs with him, and married her.

author: Grimms
sentence: After Hans had had her some time, he said: "Wife, I am going out to work and earn some money for us; go into the field and cut the corn that we may have some bread."

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, dear Hans, I will do that.

author: Grimms
sentence: After Hans had gone away, she cooked herself some good broth and took it into the field with her.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, I will eat first."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she drank her cup of broth and when she was fully satisfied, she once more said: "What shall I do?

author: Grimms
sentence: Shall I cut first, or shall I sleep first?

author: Grimms
sentence: I will sleep first."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she lay down among the corn and fell asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hans had been at home for a long time, but Elsie did not come; then said he: "What a clever Elsie I have; she is so industrious that she does not even come home to eat."

author: Grimms
sentence: But when evening came and she still stayed away, Hans went out to see what she had cut, but nothing was cut, and she was lying among the corn asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Hans hastened home and brought a fowler"s net with little bells and hung it round about her, and she still went on sleeping.

author: Grimms
sentence: At length, when it was quite dark, Clever Elsie awoke and when she got up there was a jingling all round about her, and the bells rang at each step which she took.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she was alarmed, and became uncertain whether she really was Clever Elsie or not, and said: "Is it I, or is it not I?"

author: Grimms
sentence: But she knew not what answer to make to this, and stood for a time in doubt; at length she thought: "I will go home and ask if it be I, or if it be not I, they will be sure to know."

author: Grimms
sentence: She ran to the door of her own house, but it was shut; then she knocked at the window and cried: "Hans, is Elsie within?"

sentence: Yes, answered Hans, "she is within."

author: Grimms
sentence: Hereupon she was terrified, and said: "Ah, heavens!

author: Grimms
sentence: Then it is not I," and went to another door; but when the people heard the jingling of the bells they would not open it, and she could get in nowhere.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she ran out of the village, and no one has seen her since.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a cook named Gretel, who wore shoes with red heels, and when she walked out with them on, she turned herself this way and that, was quite happy and thought: "You certainly are a pretty girl!"

author: Grimms
sentence: And when she came home she drank, in her gladness of heart, a draught of wine, and as wine excites a desire to eat, she tasted the best of whatever she was cooking until she was satisfied, and said: "The cook must know what the food is like."

author: Grimms
sentence: It came to pass that the master one day said to her: "Gretel, there is a guest coming this evening; prepare me two fowls very daintily."

author: Grimms
sentence: I will see to it, master, answered Gretel.

author: Grimms
sentence: She killed two fowls, scalded them, plucked them, put them on the spit, and towards evening set them before the fire, that they might roast.

author: Grimms
sentence: The fowls began to turn brown, and were nearly ready, but the guest had not yet arrived.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Gretel called out to her master: "If the guest does not come, I must take the fowls away from the fire, but it will be a sin and a shame if they are not eaten the moment they are at their juiciest."

author: Grimms
sentence: The master said: "I will run myself, and fetch the guest."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the master had turned his back, Gretel laid the spit with the fowls on one side, and thought: "Standing so long by the fire there, makes one sweat and thirsty; who knows when they will come?

author: Grimms
sentence: Meanwhile, I will run into the cellar, and take a drink."

author: Grimms
sentence: She ran down, set a jug, said: "God bless it for you, Gretel," and took a good drink, and thought that wine should flow on, and should not be interrupted, and took yet another hearty draught.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she went and put the fowls down again to the fire, basted them, and drove the spit merrily round.

author: Grimms
sentence: But as the roast meat smelt so good, Gretel thought: "Something might be wrong, it ought to be tasted!"

author: Grimms
sentence: She touched it with her finger, and said: "Ah! how good fowls are!

author: Grimms
sentence: It certainly is a sin and a shame that they are not eaten at the right time!"

author: Grimms
sentence: She ran to the window, to see if the master was not coming with his guest, but she saw no one, and went back to the fowls and thought: "One of the wings is burning!

author: Grimms
sentence: I had better take it off and eat it."

author: Grimms
sentence: So she cut it off, ate it, and enjoyed it, and when she had done, she thought: "The other must go down too, or else master will observe that something is missing."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the two wings were eaten, she went and looked for her master, and did not see him.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: They are perhaps not coming at all, and have turned in somewhere."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she said: "Well, Gretel, enjoy yourself, one fowl has been cut into, take another drink, and eat it up entirely; when it is eaten you will have some peace, why should God"s good gifts be spoilt?"

author: Grimms
sentence: So she ran into the cellar again, took an enormous drink and ate up the one chicken in great glee.

author: Grimms
sentence: When one of the chickens was swallowed down, and still her master did not come, Gretel looked at the other and said: "What one is, the other should be likewise, the two go together; what"s right for the one is right for the other; I think if I were to take another draught it would do me no harm."

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once upon a time a poor peasant called Crabb, who drove with two oxen a load of wood to the town, and sold it to a doctor for two talers.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the money was being counted out to him, it so happened that the doctor was sitting at table, and when the peasant saw how well he ate and drank, his heart desired what he saw, and would willingly have been a doctor too.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he remained standing a while, and at length inquired if he too could not be a doctor.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, yes, said the doctor, "that is soon managed."

author: Grimms
sentence: What must I do? asked the peasant.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the first place buy yourself an A B C book of the kind which has a cock on the frontispiece; in the second, turn your cart and your two oxen into money, and get yourself some clothes, and whatsoever else pertains to medicine; thirdly, have a sign painted for yourself with the words: I am Doctor Knowall," and have that nailed up above your house-door."

author: Grimms
sentence: The peasant did everything that he had been told to do.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had doctored people awhile, but not long, a rich and great lord had some money stolen.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he was told about Doctor Knowall who lived in such and such a village, and must know what had become of the money.

author: Grimms
sentence: So the lord had the horses harnessed to his carriage, drove out to the village, and asked Crabb if he were Doctor Knowall.

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, he was, he said.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he was to go with him and bring back the stolen money.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, yes, but Grete, my wife, must go too.

author: Grimms
sentence: The lord was willing, and let both of them have a seat in the carriage, and they all drove away together.

author: Grimms
sentence: When they came to the nobleman"s castle, the table was spread, and Crabb was told to sit down and eat.

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, but my wife, Grete, too, said he, and he seated himself with her at the table.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when the first servant came with a dish of delicate fare, the peasant nudged his wife, and said: "Grete, that was the first," meaning that was the servant who brought the first dish.

author: Grimms
sentence: The servant, however, thought he intended by that to say: "That is the first thief," and as he actually was so, he was terrified, and said to his comrade outside: "The doctor knows all: we shall fare ill, he said I was the first."

author: Grimms
sentence: The second did not want to go in at all, but was forced.

author: Grimms
sentence: So when he went in with his dish, the peasant nudged his wife, and said: "Grete, that is the second."

author: Grimms
sentence: This servant was equally alarmed, and he got out as fast as he could.

author: Grimms
sentence: The third fared no better, for the peasant again said: "Grete, that is the third."

author: Grimms
sentence: The fourth had to carry in a dish that was covered, and the lord told the doctor that he was to show his skill, and guess what was beneath the cover.

author: Grimms
sentence: Actually, there were crabs.

author: Grimms
sentence: The doctor looked at the dish, had no idea what to say, and cried: "Ah, poor Crabb."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the lord heard that, he cried: "There! he knows it; he must also know who has the money!"

author: Grimms
sentence: On this the servants looked terribly uneasy, and made a sign to the doctor that they wished him to step outside for a moment.

author: Grimms
sentence: When therefore he went out, all four of them confessed to him that they had stolen the money, and said that they would willingly restore it and give him a heavy sum into the bargain, if he would not denounce them, for if he did they would be hanged.

author: Grimms
sentence: They led him to the spot where the money was concealed.

author: Grimms
sentence: With this the doctor was satisfied, and returned to the hall, sat down to the table, and said: "My lord, now will I search in my book where the gold is hidden."

author: Grimms
sentence: The fifth servant, however, crept into the stove to hear if the doctor knew still more.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the doctor sat still and opened his A B C book, turned the pages backwards and forwards, and looked for the cock.

author: Grimms
sentence: As he could not find it immediately he said: "I know you are there, so you had better come out!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the fellow in the stove thought that the doctor meant him, and full of terror, sprang out, crying: "That man knows everything!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Doctor Knowall showed the lord where the money was, but did not say who had stolen it, and received from both sides much money in reward, and became a renowned man.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once upon a time an old fox with nine tails, who believed that his wife was not faithful to him, and wished to put her to the test.
