author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a man called Frederick: he had a wife whose name was Catherine, and they had not long been married.

author: Grimms
sentence: One day Frederick said.

author: Grimms
sentence:
Kate!
3:3	N:N	N:N	I am going to work in the fields; when I come back I shall be hungry so let me have something nice cooked, and a good draught of ale.

author: Grimms
sentence: Very well, said she, "it shall all be ready."

author: Grimms
sentence: When dinner-time drew nigh, Catherine took a nice steak, which was all the meat she had, and put it on the fire to fry.

author: Grimms
sentence: The steak soon began to look brown, and to crackle in the pan; and Catherine stood by with a fork and turned it: then she said to herself, "The steak is almost ready, I may as well go to the cellar for the ale."

author: Grimms
sentence: So she left the pan on the fire and took a large jug and went into the cellar and tapped the ale cask.

author: Grimms
sentence: The beer ran into the jug and Catherine stood looking on.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last it popped into her head, "The dog is not shut up--he may be running away with the steak; that"s well thought of."

author: Grimms
sentence: So up she ran from the cellar; and sure enough the rascally cur had got the steak in his mouth, and was making off with it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Away ran Catherine, and away ran the dog across the field: but he ran faster than she, and stuck close to the steak.

author: Grimms
sentence: Its all gone, and "what can"t be cured must be endured"," said Catherine.

author: Grimms
sentence: So she turned round; and as she had run a good way and was tired, she walked home leisurely to cool herself.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now all this time the ale was running too, for Catherine had not turned the cock; and when the jug was full the liquor ran upon the floor till the cask was empty.

author: Grimms
sentence: When she got to the cellar stairs she saw what had happened.

author: Grimms
sentence: My stars! said she, "what shall I do to keep Frederick from seeing all this slopping about?"

author: Grimms
sentence: So she thought a while; and at last remembered that there was a sack of fine meal bought at the last fair, and that if she sprinkled this over the floor it would suck up the ale nicely.

author: Grimms
sentence: What a lucky thing, said she, "that we kept that meal! we have now a good use for it."

author: Grimms
sentence: So away she went for it: but she managed to set it down just upon the great jug full of beer, and upset it; and thus all the ale that had been saved was set swimming on the floor also.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah! well, said she, "when one goes another may as well follow."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she strewed the meal all about the cellar, and was quite pleased with her cleverness, and said, "How very neat and clean it looks!"

author: Grimms
sentence: At noon Frederick came home.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now, wife, cried he, "what have you for dinner?"

author: Grimms
sentence: O Frederick! answered she, "I was cooking you a steak; but while I went down to draw the ale, the dog ran away with it; and while I ran after him, the ale ran out; and when I went to dry up the ale with the sack of meal that we got at the fair, I upset the jug: but the cellar is now quite dry, and looks so clean!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Kate, Kate, said he, "how could you do all this?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Why did you leave the steak to fry, and the ale to run, and then spoil all the meal?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Why, Frederick, said she, "I did not know I was doing wrong; you should have told me before."

author: Grimms
sentence: The husband thought to himself, "If my wife manages matters thus, I must look sharp myself."

author: Grimms
sentence: Now he had a good deal of gold in the house: so he said to Catherine, "What pretty yellow buttons these are!

author: Grimms
sentence: I shall put them into a box and bury them in the garden; but take care that you never go near or meddle with them."

author: Grimms
sentence: No, Frederick, said she, "that I never will."

author: Grimms
sentence: As soon as he was gone, there came by some pedlars with earthenware plates and dishes, and they asked her whether she would buy.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh dear me, I should like to buy very much, but I have no money: if you had any use for yellow buttons, I might deal with you.

author: Grimms
sentence: Yellow buttons! said they: "let us have a look at them."

author: Grimms
sentence: Go into the garden and dig where I tell you, and you will find the yellow buttons: I dare not go myself.

author: Grimms
sentence: So the rogues went: and when they found what these yellow buttons were, they took them all away, and left her plenty of plates and dishes.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she set them all about the house for a show: and when Frederick came back, he cried out, "Kate, what have you been doing?"

author: Grimms
sentence: See, said she, "I have bought all these with your yellow buttons: but I did not touch them myself; the pedlars went themselves and dug them up."

author: Grimms
sentence: Wife, wife, said Frederick, "what a pretty piece of work you have made! those yellow buttons were all my money: how came you to do such a thing?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Why, answered she, "I did not know there was any harm in it; you should have told me."

author: Grimms
sentence: Catherine stood musing for a while, and at last said to her husband, "Hark ye, Frederick, we will soon get the gold back: let us run after the thieves."

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, we will try, answered he; "but take some butter and cheese with you, that we may have something to eat by the way."

author: Grimms
sentence: Very well, said she; and they set out: and as Frederick walked the fastest, he left his wife some way behind.

author: Grimms
sentence: It does not matter, thought she: "when we turn back, I shall be so much nearer home than he."

author: Grimms
sentence: Presently she came to the top of a hill, down the side of which there was a road so narrow that the cart wheels always chafed the trees on each side as they passed.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, see now, said she, "how they have bruised and wounded those poor trees; they will never get well."

author: Grimms
sentence: So she took pity on them, and made use of the butter to grease them all, so that the wheels might not hurt them so much.

author: Grimms
sentence: While she was doing this kind office one of her cheeses fell out of the basket, and rolled down the hill.

author: Grimms
sentence: Catherine looked, but could not see where it had gone; so she said, "Well, I suppose the other will go the same way and find you; he has younger legs than I have."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she rolled the other cheese after it; and away it went, nobody knows where, down the hill.

author: Grimms
sentence: But she said she supposed that they knew the road, and would follow her, and she could not stay there all day waiting for them.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last she overtook Frederick, who desired her to give him something to eat.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she gave him the dry bread.

author: Grimms
sentence: Where are the butter and cheese? said he.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh! answered she, "I used the butter to grease those poor trees that the wheels chafed so: and one of the cheeses ran away so I sent the other after it to find it, and I suppose they are both on the road together somewhere."

author: Grimms
sentence: What a goose you are to do such silly things! said the husband.

author: Grimms
sentence: How can you say so? said she; "I am sure you never told me not."

author: Grimms
sentence: They ate the dry bread together; and Frederick said, "Kate, I hope you locked the door safe when you came away."

author: Grimms
sentence: No, answered she, "you did not tell me."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then go home, and do it now before we go any farther, said Frederick, "and bring with you something to eat."

author: Grimms
sentence: Catherine did as he told her, and thought to herself by the way, "Frederick wants something to eat; but I don"t think he is very fond of butter and cheese: I"ll bring him a bag of fine nuts, and the vinegar, for I have often seen him take some."

author: Grimms
sentence: When she reached home, she bolted the back door, but the front door she took off the hinges, and said, "Frederick told me to lock the door, but surely it can nowhere be so safe if I take it with me."

author: Grimms
sentence: So she took her time by the way; and when she overtook her husband she cried out, "There, Frederick, there is the door itself, you may watch it as carefully as you please."

author: Grimms
sentence: Alas! alas! said he, "what a clever wife I have!

author: Grimms
sentence: I sent you to make the house fast, and you take the door away, so that everybody may go in and out as they please--however, as you have brought the door, you shall carry it about with you for your pains."

author: Grimms
sentence: Very well, answered she, "I"ll carry the door; but I"ll not carry the nuts and vinegar bottle also--that would be too much of a load; so if you please, I"ll fasten them to the door."

author: Grimms
sentence: Frederick of course made no objection to that plan, and they set off into the wood to look for the thieves; but they could not find them: and when it grew dark, they climbed up into a tree to spend the night there.

author: Grimms
sentence: Scarcely were they up, than who should come by but the very rogues they were looking for.

author: Grimms
sentence: They were in truth great rascals, and belonged to that class of people who find things before they are lost; they were tired; so they sat down and made a fire under the very tree where Frederick and Catherine were.

author: Grimms
sentence: Frederick slipped down on the other side, and picked up some stones.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he climbed up again, and tried to hit the thieves on the head with them: but they only said, "It must be near morning, for the wind shakes the fir-apples down."

author: Grimms
sentence: Catherine, who had the door on her shoulder, began to be very tired; but she thought it was the nuts upon it that were so heavy: so she said softly, "Frederick, I must let the nuts go."

author: Grimms
sentence: No, answered he, "not now, they will discover us."

author: Grimms
sentence: I cant help that: they must go."

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, then, make haste and throw them down, if you will.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then away rattled the nuts down among the boughs and one of the thieves cried, "Bless me, it is hailing."

author: Grimms
sentence: A little while after, Catherine thought the door was still very heavy: so she whispered to Frederick, "I must throw the vinegar down."

author: Grimms
sentence: Pray dont," answered he, "it will discover us."

author: Grimms
sentence: I cant help that," said she, "go it must."

author: Grimms
sentence: So she poured all the vinegar down; and the thieves said, "What a heavy dew there is!"

author: Grimms
sentence: At last it popped into Catherine"s head that it was the door itself that was so heavy all the time: so she whispered, "Frederick, I must throw the door down soon."

author: Grimms
sentence: But he begged and prayed her not to do so, for he was sure it would betray them.

author: Grimms
sentence: Here goes, however, said she: and down went the door with such a clatter upon the thieves, that they cried out "Murder!" and not knowing what was coming, ran away as fast as they could, and left all the gold.

author: Grimms
sentence: So when Frederick and Catherine came down, there they found all their money safe and sound.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a forester who went into the forest to hunt, and as he entered it he heard a sound of screaming as if a little child were there.

author: Grimms
sentence: He followed the sound, and at last came to a high tree, and at the top of this a little child was sitting, for the mother had fallen asleep under the tree with the child, and a bird of prey had seen it in her arms, had flown down, snatched it away, and set it on the high tree.

author: Grimms
sentence: The forester climbed up, brought the child down, and thought to himself: "You will take him home with you, and bring him up with your Lina."

author: Grimms
sentence: He took it home, therefore, and the two children grew up together.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the one, which he had found on a tree was called Fundevogel, because a bird had carried it away.

author: Grimms
sentence: Fundevogel and Lina loved each other so dearly that when they did not see each other they were sad.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now the forester had an old cook, who one evening took two pails and began to fetch water, and did not go once only, but many times, out to the spring.

author: Grimms
sentence: Lina saw this and said, "Listen, old Sanna, why are you fetching so much water?"

author: Grimms
sentence: If you will never repeat it to anyone, I will tell you why.

author: Grimms
sentence: So Lina said, no, she would never repeat it to anyone, and then the cook said: "Early tomorrow morning, when the forester is out hunting, I will heat the water, and when it is boiling in the kettle, I will throw in Fundevogel, and will boil him in it."

author: Grimms
sentence: Early next morning the forester got up and went out hunting, and when he was gone the children were still in bed.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Lina said to Fundevogel: "If you will never leave me, I too will never leave you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Fundevogel said: "Neither now, nor ever will I leave you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said Lina: "Then will I tell you.

author: Grimms
sentence: Last night, old Sanna carried so many buckets of water into the house that I asked her why she was doing that, and she said that if I would promise not to tell anyone, and she said that early tomorrow morning when father was out hunting, she would set the kettle full of water, throw you into it and boil you; but we will get up quickly, dress ourselves, and go away together."

author: Grimms
sentence: The two children therefore got up, dressed themselves quickly, and went away.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the water in the kettle was boiling, the cook went into the bedroom to fetch Fundevogel and throw him into it.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when she came in, and went to the beds, both the children were gone.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she was terribly alarmed, and she said to herself: "What shall I say now when the forester comes home and sees that the children are gone?

author: Grimms
sentence: They must be followed instantly to get them back again."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the cook sent three servants after them, who were to run and overtake the children.

author: Grimms
sentence: The children, however, were sitting outside the forest, and when they saw from afar the three servants running, Lina said to Fundevogel: "Never leave me, and I will never leave you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Fundevogel said: "Neither now, nor ever."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said Lina: "Do you become a rose-tree, and I the rose upon it."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the three servants came to the forest, nothing was there but a rose-tree and one rose on it, but the children were nowhere.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said they: "There is nothing to be done here," and they went home and told the cook that they had seen nothing in the forest but a little rose-bush with one rose on it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the old cook scolded and said: "You simpletons, you should have cut the rose-bush in two, and have broken off the rose and brought it home with you; go, and do it at once."

author: Grimms
sentence: They had therefore to go out and look for the second time.

author: Grimms
sentence: The children, however, saw them coming from a distance.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Lina said: "Fundevogel, never leave me, and I will never leave you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Fundevogel said: "Neither now; nor ever."

author: Grimms
sentence: Said Lina: "Then do you become a church, and I"ll be the chandelier in it."

author: Grimms
sentence: So when the three servants came, nothing was there but a church, with a chandelier in it.

author: Grimms
sentence: They said therefore to each other: "What can we do here, let us go home."

author: Grimms
sentence: When they got home, the cook asked if they had not found them; so they said no, they had found nothing but a church, and there was a chandelier in it.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the cook scolded them and said: "You fools! why did you not pull the church to pieces, and bring the chandelier home with you?"

author: Grimms
sentence: And now the old cook herself got on her legs, and went with the three servants in pursuit of the children.

author: Grimms
sentence: The children, however, saw from afar that the three servants were coming, and the cook waddling after them.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said Lina: "Fundevogel, never leave me, and I will never leave you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said Fundevogel: "Neither now, nor ever."

author: Grimms
sentence: Said Lina: "Be a fishpond, and I will be the duck upon it."

author: Grimms
sentence: The cook, however, came up to them, and when she saw the pond she lay down by it, and was about to drink it up.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the duck swam quickly to her, seized her head in its beak and drew her into the water, and there the old witch had to drown.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the children went home together, and were heartily delighted, and if they have not died, they are living still.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hard by a great forest dwelt a poor wood-cutter with his wife and his two children.

author: Grimms
sentence: The boy was called Hansel and the girl Gretel.

author: Grimms
sentence: He had little to bite and to break, and once when great dearth fell on the land, he could no longer procure even daily bread.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now when he thought over this by night in his bed, and tossed about in his anxiety, he groaned and said to his wife: "What is to become of us?

author: Grimms
sentence: How are we to feed our poor children, when we no longer have anything even for ourselves?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Ill tell you what, husband," answered the woman, "early tomorrow morning we will take the children out into the forest to where it is the thickest; there we will light a fire for them, and give each of them one more piece of bread, and then we will go to our work and leave them alone.

author: Grimms
sentence: They will not find the way home again, and we shall be rid of them."

author: Grimms
sentence: No, wife, said the man, "I will not do that; how can I bear to leave my children alone in the forest?--the wild animals would soon come and tear them to pieces."

author: Grimms
sentence: O, you fool! said she, "then we must all four die of hunger, you may as well plane the planks for our coffins," and she left him no peace until he consented.

author: Grimms
sentence: But I feel very sorry for the poor children, all the same, said the man.

author: Grimms
sentence: The two children had also not been able to sleep for hunger, and had heard what their stepmother had said to their father.

author: Grimms
sentence: Gretel wept bitter tears, and said to Hansel: "Now all is over with us."

author: Grimms
sentence: Be quiet, Gretel, said Hansel, "do not distress yourself, I will soon find a way to help us."

author: Grimms
sentence: And when the old folks had fallen asleep, he got up, put on his little coat, opened the door below, and crept outside.

author: Grimms
sentence: The moon shone brightly, and the white pebbles which lay in front of the house glittered like real silver pennies.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hansel stooped and stuffed the little pocket of his coat with as many as he could get in.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went back and said to Gretel: "Be comforted, dear little sister, and sleep in peace, God will not forsake us," and he lay down again in his bed.

author: Grimms
sentence: When day dawned, but before the sun had risen, the woman came and awoke the two children, saying: "Get up, you sluggards! we are going into the forest to fetch wood."

author: Grimms
sentence: She gave each a little piece of bread, and said: "There is something for your dinner, but do not eat it up before then, for you will get nothing else."

author: Grimms
sentence: Gretel took the bread under her apron, as Hansel had the pebbles in his pocket.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they all set out together on the way to the forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: When they had walked a short time, Hansel stood still and peeped back at the house, and did so again and again.

author: Grimms
sentence: His father said: "Hansel, what are you looking at there and staying behind for?

author: Grimms
sentence: Pay attention, and do not forget how to use your legs."

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, father, said Hansel, "I am looking at my little white cat, which is sitting up on the roof, and wants to say goodbye to me."

author: Grimms
sentence: The wife said: "Fool, that is not your little cat, that is the morning sun which is shining on the chimneys."

author: Grimms
sentence: Hansel, however, had not been looking back at the cat, but had been constantly throwing one of the white pebble-stones out of his pocket on the road.

author: Grimms
sentence: When they had reached the middle of the forest, the father said: "Now, children, pile up some wood, and I will light a fire that you may not be cold."

author: Grimms
sentence: Hansel and Gretel gathered brushwood together, as high as a little hill.

author: Grimms
sentence: The brushwood was lighted, and when the flames were burning very high, the woman said: "Now, children, lay yourselves down by the fire and rest, we will go into the forest and cut some wood.

author: Grimms
sentence: When we have done, we will come back and fetch you away."

author: Grimms
sentence: Hansel and Gretel sat by the fire, and when noon came, each ate a little piece of bread, and as they heard the strokes of the wood-axe they believed that their father was near.

author: Grimms
sentence: It was not the axe, however, but a branch which he had fastened to a withered tree which the wind was blowing backwards and forwards.

author: Grimms
sentence: And as they had been sitting such a long time, their eyes closed with fatigue, and they fell fast asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: When at last they awoke, it was already dark night.

author: Grimms
sentence: Gretel began to cry and said: "How are we to get out of the forest now?"

author: Grimms
sentence: But Hansel comforted her and said: "Just wait a little, until the moon has risen, and then we will soon find the way."

author: Grimms
sentence: And when the full moon had risen, Hansel took his little sister by the hand, and followed the pebbles which shone like newly-coined silver pieces, and showed them the way.

author: Grimms
sentence: They walked the whole night long, and by break of day came once more to their father"s house.

author: Grimms
sentence: They knocked at the door, and when the woman opened it and saw that it was Hansel and Gretel, she said: "You naughty children, why have you slept so long in the forest?--we thought you were never coming back at all!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The father, however, rejoiced, for it had cut him to the heart to leave them behind alone.

author: Grimms
sentence: Not long afterwards, there was once more great dearth throughout the land, and the children heard their mother saying at night to their father: "Everything is eaten again, we have one half loaf left, and that is the end.

author: Grimms
sentence: The children must go, we will take them farther into the wood, so that they will not find their way out again; there is no other means of saving ourselves!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The man"s heart was heavy, and he thought: "It would be better for you to share the last mouthful with your children."

author: Grimms
sentence: The woman, however, would listen to nothing that he had to say, but scolded and reproached him.

author: Grimms
sentence: He who says A must say B, likewise, and as he had yielded the first time, he had to do so a second time also.

author: Grimms
sentence: The children, however, were still awake and had heard the conversation.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the old folks were asleep, Hansel again got up, and wanted to go out and pick up pebbles as he had done before, but the woman had locked the door, and Hansel could not get out.

author: Grimms
sentence: Nevertheless he comforted his little sister, and said: "Do not cry, Gretel, go to sleep quietly, the good God will help us."

author: Grimms
sentence: Early in the morning came the woman, and took the children out of their beds.

author: Grimms
sentence: Their piece of bread was given to them, but it was still smaller than the time before.

author: Grimms
sentence: On the way into the forest Hansel crumbled his in his pocket, and often stood still and threw a morsel on the ground.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hansel, why do you stop and look round? said the father, "go on."

author: Grimms
sentence: I am looking back at my little pigeon which is sitting on the roof, and wants to say goodbye to me, answered Hansel.

author: Grimms
sentence: Fool! said the woman, "that is not your little pigeon, that is the morning sun that is shining on the chimney."

author: Grimms
sentence: Hansel, however little by little, threw all the crumbs on the path.

author: Grimms
sentence: The woman led the children still deeper into the forest, where they had never in their lives been before.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then a great fire was again made, and the mother said: "Just sit there, you children, and when you are tired you may sleep a little; we are going into the forest to cut wood, and in the evening when we are done, we will come and fetch you away."

author: Grimms
sentence: When it was noon, Gretel shared her piece of bread with Hansel, who had scattered his by the way.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they fell asleep and evening passed, but no one came to the poor children.

author: Grimms
sentence: They did not awake until it was dark night, and Hansel comforted his little sister and said: "Just wait, Gretel, until the moon rises, and then we shall see the crumbs of bread which I have strewn about, they will show us our way home again."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the moon came they set out, but they found no crumbs, for the many thousands of birds which fly about in the woods and fields had picked them all up.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hansel said to Gretel: "We shall soon find the way," but they did not find it.

author: Grimms
sentence: They walked the whole night and all the next day too from morning till evening, but they did not get out of the forest, and were very hungry, for they had nothing to eat but two or three berries, which grew on the ground.

author: Grimms
sentence: And as they were so weary that their legs would carry them no longer, they lay down beneath a tree and fell asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: It was now three mornings since they had left their father"s house.

author: Grimms
sentence: They began to walk again, but they always came deeper into the forest, and if help did not come soon, they must die of hunger and weariness.

author: Grimms
sentence: When it was mid-day, they saw a beautiful snow-white bird sitting on a bough, which sang so delightfully that they stood still and listened to it.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when its song was over, it spread its wings and flew away before them, and they followed it until they reached a little house, on the roof of which it alighted; and when they approached the little house they saw that it was built of bread and covered with cakes, but that the windows were of clear sugar.

author: Grimms
sentence: We will set to work on that, said Hansel, "and have a good meal.

author: Grimms
sentence: I will eat a bit of the roof, and you Gretel, can eat some of the window, it will taste sweet."

author: Grimms
sentence: Hansel reached up above, and broke off a little of the roof to try how it tasted, and Gretel leant against the window and nibbled at the panes.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then a soft voice cried from the parlour:

author: Grimms
sentence: Nibble, nibble, gnaw, Who is nibbling at my little house?

author: Grimms
sentence: The children answered:

author: Grimms
sentence: The wind, the wind, The heaven-born wind,

author: Grimms
sentence: and went on eating without disturbing themselves.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hansel, who liked the taste of the roof, tore down a great piece of it, and Gretel pushed out the whole of one round window-pane, sat down, and enjoyed herself with it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Suddenly the door opened, and a woman as old as the hills, who supported herself on crutches, came creeping out.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hansel and Gretel were so terribly frightened that they let fall what they had in their hands.

author: Grimms
sentence: The old woman, however, nodded her head, and said: "Oh, you dear children, who has brought you here? do come in, and stay with me.

author: Grimms
sentence: No harm shall happen to you."

author: Grimms
sentence: She took them both by the hand, and led them into her little house.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then good food was set before them, milk and pancakes, with sugar, apples, and nuts.

author: Grimms
sentence: Afterwards two pretty little beds were covered with clean white linen, and Hansel and Gretel lay down in them, and thought they were in heaven.

author: Grimms
sentence: The old woman had only pretended to be so kind; she was in reality a wicked witch, who lay in wait for children, and had only built the little house of bread in order to entice them there.

author: Grimms
sentence: When a child fell into her power, she killed it, cooked and ate it, and that was a feast day with her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Witches have red eyes, and cannot see far, but they have a keen scent like the beasts, and are aware when human beings draw near.

author: Grimms
sentence: When Hansel and Gretel came into her neighbourhood, she laughed with malice, and said mockingly: "I have them, they shall not escape me again!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Early in the morning before the children were awake, she was already up, and when she saw both of them sleeping and looking so pretty, with their plump and rosy cheeks she muttered to herself: "That will be a dainty mouthful!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she seized Hansel with her shrivelled hand, carried him into a little stable, and locked him in behind a grated door.

author: Grimms
sentence: Scream as he might, it would not help him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she went to Gretel, shook her till she awoke, and cried: "Get up, lazy thing, fetch some water, and cook something good for your brother, he is in the stable outside, and is to be made fat.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he is fat, I will eat him."

author: Grimms
sentence: Gretel began to weep bitterly, but it was all in vain, for she was forced to do what the wicked witch commanded.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now the best food was cooked for poor Hansel, but Gretel got nothing but crab-shells.

author: Grimms
sentence: Every morning the woman crept to the little stable, and cried: "Hansel, stretch out your finger that I may feel if you will soon be fat."

author: Grimms
sentence: Hansel, however, stretched out a little bone to her, and the old woman, who had dim eyes, could not see it, and thought it was Hansel"s finger, and was astonished that there was no way of fattening him.

author: Grimms
sentence: When four weeks had gone by, and Hansel still remained thin, she was seized with impatience and would not wait any longer.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now, then, Gretel, she cried to the girl, "stir yourself, and bring some water.

author: Grimms
sentence: Let Hansel be fat or lean, tomorrow I will kill him, and cook him."

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, how the poor little sister did lament when she had to fetch the water, and how her tears did flow down her cheeks!

author: Grimms
sentence: Dear God, do help us, she cried.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: Some men are born to good luck: all they do or try to do comes right-- all that falls to them is so much gain--all their geese are swans--all their cards are trumps--toss them which way you will, they will always, like poor puss, alight upon their legs, and only move on so much the faster.

sentence: As the sun shone on his hair it glittered and flashed so that the rays fell into the bedroom of the king"s daughter, and up she sprang to see what that could be.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she saw the boy, and cried to him: "Boy, bring me a wreath of flowers."

author: Grimms
sentence: He put his cap on with all haste, and gathered wild field-flowers and bound them together.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he was ascending the stairs with them, the gardener met him, and said: "How can you take the king"s daughter a garland of such common flowers?

author: Grimms
sentence: Go quickly, and get another, and seek out the prettiest and rarest."

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, no, replied the boy, "the wild ones have more scent, and will please her better."

author: Grimms
sentence: When he got into the room, the king"s daughter said: "Take your cap off, it is not seemly to keep it on in my presence."

author: Grimms
sentence: He again said: "I may not, I have a sore head."

author: Grimms
sentence: She, however, caught at his cap and pulled it off, and then his golden hair rolled down on his shoulders, and it was splendid to behold.

author: Grimms
sentence: He wanted to run out, but she held him by the arm, and gave him a handful of ducats.

author: Grimms
sentence: With these he departed, but he cared nothing for the gold pieces.

author: Grimms
sentence: He took them to the gardener, and said: "I present them to your children, they can play with them."

author: Grimms
sentence: The following day the king"s daughter again called to him that he was to bring her a wreath of field-flowers, and then he went in with it, she instantly snatched at his cap, and wanted to take it away from him, but he held it fast with both hands.

author: Grimms
sentence: She again gave him a handful of ducats, but he would not keep them, and gave them to the gardener for playthings for his children.

author: Grimms
sentence: On the third day things went just the same; she could not get his cap away from him, and he would not have her money.

author: Grimms
sentence: Not long afterwards, the country was overrun by war.

author: Grimms
sentence: The king gathered together his people, and did not know whether or not he could offer any opposition to the enemy, who was superior in strength and had a mighty army.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the gardener"s boy: "I am grown up, and will go to the wars also, only give me a horse."

author: Grimms
sentence: The others laughed, and said: "Seek one for yourself when we are gone, we will leave one behind us in the stable for you."

author: Grimms
sentence: When they had gone forth, he went into the stable, and led the horse out; it was lame of one foot, and limped hobblety jib, hobblety jib; nevertheless he mounted it, and rode away to the dark forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he came to the outskirts, he called "Iron Hans" three times so loudly that it echoed through the trees.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon the wild man appeared immediately, and said: "What do you desire?"

author: Grimms
sentence: I want a strong steed, for I am going to the wars.

author: Grimms
sentence: That you shall have, and still more than you ask for.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the wild man went back into the forest, and it was not long before a stable-boy came out of it, who led a horse that snorted with its nostrils, and could hardly be restrained, and behind them followed a great troop of warriors entirely equipped in iron, and their swords flashed in the sun.

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth made over his three-legged horse to the stable-boy, mounted the other, and rode at the head of the soldiers.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he got near the battlefield a great part of the king"s men had already fallen, and little was wanting to make the rest give way.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the youth galloped thither with his iron soldiers, broke like a hurricane over the enemy, and beat down all who opposed him.

author: Grimms
sentence: They began to flee, but the youth pursued, and never stopped, until there was not a single man left.

author: Grimms
sentence: Instead of returning to the king, however, he conducted his troop by byways back to the forest, and called forth Iron Hans.

author: Grimms
sentence: What do you desire? asked the wild man.

author: Grimms
sentence: Take back your horse and your troops, and give me my three-legged horse again.

author: Grimms
sentence: All that he asked was done, and soon he was riding on his three-legged horse.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the king returned to his palace, his daughter went to meet him, and wished him joy of his victory.

author: Grimms
sentence: I am not the one who carried away the victory, said he, "but a strange knight who came to my assistance with his soldiers."

author: Grimms
sentence: The daughter wanted to hear who the strange knight was, but the king did not know, and said: "He followed the enemy, and I did not see him again."

author: Grimms
sentence: She inquired of the gardener where his boy was, but he smiled, and said: "He has just come home on his threelegged horse, and the others have been mocking him, and crying: "Here comes our hobblety jib back again!"

author: Grimms
sentence: They asked, too: "Under what hedge have you been lying sleeping all the time?"

author: Grimms
sentence: So he said: "I did the best of all, and it would have gone badly without me."

author: Grimms
sentence: And then he was still more ridiculed."

author: Grimms
sentence: The king said to his daughter: "I will proclaim a great feast that shall last for three days, and you shall throw a golden apple.

author: Grimms
sentence: Perhaps the unknown man will show himself."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the feast was announced, the youth went out to the forest, and called Iron Hans.

author: Grimms
sentence: What do you desire? asked he.

author: Grimms
sentence: That I may catch the kings daughter"s golden apple."

author: Grimms
sentence: It is as safe as if you had it already, said Iron Hans.

author: Grimms
sentence: You shall likewise have a suit of red armour for the occasion, and ride on a spirited chestnut-horse.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the day came, the youth galloped to the spot, took his place amongst the knights, and was recognized by no one.

author: Grimms
sentence: The king"s daughter came forward, and threw a golden apple to the knights, but none of them caught it but he, only as soon as he had it he galloped away.

author: Grimms
sentence: On the second day Iron Hans equipped him as a white knight, and gave him a white horse.

author: Grimms
sentence: Again he was the only one who caught the apple, and he did not linger an instant, but galloped off with it.

author: Grimms
sentence: The king grew angry, and said: "That is not allowed; he must appear before me and tell his name."

author: Grimms
sentence: He gave the order that if the knight who caught the apple, should go away again they should pursue him, and if he would not come back willingly, they were to cut him down and stab him.

author: Grimms
sentence: On the third day, he received from Iron Hans a suit of black armour and a black horse, and again he caught the apple.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when he was riding off with it, the king"s attendants pursued him, and one of them got so near him that he wounded the youth"s leg with the point of his sword.

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth nevertheless escaped from them, but his horse leapt so violently that the helmet fell from the youth"s head, and they could see that he had golden hair.

author: Grimms
sentence: They rode back and announced this to the king.

author: Grimms
sentence: The following day the king"s daughter asked the gardener about his boy.

author: Grimms
sentence: He is at work in the garden; the queer creature has been at the festival too, and only came home yesterday evening; he has likewise shown my children three golden apples which he has won.

author: Grimms
sentence: The king had him summoned into his presence, and he came and again had his little cap on his head.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the king"s daughter went up to him and took it off, and then his golden hair fell down over his shoulders, and he was so handsome that all were amazed.

author: Grimms
sentence: Are you the knight who came every day to the festival, always in different colours, and who caught the three golden apples? asked the king.

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, answered he, "and here the apples are," and he took them out of his pocket, and returned them to the king.

author: Grimms
sentence:
If you desire further proof, you may see the wound which your people gave me when they followed me.

author: Grimms
sentence: If you can perform such deeds as that, you are no gardeners boy; tell me, who is your father?"

author: Grimms
sentence: My father is a mighty king, and gold have I in plenty as great as I require.

author: Grimms
sentence: I well see, said the king, "that I owe my thanks to you; can I do anything to please you?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, answered he, "that indeed you can.

author: Grimms
sentence: Give me your daughter to wife."

author: Grimms
sentence: The maiden laughed, and said: "He does not stand much on ceremony, but I have already seen by his golden hair that he was no gardener"s boy," and then she went and kissed him.

author: Grimms
sentence: His father and mother came to the wedding, and were in great delight, for they had given up all hope of ever seeing their dear son again.

author: Grimms
sentence: And as they were sitting at the marriage-feast, the music suddenly stopped, the doors opened, and a stately king came in with a great retinue.

author: Grimms
sentence: He went up to the youth, embraced him and said: "I am Iron Hans, and was by enchantment a wild man, but you have set me free; all the treasures which I possess, shall be your property."

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once an old castle, that stood in the middle of a deep gloomy wood, and in the castle lived an old fairy.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now this fairy could take any shape she pleased.

author: Grimms
sentence: All the day long she flew about in the form of an owl, or crept about the country like a cat; but at night she always became an old woman again.

author: Grimms
sentence: When any young man came within a hundred paces of her castle, he became quite fixed, and could not move a step till she came and set him free; which she would not do till he had given her his word never to come there again: but when any pretty maiden came within that space she was changed into a bird, and the fairy put her into a cage, and hung her up in a chamber in the castle.

author: Grimms
sentence: There were seven hundred of these cages hanging in the castle, and all with beautiful birds in them.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now there was once a maiden whose name was Jorinda.

author: Grimms
sentence: She was prettier than all the pretty girls that ever were seen before, and a shepherd lad, whose name was Jorindel, was very fond of her, and they were soon to be married.

author: Grimms
sentence: One day they went to walk in the wood, that they might be alone; and Jorindel said, "We must take care that we don"t go too near to the fairy"s castle."

author: Grimms
sentence: It was a beautiful evening; the last rays of the setting sun shone bright through the long stems of the trees upon the green underwood beneath, and the turtle-doves sang from the tall birches.

author: Grimms
sentence: Jorinda sat down to gaze upon the sun; Jorindel sat by her side; and both felt sad, they knew not why; but it seemed as if they were to be parted from one another for ever.

author: Grimms
sentence: They had wandered a long way; and when they looked to see which way they should go home, they found themselves at a loss to know what path to take.

author: Grimms
sentence: The sun was setting fast, and already half of its circle had sunk behind the hill: Jorindel on a sudden looked behind him, and saw through the bushes that they had, without knowing it, sat down close under the old walls of the castle.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he shrank for fear, turned pale, and trembled.

author: Grimms
sentence: Jorinda was just singing,

author: Grimms

The ring-dove sang from the willow spray, Well-a-day!

author: Grimms
sentence: when her song stopped suddenly.

author: Grimms
sentence: Jorindel turned to see the reason, and beheld his Jorinda changed into a nightingale, so that her song ended with a mournful /jug, jug/.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: And now the sun went quite down; the gloomy night came; the owl flew into a bush; and a moment after the old fairy came forth pale and meagre, with staring eyes, and a nose and chin that almost met one another.

author: Grimms
sentence: She mumbled something to herself, seized the nightingale, and went away with it in her hand.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: On a sudden Jorindel found himself free.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he fell on his knees before the fairy, and prayed her to give him back his dear Jorinda: but she laughed at him, and said he should never see her again; then she went her way.

author: Grimms
sentence: He prayed, he wept, he sorrowed, but all in vain.

author: Grimms
sentence: Alas! he said, "what will become of me?"

author: Grimms
sentence: He could not go back to his own home, so he went to a strange village, and employed himself in keeping sheep.

author: Grimms
sentence: Many a time did he walk round and round as near to the hated castle as he dared go, but all in vain; he heard or saw nothing of Jorinda.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last he dreamt one night that he found a beautiful purple flower, and that in the middle of it lay a costly pearl; and he dreamt that he plucked the flower, and went with it in his hand into the castle, and that everything he touched with it was disenchanted, and that there he found his Jorinda again.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the morning when he awoke, he began to search over hill and dale for this pretty flower; and eight long days he sought for it in vain: but on the ninth day, early in the morning, he found the beautiful purple flower; and in the middle of it was a large dewdrop, as big as a costly pearl.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he plucked the flower, and set out and travelled day and night, till he came again to the castle.

author: Grimms
sentence: He walked nearer than a hundred paces to it, and yet he did not become fixed as before, but found that he could go quite close up to the door.

author: Grimms
sentence: Jorindel was very glad indeed to see this.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he touched the door with the flower, and it sprang open; so that he went in through the court, and listened when he heard so many birds singing.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last he came to the chamber where the fairy sat, with the seven hundred birds singing in the seven hundred cages.

author: Grimms
sentence: When she saw Jorindel she was very angry, and screamed with rage; but she could not come within two yards of him, for the flower he held in his hand was his safeguard.

author: Grimms
sentence: He looked around at the birds, but alas! there were many, many nightingales, and how then should he find out which was his Jorinda?

author: Grimms
sentence: While he was thinking what to do, he saw the fairy had taken down one of the cages, and was making the best of her way off through the door.

author: Grimms
sentence: He ran or flew after her, touched the cage with the flower, and Jorinda stood before him, and threw her arms round his neck looking as beautiful as ever, as beautiful as when they walked together in the wood.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he touched all the other birds with the flower, so that they all took their old forms again; and he took Jorinda home, where they were married, and lived happily together many years: and so did a good many other lads, whose maidens had been forced to sing in the old fairy"s cages by themselves, much longer than they liked.

author: Grimms
sentence: A great king of a land far away in the East had a daughter who was very beautiful, but so proud, and haughty, and conceited, that none of the princes who came to ask her in marriage was good enough for her, and she only made sport of them.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once upon a time the king held a great feast, and asked thither all her suitors; and they all sat in a row, ranged according to their rank --kings, and princes, and dukes, and earls, and counts, and barons, and knights.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the princess came in, and as she passed by them she had something spiteful to say to every one.

author: Grimms
sentence: The first was too fat: "He"s as round as a tub," said she.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next was too tall: "What a maypole!" said she.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next was too short: "What a dumpling!" said she.

author: Grimms
sentence: The fourth was too pale, and she called him "Wallface."

author: Grimms
sentence: The fifth was too red, so she called him "Coxcomb."

author: Grimms
sentence: The sixth was not straight enough; so she said he was like a green stick, that had been laid to dry over a baker"s oven.

author: Grimms
sentence: And thus she had some joke to crack upon every one: but she laughed more than all at a good king who was there.

author: Grimms
sentence: Look at him, said she; "his beard is like an old mop; he shall be called Grisly-beard."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the king got the nickname of Grisly-beard.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the old king was very angry when he saw how his daughter behaved, and how she ill-treated all his guests; and he vowed that, willing or unwilling, she should marry the first man, be he prince or beggar, that came to the door.

author: Grimms
sentence: Two days after there came by a travelling fiddler, who began to play under the window and beg alms; and when the king heard him, he said, "Let him come in."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they brought in a dirty-looking fellow; and when he had sung before the king and the princess, he begged a boon.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the king said, "You have sung so well, that I will give you my daughter for your wife."

author: Grimms
sentence: The princess begged and prayed; but the king said, "I have sworn to give you to the first comer, and I will keep my word."

author: Grimms
sentence: So words and tears were of no avail; the parson was sent for, and she was married to the fiddler.

author: Grimms
sentence: When this was over the king said, "Now get ready to go--you must not stay here--you must travel on with your husband."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the fiddler went his way, and took her with him, and they soon came to a great wood.

author: Grimms
sentence: Pray, said she, "whose is this wood?"

author: Grimms
sentence: It belongs to King Grisly-beard, answered he; "hadst thou taken him, all had been thine."

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah! unlucky wretch that I am! sighed she; "would that I had married King Grisly-beard!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Next they came to some fine meadows.

author: Grimms
sentence: Whose are these beautiful green meadows? said she.

author: Grimms
sentence: They belong to King Grisly-beard, hadst thou taken him, they had all been thine.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah! unlucky wretch that I am! said she; "would that I had married King Grisly-beard!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they came to a great city.

author: Grimms
sentence: Whose is this noble city? said she.

author: Grimms
sentence: It belongs to King Grisly-beard; hadst thou taken him, it had all been thine.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah! wretch that I am! sighed she; "why did I not marry King Grisly-beard?"

author: Grimms
sentence: That is no business of mine, said the fiddler: "why should you wish for another husband?

author: Grimms
sentence: Am not I good enough for you?"

author: Grimms
sentence: At last they came to a small cottage.

author: Grimms
sentence: What a paltry place! said she; "to whom does that little dirty hole belong?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the fiddler said, "That is your and my house, where we are to live."

author: Grimms
sentence: Where are your servants? cried she.

author: Grimms
sentence: What do we want with servants? said he; "you must do for yourself whatever is to be done.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now make the fire, and put on water and cook my supper, for I am very tired."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the princess knew nothing of making fires and cooking, and the fiddler was forced to help her.

author: Grimms
sentence: When they had eaten a very scanty meal they went to bed; but the fiddler called her up very early in the morning to clean the house.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thus they lived for two days: and when they had eaten up all there was in the cottage, the man said, "Wife, we can"t go on thus, spending money and earning nothing.

author: Grimms
sentence: You must learn to weave baskets."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went out and cut willows, and brought them home, and she began to weave; but it made her fingers very sore.

author: Grimms
sentence: I see this work wont do," said he: "try and spin; perhaps you will do that better."

author: Grimms
sentence: So she sat down and tried to spin; but the threads cut her tender fingers till the blood ran.

author: Grimms
sentence: See now, said the fiddler, "you are good for nothing; you can do no work: what a bargain I have got!

author: Grimms
sentence: However, I"ll try and set up a trade in pots and pans, and you shall stand in the market and sell them."

author: Grimms
sentence: Alas! sighed she, "if any of my father"s court should pass by and see me standing in the market, how they will laugh at me!"

author: Grimms
sentence: But her husband did not care for that, and said she must work, if she did not wish to die of hunger.

author: Grimms
sentence: At first the trade went well; for many people, seeing such a beautiful woman, went to buy her wares, and paid their money without thinking of taking away the goods.

author: Grimms
sentence: They lived on this as long as it lasted; and then her husband bought a fresh lot of ware, and she sat herself down with it in the corner of the market; but a drunken soldier soon came by, and rode his horse against her stall, and broke all her goods into a thousand pieces.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she began to cry, and knew not what to do.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah! what will become of me? said she; "what will my husband say?"

author: Grimms
sentence: So she ran home and told him all.

author: Grimms
sentence: Who would have thought you would have been so silly, said he, "as to put an earthenware stall in the corner of the market, where everybody passes? but let us have no more crying; I see you are not fit for this sort of work, so I have been to the king"s palace, and asked if they did not want a kitchen-maid; and they say they will take you, and there you will have plenty to eat."

author: Grimms
sentence: Thus the princess became a kitchen-maid, and helped the cook to do all the dirtiest work; but she was allowed to carry home some of the meat that was left, and on this they lived.

author: Grimms
sentence: She had not been there long before she heard that the king"s eldest son was passing by, going to be married; and she went to one of the windows and looked out.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: And the servants gave her some of the rich meats, which she put into her basket to take home.

author: Grimms
sentence: All on a sudden, as she was going out, in came the king"s son in golden clothes; and when he saw a beautiful woman at the door, he took her by the hand, and said she should be his partner in the dance; but she trembled for fear, for she saw that it was King Grisly-beard, who was making sport of her.

author: Grimms
sentence: However, he kept fast hold, and led her in; and the cover of the basket came off, so that the meats in it fell about.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: She sprang to the door to run away; but on the steps King Grisly-beard overtook her, and brought her back and said, "Fear me not!

sentence: I am the fiddler who has lived with you in the hut.

author: Grimms
sentence: I brought you there because I really loved you.

author: Grimms
