author: Grimms
sentence: I have done all this only to cure you of your silly pride, and to show you the folly of your ill-treatment of me.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now all is over: you have learnt wisdom, and it is time to hold our marriage feast."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the chamberlains came and brought her the most beautiful robes; and her father and his whole court were there already, and welcomed her home on her marriage.

author: Grimms
sentence: Joy was in every face and every heart.

author: Grimms
sentence: The feast was grand; they danced and sang; all were merry; and I only wish that you and I had been of the party.

author: Grimms
sentence: A merchant, who had three daughters, was once setting out upon a journey; but before he went he asked each daughter what gift he should bring back for her.

author: Grimms
sentence: The eldest wished for pearls; the second for jewels; but the third, who was called Lily, said, "Dear father, bring me a rose."

author: Grimms
sentence: Now it was no easy task to find a rose, for it was the middle of winter; yet as she was his prettiest daughter, and was very fond of flowers, her father said he would try what he could do.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he kissed all three, and bid them goodbye.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when the time came for him to go home, he had bought pearls and jewels for the two eldest, but he had sought everywhere in vain for the rose; and when he went into any garden and asked for such a thing, the people laughed at him, and asked him whether he thought roses grew in snow.

author: Grimms
sentence: This grieved him very much, for Lily was his dearest child; and as he was journeying home, thinking what he should bring her, he came to a fine castle; and around the castle was a garden, in one half of which it seemed to be summer-time and in the other half winter.

author: Grimms
sentence: On one side the finest flowers were in full bloom, and on the other everything looked dreary and buried in the snow.

author: Grimms
sentence: A lucky hit! said he, as he called to his servant, and told him to go to a beautiful bed of roses that was there, and bring him away one of the finest flowers.

author: Grimms
sentence: This done, they were riding away well pleased, when up sprang a fierce lion, and roared out, "Whoever has stolen my roses shall be eaten up alive!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the man said, "I knew not that the garden belonged to you; can nothing save my life?"

author: Grimms
sentence: No! said the lion, "nothing, unless you undertake to give me whatever meets you on your return home; if you agree to this, I will give you your life, and the rose too for your daughter."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the man was unwilling to do so and said, "It may be my youngest daughter, who loves me most, and always runs to meet me when I go home."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the servant was greatly frightened, and said, "It may perhaps be only a cat or a dog."

author: Grimms
sentence: And at last the man yielded with a heavy heart, and took the rose; and said he would give the lion whatever should meet him first on his return.

author: Grimms
sentence: And as he came near home, it was Lily, his youngest and dearest daughter, that met him; she came running, and kissed him, and welcomed him home; and when she saw that he had brought her the rose, she was still more glad.

author: Grimms
sentence: But her father began to be very sorrowful, and to weep, saying, "Alas, my dearest child!

author: Grimms
sentence: I have bought this flower at a high price, for I have said I would give you to a wild lion; and when he has you, he will tear you in pieces, and eat you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he told her all that had happened, and said she should not go, let what would happen.

author: Grimms
sentence: But she comforted him, and said, "Dear father, the word you have given must be kept; I will go to the lion, and soothe him: perhaps he will let me come safe home again."

author: Grimms
sentence: The next morning she asked the way she was to go, and took leave of her father, and went forth with a bold heart into the wood.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the lion was an enchanted prince.

author: Grimms
sentence: By day he and all his court were lions, but in the evening they took their right forms again.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when Lily came to the castle, he welcomed her so courteously that she agreed to marry him.

author: Grimms
sentence: The wedding-feast was held, and they lived happily together a long time.

author: Grimms
sentence: The prince was only to be seen as soon as evening came, and then he held his court; but every morning he left his bride, and went away by himself, she knew not whither, till the night came again.

author: Grimms
sentence: After some time he said to her, "Tomorrow there will be a great feast in your father"s house, for your eldest sister is to be married; and if you wish to go and visit her my lions shall lead you thither."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she rejoiced much at the thoughts of seeing her father once more, and set out with the lions; and everyone was overjoyed to see her, for they had thought her dead long since.

author: Grimms
sentence: But she told them how happy she was, and stayed till the feast was over, and then went back to the wood.

author: Grimms
sentence: Her second sister was soon after married, and when Lily was asked to go to the wedding, she said to the prince, "I will not go alone this time--you must go with me."

author: Grimms
sentence: But he would not, and said that it would be a very hazardous thing; for if the least ray of the torch-light should fall upon him his enchantment would become still worse, for he should be changed into a dove, and be forced to wander about the world for seven long years.

author: Grimms
sentence: However, she gave him no rest, and said she would take care no light should fall upon him.

author: Grimms
sentence: So at last they set out together, and took with them their little child; and she chose a large hall with thick walls for him to sit in while the wedding-torches were lighted; but, unluckily, no one saw that there was a crack in the door.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the wedding was held with great pomp, but as the train came from the church, and passed with the torches before the hall, a very small ray of light fell upon the prince.

author: Grimms
sentence: In a moment he disappeared, and when his wife came in and looked for him, she found only a white dove; and it said to her, "Seven years must I fly up and down over the face of the earth, but every now and then I will let fall a white feather, that will show you the way I am going; follow it, and at last you may overtake and set me free."

author: Grimms
sentence: This said, he flew out at the door, and poor Lily followed; and every now and then a white feather fell, and showed her the way she was to journey.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thus she went roving on through the wide world, and looked neither to the right hand nor to the left, nor took any rest, for seven years.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she began to be glad, and thought to herself that the time was fast coming when all her troubles should end; yet repose was still far off, for one day as she was travelling on she missed the white feather, and when she lifted up her eyes she could nowhere see the dove.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now, thought she to herself, "no aid of man can be of use to me."

author: Grimms
sentence: So she went to the sun and said, "Thou shinest everywhere, on the hill"s top and the valley"s depth--hast thou anywhere seen my white dove?"

author: Grimms
sentence: No, said the sun, "I have not seen it; but I will give thee a casket--open it when thy hour of need comes."

author: Grimms
sentence: So she thanked the sun, and went on her way till eventide; and when the moon arose, she cried unto it, and said, "Thou shinest through the night, over field and grove--hast thou nowhere seen my white dove?"

author: Grimms
sentence: No, said the moon, "I cannot help thee but I will give thee an egg-- break it when need comes."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she thanked the moon, and went on till the night-wind blew; and she raised up her voice to it, and said, "Thou blowest through every tree and under every leaf--hast thou not seen my white dove?"

author: Grimms
sentence: No, said the night-wind, "but I will ask three other winds; perhaps they have seen it."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the east wind and the west wind came, and said they too had not seen it, but the south wind said, "I have seen the white dove--he has fled to the Red Sea, and is changed once more into a lion, for the seven years are passed away, and there he is fighting with a dragon; and the dragon is an enchanted princess, who seeks to separate him from you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the night-wind said, "I will give thee counsel.

author: Grimms
sentence: Go to the Red Sea; on the right shore stand many rods--count them, and when thou comest to the eleventh, break it off, and smite the dragon with it; and so the lion will have the victory, and both of them will appear to you in their own forms.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then look round and thou wilt see a griffin, winged like bird, sitting by the Red Sea; jump on to his back with thy beloved one as quickly as possible, and he will carry you over the waters to your home.

author: Grimms
sentence: I will also give thee this nut," continued the night-wind.

author: Grimms
sentence: When you are half-way over, throw it down, and out of the waters will immediately spring up a high nut-tree on which the griffin will be able to rest, otherwise he would not have the strength to bear you the whole way; if, therefore, thou dost forget to throw down the nut, he will let you both fall into the sea.

author: Grimms
sentence: So our poor wanderer went forth, and found all as the night-wind had said; and she plucked the eleventh rod, and smote the dragon, and the lion forthwith became a prince, and the dragon a princess again.

author: Grimms
sentence: But no sooner was the princess released from the spell, than she seized the prince by the arm and sprang on to the griffin"s back, and went off carrying the prince away with her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thus the unhappy traveller was again forsaken and forlorn; but she took heart and said, "As far as the wind blows, and so long as the cock crows, I will journey on, till I find him once again."

author: Grimms
sentence: She went on for a long, long way, till at length she came to the castle whither the princess had carried the prince; and there was a feast got ready, and she heard that the wedding was about to be held.

author: Grimms
sentence: Heaven aid me now! said she; and she took the casket that the sun had given her, and found that within it lay a dress as dazzling as the sun itself.

author: Grimms
sentence: So she put it on, and went into the palace, and all the people gazed upon her; and the dress pleased the bride so much that she asked whether it was to be sold.

author: Grimms
sentence: Not for gold and silver. said she, "but for flesh and blood."

author: Grimms
sentence: The princess asked what she meant, and she said, "Let me speak with the bridegroom this night in his chamber, and I will give thee the dress."

author: Grimms
sentence: At last the princess agreed, but she told her chamberlain to give the prince a sleeping draught, that he might not hear or see her.

author: Grimms
sentence: When evening came, and the prince had fallen asleep, she was led into his chamber, and she sat herself down at his feet, and said: "I have followed thee seven years.

author: Grimms
sentence: I have been to the sun, the moon, and the night-wind, to seek thee, and at last I have helped thee to overcome the dragon.

author: Grimms
sentence: Wilt thou then forget me quite?"

author: Grimms
sentence: But the prince all the time slept so soundly, that her voice only passed over him, and seemed like the whistling of the wind among the fir-trees.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then poor Lily was led away, and forced to give up the golden dress; and when she saw that there was no help for her, she went out into a meadow, and sat herself down and wept.

author: Grimms
sentence: But as she sat she bethought herself of the egg that the moon had given her; and when she broke it, there ran out a hen and twelve chickens of pure gold, that played about, and then nestled under the old one"s wings, so as to form the most beautiful sight in the world.

author: Grimms
sentence: And she rose up and drove them before her, till the bride saw them from her window, and was so pleased that she came forth and asked her if she would sell the brood.

author: Grimms
sentence: Not for gold or silver, but for flesh and blood: let me again this evening speak with the bridegroom in his chamber, and I will give thee the whole brood.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the princess thought to betray her as before, and agreed to what she asked: but when the prince went to his chamber he asked the chamberlain why the wind had whistled so in the night.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the chamberlain told him all--how he had given him a sleeping draught, and how a poor maiden had come and spoken to him in his chamber, and was to come again that night.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the prince took care to throw away the sleeping draught; and when Lily came and began again to tell him what woes had befallen her, and how faithful and true to him she had been, he knew his beloved wife"s voice, and sprang up, and said, "You have awakened me as from a dream, for the strange princess had thrown a spell around me, so that I had altogether forgotten you; but Heaven hath sent you to me in a lucky hour."

author: Grimms
sentence: And they stole away out of the palace by night unawares, and seated themselves on the griffin, who flew back with them over the Red Sea.

author: Grimms
sentence: When they were half-way across Lily let the nut fall into the water, and immediately a large nut-tree arose from the sea, whereon the griffin rested for a while, and then carried them safely home.

author: Grimms
sentence: There they found their child, now grown up to be comely and fair; and after all their troubles they lived happily together to the end of their days.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once upon a time there was a dear little girl who was loved by everyone who looked at her, but most of all by her grandmother, and there was nothing that she would not have given to the child.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once she gave her a little cap of red velvet, which suited her so well that she would never wear anything else; so she was always called "Little RedCap."

author: Grimms
sentence: One day her mother said to her: "Come, Little Red-Cap, here is a piece of cake and a bottle of wine; take them to your grandmother, she is ill and weak, and they will do her good.

author: Grimms
sentence: Set out before it gets hot, and when you are going, walk nicely and quietly and do not run off the path, or you may fall and break the bottle, and then your grandmother will get nothing; and when you go into her room, don"t forget to say, "Good morning", and don"t peep into every corner before you do it."

author: Grimms
sentence: I will take great care, said Little Red-Cap to her mother, and gave her hand on it.

author: Grimms
sentence: The grandmother lived out in the wood, half a league from the village, and just as Little Red-Cap entered the wood, a wolf met her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Red-Cap did not know what a wicked creature he was, and was not at all afraid of him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Good day, Little Red-Cap, said he.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thank you kindly, wolf.

author: Grimms
sentence: Whither away so early, Little Red-Cap?

author: Grimms
sentence: To my grandmothers."

author: Grimms
sentence: What have you got in your apron?

author: Grimms
sentence: Cake and wine; yesterday was baking-day, so poor sick grandmother is to have something good, to make her stronger.

author: Grimms
sentence: Where does your grandmother live, Little Red-Cap?

author: Grimms
sentence: A good quarter of a league farther on in the wood; her house stands under the three large oak-trees, the nut-trees are just below; you surely must know it, replied Little Red-Cap.

author: Grimms
sentence: The wolf thought to himself: "What a tender young creature! what a nice plump mouthful--she will be better to eat than the old woman.

author: Grimms
sentence: I must act craftily, so as to catch both."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he walked for a short time by the side of Little Red-Cap, and then he said: "See, Little Red-Cap, how pretty the flowers are about here--why do you not look round?

author: Grimms
sentence: I believe, too, that you do not hear how sweetly the little birds are singing; you walk gravely along as if you were going to school, while everything else out here in the wood is merry."

author: Grimms
sentence: Little Red-Cap raised her eyes, and when she saw the sunbeams dancing here and there through the trees, and pretty flowers growing everywhere, she thought: "Suppose I take grandmother a fresh nosegay; that would please her too.

author: Grimms
sentence: It is so early in the day that I shall still get there in good time"; and so she ran from the path into the wood to look for flowers.

author: Grimms
sentence: And whenever she had picked one, she fancied that she saw a still prettier one farther on, and ran after it, and so got deeper and deeper into the wood.

author: Grimms
sentence: Meanwhile the wolf ran straight to the grandmother"s house and knocked at the door.

author: Grimms
sentence: Who is there?

author: Grimms
sentence: Little Red-Cap, replied the wolf.

author: Grimms
sentence: She is bringing cake and wine; open the door.

author: Grimms
sentence: Lift the latch, called out the grandmother, "I am too weak, and cannot get up."

author: Grimms
sentence: The wolf lifted the latch, the door sprang open, and without saying a word he went straight to the grandmother"s bed, and devoured her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he put on her clothes, dressed himself in her cap laid himself in bed and drew the curtains.

author: Grimms
sentence: Little Red-Cap, however, had been running about picking flowers, and when she had gathered so many that she could carry no more, she remembered her grandmother, and set out on the way to her.

author: Grimms
sentence: She was surprised to find the cottage-door standing open, and when she went into the room, she had such a strange feeling that she said to herself: "Oh dear! how uneasy I feel today, and at other times I like being with grandmother so much."

author: Grimms
sentence: She called out: "Good morning," but received no answer; so she went to the bed and drew back the curtains.

author: Grimms
sentence: There lay her grandmother with her cap pulled far over her face, and looking very strange.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh! grandmother, she said, "what big ears you have!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The better to hear you with, my child, was the reply.

author: Grimms
sentence: But, grandmother, what big eyes you have! she said.

author: Grimms
sentence: The better to see you with, my dear.

author: Grimms
sentence: But, grandmother, what large hands you have!

author: Grimms
sentence: The better to hug you with.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh! but, grandmother, what a terrible big mouth you have!

author: Grimms
sentence: The better to eat you with!

author: Grimms
sentence: And scarcely had the wolf said this, than with one bound he was out of bed and swallowed up Red-Cap.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the wolf had appeased his appetite, he lay down again in the bed, fell asleep and began to snore very loud.

author: Grimms
sentence: The huntsman was just passing the house, and thought to himself: "How the old woman is snoring!

author: Grimms
sentence: I must just see if she wants anything."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he went into the room, and when he came to the bed, he saw that the wolf was lying in it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Do I find you here, you old sinner! said he.

author: Grimms
sentence: I have long sought you!

author: Grimms
sentence: Then just as he was going to fire at him, it occurred to him that the wolf might have devoured the grandmother, and that she might still be saved, so he did not fire, but took a pair of scissors, and began to cut open the stomach of the sleeping wolf.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had made two snips, he saw the little Red-Cap shining, and then he made two snips more, and the little girl sprang out, crying: "Ah, how frightened I have been!

author: Grimms
sentence: How dark it was inside the wolf"; and after that the aged grandmother came out alive also, but scarcely able to breathe.

author: Grimms
sentence: Red-Cap, however, quickly fetched great stones with which they filled the wolf"s belly, and when he awoke, he wanted to run away, but the stones were so heavy that he collapsed at once, and fell dead.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then all three were delighted.

author: Grimms
sentence: The huntsman drew off the wolf"s skin and went home with it; the grandmother ate the cake and drank the wine which Red-Cap had brought, and revived, but Red-Cap thought to herself: "As long as I live, I will never by myself leave the path, to run into the wood, when my mother has forbidden me to do so."

author: Grimms
sentence: It also related that once when Red-Cap was again taking cakes to the old grandmother, another wolf spoke to her, and tried to entice her from the path.

author: Grimms
sentence: Red-Cap, however, was on her guard, and went straight forward on her way, and told her grandmother that she had met the wolf, and that he had said "good morning" to her, but with such a wicked look in his eyes, that if they had not been on the public road she was certain he would have eaten her up.

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, said the grandmother, "we will shut the door, that he may not come in."

author: Grimms
sentence: Soon afterwards the wolf knocked, and cried: "Open the door, grandmother, I am Little Red-Cap, and am bringing you some cakes."

author: Grimms
sentence: But they did not speak, or open the door, so the grey-beard stole twice or thrice round the house, and at last jumped on the roof, intending to wait until Red-Cap went home in the evening, and then to steal after her and devour her in the darkness.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the grandmother saw what was in his thoughts.

author: Grimms
sentence: In front of the house was a great stone trough, so she said to the child: "Take the pail, Red-Cap; I made some sausages yesterday, so carry the water in which I boiled them to the trough."

author: Grimms
sentence: Red-Cap carried until the great trough was quite full.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the smell of the sausages reached the wolf, and he sniffed and peeped down, and at last stretched out his neck so far that he could no longer keep his footing and began to slip, and slipped down from the roof straight into the great trough, and was drowned.

author: Grimms
sentence: But Red-Cap went joyously home, and no one ever did anything to harm her again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once upon a time there was a widow who had two daughters; one of them was beautiful and industrious, the other ugly and lazy.

author: Grimms
sentence: The mother, however, loved the ugly and lazy one best, because she was her own daughter, and so the other, who was only her stepdaughter, was made to do all the work of the house, and was quite the Cinderella of the family.

author: Grimms
sentence: Her stepmother sent her out every day to sit by the well in the high road, there to spin until she made her fingers bleed.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now it chanced one day that some blood fell on to the spindle, and as the girl stopped over the well to wash it off, the spindle suddenly sprang out of her hand and fell into the well.

author: Grimms
sentence: She ran home crying to tell of her misfortune, but her stepmother spoke harshly to her, and after giving her a violent scolding, said unkindly, "As you have let the spindle fall into the well you may go yourself and fetch it out."

author: Grimms
sentence: The girl went back to the well not knowing what to do, and at last in her distress she jumped into the water after the spindle.

author: Grimms
sentence: She remembered nothing more until she awoke and found herself in a beautiful meadow, full of sunshine, and with countless flowers blooming in every direction.

author: Grimms
sentence: She walked over the meadow, and presently she came upon a baker"s oven full of bread, and the loaves cried out to her, "Take us out, take us out, or alas! we shall be burnt to a cinder; we were baked through long ago."

author: Grimms
sentence: So she took the bread-shovel and drew them all out.

author: Grimms
sentence: She went on a little farther, till she came to a free full of apples.

author: Grimms
sentence: Shake me, shake me, I pray, cried the tree; "my apples, one and all, are ripe."

author: Grimms
sentence: So she shook the tree, and the apples came falling down upon her like rain; but she continued shaking until there was not a single apple left upon it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she carefully gathered the apples together in a heap and walked on again.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next thing she came to was a little house, and there she saw an old woman looking out, with such large teeth, that she was terrified, and turned to run away.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the old woman called after her, "What are you afraid of, dear child?

author: Grimms
sentence: Stay with me; if you will do the work of my house properly for me, I will make you very happy.

author: Grimms
sentence: You must be very careful, however, to make my bed in the right way, for I wish you always to shake it thoroughly, so that the feathers fly about; then they say, down there in the world, that it is snowing; for I am Mother Holle."

author: Grimms
sentence: The old woman spoke so kindly, that the girl summoned up courage and agreed to enter into her service.

author: Grimms
sentence: She took care to do everything according to the old woman"s bidding and every time she made the bed she shook it with all her might, so that the feathers flew about like so many snowflakes.

author: Grimms
sentence: The old woman was as good as her word: she never spoke angrily to her, and gave her roast and boiled meats every day.

author: Grimms
sentence: So she stayed on with Mother Holle for some time, and then she began to grow unhappy.

author: Grimms
sentence: She could not at first tell why she felt sad, but she became conscious at last of great longing to go home; then she knew she was homesick, although she was a thousand times better off with Mother Holle than with her mother and sister.

author: Grimms
sentence: After waiting awhile, she went to Mother Holle and said, "I am so homesick, that I cannot stay with you any longer, for although I am so happy here, I must return to my own people."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Mother Holle said, "I am pleased that you should want to go back to your own people, and as you have served me so well and faithfully, I will take you home myself."

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon she led the girl by the hand up to a broad gateway.

author: Grimms
sentence: The gate was opened, and as the girl passed through, a shower of gold fell upon her, and the gold clung to her, so that she was covered with it from head to foot.

author: Grimms
sentence: That is a reward for your industry, said Mother Holle, and as she spoke she handed her the spindle which she had dropped into the well.

author: Grimms
sentence: The gate was then closed, and the girl found herself back in the old world close to her mother"s house.

author: Grimms
sentence: As she entered the courtyard, the cock who was perched on the well, called out:

author: Grimms
sentence:
Cock-a-doodle-doo!

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she went in to her mother and sister, and as she was so richly covered with gold, they gave her a warm welcome.

author: Grimms
sentence: She related to them all that had happened, and when the mother heard how she had come by her great riches, she thought she should like her ugly, lazy daughter to go and try her fortune.

author: Grimms
sentence: So she made the sister go and sit by the well and spin, and the girl pricked her finger and thrust her hand into a thorn-bush, so that she might drop some blood on to the spindle; then she threw it into the well, and jumped in herself.

author: Grimms
sentence: Like her sister she awoke in the beautiful meadow, and walked over it till she came to the oven.

author: Grimms
sentence: Take us out, take us out, or alas! we shall be burnt to a cinder; we were baked through long ago, cried the loaves as before.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: Presently she came to the apple-tree.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: At last she came to Mother Holle"s house, and as she had heard all about the large teeth from her sister, she was not afraid of them, and engaged herself without delay to the old woman.

author: Grimms
sentence: The first day she was very obedient and industrious, and exerted herself to please Mother Holle, for she thought of the gold she should get in return.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next day, however, she began to dawdle over her work, and the third day she was more idle still; then she began to lie in bed in the mornings and refused to get up.

author: Grimms
sentence: Worse still, she neglected to make the old woman"s bed properly, and forgot to shake it so that the feathers might fly about.

author: Grimms
sentence: So Mother Holle very soon got tired of her, and told her she might go.

author: Grimms
sentence: The lazy girl was delighted at this, and thought to herself, "The gold will soon be mine."

author: Grimms
sentence: Mother Holle led her, as she had led her sister, to the broad gateway; but as she was passing through, instead of the shower of gold, a great bucketful of pitch came pouring over her.

author: Grimms
sentence: That is in return for your services, said the old woman, and she shut the gate.

author: Grimms
sentence: So the lazy girl had to go home covered with pitch, and the cock on the well called out as she saw her:

Cock-a-doodle-doo!

author: Grimms
sentence: But, try what she would, she could not get the pitch off and it stuck to her as long as she lived.

author: Grimms
sentence: A shepherd had a faithful dog, called Sultan, who was grown very old, and had lost all his teeth.

author: Grimms
sentence: And one day when the shepherd and his wife were standing together before the house the shepherd said, "I will shoot old Sultan tomorrow morning, for he is of no use now."

author: Grimms
sentence: But his wife said, "Pray let the poor faithful creature live; he has served us well a great many years, and we ought to give him a livelihood for the rest of his days."

author: Grimms
sentence: But what can we do with him? said the shepherd, "he has not a tooth in his head, and the thieves don"t care for him at all; to be sure he has served us, but then he did it to earn his livelihood; tomorrow shall be his last day, depend upon it."

author: Grimms
sentence: Poor Sultan, who was lying close by them, heard all that the shepherd and his wife said to one another, and was very much frightened to think tomorrow would be his last day; so in the evening he went to his good friend the wolf, who lived in the wood, and told him all his sorrows, and how his master meant to kill him in the morning.

author: Grimms
sentence: Make yourself easy, said the wolf, "I will give you some good advice.

author: Grimms
sentence: Your master, you know, goes out every morning very early with his wife into the field; and they take their little child with them, and lay it down behind the hedge in the shade while they are at work.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now do you lie down close by the child, and pretend to be watching it, and I will come out of the wood and run away with it; you must run after me as fast as you can, and I will let it drop; then you may carry it back, and they will think you have saved their child, and will be so thankful to you that they will take care of you as long as you live."

author: Grimms
sentence: The dog liked this plan very well; and accordingly so it was managed.

author: Grimms
sentence: The wolf ran with the child a little way; the shepherd and his wife screamed out; but Sultan soon overtook him, and carried the poor little thing back to his master and mistress.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the shepherd patted him on the head, and said, "Old Sultan has saved our child from the wolf, and therefore he shall live and be well taken care of, and have plenty to eat.

author: Grimms
sentence: Wife, go home, and give him a good dinner, and let him have my old cushion to sleep on as long as he lives."

author: Grimms
sentence: So from this time forward Sultan had all that he could wish for.

author: Grimms
sentence: Soon afterwards the wolf came and wished him joy, and said, "Now, my good fellow, you must tell no tales, but turn your head the other way when I want to taste one of the old shepherd"s fine fat sheep."

author: Grimms
sentence: No, said the Sultan; "I will be true to my master."

author: Grimms
sentence: However, the wolf thought he was in joke, and came one night to get a dainty morsel.

author: Grimms
sentence: But Sultan had told his master what the wolf meant to do; so he laid wait for him behind the barn door, and when the wolf was busy looking out for a good fat sheep, he had a stout cudgel laid about his back, that combed his locks for him finely.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the wolf was very angry, and called Sultan "an old rogue," and swore he would have his revenge.

author: Grimms
sentence: So the next morning the wolf sent the boar to challenge Sultan to come into the wood to fight the matter.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now Sultan had nobody he could ask to be his second but the shepherd"s old three-legged cat; so he took her with him, and as the poor thing limped along with some trouble, she stuck up her tail straight in the air.

author: Grimms
sentence: The wolf and the wild boar were first on the ground; and when they espied their enemies coming, and saw the cat"s long tail standing straight in the air, they thought she was carrying a sword for Sultan to fight with; and every time she limped, they thought she was picking up a stone to throw at them; so they said they should not like this way of fighting, and the boar lay down behind a bush, and the wolf jumped up into a tree.

author: Grimms
sentence: Sultan and the cat soon came up, and looked about and wondered that no one was there.

author: Grimms
sentence: The boar, however, had not quite hidden himself, for his ears stuck out of the bush; and when he shook one of them a little, the cat, seeing something move, and thinking it was a mouse, sprang upon it, and bit and scratched it, so that the boar jumped up and grunted, and ran away, roaring out, "Look up in the tree, there sits the one who is to blame."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they looked up, and espied the wolf sitting amongst the branches; and they called him a cowardly rascal, and would not suffer him to come down till he was heartily ashamed of himself, and had promised to be good friends again with old Sultan.

author: Grimms
sentence: There were once a man and a woman who had long in vain wished for a child.

author: Grimms
sentence: At length the woman hoped that God was about to grant her desire.

author: Grimms
sentence: These people had a little window at the back of their house from which a splendid garden could be seen, which was full of the most beautiful flowers and herbs.

author: Grimms
sentence: It was, however, surrounded by a high wall, and no one dared to go into it because it belonged to an enchantress, who had great power and was dreaded by all the world.

author: Grimms
sentence: One day the woman was standing by this window and looking down into the garden, when she saw a bed which was planted with the most beautiful rampion (rapunzel), and it looked so fresh and green that she longed for it, she quite pined away, and began to look pale and miserable.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then her husband was alarmed, and asked: "What ails you, dear wife?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, she replied, "if I can"t eat some of the rampion, which is in the garden behind our house, I shall die."

author: Grimms
sentence: The man, who loved her, thought: "Sooner than let your wife die, bring her some of the rampion yourself, let it cost what it will."

author: Grimms
sentence: At twilight, he clambered down over the wall into the garden of the enchantress, hastily clutched a handful of rampion, and took it to his wife.

author: Grimms
sentence: She at once made herself a salad of it, and ate it greedily.

author: Grimms
sentence: It tasted so good to her--so very good, that the next day she longed for it three times as much as before.

author: Grimms
sentence: If he was to have any rest, her husband must once more descend into the garden.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the gloom of evening therefore, he let himself down again; but when he had clambered down the wall he was terribly afraid, for he saw the enchantress standing before him.

author: Grimms
sentence: How can you dare, said she with angry look, "descend into my garden and steal my rampion like a thief?

author: Grimms
sentence: You shall suffer for it!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, answered he, "let mercy take the place of justice, I only made up my mind to do it out of necessity.

author: Grimms
sentence: My wife saw your rampion from the window, and felt such a longing for it that she would have died if she had not got some to eat."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the enchantress allowed her anger to be softened, and said to him: "If the case be as you say, I will allow you to take away with you as much rampion as you will, only I make one condition, you must give me the child which your wife will bring into the world; it shall be well treated, and I will care for it like a mother."

author: Grimms
sentence: The man in his terror consented to everything, and when the woman was brought to bed, the enchantress appeared at once, gave the child the name of Rapunzel, and took it away with her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Rapunzel grew into the most beautiful child under the sun.

author: Grimms
sentence: When she was twelve years old, the enchantress shut her into a tower, which lay in a forest, and had neither stairs nor door, but quite at the top was a little window.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the enchantress wanted to go in, she placed herself beneath it and cried:

author: Grimms
sentence: Rapunzel, Rapunzel, Let down your hair to me.

author: Grimms
sentence: Rapunzel had magnificent long hair, fine as spun gold, and when she heard the voice of the enchantress she unfastened her braided tresses, wound them round one of the hooks of the window above, and then the hair fell twenty ells down, and the enchantress climbed up by it.

author: Grimms
sentence: After a year or two, it came to pass that the king"s son rode through the forest and passed by the tower.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he heard a song, which was so charming that he stood still and listened.

author: Grimms
sentence: This was Rapunzel, who in her solitude passed her time in letting her sweet voice resound.

author: Grimms
sentence: The king"s son wanted to climb up to her, and looked for the door of the tower, but none was to be found.

author: Grimms
sentence: He rode home, but the singing had so deeply touched his heart, that every day he went out into the forest and listened to it.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: At first Rapunzel was terribly frightened when a man, such as her eyes had never yet beheld, came to her; but the king"s son began to talk to her quite like a friend, and told her that his heart had been so stirred that it had let him have no rest, and he had been forced to see her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Rapunzel lost her fear, and when he asked her if she would take him for her husband, and she saw that he was young and handsome, she thought: "He will love me more than old Dame Gothel does"; and she said yes, and laid her hand in his.

sentence: Thus he roamed about in misery for some years, and at length came to the desert where Rapunzel, with the twins to which she had given birth, a boy and a girl, lived in wretchedness.

sentence: He heard a voice, and it seemed so familiar to him that he went towards it, and when he approached, Rapunzel knew him and fell on his neck and wept.

sentence: Two of her tears wetted his eyes and they grew clear again, and he could see with them as before.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: By the side of a wood, in a country a long way off, ran a fine stream of water; and upon the stream there stood a mill.

author: Grimms
sentence: The miller"s house was close by, and the miller, you must know, had a very beautiful daughter.

author: Grimms
sentence: She was, moreover, very shrewd and clever; and the miller was so proud of her, that he one day told the king of the land, who used to come and hunt in the wood, that his daughter could spin gold out of straw.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now this king was very fond of money; and when he heard the miller"s boast his greediness was raised, and he sent for the girl to be brought before him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he led her to a chamber in his palace where there was a great heap of straw, and gave her a spinning-wheel, and said, "All this must be spun into gold before morning, as you love your life."

author: Grimms
sentence: It was in vain that the poor maiden said that it was only a silly boast of her father, for that she could do no such thing as spin straw into gold: the chamber door was locked, and she was left alone.

author: Grimms
sentence: She sat down in one corner of the room, and began to bewail her hard fate; when on a sudden the door opened, and a droll-looking little man hobbled in, and said, "Good morrow to you, my good lass; what are you weeping for?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Alas! said she, "I must spin this straw into gold, and I know not how."

Round about, round about, Lo and behold!

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: Now the queen lay awake all night, thinking of all the odd names that she had ever heard; and she sent messengers all over the land to find out new ones.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next day the little man came, and she began with TIMOTHY, ICHABOD, BENJAMIN, JEREMIAH, and all the names she could remember; but to all and each of them he said, "Madam, that is not my name."

author: Grimms
sentence: The second day she began with all the comical names she could hear of, BANDY-LEGS, HUNCHBACK, CROOK-SHANKS, and so on; but the little gentleman still said to every one of them, "Madam, that is not my name."

author: Grimms
sentence: The third day one of the messengers came back, and said, "I have travelled two days without hearing of any other names; but yesterday, as I was climbing a high hill, among the trees of the forest where the fox and the hare bid each other good night, I saw a little hut; and before the hut burnt a fire; and round about the fire a funny little dwarf was dancing upon one leg, and singing:

author: Grimms
sentence: It was the middle of winter, when the broad flakes of snow were falling around, that the queen of a country many thousand miles off sat working at her window.

author: Grimms
sentence: The frame of the window was made of fine black ebony, and as she sat looking out upon the snow, she pricked her finger, and three drops of blood fell upon it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she gazed thoughtfully upon the red drops that sprinkled the white snow, and said, "Would that my little daughter may be as white as that snow, as red as that blood, and as black as this ebony windowframe!"

author: Grimms
sentence: And so the little girl really did grow up; her skin was as white as snow, her cheeks as rosy as the blood, and her hair as black as ebony; and she was called Snowdrop.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they said, "The old woman was the queen herself; take care another time, and let no one in when we are away."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the queen got home, she went straight to her glass, and spoke to it as before; but to her great grief it still said:

author: Grimms
sentence: Thou, queen, art the fairest in all this land: But over the hills, in the greenwood shade, Where the seven dwarfs their dwelling have made, There Snowdrop is hiding her head; and she Is lovelier far, O queen! than thee.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the blood ran cold in her heart with spite and malice, to see that Snowdrop still lived; and she dressed herself up again, but in quite another dress from the one she wore before, and took with her a poisoned comb.

author: Grimms
sentence: When she reached the dwarfs" cottage, she knocked at the door, and cried, "Fine wares to sell!"

author: Grimms
sentence: But Snowdrop said, "I dare not let anyone in."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the queen said, "Only look at my beautiful combs!" and gave her the poisoned one.

author: Grimms
sentence: And it looked so pretty, that she took it up and put it into her hair to try it; but the moment it touched her head, the poison was so powerful that she fell down senseless.

author: Grimms
sentence: There you may lie, said the queen, and went her way.

author: Grimms
sentence: But by good luck the dwarfs came in very early that evening; and when they saw Snowdrop lying on the ground, they thought what had happened, and soon found the poisoned comb.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when they took it away she got well, and told them all that had passed; and they warned her once more not to open the door to anyone.

author: Grimms
sentence: Meantime the queen went home to her glass, and shook with rage when she read the very same answer as before; and she said, "Snowdrop shall die, if it cost me my life."

author: Grimms
sentence: So she went by herself into her chamber, and got ready a poisoned apple: the outside looked very rosy and tempting, but whoever tasted it was sure to die.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she dressed herself up as a peasant"s wife, and travelled over the hills to the dwarfs" cottage, and knocked at the door; but Snowdrop put her head out of the window and said, "I dare not let anyone in, for the dwarfs have told me not."

author: Grimms
sentence: Do as you please, said the old woman, "but at any rate take this pretty apple; I will give it you."

author: Grimms
sentence: No, said Snowdrop, "I dare not take it."

author: Grimms
sentence: You silly girl! answered the other, "what are you afraid of?

author: Grimms
sentence: Do you think it is poisoned?

author: Grimms
sentence: Come! do you eat one part, and I will eat the other."

author: Grimms
sentence: Now the apple was so made up that one side was good, though the other side was poisoned.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Snowdrop was much tempted to taste, for the apple looked so very nice; and when she saw the old woman eat, she could wait no longer.

author: Grimms
sentence: But she had scarcely put the piece into her mouth, when she fell down dead upon the ground.

author: Grimms
sentence: This time nothing will save thee, said the queen; and she went home to her glass, and at last it said:

author: Grimms
sentence: Thou, queen, art the fairest of all the fair.

author: Grimms
sentence: And then her wicked heart was glad, and as happy as such a heart could be.

author: Grimms
sentence: When evening came, and the dwarfs had gone home, they found Snowdrop lying on the ground: no breath came from her lips, and they were afraid that she was quite dead.

author: Grimms
sentence: They lifted her up, and combed her hair, and washed her face with wine and water; but all was in vain, for the little girl seemed quite dead.

author: Grimms
sentence: So they laid her down upon a bier, and all seven watched and bewailed her three whole days; and then they thought they would bury her: but her cheeks were still rosy; and her face looked just as it did while she was alive; so they said, "We will never bury her in the cold ground."

author: Grimms
sentence: And they made a coffin of glass, so that they might still look at her, and wrote upon it in golden letters what her name was, and that she was a king"s daughter.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the coffin was set among the hills, and one of the dwarfs always sat by it and watched.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the birds of the air came too, and bemoaned Snowdrop; and first of all came an owl, and then a raven, and at last a dove, and sat by her side.

author: Grimms
sentence: And thus Snowdrop lay for a long, long time, and still only looked as though she was asleep; for she was even now as white as snow, and as red as blood, and as black as ebony.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last a prince came and called at the dwarfs" house; and he saw Snowdrop, and read what was written in golden letters.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he offered the dwarfs money, and prayed and besought them to let him take her away; but they said, "We will not part with her for all the gold in the world."

author: Grimms
sentence: At last, however, they had pity on him, and gave him the coffin; but the moment he lifted it up to carry it home with him, the piece of apple fell from between her lips, and Snowdrop awoke, and said, "Where am I?"

author: Grimms
sentence: And the prince said, "Thou art quite safe with me."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he told her all that had happened, and said, "I love you far better than all the world; so come with me to my father"s palace, and you shall be my wife."

author: Grimms
sentence: And Snowdrop consented, and went home with the prince; and everything was got ready with great pomp and splendour for their wedding.

author: Grimms
sentence: To the feast was asked, among the rest, Snowdrop"s old enemy the queen; and as she was dressing herself in fine rich clothes, she looked in the glass and said:

author: Grimms
sentence:
Tell me, glass, tell me true!
94:94	N:N	H:N	Of all the ladies in the land, Who is fairest, tell me, who?

author: Grimms
sentence: And the glass answered:

author: Grimms
sentence: Thou, lady, art loveliest here, I ween; But lovelier far is the new-made queen.

author: Grimms
sentence: When she heard this she started with rage; but her envy and curiosity were so great, that she could not help setting out to see the bride.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when she got there, and saw that it was no other than Snowdrop, who, as she thought, had been dead a long while, she choked with rage, and fell down and died: but Snowdrop and the prince lived and reigned happily over that land many, many years; and sometimes they went up into the mountains, and paid a visit to the little dwarfs, who had been so kind to Snowdrop in her time of need.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once upon a time a woman who was a real witch and had two daughters, one ugly and wicked, and this one she loved because she was her own daughter, and one beautiful and good, and this one she hated, because she was her stepdaughter.

author: Grimms
sentence: The stepdaughter once had a pretty apron, which the other fancied so much that she became envious, and told her mother that she must and would have that apron.

author: Grimms
sentence: Be quiet, my child, said the old woman, "and you shall have it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Your stepsister has long deserved death; tonight when she is asleep I will come and cut her head off.

author: Grimms
sentence: Only be careful that you are at the far side of the bed, and push her well to the front."

author: Grimms
sentence: It would have been all over with the poor girl if she had not just then been standing in a corner, and heard everything.

author: Grimms
sentence: All day long she dared not go out of doors, and when bedtime had come, the witch"s daughter got into bed first, so as to lie at the far side, but when she was asleep, the other pushed her gently to the front, and took for herself the place at the back, close by the wall.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the night, the old woman came creeping in, she held an axe in her right hand, and felt with her left to see if anyone were lying at the outside, and then she grasped the axe with both hands, and cut her own child"s head off.

author: Grimms
sentence: When she had gone away, the girl got up and went to her sweetheart, who was called Roland, and knocked at his door.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he came out, she said to him: "Listen, dearest Roland, we must fly in all haste; my stepmother wanted to kill me, but has struck her own child.

author: Grimms
sentence: When daylight comes, and she sees what she has done, we shall be lost."

author: Grimms
sentence: But, said Roland, "I counsel you first to take away her magic wand, or we cannot escape if she pursues us."

author: Grimms
sentence: The maiden fetched the magic wand, and she took the dead girl"s head and dropped three drops of blood on the ground, one in front of the bed, one in the kitchen, and one on the stairs.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she hurried away with her lover.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the old witch got up next morning, she called her daughter, and wanted to give her the apron, but she did not come.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the witch cried: "Where are you?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Here, on the stairs, I am sweeping, answered the first drop of blood.

author: Grimms
sentence: The old woman went out, but saw no one on the stairs, and cried again: "Where are you?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Here in the kitchen, I am warming myself, cried the second drop of blood.

author: Grimms
sentence: She went into the kitchen, but found no one.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she cried again: "Where are you?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, here in the bed, I am sleeping, cried the third drop of blood.

author: Grimms
sentence: She went into the room to the bed.

author: Grimms
sentence: What did she see there?

author: Grimms
sentence: Her own child, whose head she had cut off, bathed in her blood.

author: Grimms
sentence: The witch fell into a passion, sprang to the window, and as she could look forth quite far into the world, she perceived her stepdaughter hurrying away with her sweetheart Roland.

author: Grimms
sentence: That shall not help you, cried she, "even if you have got a long way off, you shall still not escape me."

author: Grimms
sentence: She put on her many-league boots, in which she covered an hour"s walk at every step, and it was not long before she overtook them.

author: Grimms
sentence: The girl, however, when she saw the old woman striding towards her, changed, with her magic wand, her sweetheart Roland into a lake, and herself into a duck swimming in the middle of it.

author: Grimms
sentence: The witch placed herself on the shore, threw breadcrumbs in, and went to endless trouble to entice the duck; but the duck did not let herself be enticed, and the old woman had to go home at night as she had come.

author: Grimms
sentence: At this the girl and her sweetheart Roland resumed their natural shapes again, and they walked on the whole night until daybreak.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the maiden changed herself into a beautiful flower which stood in the midst of a briar hedge, and her sweetheart Roland into a fiddler.

author: Grimms
sentence: It was not long before the witch came striding up towards them, and said to the musician: "Dear musician, may I pluck that beautiful flower for myself?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, yes, he replied, "I will play to you while you do it."

author: Grimms
sentence: As she was hastily creeping into the hedge and was just going to pluck the flower, knowing perfectly well who the flower was, he began to play, and whether she would or not, she was forced to dance, for it was a magical dance.

author: Grimms
sentence: The faster he played, the more violent springs was she forced to make, and the thorns tore her clothes from her body, and pricked her and wounded her till she bled, and as he did not stop, she had to dance till she lay dead on the ground.

author: Grimms
sentence: As they were now set free, Roland said: "Now I will go to my father and arrange for the wedding."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then in the meantime I will stay here and wait for you, said the girl, "and that no one may recognize me, I will change myself into a red stone landmark."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Roland went away, and the girl stood like a red landmark in the field and waited for her beloved.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when Roland got home, he fell into the snares of another, who so fascinated him that he forgot the maiden.

author: Grimms
sentence: The poor girl remained there a long time, but at length, as he did not return at all, she was sad, and changed herself into a flower, and thought: "Someone will surely come this way, and trample me down."

author: Grimms
sentence: It befell, however, that a shepherd kept his sheep in the field and saw the flower, and as it was so pretty, plucked it, took it with him, and laid it away in his chest.

author: Grimms
sentence: From that time forth, strange things happened in the shepherd"s house.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he arose in the morning, all the work was already done, the room was swept, the table and benches cleaned, the fire in the hearth was lighted, and the water was fetched, and at noon, when he came home, the table was laid, and a good dinner served.

author: Grimms
sentence: He could not conceive how this came to pass, for he never saw a human being in his house, and no one could have concealed himself in it.

author: Grimms
sentence: He was certainly pleased with this good attendance, but still at last he was so afraid that he went to a wise woman and asked for her advice.

author: Grimms
sentence: The wise woman said: "There is some enchantment behind it, listen very early some morning if anything is moving in the room, and if you see anything, no matter what it is, throw a white cloth over it, and then the magic will be stopped."

author: Grimms
sentence: The shepherd did as she bade him, and next morning just as day dawned, he saw the chest open, and the flower come out.

author: Grimms
sentence: Swiftly he sprang towards it, and threw a white cloth over it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Instantly the transformation came to an end, and a beautiful girl stood before him, who admitted to him that she had been the flower, and that up to this time she had attended to his house-keeping.

author: Grimms
sentence: She told him her story, and as she pleased him he asked her if she would marry him, but she answered: "No," for she wanted to remain faithful to her sweetheart Roland, although he had deserted her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Nevertheless, she promised not to go away, but to continue keeping house for the shepherd.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now the time drew near when Roland"s wedding was to be celebrated, and then, according to an old custom in the country, it was announced that all the girls were to be present at it, and sing in honour of the bridal pair.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the faithful maiden heard of this, she grew so sad that she thought her heart would break, and she would not go thither, but the other girls came and took her.

author: Grimms
sentence: When it came to her turn to sing, she stepped back, until at last she was the only one left, and then she could not refuse.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when she began her song, and it reached Roland"s ears, he sprang up and cried: "I know the voice, that is the true bride, I will have no other!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Everything he had forgotten, and which had vanished from his mind, had suddenly come home again to his heart.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the faithful maiden held her wedding with her sweetheart Roland, and grief came to an end and joy began.

author: Grimms
sentence: HOW THEY WENT TO THE MOUNTAINS TO EAT NUTS

author: Grimms
sentence: The nuts are quite ripe now, said Chanticleer to his wife Partlet, "suppose we go together to the mountains, and eat as many as we can, before the squirrel takes them all away."

author: Grimms
sentence: With all my heart, said Partlet, "let us go and make a holiday of it together."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they went to the mountains; and as it was a lovely day, they stayed there till the evening.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now, whether it was that they had eaten so many nuts that they could not walk, or whether they were lazy and would not, I do not know: however, they took it into their heads that it did not become them to go home on foot.

author: Grimms
sentence: So Chanticleer began to build a little carriage of nutshells: and when it was finished, Partlet jumped into it and sat down, and bid Chanticleer harness himself to it and draw her home.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thats a good joke!" said Chanticleer; "no, that will never do; I had rather by half walk home; I"ll sit on the box and be coachman, if you like, but I"ll not draw."

author: Grimms
sentence: While this was passing, a duck came quacking up and cried out, "You thieving vagabonds, what business have you in my grounds?

author: Grimms
sentence: I"ll give it you well for your insolence!" and upon that she fell upon Chanticleer most lustily.

author: Grimms
sentence: But Chanticleer was no coward, and returned the duck"s blows with his sharp spurs so fiercely that she soon began to cry out for mercy; which was only granted her upon condition that she would draw the carriage home for them.

author: Grimms
sentence: This she agreed to do; and Chanticleer got upon the box, and drove, crying, "Now, duck, get on as fast as you can."

author: Grimms
sentence: And away they went at a pretty good pace.

author: Grimms
sentence: After they had travelled along a little way, they met a needle and a pin walking together along the road: and the needle cried out, "Stop, stop!" and said it was so dark that they could hardly find their way, and such dirty walking they could not get on at all: he told them that he and his friend, the pin, had been at a public-house a few miles off, and had sat drinking till they had forgotten how late it was; he begged therefore that the travellers would be so kind as to give them a lift in their carriage.

author: Grimms
sentence: Chanticleer observing that they were but thin fellows, and not likely to take up much room, told them they might ride, but made them promise not to dirty the wheels of the carriage in getting in, nor to tread on Partlet"s toes.

author: Grimms
sentence: Late at night they arrived at an inn; and as it was bad travelling in the dark, and the duck seemed much tired, and waddled about a good deal from one side to the other, they made up their minds to fix their quarters there: but the landlord at first was unwilling, and said his house was full, thinking they might not be very respectable company: however, they spoke civilly to him, and gave him the egg which Partlet had laid by the way, and said they would give him the duck, who was in the habit of laying one every day: so at last he let them come in, and they bespoke a handsome supper, and spent the evening very jollily.

author: Grimms
sentence: Early in the morning, before it was quite light, and when nobody was stirring in the inn, Chanticleer awakened his wife, and, fetching the egg, they pecked a hole in it, ate it up, and threw the shells into the fireplace: they then went to the pin and needle, who were fast asleep, and seizing them by the heads, stuck one into the landlord"s easy chair and the other into his handkerchief; and, having done this, they crept away as softly as possible.

author: Grimms
sentence: However, the duck, who slept in the open air in the yard, heard them coming, and jumping into the brook which ran close by the inn, soon swam out of their reach.

author: Grimms
sentence: An hour or two afterwards the landlord got up, and took his handkerchief to wipe his face, but the pin ran into him and pricked him: then he walked into the kitchen to light his pipe at the fire, but when he stirred it up the eggshells flew into his eyes, and almost blinded him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Bless me! said he, "all the world seems to have a design against my head this morning": and so saying, he threw himself sulkily into his easy chair; but, oh dear! the needle ran into him; and this time the pain was not in his head.

author: Grimms
sentence: He now flew into a very great passion, and, suspecting the company who had come in the night before, he went to look after them, but they were all off; so he swore that he never again would take in such a troop of vagabonds, who ate a great deal, paid no reckoning, and gave him nothing for his trouble but their apish tricks.

author: Grimms
sentence: HOW CHANTICLEER AND PARTLET WENT TO VIST MR KORBES

author: Grimms
sentence: Another day, Chanticleer and Partlet wished to ride out together; so Chanticleer built a handsome carriage with four red wheels, and harnessed six mice to it; and then he and Partlet got into the carriage, and away they drove.

author: Grimms
sentence: Soon afterwards a cat met them, and said, "Where are you going?"

author: Grimms
sentence: And Chanticleer replied,

author: Grimms
sentence: All on our way A visit to pay To Mr Korbes, the fox, today.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the cat said, "Take me with you," Chanticleer said, "With all my heart: get up behind, and be sure you do not fall off."

author: Grimms
sentence:
Take care of this handsome coach of mine, Nor dirty my pretty red wheels so fine!
29:29	N:N	N:H	Now, mice, be ready, And, wheels, run steady!
30:30	N:N	N:H	For we are going a visit to pay To Mr Korbes, the fox, today.

author: Grimms
sentence: Soon after came up a millstone, an egg, a duck, and a pin; and Chanticleer gave them all leave to get into the carriage and go with them.

author: Grimms
sentence: When they arrived at Mr Korbes"s house, he was not at home; so the mice drew the carriage into the coach-house, Chanticleer and Partlet flew upon a beam, the cat sat down in the fireplace, the duck got into the washing cistern, the pin stuck himself into the bed pillow, the millstone laid himself over the house door, and the egg rolled himself up in the towel.

author: Grimms
sentence: When Mr Korbes came home, he went to the fireplace to make a fire; but the cat threw all the ashes in his eyes: so he ran to the kitchen to wash himself; but there the duck splashed all the water in his face; and when he tried to wipe himself, the egg broke to pieces in the towel all over his face and eyes.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he was very angry, and went without his supper to bed; but when he laid his head on the pillow, the pin ran into his cheek: at this he became quite furious, and, jumping up, would have run out of the house; but when he came to the door, the millstone fell down on his head, and killed him on the spot.

author: Grimms
sentence: HOW PARTLET DIED AND WAS BURIED, AND HOW CHANTICLEER DIED OF GRIEF

author: Grimms
sentence: Another day Chanticleer and Partlet agreed to go again to the mountains to eat nuts; and it was settled that all the nuts which they found should be shared equally between them.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now Partlet found a very large nut; but she said nothing about it to Chanticleer, and kept it all to herself: however, it was so big that she could not swallow it, and it stuck in her throat.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she was in a great fright, and cried out to Chanticleer, "Pray run as fast as you can, and fetch me some water, or I shall be choked."

author: Grimms
sentence: Chanticleer ran as fast as he could to the river, and said, "River, give me some water, for Partlet lies in the mountain, and will be choked by a great nut."

author: Grimms
sentence: The river said, "Run first to the bride, and ask her for a silken cord to draw up the water."

author: Grimms
sentence: Chanticleer ran to the bride, and said, "Bride, you must give me a silken cord, for then the river will give me water, and the water I will carry to Partlet, who lies on the mountain, and will be choked by a great nut."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the bride said, "Run first, and bring me my garland that is hanging on a willow in the garden."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Chanticleer ran to the garden, and took the garland from the bough where it hung, and brought it to the bride; and then the bride gave him the silken cord, and he took the silken cord to the river, and the river gave him water, and he carried the water to Partlet; but in the meantime she was choked by the great nut, and lay quite dead, and never moved any more.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Chanticleer was very sorry, and cried bitterly; and all the beasts came and wept with him over poor Partlet.

author: Grimms
sentence: And six mice built a little hearse to carry her to her grave; and when it was ready they harnessed themselves before it, and Chanticleer drove them.

author: Grimms
sentence: On the way they met the fox.

author: Grimms
sentence: Where are you going, Chanticleer? said he.

author: Grimms
sentence: To bury my Partlet, said the other.

author: Grimms
sentence: May I go with you? said the fox.

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes; but you must get up behind, or my horses will not be able to draw you.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the fox got up behind; and presently the wolf, the bear, the goat, and all the beasts of the wood, came and climbed upon the hearse.

author: Grimms
sentence: So on they went till they came to a rapid stream.

author: Grimms
sentence: How shall we get over? said Chanticleer.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said a straw, "I will lay myself across, and you may pass over upon me."

author: Grimms
sentence: But as the mice were going over, the straw slipped away and fell into the water, and the six mice all fell in and were drowned.

author: Grimms
sentence: What was to be done?

author: Grimms
sentence: Then a large log of wood came and said, "I am big enough; I will lay myself across the stream, and you shall pass over upon me."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he laid himself down; but they managed so clumsily, that the log of wood fell in and was carried away by the stream.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then a stone, who saw what had happened, came up and kindly offered to help poor Chanticleer by laying himself across the stream; and this time he got safely to the other side with the hearse, and managed to get Partlet out of it; but the fox and the other mourners, who were sitting behind, were too heavy, and fell back into the water and were all carried away by the stream and drowned.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thus Chanticleer was left alone with his dead Partlet; and having dug a grave for her, he laid her in it, and made a little hillock over her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he sat down by the grave, and wept and mourned, till at last he died too; and so all were dead.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once upon a time a soldier who for many years had served the king faithfully, but when the war came to an end could serve no longer because of the many wounds which he had received.

author: Grimms
sentence: The king said to him: "You may return to your home, I need you no longer, and you will not receive any more money, for he only receives wages who renders me service for them."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the soldier did not know how to earn a living, went away greatly troubled, and walked the whole day, until in the evening he entered a forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: When darkness came on, he saw a light, which he went up to, and came to a house wherein lived a witch.

author: Grimms
sentence: Do give me one nights lodging, and a little to eat and drink," said he to her, "or I shall starve."

author: Grimms
sentence: Oho! she answered, "who gives anything to a run-away soldier?

author: Grimms
sentence: Yet will I be compassionate, and take you in, if you will do what I wish."

author: Grimms
sentence: What do you wish? said the soldier.

author: Grimms
sentence: That you should dig all round my garden for me, tomorrow.

author: Grimms
sentence: The soldier consented, and next day laboured with all his strength, but could not finish it by the evening.

author: Grimms
sentence: I see well enough, said the witch, "that you can do no more today, but I will keep you yet another night, in payment for which you must tomorrow chop me a load of wood, and chop it small."

author: Grimms
sentence: The soldier spent the whole day in doing it, and in the evening the witch proposed that he should stay one night more.

author: Grimms
sentence:
Tomorrow, you shall only do me a very trifling piece of work.
13:13	N:N	N:N	Behind my house, there is an old dry well, into which my light has fallen, it burns blue, and never goes out, and you shall bring it up again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next day the old woman took him to the well, and let him down in a basket.

author: Grimms
sentence: He found the blue light, and made her a signal to draw him up again.

author: Grimms
sentence: She did draw him up, but when he came near the edge, she stretched down her hand and wanted to take the blue light away from him.

author: Grimms
sentence: No, said he, perceiving her evil intention, "I will not give you the light until I am standing with both feet upon the ground."

author: Grimms
sentence: The witch fell into a passion, let him fall again into the well, and went away.

author: Grimms
sentence: The poor soldier fell without injury on the moist ground, and the blue light went on burning, but of what use was that to him?

author: Grimms
sentence: He saw very well that he could not escape death.

author: Grimms
sentence: He sat for a while very sorrowfully, then suddenly he felt in his pocket and found his tobacco pipe, which was still half full.

author: Grimms
sentence: This shall be my last pleasure, thought he, pulled it out, lit it at the blue light and began to smoke.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: A shepherd"s dog had a master who took no care of him, but often let him suffer the greatest hunger.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last he could bear it no longer; so he took to his heels, and off he ran in a very sad and sorrowful mood.

author: Grimms
sentence: On the road he met a sparrow that said to him, "Why are you so sad, my friend?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Because, said the dog, "I am very very hungry, and have nothing to eat."

author: Grimms
sentence: If that be all, answered the sparrow, "come with me into the next town, and I will soon find you plenty of food."

author: Grimms
sentence: So on they went together into the town: and as they passed by a butcher"s shop, the sparrow said to the dog, "Stand there a little while till I peck you down a piece of meat."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the sparrow perched upon the shelf: and having first looked carefully about her to see if anyone was watching her, she pecked and scratched at a steak that lay upon the edge of the shelf, till at last down it fell.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the dog snapped it up, and scrambled away with it into a corner, where he soon ate it all up.

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, said the sparrow, "you shall have some more if you will; so come with me to the next shop, and I will peck you down another steak."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the dog had eaten this too, the sparrow said to him, "Well, my good friend, have you had enough now?"

author: Grimms
sentence: I have had plenty of meat, answered he, "but I should like to have a piece of bread to eat after it."

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: When that was eaten, the sparrow asked him whether he had had enough now.

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said he; "and now let us take a walk a little way out of the town."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they both went out upon the high road; but as the weather was warm, they had not gone far before the dog said, "I am very much tired--I should like to take a nap."

author: Grimms
sentence: Very well, answered the sparrow, "do so, and in the meantime I will perch upon that bush."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the dog stretched himself out on the road, and fell fast asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: Whilst he slept, there came by a carter with a cart drawn by three horses, and loaded with two casks of wine.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a shoemaker, who worked very hard and was very honest: but still he could not earn enough to live upon; and at last all he had in the world was gone, save just leather enough to make one pair of shoes.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he cut his leather out, all ready to make up the next day, meaning to rise early in the morning to his work.

author: Grimms
sentence: His conscience was clear and his heart light amidst all his troubles; so he went peaceably to bed, left all his cares to Heaven, and soon fell asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the morning after he had said his prayers, he sat himself down to his work; when, to his great wonder, there stood the shoes all ready made, upon the table.

author: Grimms
sentence: The good man knew not what to say or think at such an odd thing happening.

author: Grimms
sentence: He looked at the workmanship; there was not one false stitch in the whole job; all was so neat and true, that it was quite a masterpiece.

author: Grimms
sentence: The same day a customer came in, and the shoes suited him so well that he willingly paid a price higher than usual for them; and the poor shoemaker, with the money, bought leather enough to make two pairs more.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the evening he cut out the work, and went to bed early, that he might get up and begin betimes next day; but he was saved all the trouble, for when he got up in the morning the work was done ready to his hand.

author: Grimms
sentence: Soon in came buyers, who paid him handsomely for his goods, so that he bought leather enough for four pair more.

author: Grimms
sentence: He cut out the work again overnight and found it done in the morning, as before; and so it went on for some time: what was got ready in the evening was always done by daybreak, and the good man soon became thriving and well off again.

author: Grimms
sentence: One evening, about Christmas-time, as he and his wife were sitting over the fire chatting together, he said to her, "I should like to sit up and watch tonight, that we may see who it is that comes and does my work for me."

author: Grimms
sentence: The wife liked the thought; so they left a light burning, and hid themselves in a corner of the room, behind a curtain that was hung up there, and watched what would happen.

author: Grimms
sentence: As soon as it was midnight, there came in two little naked dwarfs; and they sat themselves upon the shoemaker"s bench, took up all the work that was cut out, and began to ply with their little fingers, stitching and rapping and tapping away at such a rate, that the shoemaker was all wonder, and could not take his eyes off them.

author: Grimms
