author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a fisherman who lived with his wife in a pigsty, close by the seaside.

author: Grimms
sentence: Dear children, said a poor man to his four sons, "I have nothing to give you; you must go out into the wide world and try your luck.

sentence: A farmer had a horse that had been an excellent faithful servant to him: but he was now grown too old to work; so the farmer would give him nothing more to eat, and said, "I want you no longer, so take yourself off out of my stable; I shall not take you back again until you are stronger than a lion."

author: Grimms
sentence: A certain king had a beautiful garden, and in the garden stood a tree which bore golden apples.

author: Grimms
sentence: These apples were always counted, and about the time when they began to grow ripe it was found that every night one of them was gone.

sentence: The king became very angry at this, and ordered the gardener to keep watch all night under the tree.

author: Grimms
sentence: The gardener set his eldest son to watch; but about twelve o"clock he fell asleep, and in the morning another of the apples was missing.

sentence: Then the second son was ordered to watch; and at midnight he too fell asleep, and in the morning another apple was gone.

sentence: Then the third son offered to keep watch; but the gardener at first would not let him, for fear some harm should come to him: however, at last he consented, and the young man laid himself under the tree to watch.

author: Grimms
sentence: As the clock struck twelve he heard a rustling noise in the air, and a bird came flying that was of pure gold; and as it was snapping at one of the apples with its beak, the gardener"s son jumped up and shot an arrow at it.

sentence: But the arrow did the bird no harm; only it dropped a golden feather from its tail, and then flew away.

sentence: The golden feather was brought to the king in the morning, and all the council was called together.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the gardener"s eldest son set out and thought to find the golden bird very easily; and when he had gone but a little way, he came to a wood, and by the side of the wood he saw a fox sitting; so he took his bow and made ready to shoot at it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the fox said, "Do not shoot me, for I will give you good counsel; I know what your business is, and that you want to find the golden bird.

author: Grimms
sentence: You will reach a village in the evening; and when you get there, you will see two inns opposite to each other, one of which is very pleasant and beautiful to look at: go not in there, but rest for the night in the other, though it may appear to you to be very poor and mean."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the son thought to himself, "What can such a beast as this know about the matter?"

author: Grimms
sentence: So he shot his arrow at the fox; but he missed it, and it set up its tail above its back and ran into the wood.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went his way, and in the evening came to the village where the two inns were; and in one of these were people singing, and dancing, and feasting; but the other looked very dirty, and poor.

author: Grimms
sentence: I should be very silly, said he, "if I went to that shabby house, and left this charming place"; so he went into the smart house, and ate and drank at his ease, and forgot the bird, and his country too.

author: Grimms
sentence: Time passed on; and as the eldest son did not come back, and no tidings were heard of him, the second son set out, and the same thing happened to him.

author: Grimms
sentence: He met the fox, who gave him the good advice: but when he came to the two inns, his eldest brother was standing at the window where the merrymaking was, and called to him to come in; and he could not withstand the temptation, but went in, and forgot the golden bird and his country in the same manner.

author: Grimms
sentence: Time passed on again, and the youngest son too wished to set out into the wide world to seek for the golden bird; but his father would not listen to it for a long while, for he was very fond of his son, and was afraid that some ill luck might happen to him also, and prevent his coming back.

author: Grimms
sentence: However, at last it was agreed he should go, for he would not rest at home; and as he came to the wood, he met the fox, and heard the same good counsel.

author: Grimms
sentence: But he was thankful to the fox, and did not attempt his life as his brothers had done; so the fox said, "Sit upon my tail, and you will travel faster."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he sat down, and the fox began to run, and away they went over stock and stone so quick that their hair whistled in the wind.

author: Grimms
sentence: When they came to the village, the son followed the fox"s counsel, and without looking about him went to the shabby inn and rested there all night at his ease.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the morning came the fox again and met him as he was beginning his journey, and said, "Go straight forward, till you come to a castle, before which lie a whole troop of soldiers fast asleep and snoring: take no notice of them, but go into the castle and pass on and on till you come to a room, where the golden bird sits in a wooden cage; close by it stands a beautiful golden cage; but do not try to take the bird out of the shabby cage and put it into the handsome one, otherwise you will repent it."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the fox stretched out his tail again, and the young man sat himself down, and away they went over stock and stone till their hair whistled in the wind.

author: Grimms
sentence: Before the castle gate all was as the fox had said: so the son went in and found the chamber where the golden bird hung in a wooden cage, and below stood the golden cage, and the three golden apples that had been lost were lying close by it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then thought he to himself, "It will be a very droll thing to bring away such a fine bird in this shabby cage"; so he opened the door and took hold of it and put it into the golden cage.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the bird set up such a loud scream that all the soldiers awoke, and they took him prisoner and carried him before the king.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next morning the court sat to judge him; and when all was heard, it sentenced him to die, unless he should bring the king the golden horse which could run as swiftly as the wind; and if he did this, he was to have the golden bird given him for his own.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he set out once more on his journey, sighing, and in great despair, when on a sudden his friend the fox met him, and said, "You see now what has happened on account of your not listening to my counsel.

author: Grimms
sentence: I will still, however, tell you how to find the golden horse, if you will do as I bid you.

author: Grimms
sentence: You must go straight on till you come to the castle where the horse stands in his stall: by his side will lie the groom fast asleep and snoring: take away the horse quietly, but be sure to put the old leathern saddle upon him, and not the golden one that is close by it."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the son sat down on the fox"s tail, and away they went over stock and stone till their hair whistled in the wind.

author: Grimms
sentence: All went right, and the groom lay snoring with his hand upon the golden saddle.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when the son looked at the horse, he thought it a great pity to put the leathern saddle upon it.

author: Grimms
sentence: I will give him the good one, said he; "I am sure he deserves it."

author: Grimms
sentence: As he took up the golden saddle the groom awoke and cried out so loud, that all the guards ran in and took him prisoner, and in the morning he was again brought before the court to be judged, and was sentenced to die.

author: Grimms
sentence: But it was agreed, that, if he could bring thither the beautiful princess, he should live, and have the bird and the horse given him for his own.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went his way very sorrowful; but the old fox came and said, "Why did not you listen to me?

author: Grimms
sentence: If you had, you would have carried away both the bird and the horse; yet will I once more give you counsel.

author: Grimms
sentence: Go straight on, and in the evening you will arrive at a castle.

author: Grimms
sentence: At twelve o"clock at night the princess goes to the bathing-house: go up to her and give her a kiss, and she will let you lead her away; but take care you do not suffer her to go and take leave of her father and mother."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the fox stretched out his tail, and so away they went over stock and stone till their hair whistled again.

author: Grimms
sentence: As they came to the castle, all was as the fox had said, and at twelve o"clock the young man met the princes going to the bath and gave her the kiss, and she agreed to run away with him, but begged with many tears that he would let her take leave of her father.

author: Grimms
sentence: At first he refused, but she wept still more and more, and fell at his feet, till at last he consented; but the moment she came to her father"s house the guards awoke and he was taken prisoner again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he was brought before the king, and the king said, "You shall never have my daughter unless in eight days you dig away the hill that stops the view from my window."

author: Grimms
sentence: Now this hill was so big that the whole world could not take it away: and when he had worked for seven days, and had done very little, the fox came and said.

author: Grimms
sentence: Lie down and go to sleep; I will work for you.

author: Grimms
sentence: And in the morning he awoke and the hill was gone; so he went merrily to the king, and told him that now that it was removed he must give him the princess.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the king was obliged to keep his word, and away went the young man and the princess; and the fox came and said to him, "We will have all three, the princess, the horse, and the bird."

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah! said the young man, "that would be a great thing, but how can you contrive it?"

author: Grimms
sentence: If you will only listen, said the fox, "it can be done.

author: Grimms
sentence: When you come to the king, and he asks for the beautiful princess, you must say, "Here she is!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he will be very joyful; and you will mount the golden horse that they are to give you, and put out your hand to take leave of them; but shake hands with the princess last.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then lift her quickly on to the horse behind you; clap your spurs to his side, and gallop away as fast as you can."

author: Grimms
sentence: All went right: then the fox said, "When you come to the castle where the bird is, I will stay with the princess at the door, and you will ride in and speak to the king; and when he sees that it is the right horse, he will bring out the bird; but you must sit still, and say that you want to look at it, to see whether it is the true golden bird; and when you get it into your hand, ride away."

author: Grimms
sentence: This, too, happened as the fox said; they carried off the bird, the princess mounted again, and they rode on to a great wood.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the fox came, and said, "Pray kill me, and cut off my head and my feet."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the young man refused to do it: so the fox said, "I will at any rate give you good counsel: beware of two things; ransom no one from the gallows, and sit down by the side of no river."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then away he went.

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, thought the young man, "it is no hard matter to keep that advice."

author: Grimms
sentence: He rode on with the princess, till at last he came to the village where he had left his two brothers.

author: Grimms
sentence: And there he heard a great noise and uproar; and when he asked what was the matter, the people said, "Two men are going to be hanged."

author: Grimms
sentence: As he came nearer, he saw that the two men were his brothers, who had turned robbers; so he said, "Cannot they in any way be saved?"

author: Grimms
sentence: But the people said "No," unless he would bestow all his money upon the rascals and buy their liberty.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he did not stay to think about the matter, but paid what was asked, and his brothers were given up, and went on with him towards their home.

author: Grimms
sentence: And as they came to the wood where the fox first met them, it was so cool and pleasant that the two brothers said, "Let us sit down by the side of the river, and rest a while, to eat and drink."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he said, "Yes," and forgot the fox"s counsel, and sat down on the side of the river; and while he suspected nothing, they came behind, and threw him down the bank, and took the princess, the horse, and the bird, and went home to the king their master, and said.

author: Grimms
sentence: All this have we won by our labour.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then there was great rejoicing made; but the horse would not eat, the bird would not sing, and the princess wept.

author: Grimms
sentence: The youngest son fell to the bottom of the river"s bed: luckily it was nearly dry, but his bones were almost broken, and the bank was so steep that he could find no way to get out.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the old fox came once more, and scolded him for not following his advice; otherwise no evil would have befallen him: "Yet," said he, "I cannot leave you here, so lay hold of my tail and hold fast."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he pulled him out of the river, and said to him, as he got upon the bank, "Your brothers have set watch to kill you, if they find you in the kingdom."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he dressed himself as a poor man, and came secretly to the king"s court, and was scarcely within the doors when the horse began to eat, and the bird to sing, and princess left off weeping.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went to the king, and told him all his brothers" roguery; and they were seized and punished, and he had the princess given to him again; and after the king"s death he was heir to his kingdom.

author: Grimms
sentence: A long while after, he went to walk one day in the wood, and the old fox met him, and besought him with tears in his eyes to kill him, and cut off his head and feet.

author: Grimms
sentence: And at last he did so, and in a moment the fox was changed into a man, and turned out to be the brother of the princess, who had been lost a great many many years.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was a man who had three sons, the youngest of whom was called Dummling,[*] and was despised, mocked, and sneered at on every occasion.

author: Grimms
sentence: It happened that the eldest wanted to go into the forest to hew wood, and before he went his mother gave him a beautiful sweet cake and a bottle of wine in order that he might not suffer from hunger or thirst.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he entered the forest he met a little grey-haired old man who bade him good day, and said: "Do give me a piece of cake out of your pocket, and let me have a draught of your wine; I am so hungry and thirsty."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the clever son answered: "If I give you my cake and wine, I shall have none for myself; be off with you," and he left the little man standing and went on.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when he began to hew down a tree, it was not long before he made a false stroke, and the axe cut him in the arm, so that he had to go home and have it bound up.

author: Grimms
sentence: And this was the little grey man"s doing.

author: Grimms
sentence: After this the second son went into the forest, and his mother gave him, like the eldest, a cake and a bottle of wine.

author: Grimms
sentence: The little old grey man met him likewise, and asked him for a piece of cake and a drink of wine.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the second son, too, said sensibly enough: "What I give you will be taken away from myself; be off!" and he left the little man standing and went on.

author: Grimms
sentence: His punishment, however, was not delayed; when he had made a few blows at the tree he struck himself in the leg, so that he had to be carried home.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Dummling said: "Father, do let me go and cut wood."

author: Grimms
sentence: The father answered: "Your brothers have hurt themselves with it, leave it alone, you do not understand anything about it."

author: Grimms
sentence: But Dummling begged so long that at last he said: "Just go then, you will get wiser by hurting yourself."

author: Grimms
sentence: His mother gave him a cake made with water and baked in the cinders, and with it a bottle of sour beer.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he came to the forest the little old grey man met him likewise, and greeting him, said: "Give me a piece of your cake and a drink out of your bottle; I am so hungry and thirsty."

author: Grimms
sentence: Dummling answered: "I have only cinder-cake and sour beer; if that pleases you, we will sit down and eat."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they sat down, and when Dummling pulled out his cinder-cake, it was a fine sweet cake, and the sour beer had become good wine.

author: Grimms
sentence: So they ate and drank, and after that the little man said: "Since you have a good heart, and are willing to divide what you have, I will give you good luck.

author: Grimms
sentence: There stands an old tree, cut it down, and you will find something at the roots."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the little man took leave of him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Dummling went and cut down the tree, and when it fell there was a goose sitting in the roots with feathers of pure gold.

author: Grimms
sentence: He lifted her up, and taking her with him, went to an inn where he thought he would stay the night.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now the host had three daughters, who saw the goose and were curious to know what such a wonderful bird might be, and would have liked to have one of its golden feathers.

author: Grimms
sentence: The eldest thought: "I shall soon find an opportunity of pulling out a feather," and as soon as Dummling had gone out she seized the goose by the wing, but her finger and hand remained sticking fast to it.

author: Grimms
sentence: The second came soon afterwards, thinking only of how she might get a feather for herself, but she had scarcely touched her sister than she was held fast.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last the third also came with the like intent, and the others screamed out: "Keep away; for goodness" sake keep away!"

author: Grimms
sentence: But she did not understand why she was to keep away.

author: Grimms
sentence: The others are there, she thought, "I may as well be there too," and ran to them; but as soon as she had touched her sister, she remained sticking fast to her.

author: Grimms
sentence: So they had to spend the night with the goose.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next morning Dummling took the goose under his arm and set out, without troubling himself about the three girls who were hanging on to it.

author: Grimms
sentence: They were obliged to run after him continually, now left, now right, wherever his legs took him.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the middle of the fields the parson met them, and when he saw the procession he said: "For shame, you good-for-nothing girls, why are you running across the fields after this young man?

author: Grimms
sentence: Is that seemly?"

author: Grimms
sentence: At the same time he seized the youngest by the hand in order to pull her away, but as soon as he touched her he likewise stuck fast, and was himself obliged to run behind.

author: Grimms
sentence: Before long the sexton came by and saw his master, the parson, running behind three girls.

author: Grimms
sentence: He was astonished at this and called out: "Hi! your reverence, whither away so quickly?

author: Grimms
sentence: Do not forget that we have a christening today!" and running after him he took him by the sleeve, but was also held fast to it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Whilst the five were trotting thus one behind the other, two labourers came with their hoes from the fields; the parson called out to them and begged that they would set him and the sexton free.

author: Grimms
sentence: But they had scarcely touched the sexton when they were held fast, and now there were seven of them running behind Dummling and the goose.

author: Grimms
sentence: Soon afterwards he came to a city, where a king ruled who had a daughter who was so serious that no one could make her laugh.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he had put forth a decree that whosoever should be able to make her laugh should marry her.

author: Grimms
sentence: When Dummling heard this, he went with his goose and all her train before the king"s daughter, and as soon as she saw the seven people running on and on, one behind the other, she began to laugh quite loudly, and as if she would never stop.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon Dummling asked to have her for his wife; but the king did not like the son-inlaw, and made all manner of excuses and said he must first produce a man who could drink a cellarful of wine.

author: Grimms
sentence: Dummling thought of the little grey man, who could certainly help him; so he went into the forest, and in the same place where he had felled the tree, he saw a man sitting, who had a very sorrowful face.

author: Grimms
sentence: Dummling asked him what he was taking to heart so sorely, and he answered: "I have such a great thirst and cannot quench it; cold water I cannot stand, a barrel of wine I have just emptied, but that to me is like a drop on a hot stone!"

author: Grimms
sentence: There, I can help you, said Dummling, "just come with me and you shall be satisfied."

author: Grimms
sentence: He led him into the king"s cellar, and the man bent over the huge barrels, and drank and drank till his loins hurt, and before the day was out he had emptied all the barrels.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Dummling asked once more for his bride, but the king was vexed that such an ugly fellow, whom everyone called Dummling, should take away his daughter, and he made a new condition; he must first find a man who could eat a whole mountain of bread.

author: Grimms
sentence: Dummling did not think long, but went straight into the forest, where in the same place there sat a man who was tying up his body with a strap, and making an awful face, and saying: "I have eaten a whole ovenful of rolls, but what good is that when one has such a hunger as I?

author: Grimms
sentence: My stomach remains empty, and I must tie myself up if I am not to die of hunger."

author: Grimms
sentence: At this Dummling was glad, and said: "Get up and come with me; you shall eat yourself full."

author: Grimms
sentence: He led him to the king"s palace where all the flour in the whole Kingdom was collected, and from it he caused a huge mountain of bread to be baked.

author: Grimms
sentence: The man from the forest stood before it, began to eat, and by the end of one day the whole mountain had vanished.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Dummling for the third time asked for his bride; but the king again sought a way out, and ordered a ship which could sail on land and on water.

author: Grimms
sentence: As soon as you come sailing back in it, said he, "you shall have my daughter for wife."

author: Grimms
sentence: Dummling went straight into the forest, and there sat the little grey man to whom he had given his cake.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he heard what Dummling wanted, he said: "Since you have given me to eat and to drink, I will give you the ship; and I do all this because you once were kind to me."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he gave him the ship which could sail on land and water, and when the king saw that, he could no longer prevent him from having his daughter.

author: Grimms
sentence: The wedding was celebrated, and after the king"s death, Dummling inherited his kingdom and lived for a long time contentedly with his wife.

author: Grimms
sentence: [*] Simpleton

author: Grimms
sentence: Long, long ago, some two thousand years or so, there lived a rich man with a good and beautiful wife.

author: Grimms
sentence: They loved each other dearly, but sorrowed much that they had no children.

author: Grimms
sentence: So greatly did they desire to have one, that the wife prayed for it day and night, but still they remained childless.

author: Grimms
sentence: In front of the house there was a court, in which grew a juniper-tree.

author: Grimms
sentence: One winter"s day the wife stood under the tree to peel some apples, and as she was peeling them, she cut her finger, and the blood fell on the snow.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, sighed the woman heavily, "if I had but a child, as red as blood and as white as snow," and as she spoke the words, her heart grew light within her, and it seemed to her that her wish was granted, and she returned to the house feeling glad and comforted.

author: Grimms
sentence: A month passed, and the snow had all disappeared; then another month went by, and all the earth was green.

author: Grimms
sentence: So the months followed one another, and first the trees budded in the woods, and soon the green branches grew thickly intertwined, and then the blossoms began to fall.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once again the wife stood under the juniper-tree, and it was so full of sweet scent that her heart leaped for joy, and she was so overcome with her happiness, that she fell on her knees.

author: Grimms
sentence: Presently the fruit became round and firm, and she was glad and at peace; but when they were fully ripe she picked the berries and ate eagerly of them, and then she grew sad and ill.

author: Grimms
sentence: A little while later she called her husband, and said to him, weeping.

author: Grimms
sentence: If I die, bury me under the juniper-tree.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she felt comforted and happy again, and before another month had passed she had a little child, and when she saw that it was as white as snow and as red as blood, her joy was so great that she died.

author: Grimms
sentence: Her husband buried her under the juniper-tree, and wept bitterly for her.

author: Grimms
sentence: By degrees, however, his sorrow grew less, and although at times he still grieved over his loss, he was able to go about as usual, and later on he married again.

author: Grimms
sentence: He now had a little daughter born to him; the child of his first wife was a boy, who was as red as blood and as white as snow.

author: Grimms
sentence: The mother loved her daughter very much, and when she looked at her and then looked at the boy, it pierced her heart to think that he would always stand in the way of her own child, and she was continually thinking how she could get the whole of the property for her.

author: Grimms
sentence: This evil thought took possession of her more and more, and made her behave very unkindly to the boy.

author: Grimms
sentence: She drove him from place to place with cuffings and buffetings, so that the poor child went about in fear, and had no peace from the time he left school to the time he went back.

author: Grimms
sentence: One day the little daughter came running to her mother in the storeroom, and said, "Mother, give me an apple."

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, my child, said the wife, and she gave her a beautiful apple out of the chest; the chest had a very heavy lid and a large iron lock.

author: Grimms
sentence: Mother, said the little daughter again, "may not brother have one too?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The mother was angry at this, but she answered, "Yes, when he comes out of school."

author: Grimms
sentence: Just then she looked out of the window and saw him coming, and it seemed as if an evil spirit entered into her, for she snatched the apple out of her little daughter"s hand, and said, "You shall not have one before your brother."

author: Grimms
sentence: She threw the apple into the chest and shut it to.

author: Grimms
sentence: The little boy now came in, and the evil spirit in the wife made her say kindly to him, "My son, will you have an apple?" but she gave him a wicked look.

author: Grimms
sentence: Mother, said the boy, "how dreadful you look!

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, give me an apple."

author: Grimms
sentence: The thought came to her that she would kill him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Come with me, she said, and she lifted up the lid of the chest; "take one out for yourself."

author: Grimms
sentence: And as he bent over to do so, the evil spirit urged her, and crash! down went the lid, and off went the little boy"s head.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she was overwhelmed with fear at the thought of what she had done.

author: Grimms
sentence: If only I can prevent anyone knowing that I did it, she thought.

author: Grimms
sentence: So she went upstairs to her room, and took a white handkerchief out of her top drawer; then she set the boy"s head again on his shoulders, and bound it with the handkerchief so that nothing could be seen, and placed him on a chair by the door with an apple in his hand.

author: Grimms
sentence: Soon after this, little Marleen came up to her mother who was stirring a pot of boiling water over the fire, and said, "Mother, brother is sitting by the door with an apple in his hand, and he looks so pale; and when I asked him to give me the apple, he did not answer, and that frightened me."

author: Grimms
sentence: Go to him again, said her mother, "and if he does not answer, give him a box on the ear."

author: Grimms
sentence: So little Marleen went, and said, "Brother, give me that apple," but he did not say a word; then she gave him a box on the ear, and his head rolled off.

author: Grimms
sentence: She was so terrified at this, that she ran crying and screaming to her mother.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh! she said, "I have knocked off brother"s head," and then she wept and wept, and nothing would stop her.

author: Grimms
sentence: What have you done! said her mother, "but no one must know about it, so you must keep silence; what is done can"t be undone; we will make him into puddings."

author: Grimms
sentence: And she took the little boy and cut him up, made him into puddings, and put him in the pot.

author: Grimms
sentence: But Marleen stood looking on, and wept and wept, and her tears fell into the pot, so that there was no need of salt.

author: Grimms
sentence: Presently the father came home and sat down to his dinner; he asked, "Where is my son?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The mother said nothing, but gave him a large dish of black pudding, and Marleen still wept without ceasing.

author: Grimms
sentence: The father again asked, "Where is my son?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, answered the wife, "he is gone into the country to his mother"s great uncle; he is going to stay there some time."

author: Grimms
sentence: What has he gone there for, and he never even said goodbye to me!

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, he likes being there, and he told me he should be away quite six weeks; he is well looked after there.

author: Grimms
sentence: I feel very unhappy about it, said the husband, "in case it should not be all right, and he ought to have said goodbye to me."

author: Grimms
sentence: With this he went on with his dinner, and said, "Little Marleen, why do you weep?

author: Grimms
sentence: Brother will soon be back."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he asked his wife for more pudding, and as he ate, he threw the bones under the table.

author: Grimms
sentence: Little Marleen went upstairs and took her best silk handkerchief out of her bottom drawer, and in it she wrapped all the bones from under the table and carried them outside, and all the time she did nothing but weep.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she laid them in the green grass under the junipertree, and she had no sooner done so, then all her sadness seemed to leave her, and she wept no more.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a merchant who had only one child, a son, that was very young, and barely able to run alone.

author: Grimms
sentence: He had two richly laden ships then making a voyage upon the seas, in which he had embarked all his wealth, in the hope of making great gains, when the news came that both were lost.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thus from being a rich man he became all at once so very poor that nothing was left to him but one small plot of land; and there he often went in an evening to take his walk, and ease his mind of a little of his trouble.

author: Grimms
sentence: One day, as he was roaming along in a brown study, thinking with no great comfort on what he had been and what he now was, and was like to be, all on a sudden there stood before him a little, rough-looking, black dwarf.

author: Grimms
sentence: Prithee, friend, why so sorrowful? said he to the merchant; "what is it you take so deeply to heart?"

author: Grimms
sentence: If you would do me any good I would willingly tell you, said the merchant.

author: Grimms
sentence: Who knows but I may? said the little man: "tell me what ails you, and perhaps you will find I may be of some use."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the merchant told him how all his wealth was gone to the bottom of the sea, and how he had nothing left but that little plot of land.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, trouble not yourself about that, said the dwarf; "only undertake to bring me here, twelve years hence, whatever meets you first on your going home, and I will give you as much as you please."

author: Grimms
sentence: The merchant thought this was no great thing to ask; that it would most likely be his dog or his cat, or something of that sort, but forgot his little boy Heinel; so he agreed to the bargain, and signed and sealed the bond to do what was asked of him.

author: Grimms
sentence: But as he drew near home, his little boy was so glad to see him that he crept behind him, and laid fast hold of his legs, and looked up in his face and laughed.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the father started, trembling with fear and horror, and saw what it was that he had bound himself to do; but as no gold was come, he made himself easy by thinking that it was only a joke that the dwarf was playing him, and that, at any rate, when the money came, he should see the bearer, and would not take it in.

author: Grimms
sentence: About a month afterwards he went upstairs into a lumber-room to look for some old iron, that he might sell it and raise a little money; and there, instead of his iron, he saw a large pile of gold lying on the floor.

author: Grimms
sentence: At the sight of this he was overjoyed, and forgetting all about his son, went into trade again, and became a richer merchant than before.

author: Grimms
sentence: Meantime little Heinel grew up, and as the end of the twelve years drew near the merchant began to call to mind his bond, and became very sad and thoughtful; so that care and sorrow were written upon his face.

author: Grimms
sentence: The boy one day asked what was the matter, but his father would not tell for some time; at last, however, he said that he had, without knowing it, sold him for gold to a little, ugly-looking, black dwarf, and that the twelve years were coming round when he must keep his word.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Heinel said, "Father, give yourself very little trouble about that; I shall be too much for the little man."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the time came, the father and son went out together to the place agreed upon: and the son drew a circle on the ground, and set himself and his father in the middle of it.

author: Grimms
sentence: The little black dwarf soon came, and walked round and round about the circle, but could not find any way to get into it, and he either could not, or dared not, jump over it.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last the boy said to him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Have you anything to say to us, my friend, or what do you want?

author: Grimms
sentence: Now Heinel had found a friend in a good fairy, that was fond of him, and had told him what to do; for this fairy knew what good luck was in store for him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Have you brought me what you said you would? said the dwarf to the merchant.

author: Grimms
sentence: The old man held his tongue, but Heinel said again, "What do you want here?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The dwarf said, "I come to talk with your father, not with you."

author: Grimms
sentence: You have cheated and taken in my father, said the son; "pray give him up his bond at once."

author: Grimms
sentence: Fair and softly, said the little old man; "right is right; I have paid my money, and your father has had it, and spent it; so be so good as to let me have what I paid it for."

author: Grimms
sentence: You must have my consent to that first, said Heinel, "so please to step in here, and let us talk it over."

author: Grimms
sentence: The old man grinned, and showed his teeth, as if he should have been very glad to get into the circle if he could.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then at last, after a long talk, they came to terms.

author: Grimms
sentence: Heinel agreed that his father must give him up, and that so far the dwarf should have his way: but, on the other hand, the fairy had told Heinel what fortune was in store for him, if he followed his own course; and he did not choose to be given up to his hump-backed friend, who seemed so anxious for his company.

author: Grimms
sentence: So, to make a sort of drawn battle of the matter, it was settled that Heinel should be put into an open boat, that lay on the sea-shore hard by; that the father should push him off with his own hand, and that he should thus be set adrift, and left to the bad or good luck of wind and weather.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he took leave of his father, and set himself in the boat, but before it got far off a wave struck it, and it fell with one side low in the water, so the merchant thought that poor Heinel was lost, and went home very sorrowful, while the dwarf went his way, thinking that at any rate he had had his revenge.

author: Grimms
sentence: The boat, however, did not sink, for the good fairy took care of her friend, and soon raised the boat up again, and it went safely on.

author: Grimms
sentence: The young man sat safe within, till at length it ran ashore upon an unknown land.

author: Grimms
sentence: As he jumped upon the shore he saw before him a beautiful castle but empty and dreary within, for it was enchanted.

author: Grimms
sentence: Here, said he to himself, "must I find the prize the good fairy told me of."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he once more searched the whole palace through, till at last he found a white snake, lying coiled up on a cushion in one of the chambers.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now the white snake was an enchanted princess; and she was very glad to see him, and said, "Are you at last come to set me free?

author: Grimms
sentence: Twelve long years have I waited here for the fairy to bring you hither as she promised, for you alone can save me.

author: Grimms
sentence: This night twelve men will come: their faces will be black, and they will be dressed in chain armour.

author: Grimms
sentence: They will ask what you do here, but give no answer; and let them do what they will--beat, whip, pinch, prick, or torment you--bear all; only speak not a word, and at twelve o"clock they must go away.

author: Grimms
sentence: The second night twelve others will come: and the third night twenty-four, who will even cut off your head; but at the twelfth hour of that night their power is gone, and I shall be free, and will come and bring you the Water of Life, and will wash you with it, and bring you back to life and health."

author: Grimms
sentence: And all came to pass as she had said; Heinel bore all, and spoke not a word; and the third night the princess came, and fell on his neck and kissed him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Joy and gladness burst forth throughout the castle, the wedding was celebrated, and he was crowned king of the Golden Mountain.

author: Grimms
sentence: They lived together very happily, and the queen had a son.

author: Grimms
sentence: And thus eight years had passed over their heads, when the king thought of his father; and he began to long to see him once again.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the queen was against his going, and said, "I know well that misfortunes will come upon us if you go."

author: Grimms
sentence: However, he gave her no rest till she agreed.

author: Grimms
sentence: At his going away she gave him a wishing-ring, and said, "Take this ring, and put it on your finger; whatever you wish it will bring you; only promise never to make use of it to bring me hence to your father"s house."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he said he would do what she asked, and put the ring on his finger, and wished himself near the town where his father lived.

author: Grimms
sentence: Heinel found himself at the gates in a moment; but the guards would not let him go in, because he was so strangely clad.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he went up to a neighbouring hill, where a shepherd dwelt, and borrowed his old frock, and thus passed unknown into the town.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he came to his father"s house, he said he was his son; but the merchant would not believe him, and said he had had but one son, his poor Heinel, who he knew was long since dead: and as he was only dressed like a poor shepherd, he would not even give him anything to eat.

author: Grimms
sentence: The king, however, still vowed that he was his son, and said, "Is there no mark by which you would know me if I am really your son?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said his mother, "our Heinel had a mark like a raspberry on his right arm."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he showed them the mark, and they knew that what he had said was true.

author: Grimms
sentence: He next told them how he was king of the Golden Mountain, and was married to a princess, and had a son seven years old.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the merchant said, "that can never be true; he must be a fine king truly who travels about in a shepherd"s frock!"

author: Grimms
sentence: At this the son was vexed; and forgetting his word, turned his ring, and wished for his queen and son.

author: Grimms
sentence: In an instant they stood before him; but the queen wept, and said he had broken his word, and bad luck would follow.

author: Grimms
sentence: He did all he could to soothe her, and she at last seemed to be appeased; but she was not so in truth, and was only thinking how she should punish him.

author: Grimms
sentence: One day he took her to walk with him out of the town, and showed her the spot where the boat was set adrift upon the wide waters.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he sat himself down, and said, "I am very much tired; sit by me, I will rest my head in your lap, and sleep a while."

author: Grimms
sentence: As soon as he had fallen asleep, however, she drew the ring from his finger, and crept softly away, and wished herself and her son at home in their kingdom.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when he awoke he found himself alone, and saw that the ring was gone from his finger.

author: Grimms
sentence: I can never go back to my fathers house," said he; "they would say I am a sorcerer: I will journey forth into the world, till I come again to my kingdom."

author: Grimms
sentence: So saying he set out and travelled till he came to a hill, where three giants were sharing their father"s goods; and as they saw him pass they cried out and said, "Little men have sharp wits; he shall part the goods between us."

author: Grimms
sentence: Now there was a sword that cut off an enemy"s head whenever the wearer gave the words, "Heads off!"; a cloak that made the owner invisible, or gave him any form he pleased; and a pair of boots that carried the wearer wherever he wished.

author: Grimms
sentence: Heinel said they must first let him try these wonderful things, then he might know how to set a value upon them.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they gave him the cloak, and he wished himself a fly, and in a moment he was a fly.

author: Grimms
sentence: The cloak is very well, said he: "now give me the sword."

author: Grimms
sentence: No, said they; "not unless you undertake not to say, "Heads off!" for if you do we are all dead men."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they gave it him, charging him to try it on a tree.

author: Grimms
sentence: He next asked for the boots also; and the moment he had all three in his power, he wished himself at the Golden Mountain; and there he was at once.

author: Grimms
sentence: So the giants were left behind with no goods to share or quarrel about.

author: Grimms
sentence: As Heinel came near his castle he heard the sound of merry music; and the people around told him that his queen was about to marry another husband.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he threw his cloak around him, and passed through the castle hall, and placed himself by the side of the queen, where no one saw him.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when anything to eat was put upon her plate, he took it away and ate it himself; and when a glass of wine was handed to her, he took it and drank it; and thus, though they kept on giving her meat and drink, her plate and cup were always empty.

author: Grimms
sentence: Upon this, fear and remorse came over her, and she went into her chamber alone, and sat there weeping; and he followed her there.

author: Grimms
sentence: Alas! said she to herself, "was I not once set free?

author: Grimms
sentence: Why then does this enchantment still seem to bind me?"

author: Grimms
sentence: False and fickle one! said he.

author: Grimms
sentence:
One indeed came who set thee free, and he is now near thee again; but how have you used him?
