author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went out and sent away the company, and said the wedding was at an end, for that he was come back to the kingdom.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the princes, peers, and great men mocked at him.

author: Grimms
sentence: However, he would enter into no parley with them, but only asked them if they would go in peace or not.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they turned upon him and tried to seize him; but he drew his sword.

author: Grimms
sentence: Heads Off! cried he; and with the word the traitors" heads fell before him, and Heinel was once more king of the Golden Mountain.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was a certain village wherein no one lived but really rich peasants, and just one poor one, whom they called the little peasant.

author: Grimms
sentence: He had not even so much as a cow, and still less money to buy one, and yet he and his wife did so wish to have one.

author: Grimms
sentence: One day he said to her: "Listen, I have a good idea, there is our gossip the carpenter, he shall make us a wooden calf, and paint it brown, so that it looks like any other, and in time it will certainly get big and be a cow." the woman also liked the idea, and their gossip the carpenter cut and planed the calf, and painted it as it ought to be, and made it with its head hanging down as if it were eating.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next morning when the cows were being driven out, the little peasant called the cow-herd in and said: "Look, I have a little calf there, but it is still small and has to be carried."

author: Grimms
sentence: The cow-herd said: "All right," and took it in his arms and carried it to the pasture, and set it among the grass.

author: Grimms
sentence: The little calf always remained standing like one which was eating, and the cow-herd said: "It will soon run by itself, just look how it eats already!"

author: Grimms
sentence: At night when he was going to drive the herd home again, he said to the calf: "If you can stand there and eat your fill, you can also go on your four legs; I don"t care to drag you home again in my arms."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the little peasant stood at his door, and waited for his little calf, and when the cow-herd drove the cows through the village, and the calf was missing, he inquired where it was.

author: Grimms
sentence: The cow-herd answered: "It is still standing out there eating.

author: Grimms
sentence: It would not stop and come with us."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the little peasant said: "Oh, but I must have my beast back again."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they went back to the meadow together, but someone had stolen the calf, and it was gone.

author: Grimms
sentence: The cow-herd said: "It must have run away."

author: Grimms
sentence: The peasant, however, said: "Don"t tell me that," and led the cow-herd before the mayor, who for his carelessness condemned him to give the peasant a cow for the calf which had run away.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now the little peasant and his wife had the cow for which they had so long wished, and they were heartily glad, but they had no food for it, and could give it nothing to eat, so it soon had to be killed.

author: Grimms
sentence: They salted the flesh, and the peasant went into the town and wanted to sell the skin there, so that he might buy a new calf with the proceeds.

author: Grimms
sentence: On the way he passed by a mill, and there sat a raven with broken wings, and out of pity he took him and wrapped him in the skin.

author: Grimms
sentence: But as the weather grew so bad and there was a storm of rain and wind, he could go no farther, and turned back to the mill and begged for shelter.

author: Grimms
sentence: The miller"s wife was alone in the house, and said to the peasant: "Lay yourself on the straw there," and gave him a slice of bread and cheese.

author: Grimms
sentence: The peasant ate it, and lay down with his skin beside him, and the woman thought: "He is tired and has gone to sleep."

author: Grimms
sentence: In the meantime came the parson; the miller"s wife received him well, and said: "My husband is out, so we will have a feast."

author: Grimms
sentence: The peasant listened, and when he heard them talk about feasting he was vexed that he had been forced to make shift with a slice of bread and cheese.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the woman served up four different things, roast meat, salad, cakes, and wine.

author: Grimms
sentence: Just as they were about to sit down and eat, there was a knocking outside.

author: Grimms
sentence: The woman said: "Oh, heavens!

author: Grimms
sentence: It is my husband!" she quickly hid the roast meat inside the tiled stove, the wine under the pillow, the salad on the bed, the cakes under it, and the parson in the closet on the porch.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she opened the door for her husband, and said: "Thank heaven, you are back again!

author: Grimms
sentence: There is such a storm, it looks as if the world were coming to an end."

author: Grimms
sentence: The miller saw the peasant lying on the straw, and asked, "What is that fellow doing there?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, said the wife, "the poor knave came in the storm and rain, and begged for shelter, so I gave him a bit of bread and cheese, and showed him where the straw was."

author: Grimms
sentence: The man said: "I have no objection, but be quick and get me something to eat."

author: Grimms
sentence: The woman said: "But I have nothing but bread and cheese."

author: Grimms
sentence: I am contented with anything, replied the husband, "so far as I am concerned, bread and cheese will do," and looked at the peasant and said: "Come and eat some more with me."

author: Grimms
sentence: The peasant did not require to be invited twice, but got up and ate.

author: Grimms
sentence: After this the miller saw the skin in which the raven was, lying on the ground, and asked: "What have you there?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The peasant answered: "I have a soothsayer inside it."

author: Grimms
sentence: Can he foretell anything to me? said the miller.

author: Grimms
sentence: Why not? answered the peasant: "but he only says four things, and the fifth he keeps to himself."

author: Grimms
sentence: The miller was curious, and said: "Let him foretell something for once."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the peasant pinched the raven"s head, so that he croaked and made a noise like krr, krr.

author: Grimms
sentence: The miller said: "What did he say?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The peasant answered: "In the first place, he says that there is some wine hidden under the pillow."

author: Grimms
sentence: Bless me! cried the miller, and went there and found the wine.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now go on, said he.

author: Grimms
sentence: The peasant made the raven croak again, and said: "In the second place, he says that there is some roast meat in the tiled stove."

author: Grimms
sentence: Upon my word! cried the miller, and went thither, and found the roast meat.

author: Grimms
sentence: The peasant made the raven prophesy still more, and said: "Thirdly, he says that there is some salad on the bed."

author: Grimms
sentence: That would be a fine thing! cried the miller, and went there and found the salad.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last the peasant pinched the raven once more till he croaked, and said: "Fourthly, he says that there are some cakes under the bed."

author: Grimms
sentence: That would be a fine thing! cried the miller, and looked there, and found the cakes.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now the two sat down to the table together, but the miller"s wife was frightened to death, and went to bed and took all the keys with her.

author: Grimms
sentence: The miller would have liked much to know the fifth, but the little peasant said: "First, we will quickly eat the four things, for the fifth is something bad."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they ate, and after that they bargained how much the miller was to give for the fifth prophecy, until they agreed on three hundred talers.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the peasant once more pinched the raven"s head till he croaked loudly.

author: Grimms
sentence: The miller asked: "What did he say?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The peasant replied: "He says that the Devil is hiding outside there in the closet on the porch."

author: Grimms
sentence: The miller said: "The Devil must go out," and opened the house-door; then the woman was forced to give up the keys, and the peasant unlocked the closet.

author: Grimms
sentence: The parson ran out as fast as he could, and the miller said: "It was true; I saw the black rascal with my own eyes."

author: Grimms
sentence: The peasant, however, made off next morning by daybreak with the three hundred talers.

author: Grimms
sentence: At home the small peasant gradually launched out; he built a beautiful house, and the peasants said: "The small peasant has certainly been to the place where golden snow falls, and people carry the gold home in shovels."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the small peasant was brought before the mayor, and bidden to say from whence his wealth came.

author: Grimms
sentence: He answered: "I sold my cow"s skin in the town, for three hundred talers."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the peasants heard that, they too wished to enjoy this great profit, and ran home, killed all their cows, and stripped off their skins in order to sell them in the town to the greatest advantage.

author: Grimms
sentence: The mayor, however, said: "But my servant must go first."

author: Grimms
sentence: When she came to the merchant in the town, he did not give her more than two talers for a skin, and when the others came, he did not give them so much, and said: "What can I do with all these skins?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the peasants were vexed that the small peasant should have thus outwitted them, wanted to take vengeance on him, and accused him of this treachery before the major.

author: Grimms
sentence: The innocent little peasant was unanimously sentenced to death, and was to be rolled into the water, in a barrel pierced full of holes.

author: Grimms
sentence: He was led forth, and a priest was brought who was to say a mass for his soul.

author: Grimms
sentence: The others were all obliged to retire to a distance, and when the peasant looked at the priest, he recognized the man who had been with the miller"s wife.

author: Grimms
sentence: He said to him: "I set you free from the closet, set me free from the barrel."

author: Grimms
sentence: At this same moment up came, with a flock of sheep, the very shepherd whom the peasant knew had long been wishing to be mayor, so he cried with all his might: "No, I will not do it; if the whole world insists on it, I will not do it!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The shepherd hearing that, came up to him, and asked: "What are you about?

author: Grimms
sentence: What is it that you will not do?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The peasant said: "They want to make me mayor, if I will but put myself in the barrel, but I will not do it."

author: Grimms
sentence: The shepherd said: "If nothing more than that is needful in order to be mayor, I would get into the barrel at once."

author: Grimms
sentence: The peasant said: "If you will get in, you will be mayor."

author: Grimms
sentence: The shepherd was willing, and got in, and the peasant shut the top down on him; then he took the shepherd"s flock for himself, and drove it away.

author: Grimms
sentence: The parson went to the crowd, and declared that the mass had been said.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they came and rolled the barrel towards the water.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the barrel began to roll, the shepherd cried: "I am quite willing to be mayor."

author: Grimms
sentence: They believed no otherwise than that it was the peasant who was saying this, and answered: "That is what we intend, but first you shall look about you a little down below there," and they rolled the barrel down into the water.

author: Grimms
sentence: After that the peasants went home, and as they were entering the village, the small peasant also came quietly in, driving a flock of sheep and looking quite contented.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the peasants were astonished, and said: "Peasant, from whence do you come?

author: Grimms
sentence: Have you come out of the water?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, truly, replied the peasant, "I sank deep, deep down, until at last I got to the bottom; I pushed the bottom out of the barrel, and crept out, and there were pretty meadows on which a number of lambs were feeding, and from thence I brought this flock away with me."

author: Grimms
sentence: Said the peasants: "Are there any more there?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, yes, said he, "more than I could want."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the peasants made up their minds that they too would fetch some sheep for themselves, a flock apiece, but the mayor said: "I come first."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they went to the water together, and just then there were some of the small fleecy clouds in the blue sky, which are called little lambs, and they were reflected in the water, whereupon the peasants cried: "We already see the sheep down below!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The mayor pressed forward and said: "I will go down first, and look about me, and if things promise well I"ll call you."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he jumped in; splash! went the water; it sounded as if he were calling them, and the whole crowd plunged in after him as one man.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the entire village was dead, and the small peasant, as sole heir, became a rich man.

author: Grimms
sentence: A farmer had a faithful and diligent servant, who had worked hard for him three years, without having been paid any wages.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last it came into the man"s head that he would not go on thus without pay any longer; so he went to his master, and said, "I have worked hard for you a long time, I will trust to you to give me what I deserve to have for my trouble."

author: Grimms
sentence: The farmer was a sad miser, and knew that his man was very simple-hearted; so he took out threepence, and gave him for every year"s service a penny.

author: Grimms
sentence: The poor fellow thought it was a great deal of money to have, and said to himself, "Why should I work hard, and live here on bad fare any longer?

author: Grimms
sentence: I can now travel into the wide world, and make myself merry."

author: Grimms
sentence: With that he put his money into his purse, and set out, roaming over hill and valley.

author: Grimms
sentence: As he jogged along over the fields, singing and dancing, a little dwarf met him, and asked him what made him so merry.

author: Grimms
sentence: Why, what should make me down-hearted? said he; "I am sound in health and rich in purse, what should I care for?

author: Grimms
sentence: I have saved up my three years" earnings and have it all safe in my pocket."

author: Grimms
sentence: How much may it come to? said the little man.

author: Grimms
sentence: Full threepence, replied the countryman.

author: Grimms
sentence: I wish you would give them to me, said the other; "I am very poor."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the man pitied him, and gave him all he had; and the little dwarf said in return, "As you have such a kind honest heart, I will grant you three wishes--one for every penny; so choose whatever you like."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the countryman rejoiced at his good luck, and said, "I like many things better than money: first, I will have a bow that will bring down everything I shoot at; secondly, a fiddle that will set everyone dancing that hears me play upon it; and thirdly, I should like that everyone should grant what I ask."

author: Grimms
sentence: The dwarf said he should have his three wishes; so he gave him the bow and fiddle, and went his way.

author: Grimms
sentence: Our honest friend journeyed on his way too; and if he was merry before, he was now ten times more so.

author: Grimms
sentence: He had not gone far before he met an old miser: close by them stood a tree, and on the topmost twig sat a thrush singing away most joyfully.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, what a pretty bird! said the miser; "I would give a great deal of money to have such a one."

author: Grimms
sentence: If thats all," said the countryman, "I will soon bring it down."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he took up his bow, and down fell the thrush into the bushes at the foot of the tree.

author: Grimms
sentence: The miser crept into the bush to find it; but directly he had got into the middle, his companion took up his fiddle and played away, and the miser began to dance and spring about, capering higher and higher in the air.

author: Grimms
sentence: The thorns soon began to tear his clothes till they all hung in rags about him, and he himself was all scratched and wounded, so that the blood ran down.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, for heavens sake!" cried the miser, "Master! master! pray let the fiddle alone.

author: Grimms
sentence: What have I done to deserve this?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Thou hast shaved many a poor soul close enough, said the other; "thou art only meeting thy reward": so he played up another tune.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the miser began to beg and promise, and offered money for his liberty; but he did not come up to the musician"s price for some time, and he danced him along brisker and brisker, and the miser bid higher and higher, till at last he offered a round hundred of florins that he had in his purse, and had just gained by cheating some poor fellow.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the countryman saw so much money, he said, "I will agree to your proposal."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he took the purse, put up his fiddle, and travelled on very pleased with his bargain.

author: Grimms
sentence: Meanwhile the miser crept out of the bush half-naked and in a piteous plight, and began to ponder how he should take his revenge, and serve his late companion some trick.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last he went to the judge, and complained that a rascal had robbed him of his money, and beaten him into the bargain; and that the fellow who did it carried a bow at his back and a fiddle hung round his neck.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the judge sent out his officers to bring up the accused wherever they should find him; and he was soon caught and brought up to be tried.

author: Grimms
sentence: The miser began to tell his tale, and said he had been robbed of his money.

author: Grimms
sentence: No, you gave it me for playing a tune to you. said the countryman; but the judge told him that was not likely, and cut the matter short by ordering him off to the gallows.

author: Grimms
sentence: So away he was taken; but as he stood on the steps he said, "My Lord Judge, grant me one last request."

author: Grimms
sentence: Anything but thy life, replied the other.

author: Grimms
sentence: No, said he, "I do not ask my life; only to let me play upon my fiddle for the last time."

author: Grimms
sentence: The miser cried out, "Oh, no! no! for heaven"s sake don"t listen to him! don"t listen to him!"

author: Grimms
sentence: But the judge said, "It is only this once, he will soon have done."

author: Grimms
sentence: The fact was, he could not refuse the request, on account of the dwarf"s third gift.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the miser said, "Bind me fast, bind me fast, for pity"s sake."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the countryman seized his fiddle, and struck up a tune, and at the first note judge, clerks, and jailer were in motion; all began capering, and no one could hold the miser.

author: Grimms
sentence: At the second note the hangman let his prisoner go, and danced also, and by the time he had played the first bar of the tune, all were dancing together--judge, court, and miser, and all the people who had followed to look on.

author: Grimms
sentence: At first the thing was merry and pleasant enough; but when it had gone on a while, and there seemed to be no end of playing or dancing, they began to cry out, and beg him to leave off; but he stopped not a whit the more for their entreaties, till the judge not only gave him his life, but promised to return him the hundred florins.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he called to the miser, and said, "Tell us now, you vagabond, where you got that gold, or I shall play on for your amusement only," "I stole it," said the miser in the presence of all the people; "I acknowledge that I stole it, and that you earned it fairly."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the countryman stopped his fiddle, and left the miser to take his place at the gallows.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once upon a time, a mouse, a bird, and a sausage, entered into partnership and set up house together.

author: Grimms
sentence: For a long time all went well; they lived in great comfort, and prospered so far as to be able to add considerably to their stores.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bird"s duty was to fly daily into the wood and bring in fuel; the mouse fetched the water, and the sausage saw to the cooking.

author: Grimms
sentence: When people are too well off they always begin to long for something new.

author: Grimms
sentence: And so it came to pass, that the bird, while out one day, met a fellow bird, to whom he boastfully expatiated on the excellence of his household arrangements.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the other bird sneered at him for being a poor simpleton, who did all the hard work, while the other two stayed at home and had a good time of it.

author: Grimms
sentence: For, when the mouse had made the fire and fetched in the water, she could retire into her little room and rest until it was time to set the table.

author: Grimms
sentence: The sausage had only to watch the pot to see that the food was properly cooked, and when it was near dinner-time, he just threw himself into the broth, or rolled in and out among the vegetables three or four times, and there they were, buttered, and salted, and ready to be served.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then, when the bird came home and had laid aside his burden, they sat down to table, and when they had finished their meal, they could sleep their fill till the following morning: and that was really a very delightful life.

author: Grimms
sentence: Influenced by those remarks, the bird next morning refused to bring in the wood, telling the others that he had been their servant long enough, and had been a fool into the bargain, and that it was now time to make a change, and to try some other way of arranging the work.

author: Grimms
sentence: Beg and pray as the mouse and the sausage might, it was of no use; the bird remained master of the situation, and the venture had to be made.

author: Grimms
sentence: They therefore drew lots, and it fell to the sausage to bring in the wood, to the mouse to cook, and to the bird to fetch the water.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now what happened?

author: Grimms
sentence: The sausage started in search of wood, the bird made the fire, and the mouse put on the pot, and then these two waited till the sausage returned with the fuel for the following day.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the sausage remained so long away, that they became uneasy, and the bird flew out to meet him.

author: Grimms
sentence: He had not flown far, however, when he came across a dog who, having met the sausage, had regarded him as his legitimate booty, and so seized and swallowed him.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bird complained to the dog of this bare-faced robbery, but nothing he said was of any avail, for the dog answered that he found false credentials on the sausage, and that was the reason his life had been forfeited.

author: Grimms
sentence: He picked up the wood, and flew sadly home, and told the mouse all he had seen and heard.

author: Grimms
sentence: They were both very unhappy, but agreed to make the best of things and to remain with one another.

author: Grimms
sentence: So now the bird set the table, and the mouse looked after the food and, wishing to prepare it in the same way as the sausage, by rolling in and out among the vegetables to salt and butter them, she jumped into the pot; but she stopped short long before she reached the bottom, having already parted not only with her skin and hair, but also with life.

author: Grimms
sentence: Presently the bird came in and wanted to serve up the dinner, but he could nowhere see the cook.

author: Grimms
sentence: In his alarm and flurry, he threw the wood here and there about the floor, called and searched, but no cook was to be found.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then some of the wood that had been carelessly thrown down, caught fire and began to blaze.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bird hastened to fetch some water, but his pail fell into the well, and he after it, and as he was unable to recover himself, he was drowned.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a very old man, whose eyes had become dim, his ears dull of hearing, his knees trembled, and when he sat at table he could hardly hold the spoon, and spilt the broth upon the table-cloth or let it run out of his mouth.

author: Grimms
sentence: His son and his son"s wife were disgusted at this, so the old grandfather at last had to sit in the corner behind the stove, and they gave him his food in an earthenware bowl, and not even enough of it.

author: Grimms
sentence: And he used to look towards the table with his eyes full of tears.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once, too, his trembling hands could not hold the bowl, and it fell to the ground and broke.

author: Grimms
sentence: The young wife scolded him, but he said nothing and only sighed.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they brought him a wooden bowl for a few half-pence, out of which he had to eat.

author: Grimms
sentence: They were once sitting thus when the little grandson of four years old began to gather together some bits of wood upon the ground.

author: Grimms
sentence: What are you doing there? asked the father.

author: Grimms
sentence: I am making a little trough, answered the child, "for father and mother to eat out of when I am big."

author: Grimms
sentence: The man and his wife looked at each other for a while, and presently began to cry.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they took the old grandfather to the table, and henceforth always let him eat with them, and likewise said nothing if he did spill a little of anything.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once upon a time a queen to whom God had given no children.

author: Grimms
sentence: Every morning she went into the garden and prayed to God in heaven to bestow on her a son or a daughter.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then an angel from heaven came to her and said: "Be at rest, you shall have a son with the power of wishing, so that whatsoever in the world he wishes for, that shall he have."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she went to the king, and told him the joyful tidings, and when the time was come she gave birth to a son, and the king was filled with gladness.

author: Grimms
sentence: Every morning she went with the child to the garden where the wild beasts were kept, and washed herself there in a clear stream.

author: Grimms
sentence: It happened once when the child was a little older, that it was lying in her arms and she fell asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then came the old cook, who knew that the child had the power of wishing, and stole it away, and he took a hen, and cut it in pieces, and dropped some of its blood on the queen"s apron and on her dress.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he carried the child away to a secret place, where a nurse was obliged to suckle it, and he ran to the king and accused the queen of having allowed her child to be taken from her by the wild beasts.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the king saw the blood on her apron, he believed this, fell into such a passion that he ordered a high tower to be built, in which neither sun nor moon could be seen and had his wife put into it, and walled up.

author: Grimms
sentence: Here she was to stay for seven years without meat or drink, and die of hunger.

author: Grimms
sentence: But God sent two angels from heaven in the shape of white doves, which flew to her twice a day, and carried her food until the seven years were over.

author: Grimms
sentence: The cook, however, thought to himself: "If the child has the power of wishing, and I am here, he might very easily get me into trouble."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he left the palace and went to the boy, who was already big enough to speak, and said to him: "Wish for a beautiful palace for yourself with a garden, and all else that pertains to it."

author: Grimms
sentence: Scarcely were the words out of the boy"s mouth, when everything was there that he had wished for.

author: Grimms
sentence: After a while the cook said to him: "It is not well for you to be so alone, wish for a pretty girl as a companion."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the king"s son wished for one, and she immediately stood before him, and was more beautiful than any painter could have painted her.

author: Grimms
sentence: The two played together, and loved each other with all their hearts, and the old cook went out hunting like a nobleman.

author: Grimms
sentence: The thought occurred to him, however, that the king"s son might some day wish to be with his father, and thus bring him into great peril.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he went out and took the maiden aside, and said: "Tonight when the boy is asleep, go to his bed and plunge this knife into his heart, and bring me his heart and tongue, and if you do not do it, you shall lose your life."

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon he went away, and when he returned next day she had not done it, and said: "Why should I shed the blood of an innocent boy who has never harmed anyone?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The cook once more said: "If you do not do it, it shall cost you your own life."

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had gone away, she had a little hind brought to her, and ordered her to be killed, and took her heart and tongue, and laid them on a plate, and when she saw the old man coming, she said to the boy: "Lie down in your bed, and draw the clothes over you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the wicked wretch came in and said: "Where are the boy"s heart and tongue?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The girl reached the plate to him, but the king"s son threw off the quilt, and said: "You old sinner, why did you want to kill me?

author: Grimms
sentence: Now will I pronounce thy sentence.

author: Grimms
sentence: You shall become a black poodle and have a gold collar round your neck, and shall eat burning coals, till the flames burst forth from your throat."

author: Grimms
sentence: And when he had spoken these words, the old man was changed into a poodle dog, and had a gold collar round his neck, and the cooks were ordered to bring up some live coals, and these he ate, until the flames broke forth from his throat.

author: Grimms
sentence: The king"s son remained there a short while longer, and he thought of his mother, and wondered if she were still alive.

author: Grimms
sentence: At length he said to the maiden: "I will go home to my own country; if you will go with me, I will provide for you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, she replied, "the way is so long, and what shall I do in a strange land where I am unknown?"

author: Grimms
sentence: As she did not seem quite willing, and as they could not be parted from each other, he wished that she might be changed into a beautiful pink, and took her with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went away to his own country, and the poodle had to run after him.

author: Grimms
sentence: He went to the tower in which his mother was confined, and as it was so high, he wished for a ladder which would reach up to the very top.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he mounted up and looked inside, and cried: "Beloved mother, Lady Queen, are you still alive, or are you dead?"

author: Grimms
sentence: She answered: "I have just eaten, and am still satisfied," for she thought the angels were there.

author: Grimms
sentence: Said he: "I am your dear son, whom the wild beasts were said to have torn from your arms; but I am alive still, and will soon set you free."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he descended again, and went to his father, and caused himself to be announced as a strange huntsman, and asked if he could offer him service.

author: Grimms
sentence: The king said yes, if he was skilful and could get game for him, he should come to him, but that deer had never taken up their quarters in any part of the district or country.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the huntsman promised to procure as much game for him as he could possibly use at the royal table.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he summoned all the huntsmen together, and bade them go out into the forest with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: And he went with them and made them form a great circle, open at one end where he stationed himself, and began to wish.

author: Grimms
sentence: Two hundred deer and more came running inside the circle at once, and the huntsmen shot them.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they were all placed on sixty country carts, and driven home to the king, and for once he was able to deck his table with game, after having had none at all for years.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now the king felt great joy at this, and commanded that his entire household should eat with him next day, and made a great feast.

author: Grimms
sentence: When they were all assembled together, he said to the huntsman: "As you are so clever, you shall sit by me."

author: Grimms
sentence: He replied: "Lord King, your majesty must excuse me, I am a poor huntsman."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the king insisted on it, and said: "You shall sit by me," until he did it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Whilst he was sitting there, he thought of his dearest mother, and wished that one of the king"s principal servants would begin to speak of her, and would ask how it was faring with the queen in the tower, and if she were alive still, or had perished.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hardly had he formed the wish than the marshal began, and said: "Your majesty, we live joyously here, but how is the queen living in the tower?

author: Grimms
sentence: Is she still alive, or has she died?"

author: Grimms
sentence: But the king replied: "She let my dear son be torn to pieces by wild beasts; I will not have her named."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the huntsman arose and said: "Gracious lord father she is alive still, and I am her son, and I was not carried away by wild beasts, but by that wretch the old cook, who tore me from her arms when she was asleep, and sprinkled her apron with the blood of a chicken."

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon he took the dog with the golden collar, and said: "That is the wretch!" and caused live coals to be brought, and these the dog was compelled to devour before the sight of all, until flames burst forth from its throat.

author: Grimms
sentence: On this the huntsman asked the king if he would like to see the dog in his true shape, and wished him back into the form of the cook, in the which he stood immediately, with his white apron, and his knife by his side.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the king saw him he fell into a passion, and ordered him to be cast into the deepest dungeon.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the huntsman spoke further and said: "Father, will you see the maiden who brought me up so tenderly and who was afterwards to murder me, but did not do it, though her own life depended on it?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The king replied: "Yes, I would like to see her."

author: Grimms
sentence: The son said: "Most gracious father, I will show her to you in the form of a beautiful flower," and he thrust his hand into his pocket and brought forth the pink, and placed it on the royal table, and it was so beautiful that the king had never seen one to equal it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the son said: "Now will I show her to you in her own form," and wished that she might become a maiden, and she stood there looking so beautiful that no painter could have made her look more so.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the king sent two waiting-maids and two attendants into the tower, to fetch the queen and bring her to the royal table.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when she was led in she ate nothing, and said: "The gracious and merciful God who has supported me in the tower, will soon set me free."

author: Grimms
sentence: She lived three days more, and then died happily, and when she was buried, the two white doves which had brought her food to the tower, and were angels of heaven, followed her body and seated themselves on her grave.

author: Grimms
sentence: The aged king ordered the cook to be torn in four pieces, but grief consumed the king"s own heart, and he soon died.

author: Grimms
sentence: His son married the beautiful maiden whom he had brought with him as a flower in his pocket, and whether they are still alive or not, is known to God.

author: Grimms
sentence: Two kings" sons once upon a time went into the world to seek their fortunes; but they soon fell into a wasteful foolish way of living, so that they could not return home again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then their brother, who was a little insignificant dwarf, went out to seek for his brothers: but when he had found them they only laughed at him, to think that he, who was so young and simple, should try to travel through the world, when they, who were so much wiser, had been unable to get on.

author: Grimms
sentence: However, they all set out on their journey together, and came at last to an anthill.

author: Grimms
sentence: The two elder brothers would have pulled it down, in order to see how the poor ants in their fright would run about and carry off their eggs.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the little dwarf said, "Let the poor things enjoy themselves, I will not suffer you to trouble them."

author: Grimms
sentence: So on they went, and came to a lake where many many ducks were swimming about.

author: Grimms
sentence: The two brothers wanted to catch two, and roast them.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the dwarf said, "Let the poor things enjoy themselves, you shall not kill them."

author: Grimms
sentence: Next they came to a bees"-nest in a hollow tree, and there was so much honey that it ran down the trunk; and the two brothers wanted to light a fire under the tree and kill the bees, so as to get their honey.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the dwarf held them back, and said, "Let the pretty insects enjoy themselves, I cannot let you burn them."

author: Grimms
sentence: At length the three brothers came to a castle: and as they passed by the stables they saw fine horses standing there, but all were of marble, and no man was to be seen.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they went through all the rooms, till they came to a door on which were three locks: but in the middle of the door was a wicket, so that they could look into the next room.

author: Grimms
sentence: There they saw a little grey old man sitting at a table; and they called to him once or twice, but he did not hear: however, they called a third time, and then he rose and came out to them.

author: Grimms
sentence: He said nothing, but took hold of them and led them to a beautiful table covered with all sorts of good things: and when they had eaten and drunk, he showed each of them to a bed-chamber.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next morning he came to the eldest and took him to a marble table, where there were three tablets, containing an account of the means by which the castle might be disenchanted.

author: Grimms
sentence: The first tablet said: "In the wood, under the moss, lie the thousand pearls belonging to the king"s daughter; they must all be found: and if one be missing by set of sun, he who seeks them will be turned into marble."

author: Grimms
sentence: The eldest brother set out, and sought for the pearls the whole day: but the evening came, and he had not found the first hundred: so he was turned into stone as the tablet had foretold.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next day the second brother undertook the task; but he succeeded no better than the first; for he could only find the second hundred of the pearls; and therefore he too was turned into stone.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last came the little dwarf"s turn; and he looked in the moss; but it was so hard to find the pearls, and the job was so tiresome!--so he sat down upon a stone and cried.

author: Grimms
sentence: And as he sat there, the king of the ants (whose life he had saved) came to help him, with five thousand ants; and it was not long before they had found all the pearls and laid them in a heap.

author: Grimms
sentence: The second tablet said: "The key of the princess"s bed-chamber must be fished up out of the lake."

author: Grimms
sentence: And as the dwarf came to the brink of it, he saw the two ducks whose lives he had saved swimming about; and they dived down and soon brought in the key from the bottom.

author: Grimms
sentence: The third task was the hardest.

author: Grimms
sentence: It was to choose out the youngest and the best of the king"s three daughters.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now they were all beautiful, and all exactly alike: but he was told that the eldest had eaten a piece of sugar, the next some sweet syrup, and the youngest a spoonful of honey; so he was to guess which it was that had eaten the honey.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then came the queen of the bees, who had been saved by the little dwarf from the fire, and she tried the lips of all three; but at last she sat upon the lips of the one that had eaten the honey: and so the dwarf knew which was the youngest.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thus the spell was broken, and all who had been turned into stones awoke, and took their proper forms.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the dwarf married the youngest and the best of the princesses, and was king after her father"s death; but his two brothers married the other two sisters.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a queen who had a little daughter, still too young to run alone.

author: Grimms
sentence: One day the child was very troublesome, and the mother could not quiet it, do what she would.

author: Grimms
sentence: She grew impatient, and seeing the ravens flying round the castle, she opened the window, and said: "I wish you were a raven and would fly away, then I should have a little peace."

author: Grimms
sentence: Scarcely were the words out of her mouth, when the child in her arms was turned into a raven, and flew away from her through the open window.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bird took its flight to a dark wood and remained there for a long time, and meanwhile the parents could hear nothing of their child.

author: Grimms
sentence: Long after this, a man was making his way through the wood when he heard a raven calling, and he followed the sound of the voice.

author: Grimms
sentence: As he drew near, the raven said, "I am by birth a king"s daughter, but am now under the spell of some enchantment; you can, however, set me free."

author: Grimms
sentence: What am I to do? he asked.

author: Grimms
sentence: She replied, "Go farther into the wood until you come to a house, wherein lives an old woman; she will offer you food and drink, but you must not take of either; if you do, you will fall into a deep sleep, and will not be able to help me.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the garden behind the house is a large tan-heap, and on that you must stand and watch for me.

author: Grimms
sentence: I shall drive there in my carriage at two o"clock in the afternoon for three successive days; the first day it will be drawn by four white, the second by four chestnut, and the last by four black horses; but if you fail to keep awake and I find you sleeping, I shall not be set free."

author: Grimms
sentence: The man promised to do all that she wished, but the raven said, "Alas!

author: Grimms
sentence: I know even now that you will take something from the woman and be unable to save me."

author: Grimms
sentence: The man assured her again that he would on no account touch a thing to eat or drink.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he came to the house and went inside, the old woman met him, and said, "Poor man! how tired you are!

author: Grimms
sentence: Come in and rest and let me give you something to eat and drink."

author: Grimms
sentence: No, answered the man, "I will neither eat not drink."

author: Grimms
sentence: But she would not leave him alone, and urged him saying, "If you will not eat anything, at least you might take a draught of wine; one drink counts for nothing," and at last he allowed himself to be persuaded, and drank.

author: Grimms
sentence: As it drew towards the appointed hour, he went outside into the garden and mounted the tan-heap to await the raven.

author: Grimms
sentence: Suddenly a feeling of fatigue came over him, and unable to resist it, he lay down for a little while, fully determined, however, to keep awake; but in another minute his eyes closed of their own accord, and he fell into such a deep sleep, that all the noises in the world would not have awakened him.

author: Grimms
sentence: At two o"clock the raven came driving along, drawn by her four white horses; but even before she reached the spot, she said to herself, sighing, "I know he has fallen asleep."

author: Grimms
sentence: When she entered the garden, there she found him as she had feared, lying on the tan-heap, fast asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: She got out of her carriage and went to him; she called him and shook him, but it was all in vain, he still continued sleeping.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next day at noon, the old woman came to him again with food and drink which he at first refused.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last, overcome by her persistent entreaties that he would take something, he lifted the glass and drank again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Towards two o"clock he went into the garden and on to the tan-heap to watch for the raven.

author: Grimms
sentence: He had not been there long before he began to feel so tired that his limbs seemed hardly able to support him, and he could not stand upright any longer; so again he lay down and fell fast asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: As the raven drove along her four chestnut horses, she said sorrowfully to herself, "I know he has fallen asleep."

author: Grimms
sentence: She went as before to look for him, but he slept, and it was impossible to awaken him.

author: Grimms
sentence: The following day the old woman said to him, "What is this?

author: Grimms
sentence: You are not eating or drinking anything, do you want to kill yourself?"

author: Grimms
sentence: He answered, "I may not and will not either eat or drink."

author: Grimms
sentence: But she put down the dish of food and the glass of wine in front of him, and when he smelt the wine, he was unable to resist the temptation, and took a deep draught.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the hour came round again he went as usual on to the tan-heap in the garden to await the king"s daughter, but he felt even more overcome with weariness than on the two previous days, and throwing himself down, he slept like a log.

author: Grimms
sentence: At two o"clock the raven could be seen approaching, and this time her coachman and everything about her, as well as her horses, were black.

author: Grimms
sentence: She was sadder than ever as she drove along, and said mournfully, "I know he has fallen asleep, and will not be able to set me free."

author: Grimms
sentence: She found him sleeping heavily, and all her efforts to awaken him were of no avail.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she placed beside him a loaf, and some meat, and a flask of wine, of such a kind, that however much he took of them, they would never grow less.

author: Grimms
sentence: After that she drew a gold ring, on which her name was engraved, off her finger, and put it upon one of his.

author: Grimms
sentence: Finally, she laid a letter near him, in which, after giving him particulars of the food and drink she had left for him, she finished with the following words: "I see that as long as you remain here you will never be able to set me free; if, however, you still wish to do so, come to the golden castle of Stromberg; this is well within your power to accomplish."

author: Grimms
sentence: She then returned to her carriage and drove to the golden castle of Stromberg.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the man awoke and found that he had been sleeping, he was grieved at heart, and said, "She has no doubt been here and driven away again, and it is now too late for me to save her."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then his eyes fell on the things which were lying beside him; he read the letter, and knew from it all that had happened.

author: Grimms
sentence: He rose up without delay, eager to start on his way and to reach the castle of Stromberg, but he had no idea in which direction he ought to go.

author: Grimms
sentence: He travelled about a long time in search of it and came at last to a dark forest, through which he went on walking for fourteen days and still could not find a way out.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once more the night came on, and worn out he lay down under a bush and fell asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: Again the next day he pursued his way through the forest, and that evening, thinking to rest again, he lay down as before, but he heard such a howling and wailing that he found it impossible to sleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: He waited till it was darker and people had begun to light up their houses, and then seeing a little glimmer ahead of him, he went towards it.

author: Grimms
sentence: He found that the light came from a house which looked smaller than it really was, from the contrast of its height with that of an immense giant who stood in front of it.

author: Grimms
sentence: He thought to himself, "If the giant sees me going in, my life will not be worth much."

author: Grimms
sentence: However, after a while he summoned up courage and went forward.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the giant saw him, he called out, "It is lucky for that you have come, for I have not had anything to eat for a long time.

author: Grimms
sentence: I can have you now for my supper."

author: Grimms
sentence: I would rather you let that alone, said the man, "for I do not willingly give myself up to be eaten; if you are wanting food I have enough to satisfy your hunger."

author: Grimms
sentence: If that is so, replied the giant, "I will leave you in peace; I only thought of eating you because I had nothing else."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they went indoors together and sat down, and the man brought out the bread, meat, and wine, which although he had eaten and drunk of them, were still unconsumed.

author: Grimms
sentence: The giant was pleased with the good cheer, and ate and drank to his heart"s content.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had finished his supper the man asked him if he could direct him to the castle of Stromberg.

author: Grimms
sentence: The giant said, "I will look on my map; on it are marked all the towns, villages, and houses."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he fetched his map, and looked for the castle, but could not find it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Never mind, he said, "I have larger maps upstairs in the cupboard, we will look on those," but they searched in vain, for the castle was not marked even on these.

author: Grimms
sentence: The man now thought he should like to continue his journey, but the giant begged him to remain for a day or two longer until the return of his brother, who was away in search of provisions.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the brother came home, they asked him about the castle of Stromberg, and he told them he would look on his own maps as soon as he had eaten and appeased his hunger.

author: Grimms
sentence: Accordingly, when he had finished his supper, they all went up together to his room and looked through his maps, but the castle was not to be found.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he fetched other older maps, and they went on looking for the castle until at last they found it, but it was many thousand miles away.

author: Grimms
sentence: How shall I be able to get there? asked the man.

author: Grimms
sentence: I have two hours to spare, said the giant, "and I will carry you into the neighbourhood of the castle; I must then return to look after the child who is in our care."

author: Grimms
sentence: The giant, thereupon, carried the man to within about a hundred leagues of the castle, where he left him, saying, "You will be able to walk the remainder of the way yourself."

author: Grimms
sentence: The man journeyed on day and night till he reached the golden castle of Stromberg.

author: Grimms
sentence: He found it situated, however, on a glass mountain, and looking up from the foot he saw the enchanted maiden drive round her castle and then go inside.

author: Grimms
sentence: He was overjoyed to see her, and longed to get to the top of the mountain, but the sides were so slippery that every time he attempted to climb he fell back again.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he saw that it was impossible to reach her, he was greatly grieved, and said to himself, "I will remain here and wait for her," so he built himself a little hut, and there he sat and watched for a whole year, and every day he saw the king"s daughter driving round her castle, but still was unable to get nearer to her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Looking out from his hut one day he saw three robbers fighting and he called out to them, "God be with you."

author: Grimms
sentence: They stopped when they heard the call, but looking round and seeing nobody, they went on again with their fighting, which now became more furious.

author: Grimms
sentence: God be with you, he cried again, and again they paused and looked about, but seeing no one went back to their fighting.

author: Grimms
sentence: A third time he called out, "God be with you," and then thinking he should like to know the cause of dispute between the three men, he went out and asked them why they were fighting so angrily with one another.

author: Grimms
sentence: One of them said that he had found a stick, and that he had but to strike it against any door through which he wished to pass, and it immediately flew open.

author: Grimms
sentence: Another told him that he had found a cloak which rendered its wearer invisible; and the third had caught a horse which would carry its rider over any obstacle, and even up the glass mountain.

author: Grimms
sentence: They had been unable to decide whether they would keep together and have the things in common, or whether they would separate.

author: Grimms
sentence: On hearing this, the man said, "I will give you something in exchange for those three things; not money, for that I have not got, but something that is of far more value.

author: Grimms
sentence: I must first, however, prove whether all you have told me about your three things is true."

author: Grimms
sentence: The robbers, therefore, made him get on the horse, and handed him the stick and the cloak, and when he had put this round him he was no longer visible.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he fell upon them with the stick and beat them one after another, crying, "There, you idle vagabonds, you have got what you deserve; are you satisfied now!"

author: Grimms
sentence: After this he rode up the glass mountain.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he reached the gate of the castle, he found it closed, but he gave it a blow with his stick, and it flew wide open at once and he passed through.

author: Grimms
sentence: He mounted the steps and entered the room where the maiden was sitting, with a golden goblet full of wine in front of her.

author: Grimms
sentence: She could not see him for he still wore his cloak.

author: Grimms
sentence: He took the ring which she had given him off his finger, and threw it into the goblet, so that it rang as it touched the bottom.

author: Grimms
sentence: That is my own ring, she exclaimed, "and if that is so the man must also be here who is coming to set me free."

author: Grimms
sentence: She sought for him about the castle, but could find him nowhere.

author: Grimms
sentence: Meanwhile he had gone outside again and mounted his horse and thrown off the cloak.

author: Grimms
sentence: When therefore she came to the castle gate she saw him, and cried aloud for joy.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he dismounted and took her in his arms; and she kissed him, and said, "Now you have indeed set me free, and tomorrow we will celebrate our marriage."

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a miller who had one beautiful daughter, and as she was grown up, he was anxious that she should be well married and provided for.

author: Grimms
sentence: He said to himself, "I will give her to the first suitable man who comes and asks for her hand."

author: Grimms
sentence: Not long after a suitor appeared, and as he appeared to be very rich and the miller could see nothing in him with which to find fault, he betrothed his daughter to him.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the girl did not care for the man as a girl ought to care for her betrothed husband.

author: Grimms
sentence: She did not feel that she could trust him, and she could not look at him nor think of him without an inward shudder.

author: Grimms
sentence: One day he said to her, "You have not yet paid me a visit, although we have been betrothed for some time."

author: Grimms
sentence: I do not know where your house is, she answered.

author: Grimms
sentence: My house is out there in the dark forest, he said.

author: Grimms
sentence: She tried to excuse herself by saying that she would not be able to find the way thither.

author: Grimms
sentence: Her betrothed only replied, "You must come and see me next Sunday; I have already invited guests for that day, and that you may not mistake the way, I will strew ashes along the path."

author: Grimms
sentence: When Sunday came, and it was time for the girl to start, a feeling of dread came over her which she could not explain, and that she might be able to find her path again, she filled her pockets with peas and lentils to sprinkle on the ground as she went along.

author: Grimms
sentence: On reaching the entrance to the forest she found the path strewed with ashes, and these she followed, throwing down some peas on either side of her at every step she took.

author: Grimms
sentence: She walked the whole day until she came to the deepest, darkest part of the forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: There she saw a lonely house, looking so grim and mysterious, that it did not please her at all.

author: Grimms
sentence: She stepped inside, but not a soul was to be seen, and a great silence reigned throughout.

author: Grimms
sentence: Suddenly a voice cried:

author: Grimms
sentence: Turn back, turn back, young maiden fair, Linger not in this murderers lair."

author: Grimms
sentence: The girl looked up and saw that the voice came from a bird hanging in a cage on the wall.

author: Grimms
sentence: Again it cried:

author: Grimms
sentence: Turn back, turn back, young maiden fair, Linger not in this murderers lair."

author: Grimms
sentence: The girl passed on, going from room to room of the house, but they were all empty, and still she saw no one.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last she came to the cellar, and there sat a very, very old woman, who could not keep her head from shaking.

author: Grimms
sentence: Can you tell me, asked the girl, "if my betrothed husband lives here?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, you poor child, answered the old woman, "what a place for you to come to!

author: Grimms
sentence: This is a murderers" den.

author: Grimms
sentence: You think yourself a promised bride, and that your marriage will soon take place, but it is with death that you will keep your marriage feast.

author: Grimms
sentence: Look, do you see that large cauldron of water which I am obliged to keep on the fire!

author: Grimms
sentence: As soon as they have you in their power they will kill you without mercy, and cook and eat you, for they are eaters of men.

author: Grimms
sentence: If I did not take pity on you and save you, you would be lost."

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon the old woman led her behind a large cask, which quite hid her from view.

author: Grimms
sentence: Keep as still as a mouse, she said; "do not move or speak, or it will be all over with you.

author: Grimms
sentence: Tonight, when the robbers are all asleep, we will flee together.

author: Grimms
sentence: I have long been waiting for an opportunity to escape."

author: Grimms
sentence: The words were hardly out of her mouth when the godless crew returned, dragging another young girl along with them.

author: Grimms
sentence: They were all drunk, and paid no heed to her cries and lamentations.

author: Grimms
sentence: They gave her wine to drink, three glasses full, one of white wine, one of red, and one of yellow, and with that her heart gave way and she died.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they tore of her dainty clothing, laid her on a table, and cut her beautiful body into pieces, and sprinkled salt upon it.

author: Grimms
sentence: The poor betrothed girl crouched trembling and shuddering behind the cask, for she saw what a terrible fate had been intended for her by the robbers.

author: Grimms
sentence: One of them now noticed a gold ring still remaining on the little finger of the murdered girl, and as he could not draw it off easily, he took a hatchet and cut off the finger; but the finger sprang into the air, and fell behind the cask into the lap of the girl who was hiding there.

author: Grimms
sentence: The robber took a light and began looking for it, but he could not find it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Have you looked behind the large cask? said one of the others.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the old woman called out, "Come and eat your suppers, and let the thing be till tomorrow; the finger won"t run away."

author: Grimms
sentence: The old woman is right, said the robbers, and they ceased looking for the finger and sat down.

author: Grimms
sentence: The old woman then mixed a sleeping draught with their wine, and before long they were all lying on the floor of the cellar, fast asleep and snoring.

author: Grimms
sentence: As soon as the girl was assured of this, she came from behind the cask.

author: Grimms
sentence: She was obliged to step over the bodies of the sleepers, who were lying close together, and every moment she was filled with renewed dread lest she should awaken them.

author: Grimms
sentence: But God helped her, so that she passed safely over them, and then she and the old woman went upstairs, opened the door, and hastened as fast as they could from the murderers" den.

author: Grimms
sentence: They found the ashes scattered by the wind, but the peas and lentils had sprouted, and grown sufficiently above the ground, to guide them in the moonlight along the path.

author: Grimms
sentence: All night long they walked, and it was morning before they reached the mill.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the girl told her father all that had happened.

author: Grimms
sentence: The day came that had been fixed for the marriage.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bridegroom arrived and also a large company of guests, for the miller had taken care to invite all his friends and relations.

author: Grimms
sentence: As they sat at the feast, each guest in turn was asked to tell a tale; the bride sat still and did not say a word.

author: Grimms
sentence: And you, my love, said the bridegroom, turning to her, "is there no tale you know?

author: Grimms
sentence: Tell us something."

author: Grimms
sentence: I will tell you a dream, then, said the bride.

author: Grimms
sentence:
I went alone through a forest and came at last to a house; not a soul could I find within, but a bird that was hanging in a cage on the wall cried:
57:57	N:N	N:F	Turn back, turn back, young maiden fair, Linger not in this murderers" lair."

author: Grimms
sentence: and again a second time it said these words."

author: Grimms
sentence: My darling, this is only a dream.

author: Grimms
sentence:

author: Grimms
sentence: As a merry young huntsman was once going briskly along through a wood, there came up a little old woman, and said to him, "Good day, good day; you seem merry enough, but I am hungry and thirsty; do pray give me something to eat."

author: Grimms
sentence: The huntsman took pity on her, and put his hand in his pocket and gave her what he had.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he wanted to go his way; but she took hold of him, and said, "Listen, my friend, to what I am going to tell you; I will reward you for your kindness; go your way, and after a little time you will come to a tree where you will see nine birds sitting on a cloak.

author: Grimms
sentence: Shoot into the midst of them, and one will fall down dead: the cloak will fall too; take it, it is a wishing-cloak, and when you wear it you will find yourself at any place where you may wish to be.

author: Grimms
sentence: Cut open the dead bird, take out its heart and keep it, and you will find a piece of gold under your pillow every morning when you rise.

author: Grimms
sentence: It is the bird"s heart that will bring you this good luck."

author: Grimms
sentence: The huntsman thanked her, and thought to himself, "If all this does happen, it will be a fine thing for me."

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had gone a hundred steps or so, he heard a screaming and chirping in the branches over him, and looked up and saw a flock of birds pulling a cloak with their bills and feet; screaming, fighting, and tugging at each other as if each wished to have it himself.

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, said the huntsman, "this is wonderful; this happens just as the old woman said"; then he shot into the midst of them so that their feathers flew all about.

author: Grimms
sentence: Off went the flock chattering away; but one fell down dead, and the cloak with it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the huntsman did as the old woman told him, cut open the bird, took out the heart, and carried the cloak home with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: The next morning when he awoke he lifted up his pillow, and there lay the piece of gold glittering underneath; the same happened next day, and indeed every day when he arose.

author: Grimms
sentence: He heaped up a great deal of gold, and at last thought to himself, "Of what use is this gold to me whilst I am at home?

author: Grimms
sentence: I will go out into the world and look about me."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he took leave of his friends, and hung his bag and bow about his neck, and went his way.

author: Grimms
sentence: It so happened that his road one day led through a thick wood, at the end of which was a large castle in a green meadow, and at one of the windows stood an old woman with a very beautiful young lady by her side looking about them.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now the old woman was a witch, and said to the young lady, "There is a young man coming out of the wood who carries a wonderful prize; we must get it away from him, my dear child, for it is more fit for us than for him.

author: Grimms
sentence: He has a bird"s heart that brings a piece of gold under his pillow every morning."

author: Grimms
sentence: Meantime the huntsman came nearer and looked at the lady, and said to himself, "I have been travelling so long that I should like to go into this castle and rest myself, for I have money enough to pay for anything I want"; but the real reason was, that he wanted to see more of the beautiful lady.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went into the house, and was welcomed kindly; and it was not long before he was so much in love that he thought of nothing else but looking at the lady"s eyes, and doing everything that she wished.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the old woman said, "Now is the time for getting the bird"s heart."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the lady stole it away, and he never found any more gold under his pillow, for it lay now under the young lady"s, and the old woman took it away every morning; but he was so much in love that he never missed his prize.

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, said the old witch, "we have got the bird"s heart, but not the wishing-cloak yet, and that we must also get."

author: Grimms
sentence: Let us leave him that, said the young lady; "he has already lost his wealth."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the witch was very angry, and said, "Such a cloak is a very rare and wonderful thing, and I must and will have it."

author: Grimms
sentence: So she did as the old woman told her, and set herself at the window, and looked about the country and seemed very sorrowful; then the huntsman said, "What makes you so sad?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Alas! dear sir, said she, "yonder lies the granite rock where all the costly diamonds grow, and I want so much to go there, that whenever I think of it I cannot help being sorrowful, for who can reach it? only the birds and the flies--man cannot."

author: Grimms
sentence: If thats all your grief," said the huntsman, "I"ll take there with all my heart"; so he drew her under his cloak, and the moment he wished to be on the granite mountain they were both there.

author: Grimms
sentence: The diamonds glittered so on all sides that they were delighted with the sight and picked up the finest.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the old witch made a deep sleep come upon him, and he said to the young lady, "Let us sit down and rest ourselves a little, I am so tired that I cannot stand any longer."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they sat down, and he laid his head in her lap and fell asleep; and whilst he was sleeping on she took the cloak from his shoulders, hung it on her own, picked up the diamonds, and wished herself home again.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he awoke and found that his lady had tricked him, and left him alone on the wild rock, he said, "Alas! what roguery there is in the world!" and there he sat in great grief and fear, not knowing what to do.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now this rock belonged to fierce giants who lived upon it; and as he saw three of them striding about, he thought to himself, "I can only save myself by feigning to be asleep"; so he laid himself down as if he were in a sound sleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the giants came up to him, the first pushed him with his foot, and said, "What worm is this that lies here curled up?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Tread upon him and kill him, said the second.

author: Grimms
sentence: Its not worth the trouble," said the third; "let him live, he"ll go climbing higher up the mountain, and some cloud will come rolling and carry him away."

author: Grimms
sentence: And they passed on.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the huntsman had heard all they said; and as soon as they were gone, he climbed to the top of the mountain, and when he had sat there a short time a cloud came rolling around him, and caught him in a whirlwind and bore him along for some time, till it settled in a garden, and he fell quite gently to the ground amongst the greens and cabbages.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he looked around him, and said, "I wish I had something to eat, if not I shall be worse off than before; for here I see neither apples nor pears, nor any kind of fruits, nothing but vegetables."

author: Grimms
sentence: At last he thought to himself, "I can eat salad, it will refresh and strengthen me."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he picked out a fine head and ate of it; but scarcely had he swallowed two bites when he felt himself quite changed, and saw with horror that he was turned into an ass.

author: Grimms
sentence: However, he still felt very hungry, and the salad tasted very nice; so he ate on till he came to another kind of salad, and scarcely had he tasted it when he felt another change come over him, and soon saw that he was lucky enough to have found his old shape again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he laid himself down and slept off a little of his weariness; and when he awoke the next morning he broke off a head both of the good and the bad salad, and thought to himself, "This will help me to my fortune again, and enable me to pay off some folks for their treachery."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he went away to try and find the castle of his friends; and after wandering about a few days he luckily found it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he stained his face all over brown, so that even his mother would not have known him, and went into the castle and asked for a lodging; "I am so tired," said he, "that I can go no farther."

author: Grimms
sentence: I am, said he, "a messenger sent by the king to find the finest salad that grows under the sun.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now the servant-maid came into the kitchen, and seeing the salad ready, was going to carry it up; but on the way she too felt a wish to taste it as the old woman had done, and ate some leaves; so she also was turned into an ass and ran after the other, letting the dish with the salad fall on the ground.

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: Now you shall be paid for your roguery, said he; and tied them all three to a rope and took them along with him till he came to a mill and knocked at the window.

author: Grimms
sentence: Whats the matter?" said the miller.

author: Grimms
sentence: I have three tiresome beasts here, said the other; "if you will take them, give them food and room, and treat them as I tell you, I will pay you whatever you ask."

author: Grimms
sentence: With all my heart, said the miller; "but how shall I treat them?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the huntsman said, "Give the old one stripes three times a day and hay once; give the next (who was the servant-maid) stripes once a day and hay three times; and give the youngest (who was the beautiful lady) hay three times a day and no stripes": for he could not find it in his heart to have her beaten.

author: Grimms
sentence: After this he went back to the castle, where he found everything he wanted.

author: Grimms
sentence: Some days after, the miller came to him and told him that the old ass was dead; "The other two," said he, "are alive and eat, but are so sorrowful that they cannot last long."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the huntsman pitied them, and told the miller to drive them back to him, and when they came, he gave them some of the good salad to eat.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the beautiful young lady fell upon her knees before him, and said, "O dearest huntsman! forgive me all the ill I have done you; my mother forced me to it, it was against my will, for I always loved you very much.

sentence: Your wishing-cloak hangs up in the closet, and as for the bird"s heart, I will give it you too."
