author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a man who had seven sons, and last of all one daughter.

author: Grimms
sentence: Although the little girl was very pretty, she was so weak and small that they thought she could not live; but they said she should at once be christened.

author: Grimms
sentence: So the father sent one of his sons in haste to the spring to get some water, but the other six ran with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Each wanted to be first at drawing the water, and so they were in such a hurry that all let their pitchers fall into the well, and they stood very foolishly looking at one another, and did not know what to do, for none dared go home.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the meantime the father was uneasy, and could not tell what made the young men stay so long.

author: Grimms
sentence: Surely, said he, "the whole seven must have forgotten themselves over some game of play"; and when he had waited still longer and they yet did not come, he flew into a rage and wished them all turned into ravens.

author: Grimms
sentence: Scarcely had he spoken these words when he heard a croaking over his head, and looked up and saw seven ravens as black as coal flying round and round.

author: Grimms
sentence: Sorry as he was to see his wish so fulfilled, he did not know how what was done could be undone, and comforted himself as well as he could for the loss of his seven sons with his dear little daughter, who soon became stronger and every day more beautiful.

author: Grimms
sentence: For a long time she did not know that she had ever had any brothers; for her father and mother took care not to speak of them before her: but one day by chance she heard the people about her speak of them.

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said they, "she is beautiful indeed, but still "tis a pity that her brothers should have been lost for her sake."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she was much grieved, and went to her father and mother, and asked if she had any brothers, and what had become of them.

author: Grimms
sentence: So they dared no longer hide the truth from her, but said it was the will of Heaven, and that her birth was only the innocent cause of it; but the little girl mourned sadly about it every day, and thought herself bound to do all she could to bring her brothers back; and she had neither rest nor ease, till at length one day she stole away, and set out into the wide world to find her brothers, wherever they might be, and free them, whatever it might cost her.

author: Grimms
sentence: She took nothing with her but a little ring which her father and mother had given her, a loaf of bread in case she should be hungry, a little pitcher of water in case she should be thirsty, and a little stool to rest upon when she should be weary.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thus she went on and on, and journeyed till she came to the world"s end; then she came to the sun, but the sun looked much too hot and fiery; so she ran away quickly to the moon, but the moon was cold and chilly, and said, "I smell flesh and blood this way!" so she took herself away in a hurry and came to the stars, and the stars were friendly and kind to her, and each star sat upon his own little stool; but the morning star rose up and gave her a little piece of wood, and said, "If you have not this little piece of wood, you cannot unlock the castle that stands on the glass-mountain, and there your brothers live."

author: Grimms
sentence: The little girl took the piece of wood, rolled it up in a little cloth, and went on again until she came to the glass-mountain, and found the door shut.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she felt for the little piece of wood; but when she unwrapped the cloth it was not there, and she saw she had lost the gift of the good stars.

author: Grimms
sentence: What was to be done?

author: Grimms
sentence: She wanted to save her brothers, and had no key of the castle of the glass-mountain; so this faithful little sister took a knife out of her pocket and cut off her little finger, that was just the size of the piece of wood she had lost, and put it in the door and opened it.

author: Grimms
sentence: As she went in, a little dwarf came up to her, and said, "What are you seeking for?"

author: Grimms
sentence: I seek for my brothers, the seven ravens, answered she.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the dwarf said, "My masters are not at home; but if you will wait till they come, pray step in."

author: Grimms
sentence: Now the little dwarf was getting their dinner ready, and he brought their food upon seven little plates, and their drink in seven little glasses, and set them upon the table, and out of each little plate their sister ate a small piece, and out of each little glass she drank a small drop; but she let the ring that she had brought with her fall into the last glass.

author: Grimms
sentence: On a sudden she heard a fluttering and croaking in the air, and the dwarf said, "Here come my masters."

author: Grimms

author: Grimms
sentence: When the little girl heard this (for she stood behind the door all the time and listened), she ran forward, and in an instant all the ravens took their right form again; and all hugged and kissed each other, and went merrily home.

author: Grimms
sentence: A certain father had two sons, the elder of who was smart and sensible, and could do everything, but the younger was stupid and could neither learn nor understand anything, and when people saw him they said: "There"s a fellow who will give his father some trouble!"

author: Grimms
sentence: When anything had to be done, it was always the elder who was forced to do it; but if his father bade him fetch anything when it was late, or in the night-time, and the way led through the churchyard, or any other dismal place, he answered: "Oh, no father, I"ll not go there, it makes me shudder!" for he was afraid.

author: Grimms
sentence: Or when stories were told by the fire at night which made the flesh creep, the listeners sometimes said: "Oh, it makes us shudder!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The younger sat in a corner and listened with the rest of them, and could not imagine what they could mean.

author: Grimms
sentence: They are always saying: It makes me shudder, it makes me shudder!"

author: Grimms
sentence: It does not make me shudder," thought he.

sentence: That, too, must be an art of which I understand nothing!

author: Grimms
sentence: Now it came to pass that his father said to him one day: "Hearken to me, you fellow in the corner there, you are growing tall and strong, and you too must learn something by which you can earn your bread.

author: Grimms
sentence: Look how your brother works, but you do not even earn your salt."

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, father, he replied, "I am quite willing to learn something-- indeed, if it could but be managed, I should like to learn how to shudder.

author: Grimms
sentence: The father sighed, and answered him: "You shall soon learn what it is to shudder, but you will not earn your bread by that."

author: Grimms
sentence: Soon after this the sexton came to the house on a visit, and the father bewailed his trouble, and told him how his younger son was so backward in every respect that he knew nothing and learnt nothing.

author: Grimms
sentence: Just think, said he, "when I asked him how he was going to earn his bread, he actually wanted to learn to shudder."

sentence: If that be all, replied the sexton, "he can learn that with me.

author: Grimms
sentence: The sexton therefore took him into his house, and he had to ring the church bell.

author: Grimms
sentence: You shall soon learn what shuddering is, thought he, and secretly went there before him; and when the boy was at the top of the tower and turned round, and was just going to take hold of the bell rope, he saw a white figure standing on the stairs opposite the sounding hole.

author: Grimms
sentence: Who is there? cried he, but the figure made no reply, and did not move or stir.

author: Grimms
sentence: Give an answer, cried the boy, "or take yourself off, you have no business here at night."

author: Grimms
sentence: The sexton, however, remained standing motionless that the boy might think he was a ghost.

sentence: The boy cried a second time: "What do you want here?--speak if you are an honest fellow, or I will throw you down the steps!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The sexton thought: "He can"t mean to be as bad as his words," uttered no sound and stood as if he were made of stone.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the boy called to him for the third time, and as that was also to no purpose, he ran against him and pushed the ghost down the stairs, so that it fell down the ten steps and remained lying there in a corner.

author: Grimms

sentence: The sexton"s wife waited a long time for her husband, but he did not come back.

sentence: At length she became uneasy, and wakened the boy, and asked: "Do you know where my husband is?

author: Grimms
sentence: No, I dont know," replied the boy, "but someone was standing by the sounding hole on the other side of the steps, and as he would neither gave an answer nor go away, I took him for a scoundrel, and threw him downstairs.

sentence: Just go there and you will see if it was he.

sentence: I should be sorry if it were."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the day dawned, therefore, the boy put his fifty talers into his pocket, and went forth on the great highway, and continually said to himself: "If I could but shudder!

author: Grimms
sentence: If I could but shudder!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then a man approached who heard this conversation which the youth was holding with himself, and when they had walked a little farther to where they could see the gallows, the man said to him: "Look, there is the tree where seven men have married the ropemaker"s daughter, and are now learning how to fly.

author: Grimms
sentence: Sit down beneath it, and wait till night comes, and you will soon learn how to shudder."

sentence: If that is all that is wanted, answered the youth, "it is easily done; but if I learn how to shudder as fast as that, you shall have my fifty talers.

sentence: Then the youth went to the gallows, sat down beneath it, and waited till evening came.

author: Grimms
sentence: And as he was cold, he lighted himself a fire, but at midnight the wind blew so sharply that in spite of his fire, he could not get warm.

author: Grimms
sentence: And as the wind knocked the hanged men against each other, and they moved backwards and forwards, he thought to himself: "If you shiver below by the fire, how those up above must freeze and suffer!"

author: Grimms
sentence: And as he felt pity for them, he raised the ladder, and climbed up, unbound one of them after the other, and brought down all seven.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the man saw that he would not get the fifty talers that day, and went away saying: "Such a youth has never come my way before."

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth likewise went his way, and once more began to mutter to himself: "Ah, if I could but shudder!

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, if I could but shudder!"

author: Grimms
sentence: A waggoner who was striding behind him heard this and asked: "Who are you?"

author: Grimms
sentence: I dont know," answered the youth.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the waggoner asked: "From whence do you come?"

author: Grimms
sentence: I know not.

author: Grimms
sentence: Who is your father?

author: Grimms
sentence: That I may not tell you.

author: Grimms
sentence: What is it that you are always muttering between your teeth?

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, replied the youth, "I do so wish I could shudder, but no one can teach me how."

author: Grimms
sentence: Enough of your foolish chatter, said the waggoner.

author: Grimms
sentence: Come, go with me, I will see about a place for you.

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth went with the waggoner, and in the evening they arrived at an inn where they wished to pass the night.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then at the entrance of the parlour the youth again said quite loudly: "If I could but shudder!

author: Grimms
sentence: If I could but shudder!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The host who heard this, laughed and said: "If that is your desire, there ought to be a good opportunity for you here."

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, be silent, said the hostess, "so many prying persons have already lost their lives, it would be a pity and a shame if such beautiful eyes as these should never see the daylight again."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the youth said: "However difficult it may be, I will learn it.

author: Grimms
sentence: For this purpose indeed have I journeyed forth."

author: Grimms
sentence: He let the host have no rest, until the latter told him, that not far from thence stood a haunted castle where anyone could very easily learn what shuddering was, if he would but watch in it for three nights.

author: Grimms
sentence: The king had promised that he who would venture should have his daughter to wife, and she was the most beautiful maiden the sun shone on.

author: Grimms
sentence: Likewise in the castle lay great treasures, which were guarded by evil spirits, and these treasures would then be freed, and would make a poor man rich enough.

author: Grimms
sentence: Already many men had gone into the castle, but as yet none had come out again.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the youth went next morning to the king, and said: "If it be allowed, I will willingly watch three nights in the haunted castle."

author: Grimms
sentence: The king looked at him, and as the youth pleased him, he said: "You may ask for three things to take into the castle with you, but they must be things without life."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he answered: "Then I ask for a fire, a turning lathe, and a cutting-board with the knife."

author: Grimms
sentence: The king had these things carried into the castle for him during the day.

author: Grimms
sentence: When night was drawing near, the youth went up and made himself a bright fire in one of the rooms, placed the cutting-board and knife beside it, and seated himself by the turning-lathe.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, if I could but shudder! said he, "but I shall not learn it here either."

author: Grimms
sentence: Towards midnight he was about to poke his fire, and as he was blowing it, something cried suddenly from one corner: "Au, miau! how cold we are!"

author: Grimms
sentence: You fools! cried he, "what are you crying about?

author: Grimms
sentence: If you are cold, come and take a seat by the fire and warm yourselves."

author: Grimms
sentence: And when he had said that, two great black cats came with one tremendous leap and sat down on each side of him, and looked savagely at him with their fiery eyes.

author: Grimms
sentence: After a short time, when they had warmed themselves, they said: "Comrade, shall we have a game of cards?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Why not? he replied, "but just show me your paws."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they stretched out their claws.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, said he, "what long nails you have!

author: Grimms
sentence: Wait, I must first cut them for you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon he seized them by the throats, put them on the cutting-board and screwed their feet fast.

author: Grimms
sentence: I have looked at your fingers, said he, "and my fancy for card-playing has gone," and he struck them dead and threw them out into the water.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when he had made away with these two, and was about to sit down again by his fire, out from every hole and corner came black cats and black dogs with red-hot chains, and more and more of them came until he could no longer move, and they yelled horribly, and got on his fire, pulled it to pieces, and tried to put it out.

author: Grimms
sentence: He watched them for a while quietly, but at last when they were going too far, he seized his cutting-knife, and cried: "Away with you, vermin," and began to cut them down.

author: Grimms
sentence: Some of them ran away, the others he killed, and threw out into the fish-pond.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he came back he fanned the embers of his fire again and warmed himself.

author: Grimms
sentence: And as he thus sat, his eyes would keep open no longer, and he felt a desire to sleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he looked round and saw a great bed in the corner.

author: Grimms
sentence: That is the very thing for me, said he, and got into it.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he was just going to shut his eyes, however, the bed began to move of its own accord, and went over the whole of the castle.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thats right," said he, "but go faster."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the bed rolled on as if six horses were harnessed to it, up and down, over thresholds and stairs, but suddenly hop, hop, it turned over upside down, and lay on him like a mountain.

author: Grimms
sentence: But he threw quilts and pillows up in the air, got out and said: "Now anyone who likes, may drive," and lay down by his fire, and slept till it was day.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the morning the king came, and when he saw him lying there on the ground, he thought the evil spirits had killed him and he was dead.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said he: "After all it is a pity,--for so handsome a man."

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth heard it, got up, and said: "It has not come to that yet."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the king was astonished, but very glad, and asked how he had fared.

author: Grimms
sentence: Very well indeed, answered he; "one night is past, the two others will pass likewise."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he went to the innkeeper, who opened his eyes very wide, and said: "I never expected to see you alive again!

author: Grimms
sentence: Have you learnt how to shudder yet?"

author: Grimms
sentence: No, said he, "it is all in vain.

author: Grimms
sentence: If someone would but tell me!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The second night he again went up into the old castle, sat down by the fire, and once more began his old song: "If I could but shudder!"

author: Grimms
sentence: When midnight came, an uproar and noise of tumbling about was heard; at first it was low, but it grew louder and louder.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then it was quiet for a while, and at length with a loud scream, half a man came down the chimney and fell before him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hullo! cried he, "another half belongs to this.

author: Grimms
sentence: This is not enough!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the uproar began again, there was a roaring and howling, and the other half fell down likewise.

author: Grimms
sentence: Wait, said he, "I will just stoke up the fire a little for you."

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had done that and looked round again, the two pieces were joined together, and a hideous man was sitting in his place.

author: Grimms
sentence: That is no part of our bargain, said the youth, "the bench is mine."

author: Grimms
sentence: The man wanted to push him away; the youth, however, would not allow that, but thrust him off with all his strength, and seated himself again in his own place.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then still more men fell down, one after the other; they brought nine dead men"s legs and two skulls, and set them up and played at nine-pins with them.

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth also wanted to play and said: "Listen you, can I join you?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, if you have any money.

author: Grimms
sentence: Money enough, replied he, "but your balls are not quite round."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he took the skulls and put them in the lathe and turned them till they were round.

author: Grimms
sentence: There, now they will roll better! said he.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hurrah! now well have fun!"

author: Grimms
sentence: He played with them and lost some of his money, but when it struck twelve, everything vanished from his sight.

author: Grimms
sentence: He lay down and quietly fell asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next morning the king came to inquire after him.

author: Grimms
sentence: How has it fared with you this time? asked he.

author: Grimms
sentence: I have been playing at ninepins, he answered, "and have lost a couple of farthings."

author: Grimms
sentence: Have you not shuddered then?

author: Grimms
sentence: What? said he, "I have had a wonderful time!

author: Grimms
sentence: If I did but know what it was to shudder!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The third night he sat down again on his bench and said quite sadly: "If I could but shudder."

author: Grimms
sentence: When it grew late, six tall men came in and brought a coffin.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he said: "Ha, ha, that is certainly my little cousin, who died only a few days ago," and he beckoned with his finger, and cried: "Come, little cousin, come."

author: Grimms
sentence: They placed the coffin on the ground, but he went to it and took the lid off, and a dead man lay therein.

author: Grimms
sentence: He felt his face, but it was cold as ice.

author: Grimms
sentence: Wait, said he, "I will warm you a little," and went to the fire and warmed his hand and laid it on the dead man"s face, but he remained cold.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he took him out, and sat down by the fire and laid him on his breast and rubbed his arms that the blood might circulate again.

author: Grimms
sentence: As this also did no good, he thought to himself: "When two people lie in bed together, they warm each other," and carried him to the bed, covered him over and lay down by him.

author: Grimms
sentence: After a short time the dead man became warm too, and began to move.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the youth, "See, little cousin, have I not warmed you?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The dead man, however, got up and cried: "Now will I strangle you."

author: Grimms
sentence: What! said he, "is that the way you thank me?

author: Grimms
sentence: You shall at once go into your coffin again," and he took him up, threw him into it, and shut the lid.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then came the six men and carried him away again.

author: Grimms
sentence: I cannot manage to shudder, said he.

author: Grimms
sentence: I shall never learn it here as long as I live.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then a man entered who was taller than all others, and looked terrible.

author: Grimms
sentence: He was old, however, and had a long white beard.

author: Grimms
sentence: You wretch, cried he, "you shall soon learn what it is to shudder, for you shall die."

author: Grimms
sentence: Not so fast, replied the youth.

author: Grimms
sentence: If I am to die, I shall have to have a say in it.

author: Grimms
sentence: I will soon seize you, said the fiend.

author: Grimms
sentence:
Softly, softly, do not talk so big.
184:184	A:N	A:F	I am as strong as you are, and perhaps even stronger.

author: Grimms
sentence: We shall see, said the old man.

author: Grimms
sentence: If you are stronger, I will let you go--come, we will try.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he led him by dark passages to a smith"s forge, took an axe, and with one blow struck an anvil into the ground.

author: Grimms
sentence: I can do better than that, said the youth, and went to the other anvil.

author: Grimms
sentence: The old man placed himself near and wanted to look on, and his white beard hung down.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the youth seized the axe, split the anvil with one blow, and in it caught the old man"s beard.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now I have you, said the youth.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now it is your turn to die.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he seized an iron bar and beat the old man till he moaned and entreated him to stop, when he would give him great riches.

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth drew out the axe and let him go.

author: Grimms
sentence: The old man led him back into the castle, and in a cellar showed him three chests full of gold.

author: Grimms
sentence: Of these, said he, "one part is for the poor, the other for the king, the third yours."

author: Grimms
sentence: In the meantime it struck twelve, and the spirit disappeared, so that the youth stood in darkness.

author: Grimms
sentence: I shall still be able to find my way out, said he, and felt about, found the way into the room, and slept there by his fire.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next morning the king came and said: "Now you must have learnt what shuddering is?"

author: Grimms
sentence: No, he answered; "what can it be?

author: Grimms
sentence: My dead cousin was here, and a bearded man came and showed me a great deal of money down below, but no one told me what it was to shudder."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then, said the king, "you have saved the castle, and shall marry my daughter."

author: Grimms
sentence: That is all very well, said he, "but still I do not know what it is to shudder!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the gold was brought up and the wedding celebrated; but howsoever much the young king loved his wife, and however happy he was, he still said always: "If I could but shudder--if I could but shudder."

author: Grimms
sentence: And this at last angered her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Her waiting-maid said: "I will find a cure for him; he shall soon learn what it is to shudder."

author: Grimms
sentence: She went out to the stream which flowed through the garden, and had a whole bucketful of gudgeons brought to her.

author: Grimms
sentence: At night when the young king was sleeping, his wife was to draw the clothes off him and empty the bucket full of cold water with the gudgeons in it over him, so that the little fishes would sprawl about him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he woke up and cried: "Oh, what makes me shudder so?-- what makes me shudder so, dear wife?

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah! now I know what it is to shudder!"

author: Grimms
sentence: In a village dwelt a poor old woman, who had gathered together a dish of beans and wanted to cook them.

author: Grimms
sentence: So she made a fire on her hearth, and that it might burn the quicker, she lighted it with a handful of straw.

author: Grimms
sentence: When she was emptying the beans into the pan, one dropped without her observing it, and lay on the ground beside a straw, and soon afterwards a burning coal from the fire leapt down to the two.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the straw began and said: "Dear friends, from whence do you come here?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The coal replied: "I fortunately sprang out of the fire, and if I had not escaped by sheer force, my death would have been certain,--I should have been burnt to ashes."

author: Grimms
sentence: The bean said: "I too have escaped with a whole skin, but if the old woman had got me into the pan, I should have been made into broth without any mercy, like my comrades."

author: Grimms
sentence: And would a better fate have fallen to my lot? said the straw.

author: Grimms
sentence:
The old woman has destroyed all my brethren in fire and smoke; she seized sixty of them at once, and took their lives.
8:8	H:H	S:H	I luckily slipped through her fingers.

author: Grimms
sentence: But what are we to do now? said the coal.

author: Grimms
sentence: I think, answered the bean, "that as we have so fortunately escaped death, we should keep together like good companions, and lest a new mischance should overtake us here, we should go away together, and repair to a foreign country."

author: Grimms
sentence: The proposition pleased the two others, and they set out on their way together.

author: Grimms
sentence: Soon, however, they came to a little brook, and as there was no bridge or foot-plank, they did not know how they were to get over it.

author: Grimms
sentence: The straw hit on a good idea, and said: "I will lay myself straight across, and then you can walk over on me as on a bridge."

author: Grimms
sentence: The straw therefore stretched itself from one bank to the other, and the coal, who was of an impetuous disposition, tripped quite boldly on to the newly-built bridge.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when she had reached the middle, and heard the water rushing beneath her, she was after all, afraid, and stood still, and ventured no farther.

author: Grimms
sentence: The straw, however, began to burn, broke in two pieces, and fell into the stream.

author: Grimms
sentence: The coal slipped after her, hissed when she got into the water, and breathed her last.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bean, who had prudently stayed behind on the shore, could not but laugh at the event, was unable to stop, and laughed so heartily that she burst.

author: Grimms
sentence: It would have been all over with her, likewise, if, by good fortune, a tailor who was travelling in search of work, had not sat down to rest by the brook.

author: Grimms
sentence: As he had a compassionate heart he pulled out his needle and thread, and sewed her together.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bean thanked him most prettily, but as the tailor used black thread, all beans since then have a black seam.

author: Grimms
sentence: An aged count once lived in Switzerland, who had an only son, but he was stupid, and could learn nothing.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then said the father: "Hark you, my son, try as I will I can get nothing into your head.

author: Grimms
sentence: You must go from hence, I will give you into the care of a celebrated master, who shall see what he can do with you."

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth was sent into a strange town, and remained a whole year with the master.

author: Grimms
sentence: At the end of this time, he came home again, and his father asked: "Now, my son, what have you learnt?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Father, I have learnt what the dogs say when they bark.

author: Grimms
sentence: Lord have mercy on us! cried the father; "is that all you have learnt?

author: Grimms
sentence: I will send you into another town, to another master."

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth was taken thither, and stayed a year with this master likewise.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he came back the father again asked: "My son, what have you learnt?"

author: Grimms
sentence: He answered: "Father, I have learnt what the birds say."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the father fell into a rage and said: "Oh, you lost man, you have spent the precious time and learnt nothing; are you not ashamed to appear before my eyes?

author: Grimms
sentence: I will send you to a third master, but if you learn nothing this time also, I will no longer be your father."

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth remained a whole year with the third master also, and when he came home again, and his father inquired: "My son, what have you learnt?" he answered: "Dear father, I have this year learnt what the frogs croak."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the father fell into the most furious anger, sprang up, called his people thither, and said: "This man is no longer my son, I drive him forth, and command you to take him out into the forest, and kill him."

author: Grimms
sentence: They took him forth, but when they should have killed him, they could not do it for pity, and let him go, and they cut the eyes and tongue out of a deer that they might carry them to the old man as a token.

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth wandered on, and after some time came to a fortress where he begged for a night"s lodging.

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said the lord of the castle, "if you will pass the night down there in the old tower, go thither; but I warn you, it is at the peril of your life, for it is full of wild dogs, which bark and howl without stopping, and at certain hours a man has to be given to them, whom they at once devour."

author: Grimms
sentence: The whole district was in sorrow and dismay because of them, and yet no one could do anything to stop this.

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth, however, was without fear, and said: "Just let me go down to the barking dogs, and give me something that I can throw to them; they will do nothing to harm me."

author: Grimms
sentence: As he himself would have it so, they gave him some food for the wild animals, and led him down to the tower.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he went inside, the dogs did not bark at him, but wagged their tails quite amicably around him, ate what he set before them, and did not hurt one hair of his head.

author: Grimms
sentence: Next morning, to the astonishment of everyone, he came out again safe and unharmed, and said to the lord of the castle: "The dogs have revealed to me, in their own language, why they dwell there, and bring evil on the land.

author: Grimms
sentence: They are bewitched, and are obliged to watch over a great treasure which is below in the tower, and they can have no rest until it is taken away, and I have likewise learnt, from their discourse, how that is to be done."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then all who heard this rejoiced, and the lord of the castle said he would adopt him as a son if he accomplished it successfully.

author: Grimms
sentence: He went down again, and as he knew what he had to do, he did it thoroughly, and brought a chest full of gold out with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: The howling of the wild dogs was henceforth heard no more; they had disappeared, and the country was freed from the trouble.

author: Grimms
sentence: After some time he took it in his head that he would travel to Rome.

author: Grimms
sentence: On the way he passed by a marsh, in which a number of frogs were sitting croaking.

author: Grimms
sentence: He listened to them, and when he became aware of what they were saying, he grew very thoughtful and sad.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last he arrived in Rome, where the Pope had just died, and there was great doubt among the cardinals as to whom they should appoint as his successor.

author: Grimms
sentence: They at length agreed that the person should be chosen as pope who should be distinguished by some divine and miraculous token.

author: Grimms
sentence: And just as that was decided on, the young count entered into the church, and suddenly two snow-white doves flew on his shoulders and remained sitting there.

author: Grimms
sentence: The ecclesiastics recognized therein the token from above, and asked him on the spot if he would be pope.

author: Grimms
sentence: He was undecided, and knew not if he were worthy of this, but the doves counselled him to do it, and at length he said yes.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then was he anointed and consecrated, and thus was fulfilled what he had heard from the frogs on his way, which had so affected him, that he was to be his Holiness the Pope.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he had to sing a mass, and did not know one word of it, but the two doves sat continually on his shoulders, and said it all in his ear.

author: Grimms
sentence: An honest farmer had once an ass that had been a faithful servant to him a great many years, but was now growing old and every day more and more unfit for work.

author: Grimms
sentence: His master therefore was tired of keeping him and began to think of putting an end to him; but the ass, who saw that some mischief was in the wind, took himself slyly off, and began his journey towards the great city, "For there," thought he, "I may turn musician."

author: Grimms
sentence: After he had travelled a little way, he spied a dog lying by the roadside and panting as if he were tired.

author: Grimms
sentence: What makes you pant so, my friend? said the ass.

author: Grimms
sentence: Alas! said the dog, "my master was going to knock me on the head, because I am old and weak, and can no longer make myself useful to him in hunting; so I ran away; but what can I do to earn my livelihood?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Hark ye! said the ass, "I am going to the great city to turn musician: suppose you go with me, and try what you can do in the same way?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The dog said he was willing, and they jogged on together.

author: Grimms
sentence: They had not gone far before they saw a cat sitting in the middle of the road and making a most rueful face.

author: Grimms
sentence: Pray, my good lady, said the ass, "what"s the matter with you?

author: Grimms
sentence: You look quite out of spirits!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, me! said the cat, "how can one be in good spirits when one"s life is in danger?

author: Grimms
sentence: Because I am beginning to grow old, and had rather lie at my ease by the fire than run about the house after the mice, my mistress laid hold of me, and was going to drown me; and though I have been lucky enough to get away from her, I do not know what I am to live upon."

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, said the ass, "by all means go with us to the great city; you are a good night singer, and may make your fortune as a musician."

author: Grimms
sentence: The cat was pleased with the thought, and joined the party.

author: Grimms
sentence: Soon afterwards, as they were passing by a farmyard, they saw a cock perched upon a gate, and screaming out with all his might and main.

author: Grimms
sentence: Bravo! said the ass; "upon my word, you make a famous noise; pray what is all this about?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Why, said the cock, "I was just now saying that we should have fine weather for our washing-day, and yet my mistress and the cook don"t thank me for my pains, but threaten to cut off my head tomorrow, and make broth of me for the guests that are coming on Sunday!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Heaven forbid! said the ass, "come with us Master Chanticleer; it will be better, at any rate, than staying here to have your head cut off!

author: Grimms
sentence: Besides, who knows?

author: Grimms
sentence: If we care to sing in tune, we may get up some kind of a concert; so come along with us."

author: Grimms
sentence: With all my heart, said the cock: so they all four went on jollily together.

author: Grimms
sentence: They could not, however, reach the great city the first day; so when night came on, they went into a wood to sleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: The ass and the dog laid themselves down under a great tree, and the cat climbed up into the branches; while the cock, thinking that the higher he sat the safer he should be, flew up to the very top of the tree, and then, according to his custom, before he went to sleep, looked out on all sides of him to see that everything was well.

author: Grimms
sentence: In doing this, he saw afar off something bright and shining and calling to his companions said, "There must be a house no great way off, for I see a light."

author: Grimms
sentence: If that be the case, said the ass, "we had better change our quarters, for our lodging is not the best in the world!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Besides, added the dog, "I should not be the worse for a bone or two, or a bit of meat."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they walked off together towards the spot where Chanticleer had seen the light, and as they drew near it became larger and brighter, till they at last came close to a house in which a gang of robbers lived.

author: Grimms
sentence: The ass, being the tallest of the company, marched up to the window and peeped in.

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, Donkey, said Chanticleer, "what do you see?"

author: Grimms
sentence: What do I see? replied the ass.

author: Grimms
sentence: Why, I see a table spread with all kinds of good things, and robbers sitting round it making merry.

author: Grimms
sentence: That would be a noble lodging for us, said the cock.

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said the ass, "if we could only get in"; so they consulted together how they should contrive to get the robbers out; and at last they hit upon a plan.

author: Grimms
sentence: The ass placed himself upright on his hind legs, with his forefeet resting against the window; the dog got upon his back; the cat scrambled up to the dog"s shoulders, and the cock flew up and sat upon the cat"s head.

author: Grimms
sentence: When all was ready a signal was given, and they began their music.

author: Grimms
sentence: The ass brayed, the dog barked, the cat mewed, and the cock screamed; and then they all broke through the window at once, and came tumbling into the room, amongst the broken glass, with a most hideous clatter!

author: Grimms
sentence: The robbers, who had been not a little frightened by the opening concert, had now no doubt that some frightful hobgoblin had broken in upon them, and scampered away as fast as they could.

author: Grimms
sentence: The coast once clear, our travellers soon sat down and dispatched what the robbers had left, with as much eagerness as if they had not expected to eat again for a month.

author: Grimms
sentence: As soon as they had satisfied themselves, they put out the lights, and each once more sought out a resting-place to his own liking.

author: Grimms
sentence: The donkey laid himself down upon a heap of straw in the yard, the dog stretched himself upon a mat behind the door, the cat rolled herself up on the hearth before the warm ashes, and the cock perched upon a beam on the top of the house; and, as they were all rather tired with their journey, they soon fell asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: But about midnight, when the robbers saw from afar that the lights were out and that all seemed quiet, they began to think that they had been in too great a hurry to run away; and one of them, who was bolder than the rest, went to see what was going on.

author: Grimms
sentence: Finding everything still, he marched into the kitchen, and groped about till he found a match in order to light a candle; and then, espying the glittering fiery eyes of the cat, he mistook them for live coals, and held the match to them to light it.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the cat, not understanding this joke, sprang at his face, and spat, and scratched at him.

author: Grimms
sentence: This frightened him dreadfully, and away he ran to the back door; but there the dog jumped up and bit him in the leg; and as he was crossing over the yard the ass kicked him; and the cock, who had been awakened by the noise, crowed with all his might.

author: Grimms
sentence: At this the robber ran back as fast as he could to his comrades, and told the captain how a horrid witch had got into the house, and had spat at him and scratched his face with her long bony fingers; how a man with a knife in his hand had hidden himself behind the door, and stabbed him in the leg; how a black monster stood in the yard and struck him with a club, and how the devil had sat upon the top of the house and cried out, "Throw the rascal up here!"

author: Grimms
sentence: After this the robbers never dared to go back to the house; but the musicians were so pleased with their quarters that they took up their abode there; and there they are, I dare say, at this very day.

author: Grimms
sentence: There were two brothers who were both soldiers; the one was rich and the other poor.

author: Grimms
sentence: The poor man thought he would try to better himself; so, pulling off his red coat, he became a gardener, and dug his ground well, and sowed turnips.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the seed came up, there was one plant bigger than all the rest; and it kept getting larger and larger, and seemed as if it would never cease growing; so that it might have been called the prince of turnips for there never was such a one seen before, and never will again.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last it was so big that it filled a cart, and two oxen could hardly draw it; and the gardener knew not what in the world to do with it, nor whether it would be a blessing or a curse to him.

author: Grimms
sentence: One day he said to himself, "What shall I do with it? if I sell it, it will bring no more than another; and for eating, the little turnips are better than this; the best thing perhaps is to carry it and give it to the king as a mark of respect."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he yoked his oxen, and drew the turnip to the court, and gave it to the king.

author: Grimms
sentence: What a wonderful thing! said the king; "I have seen many strange things, but such a monster as this I never saw.

author: Grimms
sentence: Where did you get the seed? or is it only your good luck?

author: Grimms
sentence: If so, you are a true child of fortune."

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, no! answered the gardener, "I am no child of fortune; I am a poor soldier, who never could get enough to live upon; so I laid aside my red coat, and set to work, tilling the ground.

author: Grimms
sentence: I have a brother, who is rich, and your majesty knows him well, and all the world knows him; but because I am poor, everybody forgets me."

author: Grimms
sentence: The king then took pity on him, and said, "You shall be poor no longer.

author: Grimms
sentence: I will give you so much that you shall be even richer than your brother."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he gave him gold and lands and flocks, and made him so rich that his brother"s fortune could not at all be compared with his.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the brother heard of all this, and how a turnip had made the gardener so rich, he envied him sorely, and bethought himself how he could contrive to get the same good fortune for himself.

author: Grimms
sentence: However, he determined to manage more cleverly than his brother, and got together a rich present of gold and fine horses for the king; and thought he must have a much larger gift in return; for if his brother had received so much for only a turnip, what must his present be wroth?

author: Grimms
sentence: The king took the gift very graciously, and said he knew not what to give in return more valuable and wonderful than the great turnip; so the soldier was forced to put it into a cart, and drag it home with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he reached home, he knew not upon whom to vent his rage and spite; and at length wicked thoughts came into his head, and he resolved to kill his brother.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he hired some villains to murder him; and having shown them where to lie in ambush, he went to his brother, and said, "Dear brother, I have found a hidden treasure; let us go and dig it up, and share it between us."

author: Grimms
sentence: The other had no suspicions of his roguery: so they went out together, and as they were travelling along, the murderers rushed out upon him, bound him, and were going to hang him on a tree.

author: Grimms
sentence: But whilst they were getting all ready, they heard the trampling of a horse at a distance, which so frightened them that they pushed their prisoner neck and shoulders together into a sack, and swung him up by a cord to the tree, where they left him dangling, and ran away.

author: Grimms
sentence: Meantime he worked and worked away, till he made a hole large enough to put out his head.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the horseman came up, he proved to be a student, a merry fellow, who was journeying along on his nag, and singing as he went.

author: Grimms
sentence: As soon as the man in the sack saw him passing under the tree, he cried out, "Good morning! good morning to thee, my friend!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The student looked about everywhere; and seeing no one, and not knowing where the voice came from, cried out, "Who calls me?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the man in the tree answered, "Lift up thine eyes, for behold here I sit in the sack of wisdom; here have I, in a short time, learned great and wondrous things.

author: Grimms
sentence: Compared to this seat, all the learning of the schools is as empty air.

author: Grimms
sentence: A little longer, and I shall know all that man can know, and shall come forth wiser than the wisest of mankind.

author: Grimms
sentence: Here I discern the signs and motions of the heavens and the stars; the laws that control the winds; the number of the sands on the seashore; the healing of the sick; the virtues of all simples, of birds, and of precious stones.

author: Grimms
sentence: Wert thou but once here, my friend, though wouldst feel and own the power of knowledge.

author: Grimms
sentence: The student listened to all this and wondered much; at last he said, "Blessed be the day and hour when I found you; cannot you contrive to let me into the sack for a little while?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the other answered, as if very unwillingly, "A little space I may allow thee to sit here, if thou wilt reward me well and entreat me kindly; but thou must tarry yet an hour below, till I have learnt some little matters that are yet unknown to me."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the student sat himself down and waited a while; but the time hung heavy upon him, and he begged earnestly that he might ascend forthwith, for his thirst for knowledge was great.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the other pretended to give way, and said, "Thou must let the sack of wisdom descend, by untying yonder cord, and then thou shalt enter."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the student let him down, opened the sack, and set him free.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now then, cried he, "let me ascend quickly."

author: Grimms
sentence: As he began to put himself into the sack heels first, "Wait a while," said the gardener, "that is not the way."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he pushed him in head first, tied up the sack, and soon swung up the searcher after wisdom dangling in the air.

author: Grimms
sentence: How is it with thee, friend? said he, "dost thou not feel that wisdom comes unto thee?

author: Grimms
sentence: Rest there in peace, till thou art a wiser man than thou wert."

author: Grimms
sentence: So saying, he trotted off on the student"s nag, and left the poor fellow to gather wisdom till somebody should come and let him down.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was a king who had twelve beautiful daughters.

author: Grimms
sentence: They slept in twelve beds all in one room; and when they went to bed, the doors were shut and locked up; but every morning their shoes were found to be quite worn through as if they had been danced in all night; and yet nobody could find out how it happened, or where they had been.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the king made it known to all the land, that if any person could discover the secret, and find out where it was that the princesses danced in the night, he should have the one he liked best for his wife, and should be king after his death; but whoever tried and did not succeed, after three days and nights, should be put to death.

author: Grimms
sentence: A king"s son soon came.

author: Grimms
sentence: He was well entertained, and in the evening was taken to the chamber next to the one where the princesses lay in their twelve beds.

author: Grimms
sentence: There he was to sit and watch where they went to dance; and, in order that nothing might pass without his hearing it, the door of his chamber was left open.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the king"s son soon fell asleep; and when he awoke in the morning he found that the princesses had all been dancing, for the soles of their shoes were full of holes.

author: Grimms
sentence: The same thing happened the second and third night: so the king ordered his head to be cut off.

author: Grimms
sentence: After him came several others; but they had all the same luck, and all lost their lives in the same manner.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now it chanced that an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer, passed through the country where this king reigned: and as he was travelling through a wood, he met an old woman, who asked him where he was going.

author: Grimms
sentence: I hardly know where I am going, or what I had better do, said the soldier; "but I think I should like very well to find out where it is that the princesses dance, and then in time I might be a king."

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, said the old dame, "that is no very hard task: only take care not to drink any of the wine which one of the princesses will bring to you in the evening; and as soon as she leaves you pretend to be fast asleep."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she gave him a cloak, and said, "As soon as you put that on you will become invisible, and you will then be able to follow the princesses wherever they go."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the soldier heard all this good counsel, he determined to try his luck: so he went to the king, and said he was willing to undertake the task.

author: Grimms
sentence: He was as well received as the others had been, and the king ordered fine royal robes to be given him; and when the evening came he was led to the outer chamber.

author: Grimms
sentence: Just as he was going to lie down, the eldest of the princesses brought him a cup of wine; but the soldier threw it all away secretly, taking care not to drink a drop.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he laid himself down on his bed, and in a little while began to snore very loud as if he was fast asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the twelve princesses heard this they laughed heartily; and the eldest said, "This fellow too might have done a wiser thing than lose his life in this way!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they rose up and opened their drawers and boxes, and took out all their fine clothes, and dressed themselves at the glass, and skipped about as if they were eager to begin dancing.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the youngest said, "I don"t know how it is, while you are so happy I feel very uneasy; I am sure some mischance will befall us."

author: Grimms
sentence: You simpleton, said the eldest, "you are always afraid; have you forgotten how many kings" sons have already watched in vain?

author: Grimms
sentence: And as for this soldier, even if I had not given him his sleeping draught, he would have slept soundly enough."

author: Grimms
sentence: When they were all ready, they went and looked at the soldier; but he snored on, and did not stir hand or foot: so they thought they were quite safe; and the eldest went up to her own bed and clapped her hands, and the bed sank into the floor and a trap-door flew open.

author: Grimms
sentence: The soldier saw them going down through the trap-door one after another, the eldest leading the way; and thinking he had no time to lose, he jumped up, put on the cloak which the old woman had given him, and followed them; but in the middle of the stairs he trod on the gown of the youngest princess, and she cried out to her sisters, "All is not right; someone took hold of my gown."

author: Grimms
sentence: You silly creature! said the eldest, "it is nothing but a nail in the wall."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then down they all went, and at the bottom they found themselves in a most delightful grove of trees; and the leaves were all of silver, and glittered and sparkled beautifully.

author: Grimms
sentence: The soldier wished to take away some token of the place; so he broke off a little branch, and there came a loud noise from the tree.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the youngest daughter said again, "I am sure all is not right--did not you hear that noise?

author: Grimms
sentence: That never happened before."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the eldest said, "It is only our princes, who are shouting for joy at our approach."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they came to another grove of trees, where all the leaves were of gold; and afterwards to a third, where the leaves were all glittering diamonds.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the soldier broke a branch from each; and every time there was a loud noise, which made the youngest sister tremble with fear; but the eldest still said, it was only the princes, who were crying for joy.

author: Grimms
sentence: So they went on till they came to a great lake; and at the side of the lake there lay twelve little boats with twelve handsome princes in them, who seemed to be waiting there for the princesses.

author: Grimms
sentence: One of the princesses went into each boat, and the soldier stepped into the same boat with the youngest.

author: Grimms
sentence: As they were rowing over the lake, the prince who was in the boat with the youngest princess and the soldier said, "I do not know why it is, but though I am rowing with all my might we do not get on so fast as usual, and I am quite tired: the boat seems very heavy today."

author: Grimms
sentence: It is only the heat of the weather, said the princess: "I feel it very warm too."

author: Grimms
sentence: On the other side of the lake stood a fine illuminated castle, from which came the merry music of horns and trumpets.

author: Grimms
sentence: There they all landed, and went into the castle, and each prince danced with his princess; and the soldier, who was all the time invisible, danced with them too; and when any of the princesses had a cup of wine set by her, he drank it all up, so that when she put the cup to her mouth it was empty.

author: Grimms
sentence: At this, too, the youngest sister was terribly frightened, but the eldest always silenced her.

author: Grimms
sentence: They danced on till three o"clock in the morning, and then all their shoes were worn out, so that they were obliged to leave off.

author: Grimms
sentence: The princes rowed them back again over the lake (but this time the soldier placed himself in the boat with the eldest princess); and on the opposite shore they took leave of each other, the princesses promising to come again the next night.

author: Grimms
sentence: When they came to the stairs, the soldier ran on before the princesses, and laid himself down; and as the twelve sisters slowly came up very much tired, they heard him snoring in his bed; so they said, "Now all is quite safe"; then they undressed themselves, put away their fine clothes, pulled off their shoes, and went to bed.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the morning the soldier said nothing about what had happened, but determined to see more of this strange adventure, and went again the second and third night; and every thing happened just as before; the princesses danced each time till their shoes were worn to pieces, and then returned home.

author: Grimms
sentence: However, on the third night the soldier carried away one of the golden cups as a token of where he had been.

author: Grimms
sentence: As soon as the time came when he was to declare the secret, he was taken before the king with the three branches and the golden cup; and the twelve princesses stood listening behind the door to hear what he would say.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when the king asked him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Where do my twelve daughters dance at night? he answered, "With twelve princes in a castle under ground."

author: Grimms
sentence: And then he told the king all that had happened, and showed him the three branches and the golden cup which he had brought with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the king called for the princesses, and asked them whether what the soldier said was true: and when they saw that they were discovered, and that it was of no use to deny what had happened, they confessed it all.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the king asked the soldier which of them he would choose for his wife; and he answered, "I am not very young, so I will have the eldest."--And they were married that very day, and the soldier was chosen to be the king"s heir.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once a king"s son who had a bride whom he loved very much.

author: Grimms
sentence: And when he was sitting beside her and very happy, news came that his father lay sick unto death, and desired to see him once again before his end.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he said to his beloved: "I must now go and leave you, I give you a ring as a remembrance of me.

author: Grimms
sentence: When I am king, I will return and fetch you."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he rode away, and when he reached his father, the latter was dangerously ill, and near his death.

author: Grimms
sentence: He said to him: "Dear son, I wished to see you once again before my end, promise me to marry as I wish," and he named a certain king"s daughter who was to be his wife.

author: Grimms
sentence: The son was in such trouble that he did not think what he was doing, and said: "Yes, dear father, your will shall be done," and thereupon the king shut his eyes, and died.

author: Grimms
sentence: When therefore the son had been proclaimed king, and the time of mourning was over, he was forced to keep the promise which he had given his father, and caused the king"s daughter to be asked in marriage, and she was promised to him.

author: Grimms
sentence: His first betrothed heard of this, and fretted so much about his faithfulness that she nearly died.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then her father said to her: "Dearest child, why are you so sad?

author: Grimms
sentence: You shall have whatsoever you will."

author: Grimms
sentence: She thought for a moment and said: "Dear father, I wish for eleven girls exactly like myself in face, figure, and size."

author: Grimms
sentence: The father said: "If it be possible, your desire shall be fulfilled," and he caused a search to be made in his whole kingdom, until eleven young maidens were found who exactly resembled his daughter in face, figure, and size.

author: Grimms
sentence: When they came to the king"s daughter, she had twelve suits of huntsmen"s clothes made, all alike, and the eleven maidens had to put on the huntsmen"s clothes, and she herself put on the twelfth suit.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon she took her leave of her father, and rode away with them, and rode to the court of her former betrothed, whom she loved so dearly.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then she asked if he required any huntsmen, and if he would take all of them into his service.

author: Grimms
sentence: The king looked at her and did not know her, but as they were such handsome fellows, he said: "Yes," and that he would willingly take them, and now they were the king"s twelve huntsmen.

author: Grimms
sentence: The king, however, had a lion which was a wondrous animal, for he knew all concealed and secret things.

author: Grimms
sentence: It came to pass that one evening he said to the king: "You think you have twelve huntsmen?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said the king, "they are twelve huntsmen."

author: Grimms
sentence: The lion continued: "You are mistaken, they are twelve girls."

author: Grimms
sentence: The king said: "That cannot be true!

author: Grimms
sentence: How will you prove that to me?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, just let some peas be strewn in the ante-chamber, answered the lion, "and then you will soon see.

author: Grimms
sentence: Men have a firm step, and when they walk over peas none of them stir, but girls trip and skip, and drag their feet, and the peas roll about."

author: Grimms
sentence: The king was well pleased with the counsel, and caused the peas to be strewn.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was, however, a servant of the king"s who favoured the huntsmen, and when he heard that they were going to be put to this test he went to them and repeated everything, and said: "The lion wants to make the king believe that you are girls."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the king"s daughter thanked him, and said to her maidens: "Show some strength, and step firmly on the peas."

author: Grimms
sentence: So next morning when the king had the twelve huntsmen called before him, and they came into the ante-chamber where the peas were lying, they stepped so firmly on them, and had such a strong, sure walk, that not one of the peas either rolled or stirred.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they went away again, and the king said to the lion: "You have lied to me, they walk just like men."

author: Grimms
sentence: The lion said: "They have been informed that they were going to be put to the test, and have assumed some strength.

author: Grimms
sentence: Just let twelve spinning-wheels be brought into the antechamber, and they will go to them and be pleased with them, and that is what no man would do."

author: Grimms
sentence: The king liked the advice, and had the spinning-wheels placed in the ante-chamber.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the servant, who was well disposed to the huntsmen, went to them, and disclosed the project.

author: Grimms
sentence: So when they were alone the king"s daughter said to her eleven girls: "Show some constraint, and do not look round at the spinning-wheels."

author: Grimms
sentence: And next morning when the king had his twelve huntsmen summoned, they went through the ante-chamber, and never once looked at the spinning-wheels.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the king again said to the lion: "You have deceived me, they are men, for they have not looked at the spinning-wheels."

author: Grimms
sentence: The lion replied: "They have restrained themselves."

author: Grimms
sentence: The king, however, would no longer believe the lion.

author: Grimms
sentence: The twelve huntsmen always followed the king to the chase, and his liking for them continually increased.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now it came to pass that once when they were out hunting, news came that the king"s bride was approaching.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the true bride heard that, it hurt her so much that her heart was almost broken, and she fell fainting to the ground.

author: Grimms
sentence: The king thought something had happened to his dear huntsman, ran up to him, wanted to help him, and drew his glove off.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he saw the ring which he had given to his first bride, and when he looked in her face he recognized her.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then his heart was so touched that he kissed her, and when she opened her eyes he said: "You are mine, and I am yours, and no one in the world can alter that."

author: Grimms
sentence: He sent a messenger to the other bride, and entreated her to return to her own kingdom, for he had a wife already, and someone who had just found an old key did not require a new one.

author: Grimms
sentence: Thereupon the wedding was celebrated, and the lion was again taken into favour, because, after all, he had told the truth.

author: Grimms
sentence: One summer"s morning a little tailor was sitting on his table by the window; he was in good spirits, and sewed with all his might.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then came a peasant woman down the street crying: "Good jams, cheap!

author: Grimms
sentence: Good jams, cheap!"

author: Grimms
sentence: This rang pleasantly in the tailor"s ears; he stretched his delicate head out of the window, and called: "Come up here, dear woman; here you will get rid of your goods."

author: Grimms
sentence: The woman came up the three steps to the tailor with her heavy basket, and he made her unpack all the pots for him.

author: Grimms
sentence: He inspected each one, lifted it up, put his nose to it, and at length said: "The jam seems to me to be good, so weigh me out four ounces, dear woman, and if it is a quarter of a pound that is of no consequence."

author: Grimms
sentence: The woman who had hoped to find a good sale, gave him what he desired, but went away quite angry and grumbling.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now, this jam shall be blessed by God, cried the little tailor, "and give me health and strength"; so he brought the bread out of the cupboard, cut himself a piece right across the loaf and spread the jam over it.

author: Grimms
sentence: This wont taste bitter," said he, "but I will just finish the jacket before I take a bite."

author: Grimms
sentence: He laid the bread near him, sewed on, and in his joy, made bigger and bigger stitches.

author: Grimms
sentence: In the meantime the smell of the sweet jam rose to where the flies were sitting in great numbers, and they were attracted and descended on it in hosts.

author: Grimms
sentence: Hi! who invited you? said the little tailor, and drove the unbidden guests away.

author: Grimms
sentence: The flies, however, who understood no German, would not be turned away, but came back again in ever-increasing companies.

author: Grimms
sentence: The little tailor at last lost all patience, and drew a piece of cloth from the hole under his work-table, and saying: "Wait, and I will give it to you," struck it mercilessly on them.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he drew it away and counted, there lay before him no fewer than seven, dead and with legs stretched out.

author: Grimms
sentence: Are you a fellow of that sort? said he, and could not help admiring his own bravery.

author: Grimms
sentence: The whole town shall know of this!

author: Grimms
sentence: And the little tailor hastened to cut himself a girdle, stitched it, and embroidered on it in large letters: "Seven at one stroke!"

author: Grimms
sentence: What, the town! he continued, "the whole world shall hear of it!" and his heart wagged with joy like a lamb"s tail.

author: Grimms
sentence: The tailor put on the girdle, and resolved to go forth into the world, because he thought his workshop was too small for his valour.

author: Grimms
sentence: Before he went away, he sought about in the house to see if there was anything which he could take with him; however, he found nothing but an old cheese, and that he put in his pocket.

author: Grimms
sentence: In front of the door he observed a bird which had caught itself in the thicket.

author: Grimms
sentence: It had to go into his pocket with the cheese.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now he took to the road boldly, and as he was light and nimble, he felt no fatigue.

author: Grimms
sentence: The road led him up a mountain, and when he had reached the highest point of it, there sat a powerful giant looking peacefully about him.

author: Grimms
sentence: The little tailor went bravely up, spoke to him, and said: "Good day, comrade, so you are sitting there overlooking the wide-spread world!

author: Grimms
sentence: I am just on my way thither, and want to try my luck.

author: Grimms
sentence: Have you any inclination to go with me?"

author: Grimms
sentence: The giant looked contemptuously at the tailor, and said: "You ragamuffin!

author: Grimms
sentence: You miserable creature!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, indeed? answered the little tailor, and unbuttoned his coat, and showed the giant the girdle, "there may you read what kind of a man I am!"

author: Grimms

sentence: The time soon came, when the eldest brother thought that he would make haste to go to the princess, and say that he was the one who had set her free, and that he should have her for his wife, and the kingdom with her.

author: Grimms
sentence: As he came before the palace and saw the golden road, he stopped to look at it, and he thought to himself, "It is a pity to ride upon this beautiful road"; so he turned aside and rode on the right-hand side of it.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when he came to the gate, the guards, who had seen the road he took, said to him, he could not be what he said he was, and must go about his business.

author: Grimms
sentence: The second prince set out soon afterwards on the same errand; and when he came to the golden road, and his horse had set one foot upon it, he stopped to look at it, and thought it very beautiful, and said to himself, "What a pity it is that anything should tread here!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he too turned aside and rode on the left side of it.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when he came to the gate the guards said he was not the true prince, and that he too must go away about his business; and away he went.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now when the full year was come round, the third brother left the forest in which he had lain hid for fear of his father"s anger, and set out in search of his betrothed bride.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he journeyed on, thinking of her all the way, and rode so quickly that he did not even see what the road was made of, but went with his horse straight over it; and as he came to the gate it flew open, and the princess welcomed him with joy, and said he was her deliverer, and should now be her husband and lord of the kingdom.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the first joy at their meeting was over, the princess told him she had heard of his father having forgiven him, and of his wish to have him home again: so, before his wedding with the princess, he went to visit his father, taking her with him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he told him everything; how his brothers had cheated and robbed him, and yet that he had borne all those wrongs for the love of his father.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the old king was very angry, and wanted to punish his wicked sons; but they made their escape, and got into a ship and sailed away over the wide sea, and where they went to nobody knew and nobody cared.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now the old king gathered together his court, and asked all his kingdom to come and celebrate the wedding of his son and the princess.

author: Grimms
sentence: And young and old, noble and squire, gentle and simple, came at once on the summons; and among the rest came the friendly dwarf, with the sugarloaf hat, and a new scarlet cloak.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the wedding was held, and the merry bells run.

author: Grimms
sentence: And all the good people they danced and they sung, And feasted and frolick"d I can"t tell how long.

author: Grimms
sentence: A long time ago there lived a king who was famed for his wisdom through all the land.

author: Grimms
sentence: Nothing was hidden from him, and it seemed as if news of the most secret things was brought to him through the air.

author: Grimms
sentence: But he had a strange custom; every day after dinner, when the table was cleared, and no one else was present, a trusty servant had to bring him one more dish.

author: Grimms
sentence: It was covered, however, and even the servant did not know what was in it, neither did anyone know, for the king never took off the cover to eat of it until he was quite alone.

author: Grimms
sentence: This had gone on for a long time, when one day the servant, who took away the dish, was overcome with such curiosity that he could not help carrying the dish into his room.

author: Grimms
sentence: When he had carefully locked the door, he lifted up the cover, and saw a white snake lying on the dish.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when he saw it he could not deny himself the pleasure of tasting it, so he cut of a little bit and put it into his mouth.

author: Grimms
sentence: No sooner had it touched his tongue than he heard a strange whispering of little voices outside his window.

author: Grimms
sentence: He went and listened, and then noticed that it was the sparrows who were chattering together, and telling one another of all kinds of things which they had seen in the fields and woods.

author: Grimms
sentence: Eating the snake had given him power of understanding the language of animals.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now it so happened that on this very day the queen lost her most beautiful ring, and suspicion of having stolen it fell upon this trusty servant, who was allowed to go everywhere.

author: Grimms
sentence: The king ordered the man to be brought before him, and threatened with angry words that unless he could before the morrow point out the thief, he himself should be looked upon as guilty and executed.

author: Grimms
sentence: In vain he declared his innocence; he was dismissed with no better answer.

author: Grimms
sentence: In his trouble and fear he went down into the courtyard and took thought how to help himself out of his trouble.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now some ducks were sitting together quietly by a brook and taking their rest; and, whilst they were making their feathers smooth with their bills, they were having a confidential conversation together.

author: Grimms
sentence: The servant stood by and listened.

author: Grimms
sentence: They were telling one another of all the places where they had been waddling about all the morning, and what good food they had found; and one said in a pitiful tone: "Something lies heavy on my stomach; as I was eating in haste I swallowed a ring which lay under the queen"s window."

author: Grimms
sentence: The servant at once seized her by the neck, carried her to the kitchen, and said to the cook: "Here is a fine duck; pray, kill her."

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, said the cook, and weighed her in his hand; "she has spared no trouble to fatten herself, and has been waiting to be roasted long enough."

author: Grimms
sentence: So he cut off her head, and as she was being dressed for the spit, the queen"s ring was found inside her.

author: Grimms
sentence: The servant could now easily prove his innocence; and the king, to make amends for the wrong, allowed him to ask a favour, and promised him the best place in the court that he could wish for.

author: Grimms
sentence: The servant refused everything, and only asked for a horse and some money for travelling, as he had a mind to see the world and go about a little.

author: Grimms
sentence: When his request was granted he set out on his way, and one day came to a pond, where he saw three fishes caught in the reeds and gasping for water.

author: Grimms
sentence: Now, though it is said that fishes are dumb, he heard them lamenting that they must perish so miserably, and, as he had a kind heart, he got off his horse and put the three prisoners back into the water.

author: Grimms
sentence: They leapt with delight, put out their heads, and cried to him: "We will remember you and repay you for saving us!"

author: Grimms
sentence: He rode on, and after a while it seemed to him that he heard a voice in the sand at his feet.

author: Grimms
sentence: He listened, and heard an ant-king complain: "Why cannot folks, with their clumsy beasts, keep off our bodies?

author: Grimms
sentence: That stupid horse, with his heavy hoofs, has been treading down my people without mercy!"

author: Grimms
sentence: So he turned on to a side path and the ant-king cried out to him: "We will remember you--one good turn deserves another!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The path led him into a wood, and there he saw two old ravens standing by their nest, and throwing out their young ones.

author: Grimms
sentence: Out with you, you idle, good-for-nothing creatures! cried they; "we cannot find food for you any longer; you are big enough, and can provide for yourselves."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the poor young ravens lay upon the ground, flapping their wings, and crying: "Oh, what helpless chicks we are!

author: Grimms
sentence: We must shift for ourselves, and yet we cannot fly!

author: Grimms
sentence: What can we do, but lie here and starve?"

author: Grimms
sentence: So the good young fellow alighted and killed his horse with his sword, and gave it to them for food.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they came hopping up to it, satisfied their hunger, and cried: "We will remember you--one good turn deserves another!"

author: Grimms
sentence: And now he had to use his own legs, and when he had walked a long way, he came to a large city.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was a great noise and crowd in the streets, and a man rode up on horseback, crying aloud: "The king"s daughter wants a husband; but whoever seeks her hand must perform a hard task, and if he does not succeed he will forfeit his life."

author: Grimms
