sentence: Many had already made the attempt, but in vain; nevertheless when the youth saw the king"s daughter he was so overcome by her great beauty that he forgot all danger, went before the king, and declared himself a suitor.

author: Grimms
sentence: So he was led out to the sea, and a gold ring was thrown into it, before his eyes; then the king ordered him to fetch this ring up from the bottom of the sea, and added: "If you come up again without it you will be thrown in again and again until you perish amid the waves."

author: Grimms
sentence: All the people grieved for the handsome youth; then they went away, leaving him alone by the sea.

author: Grimms
sentence: He stood on the shore and considered what he should do, when suddenly he saw three fishes come swimming towards him, and they were the very fishes whose lives he had saved.

author: Grimms
sentence: The one in the middle held a mussel in its mouth, which it laid on the shore at the youth"s feet, and when he had taken it up and opened it, there lay the gold ring in the shell.

author: Grimms
sentence: Full of joy he took it to the king and expected that he would grant him the promised reward.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when the proud princess perceived that he was not her equal in birth, she scorned him, and required him first to perform another task.

author: Grimms
sentence: She went down into the garden and strewed with her own hands ten sacksful of millet-seed on the grass; then she said: "Tomorrow morning before sunrise these must be picked up, and not a single grain be wanting."

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth sat down in the garden and considered how it might be possible to perform this task, but he could think of nothing, and there he sat sorrowfully awaiting the break of day, when he should be led to death.

author: Grimms
sentence: But as soon as the first rays of the sun shone into the garden he saw all the ten sacks standing side by side, quite full, and not a single grain was missing.

author: Grimms
sentence: The ant-king had come in the night with thousands and thousands of ants, and the grateful creatures had by great industry picked up all the millet-seed and gathered them into the sacks.

author: Grimms
sentence: Presently the king"s daughter herself came down into the garden, and was amazed to see that the young man had done the task she had given him.

author: Grimms
sentence: But she could not yet conquer her proud heart, and said: "Although he has performed both the tasks, he shall not be my husband until he had brought me an apple from the Tree of Life."

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth did not know where the Tree of Life stood, but he set out, and would have gone on for ever, as long as his legs would carry him, though he had no hope of finding it.

author: Grimms
sentence: After he had wandered through three kingdoms, he came one evening to a wood, and lay down under a tree to sleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: But he heard a rustling in the branches, and a golden apple fell into his hand.

author: Grimms
sentence: At the same time three ravens flew down to him, perched themselves upon his knee, and said: "We are the three young ravens whom you saved from starving; when we had grown big, and heard that you were seeking the Golden Apple, we flew over the sea to the end of the world, where the Tree of Life stands, and have brought you the apple."

author: Grimms
sentence: The youth, full of joy, set out homewards, and took the Golden Apple to the king"s beautiful daughter, who had now no more excuses left to make.

author: Grimms
sentence: They cut the Apple of Life in two and ate it together; and then her heart became full of love for him, and they lived in undisturbed happiness to a great age.

author: Grimms
sentence: Once in summer-time the bear and the wolf were walking in the forest, and the bear heard a bird singing so beautifully that he said: "Brother wolf, what bird is it that sings so well?"

author: Grimms
sentence: That is the King of birds, said the wolf, "before whom we must bow down."

author: Grimms
sentence: In reality the bird was the willow-wren.

author: Grimms
sentence: IF thats the case," said the bear, "I should very much like to see his royal palace; come, take me thither."

author: Grimms
sentence: That is not done quite as you seem to think, said the wolf; "you must wait until the Queen comes," Soon afterwards, the Queen arrived with some food in her beak, and the lord King came too, and they began to feed their young ones.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bear would have liked to go at once, but the wolf held him back by the sleeve, and said: "No, you must wait until the lord and lady Queen have gone away again."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they took stock of the hole where the nest lay, and trotted away.

author: Grimms
sentence: The bear, however, could not rest until he had seen the royal palace, and when a short time had passed, went to it again.

author: Grimms
sentence: The King and Queen had just flown out, so he peeped in and saw five or six young ones lying there.

author: Grimms
sentence: Is that the royal palace? cried the bear; "it is a wretched palace, and you are not King"s children, you are disreputable children!"

author: Grimms
sentence: When the young wrens heard that, they were frightfully angry, and screamed: "No, that we are not!

author: Grimms
sentence: Our parents are honest people!

author: Grimms
sentence: Bear, you will have to pay for that!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The bear and the wolf grew uneasy, and turned back and went into their holes.

author: Grimms
sentence: The young willow-wrens, however, continued to cry and scream, and when their parents again brought food they said: "We will not so much as touch one fly"s leg, no, not if we were dying of hunger, until you have settled whether we are respectable children or not; the bear has been here and has insulted us!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the old King said: "Be easy, he shall be punished," and he at once flew with the Queen to the bear"s cave, and called in: "Old Growler, why have you insulted my children?

author: Grimms
sentence: You shall suffer for it--we will punish you by a bloody war."

author: Grimms
sentence: Thus war was announced to the Bear, and all four-footed animals were summoned to take part in it, oxen, asses, cows, deer, and every other animal the earth contained.

author: Grimms
sentence: And the willow-wren summoned everything which flew in the air, not only birds, large and small, but midges, and hornets, bees and flies had to come.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the time came for the war to begin, the willow-wren sent out spies to discover who was the enemy"s commander-in-chief.

author: Grimms
sentence: The gnat, who was the most crafty, flew into the forest where the enemy was assembled, and hid herself beneath a leaf of the tree where the password was to be announced.

author: Grimms
sentence: There stood the bear, and he called the fox before him and said: "Fox, you are the most cunning of all animals, you shall be general and lead us."

author: Grimms
sentence: Good, said the fox, "but what signal shall we agree upon?"

author: Grimms
sentence: No one knew that, so the fox said: "I have a fine long bushy tail, which almost looks like a plume of red feathers.

author: Grimms
sentence: When I lift my tail up quite high, all is going well, and you must charge; but if I let it hang down, run away as fast as you can."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the gnat had heard that, she flew away again, and revealed everything, down to the minutest detail, to the willow-wren.

author: Grimms
sentence: When day broke, and the battle was to begin, all the four-footed animals came running up with such a noise that the earth trembled.

author: Grimms
sentence: The willow-wren with his army also came flying through the air with such a humming, and whirring, and swarming that every one was uneasy and afraid, and on both sides they advanced against each other.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the willow-wren sent down the hornet, with orders to settle beneath the fox"s tail, and sting with all his might.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the fox felt the first string, he started so that he one leg, from pain, but he bore it, and still kept his tail high in the air; at the second sting, he was forced to put it down for a moment; at the third, he could hold out no longer, screamed, and put his tail between his legs.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the animals saw that, they thought all was lost, and began to flee, each into his hole, and the birds had won the battle.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the King and Queen flew home to their children and cried: "Children, rejoice, eat and drink to your heart"s content, we have won the battle!"

author: Grimms
sentence: But the young wrens said: "We will not eat yet, the bear must come to the nest, and beg for pardon and say that we are honourable children, before we will do that."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the willow-wren flew to the bear"s hole and cried: "Growler, you are to come to the nest to my children, and beg their pardon, or else every rib of your body shall be broken."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the bear crept thither in the greatest fear, and begged their pardon.

author: Grimms
sentence: And now at last the young wrens were satisfied, and sat down together and ate and drank, and made merry till quite late into the night.

author: Grimms
sentence: There was once upon a time an old goat who had seven little kids, and loved them with all the love of a mother for her children.

author: Grimms
sentence: One day she wanted to go into the forest and fetch some food.

author: Grimms
sentence: So she called all seven to her and said: "Dear children, I have to go into the forest, be on your guard against the wolf; if he comes in, he will devour you all--skin, hair, and everything.

author: Grimms
sentence: The wretch often disguises himself, but you will know him at once by his rough voice and his black feet."

author: Grimms
sentence: The kids said: "Dear mother, we will take good care of ourselves; you may go away without any anxiety."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the old one bleated, and went on her way with an easy mind.

author: Grimms
sentence: It was not long before someone knocked at the house-door and called: "Open the door, dear children; your mother is here, and has brought something back with her for each of you."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the little kids knew that it was the wolf, by the rough voice.

author: Grimms
sentence: We will not open the door, cried they, "you are not our mother.

author: Grimms
sentence: She has a soft, pleasant voice, but your voice is rough; you are the wolf!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the wolf went away to a shopkeeper and bought himself a great lump of chalk, ate this and made his voice soft with it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he came back, knocked at the door of the house, and called: "Open the door, dear children, your mother is here and has brought something back with her for each of you."

author: Grimms
sentence: But the wolf had laid his black paws against the window, and the children saw them and cried: "We will not open the door, our mother has not black feet like you: you are the wolf!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the wolf ran to a baker and said: "I have hurt my feet, rub some dough over them for me."

author: Grimms
sentence: And when the baker had rubbed his feet over, he ran to the miller and said: "Strew some white meal over my feet for me."

author: Grimms
sentence: The miller thought to himself: "The wolf wants to deceive someone," and refused; but the wolf said: "If you will not do it, I will devour you."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the miller was afraid, and made his paws white for him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Truly, this is the way of mankind.

author: Grimms
sentence: So now the wretch went for the third time to the house-door, knocked at it and said: "Open the door for me, children, your dear little mother has come home, and has brought every one of you something back from the forest with her."

author: Grimms
sentence: The little kids cried: "First show us your paws that we may know if you are our dear little mother."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he put his paws in through the window and when the kids saw that they were white, they believed that all he said was true, and opened the door.

author: Grimms
sentence: But who should come in but the wolf!

author: Grimms
sentence: They were terrified and wanted to hide themselves.

author: Grimms
sentence: One sprang under the table, the second into the bed, the third into the stove, the fourth into the kitchen, the fifth into the cupboard, the sixth under the washing-bowl, and the seventh into the clock-case.

author: Grimms
sentence: But the wolf found them all, and used no great ceremony; one after the other he swallowed them down his throat.

author: Grimms
sentence: The youngest, who was in the clock-case, was the only one he did not find.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the wolf had satisfied his appetite he took himself off, laid himself down under a tree in the green meadow outside, and began to sleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: Soon afterwards the old goat came home again from the forest.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah! what a sight she saw there!

author: Grimms
sentence: The house-door stood wide open.

author: Grimms
sentence: The table, chairs, and benches were thrown down, the washing-bowl lay broken to pieces, and the quilts and pillows were pulled off the bed.

author: Grimms
sentence: She sought her children, but they were nowhere to be found.

author: Grimms
sentence: She called them one after another by name, but no one answered.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last, when she came to the youngest, a soft voice cried: "Dear mother, I am in the clock-case."

author: Grimms
sentence: She took the kid out, and it told her that the wolf had come and had eaten all the others.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then you may imagine how she wept over her poor children.

author: Grimms
sentence: At length in her grief she went out, and the youngest kid ran with her.

author: Grimms
sentence: When they came to the meadow, there lay the wolf by the tree and snored so loud that the branches shook.

author: Grimms
sentence: She looked at him on every side and saw that something was moving and struggling in his gorged belly.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah, heavens, she said, "is it possible that my poor children whom he has swallowed down for his supper, can be still alive?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the kid had to run home and fetch scissors, and a needle and thread, and the goat cut open the monster"s stomach, and hardly had she made one cut, than one little kid thrust its head out, and when she had cut farther, all six sprang out one after another, and were all still alive, and had suffered no injury whatever, for in his greediness the monster had swallowed them down whole.

author: Grimms
sentence: What rejoicing there was!

author: Grimms
sentence: They embraced their dear mother, and jumped like a tailor at his wedding.

author: Grimms
sentence: The mother, however, said: "Now go and look for some big stones, and we will fill the wicked beast"s stomach with them while he is still asleep."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the seven kids dragged the stones thither with all speed, and put as many of them into this stomach as they could get in; and the mother sewed him up again in the greatest haste, so that he was not aware of anything and never once stirred.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the wolf at length had had his fill of sleep, he got on his legs, and as the stones in his stomach made him very thirsty, he wanted to go to a well to drink.

author: Grimms
sentence: But when he began to walk and to move about, the stones in his stomach knocked against each other and rattled.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then cried he:

author: Grimms
sentence:
What rumbles and tumbles Against my poor bones?
49:49	N:N	F:-	I thought twas six kids, But it feels like big stones."

author: Grimms
sentence: And when he got to the well and stooped over the water to drink, the heavy stones made him fall in, and he drowned miserably.

author: Grimms
sentence: When the seven kids saw that, they came running to the spot and cried aloud: "The wolf is dead!

author: Grimms
sentence: The wolf is dead!" and danced for joy round about the well with their mother.

author: Grimms
sentence: A poor woodman sat in his cottage one night, smoking his pipe by the fireside, while his wife sat by his side spinning.

author: Grimms
sentence: How lonely it is, wife, said he, as he puffed out a long curl of smoke, "for you and me to sit here by ourselves, without any children to play about and amuse us while other people seem so happy and merry with their children!"

author: Grimms
sentence: What you say is very true, said the wife, sighing, and turning round her wheel; "how happy should I be if I had but one child!

author: Grimms
sentence: If it were ever so small--nay, if it were no bigger than my thumb--I should be very happy, and love it dearly."

author: Grimms
sentence: Now--odd as you may think it--it came to pass that this good woman"s wish was fulfilled, just in the very way she had wished it; for, not long afterwards, she had a little boy, who was quite healthy and strong, but was not much bigger than my thumb.

author: Grimms
sentence: So they said, "Well, we cannot say we have not got what we wished for, and, little as he is, we will love him dearly."

author: Grimms
sentence: And they called him Thomas Thumb.

author: Grimms
sentence: They gave him plenty of food, yet for all they could do he never grew bigger, but kept just the same size as he had been when he was born.

author: Grimms
sentence: Still, his eyes were sharp and sparkling, and he soon showed himself to be a clever little fellow, who always knew well what he was about.

author: Grimms
sentence: One day, as the woodman was getting ready to go into the wood to cut fuel, he said, "I wish I had someone to bring the cart after me, for I want to make haste."

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, father, cried Tom, "I will take care of that; the cart shall be in the wood by the time you want it."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the woodman laughed, and said, "How can that be? you cannot reach up to the horse"s bridle."

author: Grimms
sentence: Never mind that, father, said Tom; "if my mother will only harness the horse, I will get into his ear and tell him which way to go."

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, said the father, "we will try for once."

author: Grimms
sentence: When the time came the mother harnessed the horse to the cart, and put Tom into his ear; and as he sat there the little man told the beast how to go, crying out, "Go on!" and "Stop!" as he wanted: and thus the horse went on just as well as if the woodman had driven it himself into the wood.

author: Grimms
sentence: It happened that as the horse was going a little too fast, and Tom was calling out, "Gently! gently!" two strangers came up.

author: Grimms
sentence: What an odd thing that is! said one: "there is a cart going along, and I hear a carter talking to the horse, but yet I can see no one."

author: Grimms
sentence: That is queer, indeed, said the other; "let us follow the cart, and see where it goes."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they went on into the wood, till at last they came to the place where the woodman was.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Tom Thumb, seeing his father, cried out, "See, father, here I am with the cart, all right and safe! now take me down!"

author: Grimms
sentence: So his father took hold of the horse with one hand, and with the other took his son out of the horse"s ear, and put him down upon a straw, where he sat as merry as you please.

author: Grimms
sentence: The two strangers were all this time looking on, and did not know what to say for wonder.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last one took the other aside, and said, "That little urchin will make our fortune, if we can get him, and carry him about from town to town as a show; we must buy him."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they went up to the woodman, and asked him what he would take for the little man.

author: Grimms
sentence: He will be better off, said they, "with us than with you."

author: Grimms
sentence: I wont sell him at all," said the father; "my own flesh and blood is dearer to me than all the silver and gold in the world."

author: Grimms
sentence: But Tom, hearing of the bargain they wanted to make, crept up his father"s coat to his shoulder and whispered in his ear, "Take the money, father, and let them have me; I"ll soon come back to you."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the woodman at last said he would sell Tom to the strangers for a large piece of gold, and they paid the price.

author: Grimms
sentence: Where would you like to sit? said one of them.

author: Grimms
sentence: Oh, put me on the rim of your hat; that will be a nice gallery for me; I can walk about there and see the country as we go along.

author: Grimms
sentence: So they did as he wished; and when Tom had taken leave of his father they took him away with them.

author: Grimms
sentence: They journeyed on till it began to be dusky, and then the little man said, "Let me get down, I"m tired."

author: Grimms
sentence: So the man took off his hat, and put him down on a clod of earth, in a ploughed field by the side of the road.

author: Grimms
sentence: But Tom ran about amongst the furrows, and at last slipped into an old mouse-hole.

author: Grimms
sentence: Good night, my masters! said he, "I"m off! mind and look sharp after me the next time."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they ran at once to the place, and poked the ends of their sticks into the mouse-hole, but all in vain; Tom only crawled farther and farther in; and at last it became quite dark, so that they were forced to go their way without their prize, as sulky as could be.

author: Grimms
sentence: When Tom found they were gone, he came out of his hiding-place.

author: Grimms
sentence: What dangerous walking it is, said he, "in this ploughed field!

author: Grimms
sentence: If I were to fall from one of these great clods, I should undoubtedly break my neck."

author: Grimms
sentence: At last, by good luck, he found a large empty snail-shell.

author: Grimms
sentence: This is lucky, said he, "I can sleep here very well"; and in he crept.

author: Grimms
sentence: Just as he was falling asleep, he heard two men passing by, chatting together; and one said to the other, "How can we rob that rich parson"s house of his silver and gold?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Ill tell you!" cried Tom.

author: Grimms
sentence: What noise was that? said the thief, frightened; "I"m sure I heard someone speak."

author: Grimms
sentence: They stood still listening, and Tom said, "Take me with you, and I"ll soon show you how to get the parson"s money."

author: Grimms
sentence: But where are you? said they.

author: Grimms
sentence: Look about on the ground, answered he, "and listen where the sound comes from."

author: Grimms
sentence: At last the thieves found him out, and lifted him up in their hands.

author: Grimms
sentence: You little urchin! they said, "what can you do for us?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Why, I can get between the iron window-bars of the parsons house, and throw you out whatever you want."

author: Grimms
sentence: Thats a good thought," said the thieves; "come along, we shall see what you can do."

author: Grimms
sentence: When they came to the parson"s house, Tom slipped through the windowbars into the room, and then called out as loud as he could bawl, "Will you have all that is here?"

author: Grimms
sentence: At this the thieves were frightened, and said, "Softly, softly!

author: Grimms
sentence: Speak low, that you may not awaken anybody."

author: Grimms
sentence: But Tom seemed as if he did not understand them, and bawled out again, "How much will you have?

author: Grimms
sentence: Shall I throw it all out?"

author: Grimms
sentence: Now the cook lay in the next room; and hearing a noise she raised herself up in her bed and listened.

author: Grimms
sentence: Meantime the thieves were frightened, and ran off a little way; but at last they plucked up their hearts, and said, "The little urchin is only trying to make fools of us."

author: Grimms
sentence: So they came back and whispered softly to him, saying, "Now let us have no more of your roguish jokes; but throw us out some of the money."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then Tom called out as loud as he could, "Very well! hold your hands! here it comes."

author: Grimms
sentence: The cook heard this quite plain, so she sprang out of bed, and ran to open the door.

author: Grimms
sentence: The thieves ran off as if a wolf was at their tails: and the maid, having groped about and found nothing, went away for a light.

author: Grimms
sentence: By the time she came back, Tom had slipped off into the barn; and when she had looked about and searched every hole and corner, and found nobody, she went to bed, thinking she must have been dreaming with her eyes open.

author: Grimms
sentence: The little man crawled about in the hay-loft, and at last found a snug place to finish his night"s rest in; so he laid himself down, meaning to sleep till daylight, and then find his way home to his father and mother.

author: Grimms
sentence: But alas! how woefully he was undone! what crosses and sorrows happen to us all in this world!

author: Grimms
sentence: The cook got up early, before daybreak, to feed the cows; and going straight to the hay-loft, carried away a large bundle of hay, with the little man in the middle of it, fast asleep.

author: Grimms
sentence: He still, however, slept on, and did not awake till he found himself in the mouth of the cow; for the cook had put the hay into the cow"s rick, and the cow had taken Tom up in a mouthful of it.

author: Grimms
sentence: Good lack-a-day! said he, "how came I to tumble into the mill?"

author: Grimms
sentence: But he soon found out where he really was; and was forced to have all his wits about him, that he might not get between the cow"s teeth, and so be crushed to death.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last down he went into her stomach.

author: Grimms
sentence: It is rather dark, said he; "they forgot to build windows in this room to let the sun in; a candle would be no bad thing."

author: Grimms
sentence: Though he made the best of his bad luck, he did not like his quarters at all; and the worst of it was, that more and more hay was always coming down, and the space left for him became smaller and smaller.

author: Grimms
sentence: At last he cried out as loud as he could, "Don"t bring me any more hay!

author: Grimms
sentence: Don"t bring me any more hay!"

author: Grimms
sentence: The maid happened to be just then milking the cow; and hearing someone speak, but seeing nobody, and yet being quite sure it was the same voice that she had heard in the night, she was so frightened that she fell off her stool, and overset the milk-pail.

author: Grimms
sentence: As soon as she could pick herself up out of the dirt, she ran off as fast as she could to her master the parson, and said, "Sir, sir, the cow is talking!"

author: Grimms
sentence: But the parson said, "Woman, thou art surely mad!"

author: Grimms
sentence: However, he went with her into the cow-house, to try and see what was the matter.

author: Grimms
sentence: Scarcely had they set foot on the threshold, when Tom called out, "Don"t bring me any more hay!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Then the parson himself was frightened; and thinking the cow was surely bewitched, told his man to kill her on the spot.

author: Grimms
sentence: So the cow was killed, and cut up; and the stomach, in which Tom lay, was thrown out upon a dunghill.

author: Grimms
sentence: Tom soon set himself to work to get out, which was not a very easy task; but at last, just as he had made room to get his head out, fresh ill-luck befell him.

author: Grimms
sentence: A hungry wolf sprang out, and swallowed up the whole stomach, with Tom in it, at one gulp, and ran away.

author: Grimms
sentence: Tom, however, was still not disheartened; and thinking the wolf would not dislike having some chat with him as he was going along, he called out, "My good friend, I can show you a famous treat."

author: Grimms
sentence: Wheres that?" said the wolf.

author: Grimms
sentence: In such and such a house, said Tom, describing his own father"s house.

author: Grimms
sentence: You can crawl through the drain into the kitchen and then into the pantry, and there you will find cakes, ham, beef, cold chicken, roast pig, apple-dumplings, and everything that your heart can wish.

author: Grimms
sentence: The wolf did not want to be asked twice; so that very night he went to the house and crawled through the drain into the kitchen, and then into the pantry, and ate and drank there to his heart"s content.

author: Grimms
sentence: As soon as he had had enough he wanted to get away; but he had eaten so much that he could not go out by the same way he came in.

author: Grimms
sentence: This was just what Tom had reckoned upon; and now he began to set up a great shout, making all the noise he could.

author: Grimms
sentence: Will you be easy? said the wolf; "you"ll awaken everybody in the house if you make such a clatter."

author: Grimms
sentence: Whats that to me?" said the little man; "you have had your frolic, now I"ve a mind to be merry myself"; and he began, singing and shouting as loud as he could.

author: Grimms
sentence: The woodman and his wife, being awakened by the noise, peeped through a crack in the door; but when they saw a wolf was there, you may well suppose that they were sadly frightened; and the woodman ran for his axe, and gave his wife a scythe.

author: Grimms
sentence: Do you stay behind, said the woodman, "and when I have knocked him on the head you must rip him up with the scythe."

author: Grimms
sentence: Tom heard all this, and cried out, "Father, father!

author: Grimms
sentence: I am here, the wolf has swallowed me."

author: Grimms
sentence: And his father said, "Heaven be praised! we have found our dear child again"; and he told his wife not to use the scythe for fear she should hurt him.

author: Grimms
sentence: Then he aimed a great blow, and struck the wolf on the head, and killed him on the spot! and when he was dead they cut open his body, and set Tommy free.

author: Grimms
sentence: Ah! said the father, "what fears we have had for you!"

author: Grimms
sentence: Yes, father, answered he; "I have travelled all over the world, I think, in one way or other, since we parted; and now I am very glad to come home and get fresh air again."

author: Grimms
sentence: Why, where have you been? said his father.

author: Grimms
sentence: I have been in a mouse-hole--and in a snail-shell--and down a cows throat-- and in the wolf"s belly; and yet here I am again, safe and sound."

author: Grimms
sentence: Well, said they, "you are come back, and we will not sell you again for all the riches in the world."

author: Grimms
sentence: Then they hugged and kissed their dear little son, and gave him plenty to eat and drink, for he was very hungry; and then they fetched new clothes for him, for his old ones had been quite spoiled on his journey.

author: Grimms
sentence: So Master Thumb stayed at home with his father and mother, in peace; for though he had been so great a traveller, and had done and seen so many fine things, and was fond enough of telling the whole story, he always agreed that, after all, there"s no place like HOME!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: NEAR the grass-covered rampart which encircles Copenhagen lies a great red house.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Balsams and other flowers greet us from the long rows of windows in the house, whose interior is sufficiently poverty-stricken; and poor and old are the people who inhabit it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The building is the Warton Almshouse.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Look! at the window there leans an old maid.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She plucks the withered leaf from the balsam, and looks at the grass-covered rampart, on which many children are playing.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What is the old maid thinking of?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A whole life drama is unfolding itself before her inward gaze.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
The poor little children, how happy they are- how merrily they play and romp together!
8:8	Sa:N	S:S	What red cheeks and what angels' eyes! but they have no shoes nor stockings.
9:9	F:N	F:-	They dance on the green rampart, just on the place where, according to the old story, the ground always sank in, and where a sportive, frolicsome child had been lured by means of flowers, toys and sweetmeats into an open grave ready dug for it, and which was afterwards closed over the child; and from that moment, the old story says, the ground gave way no longer, the mound remained firm and fast, and was quickly covered with the green turf.
10:10	H:N	F:-	The little people who now play on that spot know nothing of the old tale, else would they fancy they heard a child crying deep below the earth, and the dewdrops on each blade of grass would be to them tears of woe.
11:11	Sa:N	S:-	Nor do they know anything of the Danish King who here, in the face of the coming foe, took an oath before all his trembling courtiers that he would hold out with the citizens of his capital, and die here in his nest; they know nothing of the men who have fought here, or of the women who from here have drenched with boiling water the enemy, clad in white, and 'biding in the snow to surprise the city.
12:12	Sa:N	S:-	No! the poor little ones are playing with light, childish spirits.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Play on, play on, thou little maiden!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Soon the years will come- yes, those glorious years.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The priestly hands have been laid on the candidates for confirmation; hand in hand they walk on the green rampart.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thou hast a white frock on; it has cost thy mother much labor, and yet it is only cut down for thee out of an old larger dress!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You will also wear a red shawl; and what if it hang too far down?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: People will only see how large, how very large it is.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You are thinking of your dress, and of the Giver of all good- so glorious is it to wander on the green rampart!

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
And the years roll by; they have no lack of dark days, but you have your cheerful young spirit, and you have gained a friend- you know not how.
21:21	Su-:N	S:H	You met, oh, how often!
22:22	H:N	H:H	You walk together on the rampart in the fresh spring, on the high days and holidays, when all the world come out to walk upon the ramparts, and all the bells of the church steeples seem to be singing a song of praise for the coming spring.
23:23	N:N	H:N	Scarcely have the violets come forth, but there on the rampart, just opposite the beautiful Castle of Rosenberg, there is a tree bright with the first green buds.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Every year this tree sends forth fresh green shoots.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Alas!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is not so with the human heart!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Dark mists, more in number than those that cover the northern skies, cloud the human heart.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Poor child! thy friend's bridal chamber is a black coffin, and thou becomest an old maid.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: From the almshouse window, behind the balsams, thou shalt look on the merry children at play, and shalt see thine own history renewed."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And that is the life drama that passes before the old maid while she looks out upon the rampart, the green, sunny rampart, where the children, with their red cheeks and bare shoeless feet, are rejoicing merrily, like the other free little birds.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
WHENEVER a good child dies, an angel of God comes down from heaven, takes the dead child in his arms, spreads out his great white wings, and flies with him over all the places which the child had loved during his life.
1:1	H:N	S:N	Then he gathers a large handful of flowers, which he carries up to the Almighty, that they may bloom more brightly in heaven than they do on earth.
2:2	H:N	H:H	And the Almighty presses the flowers to His heart, but He kisses the flower that pleases Him best, and it receives a voice, and is able to join the song of the chorus of bliss.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: These words were spoken by an angel of God, as he carried a dead child up to heaven, and the child listened as if in a dream.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they passed over well-known spots, where the little one had often played, and through beautiful gardens full of lovely flowers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Which of these shall we take with us to heaven to be transplanted there? asked the angel.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Close by grew a slender, beautiful, rose-bush, but some wicked hand had broken the stem, and the half-opened rosebuds hung faded and withered on the trailing branches.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Poor rose-bush! said the child, "let us take it with us to heaven, that it may bloom above in God's garden."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The angel took up the rose-bush; then he kissed the child, and the little one half opened his eyes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The angel gathered also some beautiful flowers, as well as a few humble buttercups and heart's-ease.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now we have flowers enough, said the child; but the angel only nodded, he did not fly upward to heaven.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was night, and quite still in the great town.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here they remained, and the angel hovered over a small, narrow street, in which lay a large heap of straw, ashes, and sweepings from the houses of people who had removed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There lay fragments of plates, pieces of plaster, rags, old hats, and other rubbish not pleasant to see.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Amidst all this confusion, the angel pointed to the pieces of a broken flower-pot, and to a lump of earth which had fallen out of it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The earth had been kept from falling to pieces by the roots of a withered field-flower, which had been thrown amongst the rubbish.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We will take this with us, said the angel, "I will tell you why as we fly along."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And as they flew the angel related the history.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Down in that narrow lane, in a low cellar, lived a poor sick boy; he had been afflicted from his childhood, and even in his best days he could just manage to walk up and down the room on crutches once or twice, but no more.
19:19	N:N	S:N	During some days in summer, the sunbeams would lie on the floor of the cellar for about half an hour.
20:20	Sa:N	S:S	In this spot the poor sick boy would sit warming himself in the sunshine, and watching the red blood through his delicate fingers as he held them before his face.
21:21	Su+:N	S:S	Then he would say he had been out, yet he knew nothing of the green forest in its spring verdure, till a neighbor's son brought him a green bough from a beech-tree.
22:22	H:N	S:S	This he would place over his head, and fancy that he was in the beech-wood while the sun shone, and the birds carolled gayly.
23:23	Su+:N	S:N	One spring day the neighbor's boy brought him some field-flowers, and among them was one to which the root still adhered.
24:24	H:N	H:S	This he carefully planted in a flower-pot, and placed in a window-seat near his bed.
25:25	H:N	H:H	And the flower had been planted by a fortunate hand, for it grew, put forth fresh shoots, and blossomed every year.
26:26	H:H	H:H	It became a splendid flower-garden to the sick boy, and his little treasure upon earth.
27:27	H:N	H:H	He watered it, and cherished it, and took care it should have the benefit of every sunbeam that found its way into the cellar, from the earliest morning ray to the evening sunset.
28:28	H:H	H:H	The flower entwined itself even in his dreams- for him it bloomed, for him spread its perfume.
29:29	H:H	H:H	And it gladdened his eyes, and to the flower he turned, even in death, when the Lord called him.
30:30	Sa:N	S:N	He has been one year with God.
31:31	Sa:Sa	S:S	During that time the flower has stood in the window, withered and forgotten, till at length cast out among the sweepings into the street, on the day of the lodgers' removal.
32:32	H:N	H:H	And this poor flower, withered and faded as it is, we have added to our nosegay, because it gave more real joy than the most beautiful flower in the garden of a queen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But how do you know all this? asked the child whom the angel was carrying to heaven.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I know it, said the angel, "because I myself was the poor sick boy who walked upon crutches, and I know my own flower well."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the child opened his eyes and looked into the glorious happy face of the angel, and at the same moment they found themselves in that heavenly home where all is happiness and joy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And God pressed the dead child to His heart, and wings were given him so that he could fly with the angel, hand in hand.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the Almighty pressed all the flowers to His heart; but He kissed the withered field-flower, and it received a voice.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then it joined in the song of the angels, who surrounded the throne, some near, and others in a distant circle, but all equally happy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They all joined in the chorus of praise, both great and small,- the good, happy child, and the poor field-flower, that once lay withered and cast away on a heap of rubbish in a narrow, dark street.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: ANNE LISBETH was a beautiful young woman, with a red and white complexion, glittering white teeth, and clear soft eyes; and her footstep was light in the dance, but her mind was lighter still.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She had a little child, not at all pretty; so he was put out to be nursed by a laborer's wife, and his mother went to the count's castle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She sat in splendid rooms, richly decorated with silk and velvet; not a breath of air was allowed to blow upon her, and no one was allowed to speak to her harshly, for she was nurse to the count's child.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was fair and delicate as a prince, and beautiful as an angel; and how she loved this child!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her own boy was provided for by being at the laborer's where the mouth watered more frequently than the pot boiled, and where in general no one was at home to take care of the child.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he would cry, but what nobody knows nobody cares for; so he would cry till he was tired, and then fall asleep; and while we are asleep we can feel neither hunger nor thirst.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ah, yes; sleep is a capital invention.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As years went on, Anne Lisbeth's child grew apace like weeds, although they said his growth had been stunted.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had become quite a member of the family in which he dwelt; they received money to keep him, so that his mother got rid of him altogether.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She had become quite a lady; she had a comfortable home of her own in the town; and out of doors, when she went for a walk, she wore a bonnet; but she never walked out to see the laborer: that was too far from the town, and, indeed, she had nothing to go for, the boy now belonged to these laboring people.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had food, and he could also do something towards earning his living; he took care of Mary's red cow, for he knew how to tend cattle and make himself useful.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The great dog by the yard gate of a nobleman's mansion sits proudly on the top of his kennel when the sun shines, and barks at every one that passes; but if it rains, he creeps into his house, and there he is warm and dry.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Anne Lisbeth's boy also sat in the sunshine on the top of the fence, cutting out a little toy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If it was spring-time, he knew of three strawberry-plants in blossom, which would certainly bear fruit.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This was his most hopeful thought, though it often came to nothing.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And he had to sit out in the rain in the worst weather, and get wet to the skin, and let the cold wind dry the clothes on his back afterwards.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If he went near the farmyard belonging to the count, he was pushed and knocked about, for the men and the maids said he was so horrible ugly; but he was used to all this, for nobody loved him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This was how the world treated Anne Lisbeth's boy, and how could it be otherwise.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was his fate to be beloved by no one.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Hitherto he had been a land crab; the land at last cast him adrift.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He went to sea in a wretched vessel, and sat at the helm, while the skipper sat over the grog-can.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was dirty and ugly, half-frozen and half-starved; he always looked as if he never had enough to eat, which was really the case.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Late in the autumn, when the weather was rough, windy, and wet, and the cold penetrated through the thickest clothing, especially at sea, a wretched boat went out to sea with only two men on board, or, more correctly, a man and a half, for it was the skipper and his boy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There had only been a kind of twilight all day, and it soon grew quite dark, and so bitterly cold, that the skipper took a dram to warm him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bottle was old, and the glass too.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was perfect in the upper part, but the foot was broken off, and it had therefore been fixed upon a little carved block of wood, painted blue.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A dram is a great comfort, and two are better still, thought the skipper, while the boy sat at the helm, which he held fast in his hard seamed hands.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was ugly, and his hair was matted, and he looked crippled and stunted; they called him the field-laborer's boy, though in the church register he was entered as Anne Lisbeth's son.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The wind cut through the rigging, and the boat cut through the sea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sails, filled by the wind, swelled out and carried them along in wild career.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was wet and rough above and below, and might still be worse.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Hold! what is that?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What has struck the boat?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Was it a waterspout, or a heavy sea rolling suddenly upon them?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Heaven help us! cried the boy at the helm, as the boat heeled over and lay on its beam ends.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It had struck on a rock, which rose from the depths of the sea, and sank at once, like an old shoe in a puddle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It sank at once with mouse and man, as the saying is.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There might have been mice on board, but only one man and a half, the skipper and the laborer's boy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No one saw it but the skimming sea-gulls and the fishes beneath the water; and even they did not see it properly, for they darted back with terror as the boat filled with water and sank.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There it lay, scarcely a fathom below the surface, and those two were provided for, buried, and forgotten.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The glass with the foot of blue wood was the only thing that did not sink, for the wood floated and the glass drifted away to be cast upon the shore and broken; where and when, is indeed of no consequence.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It had served its purpose, and it had been loved, which Anne Lisbeth's boy had not been.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But in heaven no soul will be able to say, "Never loved."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Anne Lisbeth had now lived in the town many years; she was called "Madame," and felt dignified in consequence; she remembered the old, noble days, in which she had driven in the carriage, and had associated with countess and baroness.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her beautiful, noble child had been a dear angel, and possessed the kindest heart; he had loved her so much, and she had loved him in return; they had kissed and loved each other, and the boy had been her joy, her second life.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now he was fourteen years of age, tall, handsome, and clever.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She had not seen him since she carried him in her arms; neither had she been for years to the count's palace; it was quite a journey thither from the town.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I must make one effort to go, said Anne Lisbeth, "to see my darling, the count's sweet child, and press him to my heart.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Certainly he must long to see me, too, the young count; no doubt he thinks of me and loves me, as in those days when he would fling his angel-arms round my neck, and lisp 'Anne Liz.'

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was music to my ears.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, I must make an effort to see him again."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She drove across the country in a grazier's cart, and then got out, and continued her journey on foot, and thus reached the count's castle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was as great and magnificent as it had always been, and the garden looked the same as ever; all the servants were strangers to her, not one of them knew Anne Lisbeth, nor of what consequence she had once been there; but she felt sure the countess would soon let them know it, and her darling boy, too: how she longed to see him!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now that Anne Lisbeth was at her journey's end, she was kept waiting a long time; and for those who wait, time passes slowly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But before the great people went in to dinner, she was called in and spoken to very graciously.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was to go in again after dinner, and then she would see her sweet boy once more.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How tall, and slender, and thin he had grown; but the eyes and the sweet angel mouth were still beautiful.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He looked at her, but he did not speak, he certainly did not know who she was.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He turned round and was going away, but she seized his hand and pressed it to her lips.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Well, well, he said; and with that he walked out of the room.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He who filled her every thought! he whom she loved best, and who was her whole earthly pride!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Anne Lisbeth went forth from the castle into the public road, feeling mournful and sad; he whom she had nursed day and night, and even now carried about in her dreams, had been cold and strange, and had not a word or thought respecting her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A great black raven darted down in front of her on the high road, and croaked dismally.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ah, said she, "what bird of ill omen art thou?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Presently she passed the laborer's hut; his wife stood at the door, and the two women spoke to each other.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You look well, said the woman; "you're fat and plump; you are well off."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh yes, answered Anne Lisbeth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The boat went down with them, continued the woman; "Hans the skipper and the boy were both drowned; so there's an end of them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I always thought the boy would be able to help me with a few dollars.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He'll never cost you anything more, Anne Lisbeth."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So they were drowned, repeated Anne Lisbeth; but she said no more, and the subject was dropped.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She felt very low-spirited, because her count-child had shown no inclination to speak to her who loved him so well, and who had travelled so far to see him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The journey had cost money too, and she had derived no great pleasure from it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Still she said not a word of all this; she could not relieve her heart by telling the laborer's wife, lest the latter should think she did not enjoy her former position at the castle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the raven flew over her, screaming again as he flew.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The black wretch! said Anne Lisbeth, "he will end by frightening me today."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She had brought coffee and chicory with her, for she thought it would be a charity to the poor woman to give them to her to boil a cup of coffee, and then she would take a cup herself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The woman prepared the coffee, and in the meantime Anne Lisbeth seated her in a chair and fell asleep.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then she dreamed of something which she had never dreamed before; singularly enough she dreamed of her own child, who had wept and hungered in the laborer's hut, and had been knocked about in heat and in cold, and who was now lying in the depths of the sea, in a spot only known by God.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She fancied she was still sitting in the hut, where the woman was busy preparing the coffee, for she could smell the coffee-berries roasting.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But suddenly it seemed to her that there stood on the threshold a beautiful young form, as beautiful as the count's child, and this apparition said to her, "The world is passing away; hold fast to me, for you are my mother after all; you have an angel in heaven, hold me fast;" and the child-angel stretched out his hand and seized her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then there was a terrible crash, as of a world crumbling to pieces, and the angel-child was rising from the earth, and holding her by the sleeve so tightly that she felt herself lifted from the ground; but, on the other hand, something heavy hung to her feet and dragged her down, and it seemed as if hundreds of women were clinging to her, and crying, "If thou art to be saved, we must be saved too.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Hold fast, hold fast."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then they all hung on her, but there were too many; and as they clung the sleeve was torn, and Anne Lisbeth fell down in horror, and awoke.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Indeed she was on the point of falling over in reality with the chair on which she sat; but she was so startled and alarmed that she could not remember what she had dreamed, only that it was something very dreadful.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They drank their coffee and had a chat together, and then Anne Lisbeth went away towards the little town where she was to meet the carrier, who was to drive her back to her own home.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But when she came to him she found that he would not be ready to start till the evening of the next day.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then she began to think of the expense, and what the distance would be to walk.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She remembered that the route by the sea-shore was two miles shorter than by the high road; and as the weather was clear, and there would be moonlight, she determined to make her way on foot, and to start at once, that she might reach home the next day.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sun had set, and the evening bells sounded through the air from the tower of the village church, but to her it was not the bells, but the cry of the frogs in the marshes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they ceased, and all around became still; not a bird could be heard, they were all at rest, even the owl had not left her hiding place; deep silence reigned on the margin of the wood by the sea-shore.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As Anne Lisbeth walked on she could hear her own footsteps in the sands; even the waves of the sea were at rest, and all in the deep waters had sunk into silence.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There was quiet among the dead and the living in the deep sea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Anne Lisbeth walked on, thinking of nothing at all, as people say, or rather her thoughts wandered, but not away from her, for thought is never absent from us, it only slumbers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Many thoughts that have lain dormant are roused at the proper time, and begin to stir in the mind and the heart, and seem even to come upon us from above.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is written, that a good deed bears a blessing for its fruit; and it is also written, that the wages of sin is death.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Much has been said and much written which we pass over or know nothing of.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A light arises within us, and then forgotten things make themselves remembered; and thus it was with Anne Lisbeth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The germ of every vice and every virtue lies in our heart, in yours and in mine; they lie like little grains of seed, till a ray of sunshine, or the touch of an evil hand, or you turn the corner to the right or to the left, and the decision is made.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The little seed is stirred, it swells and shoots up, and pours its sap into your blood, directing your course either for good or evil.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Troublesome thoughts often exist in the mind, fermenting there, which are not realized by us while the senses are as it were slumbering; but still they are there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Anne Lisbeth walked on thus with her senses half asleep, but the thoughts were fermenting within her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: From one Shrove Tuesday to another, much may occur to weigh down the heart; it is the reckoning of a whole year; much may be forgotten, sins against heaven in word and thought, sins against our neighbor, and against our own conscience.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We are scarcely aware of their existence; and Anne Lisbeth did not think of any of her errors.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She had committed no crime against the law of the land; she was an honorable person, in a good position- that she knew.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She continued her walk along by the margin of the sea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What was it she saw lying there?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: An old hat; a man's hat.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now when might that have been washed overboard?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She drew nearer, she stopped to look at the hat; "Ha! what was lying yonder?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She shuddered; yet it was nothing save a heap of grass and tangled seaweed flung across a long stone, but it looked like a corpse.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Only tangled grass, and yet she was frightened at it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As she turned to walk away, much came into her mind that she had heard in her childhood: old superstitions of spectres by the sea-shore; of the ghosts of drowned but unburied people, whose corpses had been washed up on the desolate beach.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The body, she knew, could do no harm to any one, but the spirit could pursue the lonely wanderer, attach itself to him, and demand to be carried to the churchyard, that it might rest in consecrated ground.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Hold fast! hold fast! the spectre would cry; and as Anne Lisbeth murmured these words to herself, the whole of her dream was suddenly recalled to her memory, when the mother had clung to her, and uttered these words, when, amid the crashing of worlds, her sleeve had been torn, and she had slipped from the grasp of her child, who wanted to hold her up in that terrible hour.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her child, her own child, which she had never loved, lay now buried in the sea, and might rise up, like a spectre, from the waters, and cry, "Hold fast; carry me to consecrated ground!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As these thoughts passed through her mind, fear gave speed to her feet, so that she walked faster and faster.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Fear came upon her as if a cold, clammy hand had been laid upon her heart, so that she almost fainted.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As she looked across the sea, all there grew darker; a heavy mist came rolling onwards, and clung to bush and tree, distorting them into fantastic shapes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She turned and glanced at the moon, which had risen behind her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It looked like a pale, rayless surface, and a deadly weight seemed to hang upon her limbs.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Hold, thought she; and then she turned round a second time to look at the moon.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A white face appeared quite close to her, with a mist, hanging like a garment from its shoulders.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Stop! carry me to consecrated earth, sounded in her ears, in strange, hollow tones.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sound did not come from frogs or ravens; she saw no sign of such creatures.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A grave! dig me a grave! was repeated quite loud.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, it was indeed the spectre of her child.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The child that lay beneath the ocean, and whose spirit could have no rest until it was carried to the churchyard, and until a grave had been dug for it in consecrated ground.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She would go there at once, and there she would dig.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She turned in the direction of the church, and the weight on her heart seemed to grow lighter, and even to vanish altogether; but when she turned to go home by the shortest way, it returned.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Stop! stop! and the words came quite clear, though they were like the croak of a frog, or the wail of a bird.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A grave! dig me a grave!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The mist was cold and damp, her hands and face were moist and clammy with horror, a heavy weight again seized her and clung to her, her mind became clear for thoughts that had never before been there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In these northern regions, a beech-wood often buds in a single night and appears in the morning sunlight in its full glory of youthful green.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So, in a single instant, can the consciousness of the sin that has been committed in thoughts, words, and actions of our past life, be unfolded to us.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When once the conscience is awakened, it springs up in the heart spontaneously, and God awakens the conscience when we least expect it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then we can find no excuse for ourselves; the deed is there and bears witness against us.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The thoughts seem to become words, and to sound far out into the world.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We are horrified at the thought of what we have carried within us, and at the consciousness that we have not overcome the evil which has its origin in thoughtlessness and pride.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The heart conceals within itself the vices as well as the virtues, and they grow in the shallowest ground.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Anne Lisbeth now experienced in thought what we have clothed in words.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was overpowered by them, and sank down and crept along for some distance on the ground.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A grave! dig me a grave! sounded again in her ears, and she would have gladly buried herself, if in the grave she could have found forgetfulness of her actions.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was the first hour of her awakening, full of anguish and horror.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Superstition made her alternately shudder with cold or burn with the heat of fever.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Many things, of which she had feared even to speak, came into her mind.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Silently, as the cloud-shadows in the moonshine, a spectral apparition flitted by her; she had heard of it before.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Close by her galloped four snorting steeds, with fire flashing from their eyes and nostrils.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They dragged a burning coach, and within it sat the wicked lord of the manor, who had ruled there a hundred years before.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The legend says that every night, at twelve o'clock, he drove into his castleyard and out again.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was not as pale as dead men are, but black as a coal.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He nodded, and pointed to Anne Lisbeth, crying out, "Hold fast! hold fast! and then you may ride again in a nobleman's carriage, and forget your child."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She gathered herself up, and hastened to the churchyard; but black crosses and black ravens danced before her eyes, and she could not distinguish one from the other.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The ravens croaked as the raven had done which she saw in the daytime, but now she understood what they said.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am the raven-mother; I am the raven-mother, each raven croaked, and Anne Lisbeth felt that the name also applied to her; and she fancied she should be transformed into a black bird, and have to cry as they cried, if she did not dig the grave.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And she threw herself upon the earth, and with her hands dug a grave in the hard ground, so that the blood ran from her fingers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A grave! dig me a grave! still sounded in her ears; she was fearful that the cock might crow, and the first red streak appear in the east, before she had finished her work; and then she would be lost.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the cock crowed, and the day dawned in the east, and the grave was only half dug.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: An icy hand passed over her head and face, and down towards her heart.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Only half a grave, a voice wailed, and fled away.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, it fled away over the sea; it was the ocean spectre; and, exhausted and overpowered, Anne Lisbeth sunk to the ground, and her senses left her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a bright day when she came to herself, and two men were raising her up; but she was not lying in the churchyard, but on the sea-shore, where she had dug a deep hole in the sand, and cut her hand with a piece of broken glass, whose sharp stern was stuck in a little block of painted wood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Anne Lisbeth was in a fever.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Conscience had roused the memories of superstitions, and had so acted upon her mind, that she fancied she had only half a soul, and that her child had taken the other half down into the sea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Never would she be able to cling to the mercy of Heaven till she had recovered this other half which was now held fast in the deep water.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Anne Lisbeth returned to her home, but she was no longer the woman she had been.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her thoughts were like a confused, tangled skein; only one thread, only one thought was clear to her, namely that she must carry the spectre of the sea-shore to the churchyard, and dig a grave for him there; that by so doing she might win back her soul.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Many a night she was missed from her home, and was always found on the sea-shore waiting for the spectre.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In this way a whole year passed; and then one night she vanished again, and was not to be found.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The whole of the next day was spent in a useless search after her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Towards evening, when the clerk entered the church to toll the vesper bell, he saw by the altar Anne Lisbeth, who had spent the whole day there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her powers of body were almost exhausted, but her eyes flashed brightly, and on her cheeks was a rosy flush.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The last rays of the setting sun shone upon her, and gleamed over the altar upon the shining clasps of the Bible, which lay open at the words of the prophet Joel, "Rend your hearts and not your garments, and turn unto the Lord."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That was just a chance, people said; but do things happen by chance?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the face of Anne Lisbeth, lighted up by the evening sun, could be seen peace and rest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She said she was happy now, for she had conquered.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The spectre of the shore, her own child, had come to her the night before, and had said to her, "Thou hast dug me only half a grave: but thou hast now, for a year and a day, buried me altogether in thy heart, and it is there a mother can best hide her child!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then he gave her back her lost soul, and brought her into the church.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now I am in the house of God, she said, "and in that house we are happy."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When the sun set, Anne Lisbeth's soul had risen to that region where there is no more pain; and Anne Lisbeth's troubles were at an end.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: IT was the month of May.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The wind still blew cold; but from bush and tree, field and flower, came the welcome sound, "Spring is come."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Wild-flowers in profusion covered the hedges.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Under the little apple-tree, Spring seemed busy, and told his tale from one of the branches which hung fresh and blooming, and covered with delicate pink blossoms that were just ready to open.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The branch well knew how beautiful it was; this knowledge exists as much in the leaf as in the blood; I was therefore not surprised when a nobleman's carriage, in which sat the young countess, stopped in the road just by.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She said that an apple-branch was a most lovely object, and an emblem of spring in its most charming aspect.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the branch was broken off for her, and she held it in her delicate hand, and sheltered it with her silk parasol.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they drove to the castle, in which were lofty halls and splendid drawing-rooms.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Pure white curtains fluttered before the open windows, and beautiful flowers stood in shining, transparent vases; and in one of them, which looked as if it had been cut out of newly fallen snow, the apple-branch was placed, among some fresh, light twigs of beech.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a charming sight.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the branch became proud, which was very much like human nature.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: People of every description entered the room, and, according to their position in society, so dared they to express their admiration.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Some few said nothing, others expressed too much, and the apple-branch very soon got to understand that there was as much difference in the characters of human beings as in those of plants and flowers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Some are all for pomp and parade, others have a great deal to do to maintain their own importance, while the rest might be spared without much loss to society.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So thought the apple-branch, as he stood before the open window, from which he could see out over gardens and fields, where there were flowers and plants enough for him to think and reflect upon; some rich and beautiful, some poor and humble indeed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Poor, despised herbs, said the apple-branch; "there is really a difference between them and such as I am.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How unhappy they must be, if they can feel as those in my position do!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There is a difference indeed, and so there ought to be, or we should all be equals."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the apple-branch looked with a sort of pity upon them, especially on a certain little flower that is found in fields and in ditches.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No one bound these flowers together in a nosegay; they were too common; they were even known to grow between the paving-stones, shooting up everywhere, like bad weeds; and they bore the very ugly name of "dog-flowers" or "dandelions."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Poor, despised plants, said the apple-bough, "it is not your fault that you are so ugly, and that you have such an ugly name; but it is with plants as with men,- there must be a difference."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A difference! cried the sunbeam, as he kissed the blooming apple-branch, and then kissed the yellow dandelion out in the fields.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All were brothers, and the sunbeam kissed them- the poor flowers as well as the rich.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The apple-bough had never thought of the boundless love of God, which extends over all the works of creation, over everything which lives, and moves, and has its being in Him; he had never thought of the good and beautiful which are so often hidden, but can never remain forgotten by Him,- not only among the lower creation, but also among men.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sunbeam, the ray of light, knew better.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You do not see very far, nor very clearly, he said to the apple-branch.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Which is the despised plant you so specially pity?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The dandelion, he replied.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
No one ever places it in a nosegay; it is often trodden under foot, there are so many of them; and when they run to seed, they have flowers like wool, which fly away in little pieces over the roads, and cling to the dresses of the people.
