author: HCAndersen
sentence: There came presently across the fields a whole group of children, the youngest of whom was so small that it had to be carried by the others; and when he was seated on the grass, among the yellow flowers, he laughed aloud with joy, kicked out his little legs, rolled about, plucked the yellow flowers, and kissed them in childlike innocence.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The elder children broke off the flowers with long stems, bent the stalks one round the other, to form links, and made first a chain for the neck, then one to go across the shoulders, and hang down to the waist, and at last a wreath to wear round the head, so that they looked quite splendid in their garlands of green stems and golden flowers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the eldest among them gathered carefully the faded flowers, on the stem of which was grouped together the seed, in the form of a white feathery coronal.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: These loose, airy wool-flowers are very beautiful, and look like fine snowy feathers or down.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The children held them to their mouths, and tried to blow away the whole coronal with one puff of the breath.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They had been told by their grandmothers that who ever did so would be sure to have new clothes before the end of the year.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The despised flower was by this raised to the position of a prophet or foreteller of events.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Do you see, said the sunbeam, "do you see the beauty of these flowers? do you see their powers of giving pleasure?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, to children, said the apple-bough.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: By-and-by an old woman came into the field, and, with a blunt knife without a handle, began to dig round the roots of some of the dandelion-plants, and pull them up.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: With some of these she intended to make tea for herself; but the rest she was going to sell to the chemist, and obtain some money.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But beauty is of higher value than all this, said the apple-tree branch; "only the chosen ones can be admitted into the realms of the beautiful.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There is a difference between plants, just as there is a difference between men."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the sunbeam spoke of the boundless love of God, as seen in creation, and over all that lives, and of the equal distribution of His gifts, both in time and in eternity.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That is your opinion, said the apple-bough.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then some people came into the room, and, among them, the young countess,- the lady who had placed the apple-bough in the transparent vase, so pleasantly beneath the rays of the sunlight.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She carried in her hand something that seemed like a flower.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The object was hidden by two or three great leaves, which covered it like a shield, so that no draught or gust of wind could injure it, and it was carried more carefully than the apple-branch had ever been.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Very cautiously the large leaves were removed, and there appeared the feathery seed-crown of the despised dandelion.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This was what the lady had so carefully plucked, and carried home so safely covered, so that not one of the delicate feathery arrows of which its mist-like shape was so lightly formed, should flutter away.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She now drew it forth quite uninjured, and wondered at its beautiful form, and airy lightness, and singular construction, so soon to be blown away by the wind.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: See, she exclaimed, "how wonderfully God has made this little flower.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I will paint it with the apple-branch together.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Every one admires the beauty of the apple-bough; but this humble flower has been endowed by Heaven with another kind of loveliness; and although they differ in appearance, both are the children of the realms of beauty."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the sunbeam kissed the lowly flower, and he kissed the blooming apple-branch, upon whose leaves appeared a rosy blush.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: IN the garden all the apple-trees were in blossom.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They had hastened to bring forth flowers before they got green leaves, and in the yard all the ducklings walked up and down, and the cat too: it basked in the sun and licked the sunshine from its own paws.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And when one looked at the fields, how beautifully the corn stood and how green it shone, without comparison! and there was a twittering and a fluttering of all the little birds, as if the day were a great festival; and so it was, for it was Sunday.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All the bells were ringing, and all the people went to church, looking cheerful, and dressed in their best clothes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There was a look of cheerfulness on everything.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The day was so warm and beautiful that one might well have said: "God's kindness to us men is beyond all limits."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But inside the church the pastor stood in the pulpit, and spoke very loudly and angrily.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He said that all men were wicked, and God would punish them for their sins, and that the wicked, when they died, would be cast into hell, to burn for ever and ever.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He spoke very excitedly, saying that their evil propensities would not be destroyed, nor would the fire be extinguished, and they should never find rest.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bell has indeed a strange sweet sound!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Shall we go there and see what the cause of it is?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The rich drove, the poor walked, but the way seemed to them extraordinarily long, and when they arrived at a number of willow trees on the border of the wood they sat down, looked up into the great branches and thought they were now really in the wood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A confectioner from the town also came out and put up a stall there; then came another confectioner who hung a bell over his stall, which was covered with pitch to protect it from the rain, but the clapper was wanting.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When people came home they used to say that it had been very romantic, and that really means something else than merely taking tea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Three persons declared that they had gone as far as the end of the wood; they had always heard the strange sound, but there it seemed to them as if it came from the town.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One of them wrote verses about the bell, and said that it was like the voice of a mother speaking to an intelligent and beloved child; no tune, he said, was sweeter than the sound of the bell.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The emperor of the country heard of it, and declared that he who would really find out where the sound came from should receive the title of "Bellringer to the World," even if there was no bell at all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now many went out into the wood for the sake of this splendid berth; but only one of them came back with some sort of explanation.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: None of them had gone far enough, nor had he, and yet he said that the sound of the bell came from a large owl in a hollow tree.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a wisdom owl, which continually knocked its head against the tree, but he was unable to say with certainty whether its head or the hollow trunk of the tree was the cause of the noise.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was appointed "Bellringer to the World," and wrote every year a short dissertation on the owl, but by this means people did not become any wiser than they had been before.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was just confirmation-day.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The clergyman had delivered a beautiful and touching sermon, the candidates were deeply moved by it; it was indeed a very important day for them; they were all at once transformed from mere children to grown-up people; the childish soul was to fly over, as it were, into a more reasonable being.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sun shone most brightly; and the sound of the great unknown bell was heard more distinctly than ever.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They had a mind to go thither, all except three.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One of them wished to go home and try on her ball dress, for this very dress and the ball were the cause of her being confirmed this time, otherwise she would not have been allowed to go.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The second, a poor boy, had borrowed a coat and a pair of boots from the son of his landlord to be confirmed in, and he had to return them at a certain time.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The third said that he never went into strange places if his parents were not with him; he had always been a good child, and wished to remain so, even after being confirmed, and they ought not to tease him for this; they, however, did it all the same.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: These three, therefore did not go; the others went on.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sun was shining, the birds were singing, and the confirmed children sang too, holding each other by the hand, for they had no position yet, and they were all equal in the eyes of God.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Two of the smallest soon became tired and returned to the town; two little girls sat down and made garlands of flowers, they, therefore, did not go on.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When the others arrived at the willow trees, where the confectioner had put up his stall, they said: "Now we are out here; the bell does not in reality exist- it is only something that people imagine!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then suddenly the sound of the bell was heard so beautifully and solemnly from the wood that four or five made up their minds to go still further on.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The wood was very thickly grown.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was difficult to advance: wood lilies and anemones grew almost too high; flowering convolvuli and brambles were hanging like garlands from tree to tree; while the nightingales were singing and the sunbeams played.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That was very beautiful!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the way was unfit for the girls; they would have torn their dresses.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Large rocks, covered with moss of various hues, were lying about; the fresh spring water rippled forth with a peculiar sound.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I don't think that can be the bell, said one of the confirmed children, and then he lay down and listened.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We must try to find out if it is!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And there he remained, and let the others walk on.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They came to a hut built of the bark of trees and branches; a large crab-apple tree spread its branches over it, as if it intended to pour all its fruit on the roof, upon which roses were blooming; the long boughs covered the gable, where a little bell was hanging.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Was this the one they had heard?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All agreed that it must be so, except one who said that the bell was too small and too thin to be heard at such a distance, and that it had quite a different sound to that which had so touched men's hearts.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He who spoke was a king's son, and therefore the others said that such a one always wishes to be cleverer than other people.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Therefore they let him go alone; and as he walked on, the solitude of the wood produced a feeling of reverence in his breast; but still he heard the little bell about which the others rejoiced, and sometimes, when the wind blew in that direction, he could hear the sounds from the confectioner's stall, where the others were singing at tea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the deep sounds of the bell were much stronger; soon it seemed to him as if an organ played an accompaniment- the sound came from the left, from the side where the heart is.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now something rustled among the bushes, and a little boy stood before the king's son, in wooden shoes and such a short jacket that the sleeves did not reach to his wrists.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They knew each other: the boy was the one who had not been able to go with them because he had to take the coat and boots back to his landlord's son.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That he had done, and had started again in his wooden shoes and old clothes, for the sound of the bell was too enticing- he felt he must go on.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We might go together, said the king's son.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the poor boy with the wooden shoes was quite ashamed; he pulled at the short sleeves of his jacket, and said that he was afraid he could not walk so fast; besides, he was of opinion that the bell ought to be sought at the right, for there was all that was grand and magnificent.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then we shall not meet, said the king's son, nodding to the poor boy, who went into the deepest part of the wood, where the thorns tore his shabby clothes and scratched his hands, face, and feet until they bled.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The king's son also received several good scratches, but the sun was shining on his way, and it is he whom we will now follow, for he was a quick fellow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I will and must find the bell, he said, "if I have to go to the end of the world."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ugly monkeys sat high in the branches and clenched their teeth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Shall we beat him? they said.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Shall we thrash him?
54:54	N:N	N:-	He is a king's son!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But he walked on undaunted, deeper and deeper into the wood, where the most wonderful flowers were growing; there were standing white star lilies with blood-red stamens, sky-blue tulips shining when the wind moved them; apple-trees covered with apples like large glittering soap bubbles: only think how resplendent these trees were in the sunshine!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All around were beautiful green meadows, where hart and hind played in the grass.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There grew magnificent oaks and beech-trees; and if the bark was split of any of them, long blades of grass grew out of the clefts; there were also large smooth lakes in the wood, on which the swans were swimming about and flapping their wings.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The king's son often stood still and listened; sometimes he thought that the sound of the bell rose up to him out of one of these deep lakes, but soon he found that this was a mistake, and that the bell was ringing still farther in the wood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the sun set, the clouds were as red as fire; it became quiet in the wood; he sank down on his knees, sang an evening hymn and said: "I shall never find what I am looking for!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now the sun is setting, and the night, the dark night, is approaching.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yet I may perhaps see the round sun once more before he disappears beneath the horizon.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I will climb up these rocks, they are as high as the highest trees!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then, taking hold of the creepers and roots, he climbed up on the wet stones, where water-snakes were wriggling and the toads, as it were, barked at him: he reached the top before the sun, seen from such a height, had quite set.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, what a splendour!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sea, the great majestic sea, which was rolling its long waves against the shore, stretched out before him, and the sun was standing like a large bright altar and there where sea and heaven met- all melted together in the most glowing colours; the wood was singing, and his heart too.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The whole of nature was one large holy church, in which the trees and hovering clouds formed the pillars, the flowers and grass the woven velvet carpet, and heaven itself was the great cupola; up there the flame colour vanished as soon as the sun disappeared, but millions of stars were lighted; diamond lamps were shining, and the king's son stretched his arms out towards heaven, towards the sea, and towards the wood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then suddenly the poor boy with the short-sleeved jacket and the wooden shoes appeared; he had arrived just as quickly on the road he had chosen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And they ran towards each other and took one another's hand, in the great cathedral of nature and poesy, and above them sounded the invisible holy bell; happy spirits surrounded them, singing hallelujahs and rejoicing.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: DING-DONG! ding-dong!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It sounds up from the "bell-deep" in the Odense-Au.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Every child in the old town of Odense, on the island of Funen, knows the Au, which washes the gardens round about the town, and flows on under the wooden bridges from the dam to the water-mill.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the Au grow the yellow water-lilies and brown feathery reeds; the dark velvety flag grows there, high and thick; old and decayed willows, slanting and tottering, hang far out over the stream beside the monk's meadow and by the bleaching ground; but opposite there are gardens upon gardens, each different from the rest, some with pretty flowers and bowers like little dolls' pleasure grounds, often displaying cabbage and other kitchen plants; and here and there the gardens cannot be seen at all, for the great elder trees that spread themselves out by the bank, and hang far out over the streaming waters, which are deeper here and there than an oar can fathom.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Opposite the old nunnery is the deepest place, which is called the "bell-deep," and there dwells the old water spirit, the "Au-mann."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This spirit sleeps through the day while the sun shines down upon the water; but in starry and moonlit nights he shows himself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He is very old.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Grandmother says that she has heard her own grandmother tell of him; he is said to lead a solitary life, and to have nobody with whom he can converse save the great old church Bell.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Once the Bell hung in the church tower; but now there is no trace left of the tower or of the church, which was called St. Alban's.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ding-dong! ding-dong! sounded the Bell, when the tower still stood there; and one evening, while the sun was setting, and the Bell was swinging away bravely, it broke loose and came flying down through the air, the brilliant metal shining in the ruddy beam.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Ding-dong! ding-dong!
11:11	H:H	H:N	Now I'll retire to rest! sang the Bell, and flew down into the Odense-Au, where it is deepest; and that is why the place is called the "bell-deep."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the Bell got neither rest nor sleep.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Down in the Au-mann's haunt it sounds and rings, so that the tones sometimes pierce upward through the waters; and many people maintain that its strains forebode the death of some one; but that is not true, for the Bell is only talking with the Au-mann, who is now no longer alone.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And what is the Bell telling?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is old, very old, as we have already observed; it was there long before grandmother's grandmother was born; and yet it is but a child in comparison with the Au-mann, who is quite an old quiet personage, an oddity, with his hose of eel-skin, and his scaly Jacket with the yellow lilies for buttons, and a wreath of reed in his hair and seaweed in his beard; but he looks very pretty for all that.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What the Bell tells?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: To repeat it all would require years and days; for year by year it is telling the old stories, sometimes short ones, sometimes long ones, according to its whim; it tells of old times, of the dark hard times, thus: "In the church of St. Alban, the monk had mounted up into the tower.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was young and handsome, but thoughtful exceedingly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He looked through the loophole out upon the Odense-Au, when the bed of the water was yet broad, and the monks' meadow was still a lake.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He looked out over it, and over the rampart, and over the nuns' hill opposite, where the convent lay, and the light gleamed forth from the nun's cell.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had known the nun right well, and he thought of her, and his heart beat quicker as he thought.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ding-dong! ding-dong!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, this was the story the Bell told.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Into the tower came also the dapper man-servant of the bishop; and when I, the Bell, who am made of metal, rang hard and loud, and swung to and fro, I might have beaten out his brains.

26:26	N:N	H:N	'Now I may sing it out aloud, though at other times I may not whisper it.
27:27	Sa:N	H:N	I may sing of everything that is kept concealed behind lock and bars.
28:28	Sa:N	H:N	Yonder it is cold and wet.
29:29	F:N	S:-	The rats are eating her up alive!
30:30	Sa:N	S:-	Nobody knows of it!
31:31	Sa:N	S:-	Nobody hears of it!
32:32	Sa:N	S:-	Not even now, for the bell is ringing and singing its loud Ding-dong, ding-dong!'
33:33	N:N	S:N	There was a King in those days.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They called him Canute.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He bowed himself before bishop and monk; but when he offended the free peasants with heavy taxes and hard words, they seized their weapons and put him to flight like a wild beast.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He sought shelter in the church, and shut gate and door behind him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The violent band surrounded the church; I heard tell of it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The crows, ravens and magpies started up in terror at the yelling and shouting that sounded around.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They flew into the tower and out again, they looked down upon the throng below, and they also looked into the windows of the church, and screamed out aloud what they saw there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: King Canute knelt before the altar in prayer; his brothers Eric and Benedict stood by him as a guard with drawn swords; but the King's servant, the treacherous Blake, betrayed his master.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The throng in front of the church knew where they could hit the King, and one of them flung a stone through a pane of glass, and the King lay there dead!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The cries and screams of the savage horde and of the birds sounded through the air, and I joined in it also; for I sang 'Ding-dong! ding-dong!'

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
The church bell hangs high, and looks far around, and sees the birds around it, and understands their language.
44:44	H:N	S:N	The wind roars in upon it through windows and loopholes; and the wind knows everything, for he gets it from the air, which encircles all things, and the church bell understands his tongue, and rings it out into the world, 'Ding-dong! ding-dong!'
45:45	Sa:N	S:N	But it was too much for me to hear and to know; I was not able any longer to ring it out.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I became so tired, so heavy, that the beam broke, and I flew out into the gleaming Au, where the water is deepest, and where the Au-mann lives, solitary and alone; and year by year I tell him what I have heard and what I know.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ding-dong! ding-dong" Thus it sounds complainingly out of the bell-deep in the Odense-Au.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That is what grandmother told us.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the schoolmaster says that there was not any bell that rung down there, for that it could not do so; and that no Au-mann dwelt yonder, for there was no Au-mann at all!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And when all the other church bells are sounding sweetly, he says that it is not really the bells that are sounding, but that it is the air itself which sends forth the notes; and grandmother said to us that the Bell itself said it was the air who told it to him, consequently they are agreed on that point, and this much is sure.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Be cautious, cautious, and take good heed to thyself, they both say.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The air knows everything.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is around us, it is in us, it talks of our thoughts and of our deeds, and it speaks longer of them than does the Bell down in the depths of the Odense-Au where the Au-mann dwells.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It rings it out in the vault of heaven, far, far out, forever and ever, till the heaven bells sound "Ding-dong! ding-dong!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: OUR scene is laid in Northern Jutland, in the so-called "wild moor."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We hear what is called the "Wester-wow-wow"- the peculiar roar of the North Sea as it breaks against the western coast of Jutland.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It rolls and thunders with a sound that penetrates for miles into the land; and we are quite near the roaring.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Before us rises a great mound of sand- a mountain we have long seen, and towards which we are wending our way, driving slowly along through the deep sand.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On this mountain of sand is a lofty old building- the convent of Borglum.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In one of its wings (the larger one) there is still a church.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And at this convent we now arrive in the late evening hour; but the weather is clear in the bright June night around us, and the eye can range far, far over field and moor to the Bay of Aalborg, over heath and meadow, and far across the deep blue sea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now we are there, and roll past between barns and other farm buildings; and at the left of the gate we turn aside to the Old Castle Farm, where the lime trees stand in lines along the walls, and, sheltered from the wind and weather, grow so luxuriantly that their twigs and leaves almost conceal the windows.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We mount the winding staircase of stone, and march through the long passages under the heavy roof-beams.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The wind moans very strangely here, both within and without.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is hardly known how, but the people say- yes, people say a great many things when they are frightened or want to frighten others- they say that the old dead choir-men glide silently past us into the church, where mass is sung.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They can be heard in the rushing of the storm, and their singing brings up strange thoughts in the hearers- thoughts of the old times into which we are carried back.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On the coast a ship is stranded; and the bishop's warriors are there, and spare not those whom the sea has spared.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sea washes away the blood that has flowed from the cloven skulls.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The stranded goods belong to the bishop, and there is a store of goods here.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sea casts up tubs and barrels filled with costly wine for the convent cellar, and in the convent is already good store of beer and mead.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There is plenty in the kitchen- dead game and poultry, hams and sausages; and fat fish swim in the ponds without.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The Bishop of Borglum is a mighty lord.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He has great possessions, but still he longs for more- everything must bow before the mighty Olaf Glob.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His rich cousin at Thyland is dead, and his widow is to have the rich inheritance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But how comes it that one relation is always harder towards another than even strangers would be?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The widow's husband had possessed all Thyland, with the exception of the church property.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her son was not at home.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In his boyhood he had already started on a journey, for his desire was to see foreign lands and strange people.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: For years there had been no news of him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Perhaps he had been long laid in the grave, and would never come back to his home, to rule where his mother then ruled.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What has a woman to do with rule? said the bishop.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He summoned the widow before a law court; but what did he gain thereby?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The widow had never been disobedient to the law, and was strong in her just rights.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Bishop Olaf of Borglum, what dost thou purpose?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What writest thou on yonder smooth parchment, sealing it with thy seal, and intrusting it to the horsemen and servants, who ride away, far away, to the city of the Pope?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is the time of falling leaves and of stranded ships, and soon icy winter will come.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Twice had icy winter returned before the bishop welcomed the horsemen and servants back to their home.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They came from Rome with a papal decree- a ban, or bull, against the widow who had dared to offend the pious bishop.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Cursed be she and all that belongs to her.
35:35	D:A	D:A	Let her be expelled from the congregation and the Church.
36:36	D:A	D:-	Let no man stretch forth a helping hand to her, and let friends and relations avoid her as a plague and a pestilence!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What will not bend must break, said the Bishop of Borglum And all forsake the widow; but she holds fast to her God.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He is her helper and defender.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One servant only- an old maid- remained faithful to her; and with the old servant, the widow herself followed the plough; and the crop grew, although the land had been cursed by the Pope and by the bishop.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thou child of perdition, I will yet carry out my purpose! cried the Bishop of Borglum.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now will I lay the hand of the Pope upon thee, to summon thee before the tribunal that shall condemn thee!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then did the widow yoke the last two oxen that remained to her to a wagon, and mounted up on the wagon, with her old servant, and travelled away across the heath out of the Danish land.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As a stranger she came into a foreign country, where a strange tongue was spoken and where new customs prevailed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Farther and farther she journeyed, to where green hills rise into mountains, and the vine clothes their sides.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Strange merchants drive by her, and they look anxiously after their wagons laden with merchandise.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They fear an attack from the armed followers of the robber-knights.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The two poor women, in their humble vehicle drawn by two black oxen, travel fearlessly through the dangerous sunken road and through the darksome forest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And now they were in Franconia.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And there met them a stalwart knight, with a train of twelve armed followers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He paused, gazed at the strange vehicle, and questioned the women as to the goal of their journey and the place whence they came.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then one of them mentioned Thyland in Denmark, and spoke of her sorrows, of her woes, which were soon to cease, for so Divine Providence had willed it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: For the stranger knight is the widow's son!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He seized her hand, he embraced her, and the mother wept.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: For years she had not been able to weep, but had only bitten her lips till the blood started.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is the time of falling leaves and of stranded ships, and soon will icy winter come.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sea rolled wine-tubs to the shore for the bishop's cellar.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the kitchen the deer roasted on the spit before the fire.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At Borglum it was warm and cheerful in the heated rooms, while cold winter raged without, when a piece of news was brought to the bishop.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Jens Glob, of Thyland, has come back, and his mother with him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Jens Glob laid a complaint against the bishop, and summoned him before the temporal and the spiritual court.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That will avail him little, said the bishop.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Best leave off thy efforts, knight Jens.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Again it is the time of falling leaves and stranded ships.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Icy winter comes again, and the "white bees" are swarming, and sting the traveller's face till they melt.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Keen weather to-day! say the people, as they step in.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Jens Glob stands so deeply wrapped in thought, that he singes the skirt of his wide garment.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thou Borglum bishop, he exclaims, "I shall subdue thee after all!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Under the shield of the Pope, the law cannot reach thee; but Jens Glob shall reach thee!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he writes a letter to his brother-in-law, Olaf Hase, in Sallingland, and prays that knight to meet him on Christmas eve, at mass, in the church at Widberg.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bishop himself is to read the mass, and consequently will journey from Borglum to Thyland; and this is known to Jens Glob.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Moorland and meadow are covered with ice and snow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The marsh will bear horse and rider, the bishop with his priests and armed men.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They ride the shortest way, through the waving reeds, where the wind moans sadly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Blow thy brazen trumpet, thou trumpeter clad in fox-skin! it sounds merrily in the clear air.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So they ride on over heath and moorland- over what is the garden of Fata Morgana in the hot summer, though now icy, like all the country- towards the church of Widberg.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The wind is blowing his trumpet too- blowing it harder and harder.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He blows up a storm- a terrible storm- that increases more and more.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Towards the church they ride, as fast as they may through the storm.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The church stands firm, but the storm careers on over field and moorland, over land and sea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Borglum's bishop reaches the church; but Olaf Hase will scarce do so, however hard he may ride.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He journeys with his warriors on the farther side of the bay, in order that he may help Jens Glob, now that the bishop is to be summoned before the judgment seat of the Highest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The church is the judgment hall; the altar is the council table.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The lights burn clear in the heavy brass candelabra.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The storm reads out the accusation and the sentence, roaming in the air over moor and heath, and over the rolling waters.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No ferry-boat can sail over the bay in such weather as this.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Olaf Hase makes halt at Ottesworde.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There he dismisses his warriors, presents them with their horses and harness, and gives them leave to ride home and greet his wife.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He intends to risk his life alone in the roaring waters; but they are to bear witness for him that it is not his fault if Jens Glob stands without reinforcement in the church at Widberg.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The faithful warriors will not leave him, but follow him out into the deep waters.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ten of them are carried away; but Olaf Hase and two of the youngest men reach the farther side.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They have still four miles to ride.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is past midnight.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is Christmas.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The wind has abated.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The church is lighted up; the gleaming radiance shines through the window-frames, and pours out over meadow and heath.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The mass has long been finished, silence reigns in the church, and the wax is heard dropping from the candles to the stone pavement.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And now Olaf Hase arrives.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the forecourt Jens Glob greets him kindly, and says, "I have just made an agreement with the bishop."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Sayest thou so? replied Olaf Hase.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then neither thou nor the bishop shall quit this church alive.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the sword leaps from the scabbard, and Olaf Hase deals a blow that makes the panel of the church door, which Jens Glob hastily closes between them, fly in fragments.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Hold, brother!
103:103	N:N	N:-	First hear what the agreement was that I made.
104:104	N:N	-:-	I have slain the bishop and his warriors and priests.
105:105	H:N	H:-	They will have no word more to say in the matter, nor will I speak again of all the wrong that my mother has endured.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The long wicks of the altar lights glimmer red; but there is a redder gleam upon the pavement, where the bishop lies with cloven skull, and his dead warriors around him, in the quiet of the holy Christmas night.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And four days afterwards the bells toll for a funeral in the convent of Borglum.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The murdered bishop and the slain warriors and priests are displayed under a black canopy, surrounded by candelabra decked with crape.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There lies the dead man, in the black cloak wrought with silver; the crozier in the powerless hand that was once so mighty.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The incense rises in clouds, and the monks chant the funeral hymn.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It sounds like a wail- it sounds like a sentence of wrath and condemnation, that must be heard far over the land, carried by the wind- sung by the wind- the wail that sometimes is silent, but never dies; for ever again it rises in song, singing even into our own time this legend of the Bishop of Borglum and his hard nephew.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is heard in the dark night by the frightened husbandman, driving by in the heavy sandy road past the convent of Borglum.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is heard by the sleepless listener in the thickly-walled rooms at Borglum.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And not only to the ear of superstition is the sighing and the tread of hurrying feet audible in the long echoing passages leading to the convent door that has long been locked.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The door still seems to open, and the lights seem to flame in the brazen candlesticks; the fragrance of incense arises; the church gleams in its ancient splendor; and the monks sing and say the mass over the slain bishop, who lies there in the black silver-embroidered mantle, with the crozier in his powerless hand; and on his pale proud forehead gleams the red wound like fire, and there burn the worldly mind and the wicked thoughts.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Sink down into his grave- into oblivion- ye terrible shapes of the times of old!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Hark to the raging of the angry wind, sounding above the rolling sea!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A storm approaches without, calling aloud for human lives.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sea has not put on a new mind with the new time.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This night it is a horrible pit to devour up lives, and to-morrow, perhaps, it may be a glassy mirror- even as in the old time that we have buried.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Sleep sweetly, if thou canst sleep!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now it is morning.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The new time flings sunshine into the room.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The wind still keeps up mightily.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A wreck is announced- as in the old time.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: During the night, down yonder by Lokken, the little fishing village with the red-tiled roofs- we can see it up here from the window- a ship has come ashore.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It has struck, and is fast embedded in the sand; but the rocket apparatus has thrown a rope on board, and formed a bridge from the wreck to the mainland; and all on board are saved, and reach the land, and are wrapped in warm blankets; and to-day they are invited to the farm at the convent of Borglum.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In comfortable rooms they encounter hospitality and friendly faces.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They are addressed in the language of their country, and the piano sounds for them with melodies of their native land; and before these have died away, the chord has been struck, the wire of thought that reaches to the land of the sufferers announces that they are rescued.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then their anxieties are dispelled; and at even they join in the dance at the feast given in the great hall at Borglum.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Waltzes and Styrian dances are given, and Danish popular songs, and melodies of foreign lands in these modern times.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Blessed be thou, new time!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Speak thou of summer and of purer gales!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Send thy sunbeams gleaming into our hearts and thoughts!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On thy glowing canvas let them be painted- the dark legends of the rough hard times that are past!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: CLOSE to the corner of a street, among other abodes of poverty, stood an exceedingly tall, narrow house, which had been so knocked about by time that it seemed out of joint in every direction.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This house was inhabited by poor people, but the deepest poverty was apparent in the garret lodging in the gable.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In front of the little window, an old bent bird-cage hung in the sunshine, which had not even a proper water-glass, but instead of it the broken neck of a bottle, turned upside down, and a cork stuck in to make it hold the water with which it was filled.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: An old maid stood at the window; she had hung chickweed over the cage, and the little linnet which it contained hopped from perch to perch and sang and twittered merrily.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, it's all very well for you to sing, said the bottle neck: that is, he did not really speak the words as we do, for the neck of a bottle cannot speak; but he thought them to himself in his own mind, just as people sometimes talk quietly to themselves.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Yes, you may sing very well, you have all your limbs uninjured; you should feel what it is like to lose your body, and only have a neck and a mouth left, with a cork stuck in it, as I have: you wouldn't sing then, I know.
6:6	N:N	N:S	After all, it is just as well that there are some who can be happy.
7:7	Sa:N	S:S	I have no reason to sing, nor could I sing now if I were ever so happy; but when I was a whole bottle, and they rubbed me with a cork, didn't I sing then?
8:8	N:N	N:S	I used to be called a complete lark.
9:9	N:N	N:S	I remember when I went out to a picnic with the furrier's family, on the day his daughter was betrothed,- it seems as if it only happened yesterday.
10:10	N:N	N:S	I have gone through a great deal in my time, when I come to recollect: I have been in the fire and in the water, I have been deep in the earth, and have mounted higher in the air than most other people, and now I am swinging here, outside a bird-cage, in the air and the sunshine.
11:11	N:N	N:S	Oh, indeed, it would be worth while to hear my history; but I do not speak it aloud, for a good reason- because I cannot.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the bottle neck related his history, which was really rather remarkable; he, in fact, related it to himself, or, at least, thought it in his own mind.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The little bird sang his own song merrily; in the street below there was driving and running to and fro, every one thought of his own affairs, or perhaps of nothing at all; but the bottle neck thought deeply.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He thought of the blazing furnace in the factory, where he had been blown into life; he remembered how hot it felt when he was placed in the heated oven, the home from which he sprang, and that he had a strong inclination to leap out again directly; but after a while it became cooler, and he found himself very comfortable.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had been placed in a row, with a whole regiment of his brothers and sisters all brought out of the same furnace; some of them had certainly been blown into champagne bottles, and others into beer bottles, which made a little difference between them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the world it often happens that a beer bottle may contain the most precious wine, and a champagne bottle be filled with blacking, but even in decay it may always be seen whether a man has been well born.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Nobility remains noble, as a champagne bottle remains the same, even with blacking in its interior.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When the bottles were packed our bottle was packed amongst them; it little expected then to finish its career as a bottle neck, or to be used as a water-glass to a bird's-cage, which is, after all, a place of honor, for it is to be of some use in the world.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bottle did not behold the light of day again, until it was unpacked with the rest in the wine merchant's cellar, and, for the first time, rinsed with water, which caused some very curious sensations.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There it lay empty, and without a cork, and it had a peculiar feeling, as if it wanted something it knew not what.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At last it was filled with rich and costly wine, a cork was placed in it, and sealed down.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then it was labelled "first quality," as if it had carried off the first prize at an examination; besides, the wine and the bottle were both good, and while we are young is the time for poetry.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There were sounds of song within the bottle, of things it could not understand, of green sunny mountains, where the vines grow and where the merry vine-dressers laugh, sing, and are merry.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ah, how beautiful is life.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All these tones of joy and song in the bottle were like the working of a young poet's brain, who often knows not the meaning of the tones which are sounding within him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One morning the bottle found a purchaser in the furrier's apprentice, who was told to bring one of the best bottles of wine.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was placed in the provision basket with ham and cheese and sausages.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sweetest fresh butter and the finest bread were put into the basket by the furrier's daughter herself, for she packed it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was young and pretty; her brown eyes laughed, and a smile lingered round her mouth as sweet as that in her eyes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She had delicate hands, beautifully white, and her neck was whiter still.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It could easily be seen that she was a very lovely girl, and as yet she was not engaged.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The provision basket lay in the lap of the young girl as the family drove out to the forest, and the neck of the bottle peeped out from between the folds of the white napkin.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There was the red wax on the cork, and the bottle looked straight at the young girl's face, and also at the face of the young sailor who sat near her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was a young friend, the son of a portrait painter.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had lately passed his examination with honor, as mate, and the next morning he was to sail in his ship to a distant coast.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There had been a great deal of talk on this subject while the basket was being packed, and during this conversation the eyes and the mouth of the furrier's daughter did not wear a very joyful expression.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The young people wandered away into the green wood, and talked together.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What did they talk about?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bottle could not say, for he was in the provision basket.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It remained there a long time; but when at last it was brought forth it appeared as if something pleasant had happened, for every one was laughing; the furrier's daughter laughed too, but she said very little, and her cheeks were like two roses.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then her father took the bottle and the cork-screw into his hands.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What a strange sensation it was to have the cork drawn for the first time!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bottle could never after that forget the performance of that moment; indeed there was quite a convulsion within him as the cork flew out, and a gurgling sound as the wine was poured forth into the glasses.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Long life to the betrothed, cried the papa, and every glass was emptied to the dregs, while the young sailor kissed his beautiful bride.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Happiness and blessing to you both, said the old people-father and mother, and the young man filled the glasses again.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Safe return, and a wedding this day next year, he cried; and when the glasses were empty he took the bottle, raised it on high, and said, "Thou hast been present here on the happiest day of my life; thou shalt never be used by others!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So saying, he hurled it high in the air.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The furrier's daughter thought she should never see it again, but she was mistaken.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It fell among the rushes on the borders of a little woodland lake.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bottle neck remembered well how long it lay there unseen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I gave them wine, and they gave me muddy water, he had said to himself, "but I suppose it was all well meant."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He could no longer see the betrothed couple, nor the cheerful old people; but for a long time he could hear them rejoicing and singing.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At length there came by two peasant boys, who peeped in among the reeds and spied out the bottle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they took it up and carried it home with them, so that once more it was provided for.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At home in their wooden cottage these boys had an elder brother, a sailor, who was about to start on a long voyage.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had been there the day before to say farewell, and his mother was now very busy packing up various things for him to take with him on his voyage.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the evening his father was going to carry the parcel to the town to see his son once more, and take him a farewell greeting from his mother.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A small bottle had already been filled with herb tea, mixed with brandy, and wrapped in a parcel; but when the boys came in they brought with them a larger and stronger bottle, which they had found.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This bottle would hold so much more than the little one, and they all said the brandy would be so good for complaints of the stomach, especially as it was mixed with medical herbs.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The liquid which they now poured into the bottle was not like the red wine with which it had once been filled; these were bitter drops, but they are of great use sometimes-for the stomach.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The new large bottle was to go, not the little one: so the bottle once more started on its travels.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was taken on board (for Peter Jensen was one of the crew) the very same ship in which the young mate was to sail.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the mate did not see the bottle: indeed, if he had he would not have known it, or supposed it was the one out of which they had drunk to the felicity of the betrothed and to the prospect of a marriage on his own happy return.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Certainly the bottle no longer poured forth wine, but it contained something quite as good; and so it happened that whenever Peter Jensen brought it out, his messmates gave it the name of "the apothecary," for it contained the best medicine to cure the stomach, and he gave it out quite willingly as long as a drop remained.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Those were happy days, and the bottle would sing when rubbed with a cork, and it was called a great lark," "Peter Jensen's lark."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Long days and months rolled by, during which the bottle stood empty in a corner, when a storm arose- whether on the passage out or home it could not tell, for it had never been ashore.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a terrible storm, great waves arose, darkly heaving and tossing the vessel to and fro.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The main mast was split asunder, the ship sprang a leak, and the pumps became useless, while all around was black as night.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At the last moment, when the ship was sinking, the young mate wrote on a piece of paper, "We are going down: God's will be done."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he wrote the name of his betrothed, his own name, and that of the ship.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he put the leaf in an empty bottle that happened to be at hand, corked it down tightly, and threw it into the foaming sea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He knew not that it was the very same bottle from which the goblet of joy and hope had once been filled for him, and now it was tossing on the waves with his last greeting, and a message from the dead.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The ship sank, and the crew sank with her; but the bottle flew on like a bird, for it bore within it a loving letter from a loving heart.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And as the sun rose and set, the bottle felt as at the time of its first existence, when in the heated glowing stove it had a longing to fly away.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It outlived the storms and the calm, it struck against no rocks, was not devoured by sharks, but drifted on for more than a year, sometimes towards the north, sometimes towards the south, just as the current carried it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was in all other ways its own master, but even of that one may get tired.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The written leaf, the last farewell of the bridegroom to his bride, would only bring sorrow when once it reached her hands; but where were those hands, so soft and delicate, which had once spread the table-cloth on the fresh grass in the green wood, on the day of her betrothal?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ah, yes! where was the furrier's daughter? and where was the land which might lie nearest to her home?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bottle knew not, it travelled onward and onward, and at last all this wandering about became wearisome; at all events it was not its usual occupation.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But it had to travel, till at length it reached land- a foreign country.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Not a word spoken in this country could the bottle understand; it was a language it had never before heard, and it is a great loss not to be able to understand a language.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bottle was fished out of the water, and examined on all sides.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The little letter contained within it was discovered, taken out, and turned and twisted in every direction; but the people could not understand what was written upon it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They could be quite sure that the bottle had been thrown overboard from a vessel, and that something about it was written on this paper: but what was written? that was the question,- so the paper was put back into the bottle, and then both were put away in a large cupboard of one of the great houses of the town.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Whenever any strangers arrived, the paper was taken out and turned over and over, so that the address, which was only written in pencil, became almost illegible, and at last no one could distinguish any letters on it at all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: For a whole year the bottle remained standing in the cupboard, and then it was taken up to the loft, where it soon became covered with dust and cobwebs.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ah! how often then it thought of those better days- of the times when in the fresh, green wood, it had poured forth rich wine; or, while rocked by the swelling waves, it had carried in its bosom a secret, a letter, a last parting sigh.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: For full twenty years it stood in the loft, and it might have stayed there longer but that the house was going to be rebuilt.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bottle was discovered when the roof was taken off; they talked about it, but the bottle did not understand what they said- a language is not to be learnt by living in a loft, even for twenty years.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If I had been down stairs in the room, thought the bottle, "I might have learnt it."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was now washed and rinsed, which process was really quite necessary, and afterwards it looked clean and transparent, and felt young again in its old age; but the paper which it had carried so faithfully was destroyed in the washing.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They filled the bottle with seeds, though it scarcely knew what had been placed in it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they corked it down tightly, and carefully wrapped it up.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There not even the light of a torch or lantern could reach it, much less the brightness of the sun or moon.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And yet, thought the bottle, "men go on a journey that they may see as much as possible, and I can see nothing."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: However, it did something quite as important; it travelled to the place of its destination, and was unpacked.

author: HCAndersen
