author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the bottle was not broken, and, better still, it understood every word that was said: this language it had heard at the furnaces and at the wine merchant's; in the forest and on the ship,- it was the only good old language it could understand.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It had returned home, and the language was as a welcome greeting.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: For very joy, it felt ready to jump out of people's hands, and scarcely noticed that its cork had been drawn, and its contents emptied out, till it found itself carried to a cellar, to be left there and forgotten.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There's no place like home, even if it's a cellar.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It never occurred to him to think that he might lie there for years, he felt so comfortable.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: For many long years he remained in the cellar, till at last some people came to carry away the bottles, and ours amongst the number.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Out in the garden there was a great festival.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Brilliant lamps hung in festoons from tree to tree; and paper lanterns, through which the light shone till they looked like transparent tulips.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a beautiful evening, and the weather mild and clear.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The stars twinkled; and the new moon, in the form of a crescent, was surrounded by the shadowy disc of the whole moon, and looked like a gray globe with a golden rim: it was a beautiful sight for those who had good eyes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The illumination extended even to the most retired of the garden walks, at least not so retired that any one need lose himself there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the borders were placed bottles, each containing a light, and among them the bottle with which we are acquainted, and whose fate it was, one day, to be only a bottle neck, and to serve as a water-glass to a bird's-cage.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Everything here appeared lovely to our bottle, for it was again in the green wood, amid joy and feasting; again it heard music and song, and the noise and murmur of a crowd, especially in that part of the garden where the lamps blazed, and the paper lanterns displayed their brilliant colors.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It stood in a distant walk certainly, but a place pleasant for contemplation; and it carried a light; and was at once useful and ornamental.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In such an hour it is easy to forget that one has spent twenty years in a loft, and a good thing it is to be able to do so.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Close before the bottle passed a single pair, like the bridal pair- the mate and the furrier's daughter- who had so long ago wandered in the wood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It seemed to the bottle as if he were living that time over again.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Not only the guests but other people were walking in the garden, who were allowed to witness the splendor and the festivities.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Among the latter came an old maid, who seemed to be quite alone in the world.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was thinking, like the bottle, of the green wood, and of a young betrothed pair, who were closely connected with herself; she was thinking of that hour, the happiest of her life, in which she had taken part, when she had herself been one of that betrothed pair; such hours are never to be forgotten, let a maiden be as old as she may.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But she did not recognize the bottle, neither did the bottle notice the old maid.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And so we often pass each other in the world when we meet, as did these two, even while together in the same town.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bottle was taken from the garden, and again sent to a wine merchant, where it was once more filled with wine, and sold to an aeronaut, who was to make an ascent in his balloon on the following Sunday.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A great crowd assembled to witness the sight; military music had been engaged, and many other preparations made.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bottle saw it all from the basket in which he lay close to a live rabbit.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The rabbit was quite excited because he knew that he was to be taken up, and let down again in a parachute.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bottle, however, knew nothing of the "up," or the "down;" he saw only that the balloon was swelling larger and larger till it could swell no more, and began to rise and be restless.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the ropes which held it were cut through, and the aerial ship rose in the air with the aeronaut and the basket containing the bottle and the rabbit, while the music sounded and all the people shouted "Hurrah."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This is a wonderful journey up into the air, thought the bottle; "it is a new way of sailing, and here, at least, there is no fear of striking against anything."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thousands of people gazed at the balloon, and the old maid who was in the garden saw it also; for she stood at the open window of the garret, by which hung the cage containing the linnet, who then had no water-glass, but was obliged to be contented with an old cup.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the window-sill stood a myrtle in a pot, and this had been pushed a little on one side, that it might not fall out; for the old maid was leaning out of the window, that she might see.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And she did see distinctly the aeronaut in the balloon, and how he let down the rabbit in the parachute, and then drank to the health of all the spectators in the wine from the bottle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: After doing this, he hurled it high into the air.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How little she thought that this was the very same bottle which her friend had thrown aloft in her honor, on that happy day of rejoicing, in the green wood, in her youthful days.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bottle had no time to think, when raised so suddenly; and before it was aware, it reached the highest point it had ever attained in its life.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Steeples and roofs lay far, far beneath it, and the people looked as tiny as possible.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then it began to descend much more rapidly than the rabbit had done, made somersaults in the air, and felt itself quite young and unfettered, although it was half full of wine.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But this did not last long.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What a journey it was!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All the people could see the bottle; for the sun shone upon it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The balloon was already far away, and very soon the bottle was far away also; for it fell upon a roof, and broke in pieces.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the pieces had got such an impetus in them, that they could not stop themselves.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They went jumping and rolling about, till at last they fell into the court-yard, and were broken into still smaller pieces; only the neck of the bottle managed to keep whole, and it was broken off as clean as if it had been cut with a diamond.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That would make a capital bird's glass, said one of the cellar-men; but none of them had either a bird or a cage, and it was not to be expected they would provide one just because they had found a bottle neck that could be used as a glass.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the old maid who lived in the garret had a bird, and it really might be useful to her; so the bottle neck was provided with a cork, and taken up to her; and, as it often happens in life, the part that had been uppermost was now turned downwards, and it was filled with fresh water.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they hung it in the cage of the little bird, who sang and twittered more merrily than ever.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ah, you have good reason to sing, said the bottle neck, which was looked upon as something very remarkable, because it had been in a balloon; nothing further was known of its history.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As it hung there in the bird's-cage, it could hear the noise and murmur of the people in the street below, as well as the conversation of the old maid in the room within.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: An old friend had just come to visit her, and they talked, not about the bottle neck, but of the myrtle in the window.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No, you must not spend a dollar for your daughter's bridal bouquet, said the old maid; "you shall have a beautiful little bunch for a nosegay, full of blossoms.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Do you see how splendidly the tree has grown?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It has been raised from only a little sprig of myrtle that you gave me on the day after my betrothal, and from which I was to make my own bridal bouquet when a year had passed: but that day never came; the eyes were closed which were to have been my light and joy through life.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the depths of the sea my beloved sleeps sweetly; the myrtle has become an old tree, and I am a still older woman.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Before the sprig you gave me faded, I took a spray, and planted it in the earth; and now, as you see, it has become a large tree, and a bunch of the blossoms shall at last appear at a wedding festival, in the bouquet of your daughter."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There were tears in the eyes of the old maid, as she spoke of the beloved of her youth, and of their betrothal in the wood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Many thoughts came into her mind; but the thought never came, that quite close to her, in that very window, was a remembrance of those olden times,- the neck of the bottle which had, as it were shouted for joy when the cork flew out with a bang on the betrothal day.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the bottle neck did not recognize the old maid; he had not been listening to what she had related, perhaps because he was thinking so much about her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: VERY often, after a violent thunder-storm, a field of buckwheat appears blackened and singed, as if a flame of fire had passed over it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The country people say that this appearance is caused by lightning; but I will tell you what the sparrow says, and the sparrow heard it from an old willow-tree which grew near a field of buckwheat, and is there still.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is a large venerable tree, though a little crippled by age.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The trunk has been split, and out of the crevice grass and brambles grow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The tree bends for-ward slightly, and the branches hang quite down to the ground just like green hair.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Corn grows in the surrounding fields, not only rye and barley, but oats,-pretty oats that, when ripe, look like a number of little golden canary-birds sitting on a bough.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The corn has a smiling look and the heaviest and richest ears bend their heads low as if in pious humility.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Once there was also a field of buckwheat, and this field was exactly opposite to old willow-tree.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The buckwheat did not bend like the other grain, but erected its head proudly and stiffly on the stem.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am as valuable as any other corn, said he, "and I am much handsomer; my flowers are as beautiful as the bloom of the apple blossom, and it is a pleasure to look at us.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Do you know of anything prettier than we are, you old willow-tree?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the willow-tree nodded his head, as if he would say, "Indeed I do."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the buckwheat spread itself out with pride, and said, "Stupid tree; he is so old that grass grows out of his body."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There arose a very terrible storm.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All the field-flowers folded their leaves together, or bowed their little heads, while the storm passed over them, but the buckwheat stood erect in its pride.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Bend your head as we do, said the flowers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I have no occasion to do so, replied the buckwheat.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Bend your head as we do, cried the ears of corn; "the angel of the storm is coming; his wings spread from the sky above to the earth beneath.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He will strike you down before you can cry for mercy."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But I will not bend my head, said the buckwheat.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Close your flowers and bend your leaves, said the old willow-tree.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Do not look at the lightning when the cloud bursts; even men cannot do that.
22:22	F:N	F:F	In a flash of lightning heaven opens, and we can look in; but the sight will strike even human beings blind.
23:23	F:N	F:F	What then must happen to us, who only grow out of the earth, and are so inferior to them, if we venture to do so?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Inferior, indeed! said the buckwheat.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now I intend to have a peep into heaven.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Proudly and boldly he looked up, while the lightning flashed across the sky as if the whole world were in flames.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When the dreadful storm had passed, the flowers and the corn raised their drooping heads in the pure still air, refreshed by the rain, but the buckwheat lay like a weed in the field, burnt to blackness by the lightning.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The branches of the old willow-tree rustled in the wind, and large water-drops fell from his green leaves as if the old willow were weeping.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the sparrows asked why he was weeping, when all around him seemed so cheerful.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: See, they said, how the sun shines, and the clouds float in the blue sky.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Do you not smell the sweet perfume from flower and bush?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Wherefore do you weep, old willow-tree?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the willow told them of the haughty pride of the buckwheat, and of the punishment which followed in consequence.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This is the story told me by the sparrows one evening when I begged them to relate some tale to me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THERE was once a butterfly who wished for a bride, and, as may be supposed, he wanted to choose a very pretty one from among the flowers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He glanced, with a very critical eye, at all the flower-beds, and found that the flowers were seated quietly and demurely on their stalks, just as maidens should sit before they are engaged; but there was a great number of them, and it appeared as if his search would become very wearisome.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The butterfly did not like to take too much trouble, so he flew off on a visit to the daisies.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The French call this flower "Marguerite," and they say that the little daisy can prophesy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Lovers pluck off the leaves, and as they pluck each leaf, they ask a question about their lovers; thus: "Does he or she love me?- Ardently?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Distractedly?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Very much?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A little?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Not at all?" and so on.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Every one speaks these words in his own language.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The butterfly came also to Marguerite to inquire, but he did not pluck off her leaves; he pressed a kiss on each of them, for he thought there was always more to be done by kindness.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Darling Marguerite daisy, he said to her, "you are the wisest woman of all the flowers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Pray tell me which of the flowers I shall choose for my wife.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Which will be my bride?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When I know, I will fly directly to her, and propose."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But Marguerite did not answer him; she was offended that he should call her a woman when she was only a girl; and there is a great difference.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He asked her a second time, and then a third; but she remained dumb, and answered not a word.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he would wait no longer, but flew away, to commence his wooing at once.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was in the early spring, when the crocus and the snowdrop were in full bloom.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They are very pretty, thought the butterfly; "charming little lasses; but they are rather formal."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then, as the young lads often do, he looked out for the elder girls.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He next flew to the anemones; these were rather sour to his taste.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The violet, a little too sentimental.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The lime-blossoms, too small, and besides, there was such a large family of them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The apple-blossoms, though they looked like roses, bloomed to-day, but might fall off to-morrow, with the first wind that blew; and he thought that a marriage with one of them might last too short a time.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The pea-blossom pleased him most of all; she was white and red, graceful and slender, and belonged to those domestic maidens who have a pretty appearance, and can yet be useful in the kitchen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was just about to make her an offer, when, close by the maiden, he saw a pod, with a withered flower hanging at the end.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Who is that? he asked.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That is my sister, replied the pea-blossom.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, indeed; and you will be like her some day, said he; and he flew away directly, for he felt quite shocked.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A honeysuckle hung forth from the hedge, in full bloom; but there were so many girls like her, with long faces and sallow complexions.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No; he did not like her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But which one did he like?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Spring went by, and summer drew towards its close; autumn came; but he had not decided.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The flowers now appeared in their most gorgeous robes, but all in vain; they had not the fresh, fragrant air of youth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: For the heart asks for fragrance, even when it is no longer young; and there is very little of that to be found in the dahlias or the dry chrysanthemums; therefore the butterfly turned to the mint on the ground.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You know, this plant has no blossom; but it is sweetness all over,- full of fragrance from head to foot, with the scent of a flower in every leaf.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I will take her, said the butterfly; and he made her an offer.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the mint stood silent and stiff, as she listened to him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At last she said,- "Friendship, if you please; nothing more.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am old, and you are old, but we may live for each other just the same; as to marrying- no; don't let us appear ridiculous at our age."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And so it happened that the butterfly got no wife at all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had been too long choosing, which is always a bad plan.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the butterfly became what is called an old bachelor.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was late in the autumn, with rainy and cloudy weather.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The cold wind blew over the bowed backs of the willows, so that they creaked again.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was not the weather for flying about in summer clothes; but fortunately the butterfly was not out in it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had got a shelter by chance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was in a room heated by a stove, and as warm as summer.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He could exist here, he said, well enough.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But it is not enough merely to exist, said he, "I need freedom, sunshine, and a little flower for a companion."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he flew against the window-pane, and was seen and admired by those in the room, who caught him, and stuck him on a pin, in a box of curiosities.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They could not do more for him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now I am perched on a stalk, like the flowers, said the butterfly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is not very pleasant, certainly; I should imagine it is something like being married; for here I am stuck fast.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And with this thought he consoled himself a little.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That seems very poor consolation, said one of the plants in the room, that grew in a pot.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ah, thought the butterfly, "one can't very well trust these plants in pots; they have too much to do with mankind."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: FROM my father I received the best inheritance, namely a "good temper."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And who was my father?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That has nothing to do with the good temper; but I will say he was lively, good-looking round, and fat; he was both in appearance and character a complete contradiction to his profession.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And pray what was his profession and his standing in respectable society?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Well, perhaps, if in the beginning of a book these were written and printed, many, when they read it, would lay the book down and say, "It seems to me a very miserable title, I don't like things of this sort."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And yet my father was not a skin-dresser nor an executioner; on the contrary, his employment placed him at the head of the grandest people of the town, and it was his place by right.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had to precede the bishop, and even the princes of the blood; he always went first,- he was a hearse driver!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There, now, the truth is out.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And I will own, that when people saw my father perched up in front of the omnibus of death, dressed in his long, wide, black cloak, and his black-edged, three-cornered hat on his head, and then glanced at his round, jocund face, round as the sun, they could not think much of sorrow or the grave.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That face said, "It is nothing, it will all end better than people think."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So I have inherited from him, not only my good temper, but a habit of going often to the churchyard, which is good, when done in a proper humor; and then also I take in the Intelligencer, just as he used to do.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am not very young, I have neither wife nor children, nor a library, but, as I said, I read the Intelligencer, which is enough for me; it is to me a delightful paper, and so it was to my father.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is of great use, for it contains all that a man requires to know; the names of the preachers at the church, and the new books which are published; where houses, servants, clothes, and provisions may be obtained.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then what a number of subscriptions to charities, and what innocent verses!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Persons seeking interviews and engagements, all so plainly and naturally stated.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Certainly, a man who takes in the Intelligencer may live merrily and be buried contentedly, and by the end of his life will have such a capital stock of paper that he can lie on a soft bed of it, unless he prefers wood shavings for his resting-place.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The newspaper and the churchyard were always exciting objects to me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: My walks to the latter were like bathing-places to my good humor.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Every one can read the newspaper for himself, but come with me to the churchyard while the sun shines and the trees are green, and let us wander among the graves.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Each of them is like a closed book, with the back uppermost, on which we can read the title of what the book contains, but nothing more.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I had a great deal of information from my father, and I have noticed a great deal myself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I keep it in my diary, in which I write for my own use and pleasure a history of all who lie here, and a few more beside.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now we are in the churchyard.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here, behind the white iron railings, once a rose-tree grew; it is gone now, but a little bit of evergreen, from a neighboring grave, stretches out its green tendrils, and makes some appearance; there rests a very unhappy man, and yet while he lived he might be said to occupy a very good position.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had enough to live upon, and something to spare; but owing to his refined tastes the least thing in the world annoyed him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If he went to a theatre of an evening, instead of enjoying himself he would be quite annoyed if the machinist had put too strong a light into one side of the moon, or if the representations of the sky hung over the scenes when they ought to have hung behind them; or if a palm-tree was introduced into a scene representing the Zoological Gardens of Berlin, or a cactus in a view of Tyrol, or a beech-tree in the north of Norway.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As if these things were of any consequence!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Why did he not leave them alone?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Who would trouble themselves about such trifles? especially at a comedy, where every one is expected to be amused.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then sometimes the public applauded too much, or too little, to please him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They are like wet wood, he would say, looking round to see what sort of people were present, "this evening; nothing fires them."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he would vex and fret himself because they did not laugh at the right time, or because they laughed in the wrong places; and so he fretted and worried himself till at last the unhappy man fretted himself into the grave.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here rests a happy man, that is to say, a man of high birth and position, which was very lucky for him, otherwise he would have been scarcely worth notice.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is beautiful to observe how wisely nature orders these things.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He walked about in a coat embroidered all over, and in the drawing-rooms of society looked just like one of those rich pearl-embroidered bell-pulls, which are only made for show; and behind them always hangs a good thick cord for use.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This man also had a stout, useful substitute behind him, who did duty for him, and performed all his dirty work.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And there are still, even now, these serviceable cords behind other embroidered bell-ropes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is all so wisely arranged, that a man may well be in a good humor.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here rests,- ah, it makes one feel mournful to think of him!- but here rests a man who, during sixty-seven years, was never remembered to have said a good thing; he lived only in the hope of having a good idea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At last he felt convinced, in his own mind, that he really had one, and was so delighted that he positively died of joy at the thought of having at last caught an idea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Nobody got anything by it; indeed, no one even heard what the good thing was.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now I can imagine that this same idea may prevent him from resting quietly in his grave; for suppose that to produce a good effect, it is necessary to bring out his new idea at breakfast, and that he can only make his appearance on earth at midnight, as ghosts are believed generally to do; why then this good idea would not suit the hour, and the man would have to carry it down again with him into the grave- that must be a troubled grave.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The woman who lies here was so remarkably stingy, that during her life she would get up in the night and mew, that her neighbors might think she kept a cat.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What a miser she was!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here rests a young lady, of a good family, who would always make her voice heard in society, and when she sang "Mi manca la voce,"* it was the only true thing she ever said in her life.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: * "I want a voice," or, "I have no voice."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here lies a maiden of another description.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was engaged to be married,- but, her story is one of every-day life; we will leave her to rest in the grave.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here rests a widow, who, with music in her tongue, carried gall in her heart.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She used to go round among the families near, and search out their faults, upon which she preyed with all the envy and malice of her nature.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This is a family grave.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The members of this family held so firmly together in their opinions, that they would believe in no other.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If the newspapers, or even the whole world, said of a certain subject, "It is so-and-so;" and a little schoolboy declared he had learned quite differently, they would take his assertion as the only true one, because he belonged to the family.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And it is well known that if the yard-cock belonging to this family happened to crow at midnight, they would declare it was morning, although the watchman and all the clocks in the town were proclaiming the hour of twelve at night.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The great poet Goethe concludes his Faust with the words, "may be continued;" so might our wanderings in the churchyard be continued.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I come here often, and if any of my friends, or those who are not my friends, are too much for me, I go out and choose a plot of ground in which to bury him or her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then I bury them, as it were; there they lie, dead and powerless, till they come back new and better characters.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Their lives and their deeds, looked at after my own fashion, I write down in my diary, as every one ought to do.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then, if any of our friends act absurdly, no one need to be vexed about it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Let them bury the offenders out of sight, and keep their good temper.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They can also read the Intelligencer, which is a paper written by the people, with their hands guided.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When the time comes for the history of my life, to be bound by the grave, then they will write upon it as my epitaph-

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The man with a cheerful temper.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And this is my story.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: IT was a very sad day, and every heart in the house felt the deepest grief; for the youngest child, a boy of four years old, the joy and hope of his parents, was dead.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Two daughters, the elder of whom was going to be confirmed, still remained: they were both good, charming girls; but the lost child always seems the dearest; and when it is youngest, and a son, it makes the trial still more heavy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sisters mourned as young hearts can mourn, and were especially grieved at the sight of their parents' sorrow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The father's heart was bowed down, but the mother sunk completely under the deep grief.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Day and night she had attended to the sick child, nursing and carrying it in her bosom, as a part of herself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She could not realize the fact that the child was dead, and must be laid in a coffin to rest in the ground.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She thought God could not take her darling little one from her; and when it did happen notwithstanding her hopes and her belief, and there could be no more doubt on the subject, she said in her feverish agony, "God does not know it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He has hard-hearted ministering spirits on earth, who do according to their own will, and heed not a mother's prayers."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thus in her great grief she fell away from her faith in God, and dark thoughts arose in her mind respecting death and a future state.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She tried to believe that man was but dust, and that with his life all existence ended.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But these doubts were no support to her, nothing on which she could rest, and she sunk into the fathomless depths of despair.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In her darkest hours she ceased to weep, and thought not of the young daughters who were still left to her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The tears of her husband fell on her forehead, but she took no notice of him; her thoughts were with her dead child; her whole existence seemed wrapped up in the remembrances of the little one and of every innocent word it had uttered.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The day of the little child's funeral came.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: For nights previously the mother had not slept, but in the morning twilight of this day she sunk from weariness into a deep sleep; in the mean time the coffin was carried into a distant room, and there nailed down, that she might not hear the blows of the hammer.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When she awoke, and wanted to see her child, the husband, with tears, said, "We have closed the coffin; it was necessary to do so."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When God is so hard to me, how can I expect men to be better? she said with groans and tears.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The coffin was carried to the grave, and the disconsolate mother sat with her young daughters.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She looked at them, but she saw them not; for her thoughts were far away from the domestic hearth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She gave herself up to her grief, and it tossed her to and fro, as the sea tosses a ship without compass or rudder.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So the day of the funeral passed away, and similar days followed, of dark, wearisome pain.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: With tearful eyes and mournful glances, the sorrowing daughters and the afflicted husband looked upon her who would not hear their words of comfort; and, indeed, what comforting words could they speak, when they were themselves so full of grief?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It seemed as if she would never again know sleep, and yet it would have been her best friend, one who would have strengthened her body and poured peace into her soul.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They at last persuaded her to lie down, and then she would lie as still as if she slept.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One night, when her husband listened, as he often did, to her breathing, he quite believed that she had at length found rest and relief in sleep.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He folded his arms and prayed, and soon sunk himself into healthful sleep; therefore he did not notice that his wife arose, threw on her clothes, and glided silently from the house, to go where her thoughts constantly lingered- to the grave of her child.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She passed through the garden, to a path across a field that led to the churchyard.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No one saw her as she walked, nor did she see any one; for her eyes were fixed upon the one object of her wanderings.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a lovely starlight night in the beginning of September, and the air was mild and still.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She entered the churchyard, and stood by the little grave, which looked like a large nosegay of fragrant flowers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She sat down, and bent her head low over the grave, as if she could see her child through the earth that covered him- her little boy, whose smile was so vividly before her, and the gentle expression of whose eyes, even on his sick-bed, she could not forget.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How full of meaning that glance had been, as she leaned over him, holding in hers the pale hand which he had no longer strength to raise!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As she had sat by his little cot, so now she sat by his grave; and here she could weep freely, and her tears fell upon it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thou wouldst gladly go down and be with thy child, said a voice quite close to her,- a voice that sounded so deep and clear, that it went to her heart.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She looked up, and by her side stood a man wrapped in a black cloak, with a hood closely drawn over his face; but her keen glance could distinguish the face under the hood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was stern, yet awakened confidence, and the eyes beamed with youthful radiance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Down to my child, she repeated; and tones of despair and entreaty sounded in the words.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Darest thou to follow me? asked the form.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am Death.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She bowed her head in token of assent.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then suddenly it appeared as if all the stars were shining with the radiance of the full moon on the many-colored flowers that decked the grave.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The earth that covered it was drawn back like a floating drapery.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She sunk down, and the spectre covered her with a black cloak; night closed around her, the night of death.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She sank deeper than the spade of the sexton could penetrate, till the churchyard became a roof above her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the cloak was removed, and she found herself in a large hall, of wide-spreading dimensions, in which there was a subdued light, like twilight, reigning, and in a moment her child appeared before her, smiling, and more beautiful than ever; with a silent cry she pressed him to her heart.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A glorious strain of music sounded- now distant, now near.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Never had she listened to such tones as these; they came from beyond a large dark curtain which separated the regions of death from the land of eternity.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: My sweet, darling mother, she heard the child say.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was the well-known, beloved voice; and kiss followed kiss, in boundless delight.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the child pointed to the dark curtain.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
There is nothing so beautiful on earth as it is here.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the mother saw nothing of what the child pointed out, only the dark curtain.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She looked with earthly eyes, and could not see as the child saw,- he whom God has called to be with Himself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She could hear the sounds of music, but she heard not the words, the Word in which she was to trust.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I can fly now, mother, said the child; "I can fly with other happy children into the presence of the Almighty.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I would fain fly away now; but if you weep for me as you are weeping now, you may never see me again.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And yet I would go so gladly.

sentence: May I not fly away?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And you will come to me soon, will you not, dear mother?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, stay, stay! implored the mother; "only one moment more; only once more, that I may look upon thee, and kiss thee, and press thee to my heart."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then she kissed and fondled her child.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Suddenly her name was called from above; what could it mean? her name uttered in a plaintive voice.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Hearest thou? said the child.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is my father who calls thee.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And in a few moments deep sighs were heard, as of children weeping.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They are my sisters, said the child.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Mother, surely you have not forgotten them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then she remembered those she left behind, and a great terror came over her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She looked around her at the dark night.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Dim forms flitted by.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She seemed to recognize some of them, as they floated through the regions of death towards the dark curtain, where they vanished.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Would her husband and her daughters flit past?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No; their sighs and lamentations still sounded from above; and she had nearly forgotten them, for the sake of him who was dead.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Mother, now the bells of heaven are ringing, said the child; "mother, the sun is going to rise."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: An overpowering light streamed in upon her, the child had vanished, and she was being borne upwards.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All around her became cold; she lifted her head, and saw that she was lying in the churchyard, on the grave of her child.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The Lord, in a dream, had been a guide to her feet and a light to her spirit.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She bowed her knees, and prayed for forgiveness.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She had wished to keep back a soul from its immortal flight; she had forgotten her duties towards the living who were left her.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sun burst forth, over her head a little bird carolled his song, and the church-bells sounded for the early service.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Half ashamed, yet glad at heart, it looked over to the other flowers in the garden; surely they had witnessed its pleasure and the honour that had been done to it; they understood its joy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the tulips stood more stiffly than ever, their faces were pointed and red, because they were vexed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The peonies were sulky; it was well that they could not speak, otherwise they would have given the daisy a good lecture.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THERE was once a darning-needle who thought herself so fine that she fancied she must be fit for embroidery.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Hold me tight, she would say to the fingers, when they took her up, "don't let me fall; if you do I shall never be found again, I am so very fine."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That is your opinion, is it? said the fingers, as they seized her round the body.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: See, I am coming with a train, said the darning-needle, drawing a long thread after her; but there was no knot in the thread.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The fingers then placed the point of the needle against the cook's slipper.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There was a crack in the upper leather, which had to be sewn together.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What coarse work! said the darning-needle, "I shall never get through.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I shall break!- I am breaking!" and sure enough she broke.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Did I not say so? said the darning-needle, "I know I am too fine for such work as that."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This needle is quite useless for sewing now, said the fingers; but they still held it fast, and the cook dropped some sealing-wax on the needle, and fastened her handkerchief with it in front.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So now I am a breast-pin, said the darning-needle; "I knew very well I should come to honor some day: merit is sure to rise;" and she laughed, quietly to herself, for of course no one ever saw a darning-needle laugh.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And there she sat as proudly as if she were in a state coach, and looked all around her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: May I be allowed to ask if you are made of gold? she inquired of her neighbor, a pin; "you have a very pretty appearance, and a curious head, although you are rather small.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You must take pains to grow, for it is not every one who has sealing-wax dropped upon him;" and as she spoke, the darning-needle drew herself up so proudly that she fell out of the handkerchief right into the sink, which the cook was cleaning.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now I am going on a journey, said the needle, as she floated away with the dirty water, "I do hope I shall not be lost."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THERE was an old mansion surrounded by a marshy ditch with a drawbridge which was but seldom let down:- not all guests are good people.

author: HCAndersen

sentence: On the walls hung pictures of knights in armour and proud ladies in gorgeous dresses; the most stately of all walked about alive.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was called Meta Mogen; she was the mistress of the house, to her belonged the castle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Towards the evening robbers came; they killed three of her people and also the yard-dog, and attached Mrs. Meta to the kennel by the chain, while they themselves made good cheer in the hall and drank the wine and the good ale out of her cellar.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Mrs. Meta was now on the chain, she could not even bark.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But lo! the servant of one of the robbers secretly approached her; they must not see it, otherwise they would have killed him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Mrs. Meta Mogen, said the fellow, "do you still remember how my father, when your husband was still alive, had to ride on the wooden horse?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You prayed for him, but it was no good, he was to ride until his limbs were paralysed; but you stole down to him, as I steal now to you, you yourself put little stones under each of his feet that he might have support, nobody saw it, or they pretended not to see it, for you were then the young gracious mistress.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: My father has told me this, and I have not forgotten it!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now I will free you, Mrs. Meta Mogen!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they pulled the horses out of the stable and rode off in rain and wind to obtain the assistance of friends.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thus the small service done to the old man was richly rewarded! said Meta Mogen.

author: HCAndersen

sentence: Let me see that you know how to teach them good manners."

sentence: And when are they coming? asked the daughter.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That depends upon wind and weather, said the elf king; "they travel economically.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They will come when there is the chance of a ship.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I wanted them to come over to Sweden, but the old man was not inclined to take my advice.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He does not go forward with the times, and that I do not like."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Two will-o'-the-wisps came jumping in, one quicker than the other, so of course, one arrived first.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They are coming! they are coming! he cried.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Give me my crown, said the elf king, "and let me stand in the moonshine."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The daughters drew on their shawls and bowed down to the ground.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There stood the old goblin from the Dovre mountains, with his crown of hardened ice and polished fir-cones.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Besides this, he wore a bear-skin, and great, warm boots, while his sons went with their throats bare and wore no braces, for they were strong men.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Is that a hill? said the youngest of the boys, pointing to the elf hill, "we should call it a hole in Norway."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Boys, said the old man, "a hole goes in, and a hill stands out; have you no eyes in your heads?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Another thing they wondered at was, that they were able without trouble to understand the language.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Take care, said the old man, "or people will think you have not been well brought up."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they entered the elfin hill, where the select and grand company were assembled, and so quickly had they appeared that they seemed to have been blown together.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But for each guest the neatest and pleasantest arrangement had been made.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sea folks sat at table in great water-tubs, and they said it was just like being at home.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All behaved themselves properly excepting the two young northern goblins; they put their legs on the table and thought they were all right.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Feet off the table-cloth! said the old goblin.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They obeyed, but not immediately.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they tickled the ladies who waited at table, with the fir-cones, which they carried in their pockets.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They took off their boots, that they might be more at ease, and gave them to the ladies to hold.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But their father, the old goblin, was very different; he talked pleasantly about the stately Norwegian rocks, and told fine tales of the waterfalls which dashed over them with a clattering noise like thunder or the sound of an organ, spreading their white foam on every side.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He told of the salmon that leaps in the rushing waters, while the water-god plays on his golden harp.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He spoke of the bright winter nights, when the sledge bells are ringing, and the boys run with burning torches across the smooth ice, which is so transparent that they can see the fishes dart forward beneath their feet.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He described everything so clearly, that those who listened could see it all; they could see the saw-mills going, the men-servants and the maidens singing songs, and dancing a rattling dance,- when all at once the old goblin gave the old elfin maiden a kiss, such a tremendous kiss, and yet they were almost strangers to each other.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the elfin girls had to dance, first in the usual way, and then with stamping feet, which they performed very well; then followed the artistic and solo dance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Dear me, how they did throw their legs about!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No one could tell where the dance begun, or where it ended, nor indeed which were legs and which were arms, for they were all flying about together, like the shavings in a saw-pit!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then they spun round so quickly that the death-horse and the grave-pig became sick and giddy, and were obliged to leave the table.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Stop! cried the old goblin," is that the only house-keeping they can perform?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Can they do anything more than dance and throw about their legs, and make a whirlwind?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You shall soon see what they can do, said the elf king.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then he called his youngest daughter to him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was slender and fair as moonlight, and the most graceful of all the sisters.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She took a white chip in her mouth, and vanished instantly; this was her accomplishment.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the old goblin said he should not like his wife to have such an accomplishment, and thought his boys would have the same objection.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Another daughter could make a figure like herself follow her, as if she had a shadow, which none of the goblin folk ever had.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The third was of quite a different sort; she had learnt in the brew-house of the moor witch how to lard elfin puddings with glow-worms.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She will make a good housewife, said the old goblin, and then saluted her with his eyes instead of drinking her health; for he did not drink much.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now came the fourth daughter, with a large harp to play upon; and when she struck the first chord, every one lifted up the left leg (for the goblins are left-legged), and at the second chord they found they must all do just what she wanted.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That is a dangerous woman, said the old goblin; and the two sons walked out of the hill; they had had enough of it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And what can the next daughter do? asked the old goblin.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I have learnt everything that is Norwegian, said she; "and I will never marry, unless I can go to Norway."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then her youngest sister whispered to the old goblin, "That is only because she has heard, in a Norwegian song, that when the world shall decay, the cliffs of Norway will remain standing like monuments; and she wants to get there, that she may be safe; for she is so afraid of sinking."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ho! ho! said the old goblin, "is that what she means?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Well, what can the seventh and last do?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sixth comes before the seventh, said the elf king, for he could reckon; but the sixth would not come forward.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I can only tell people the truth, said she.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No one cares for me, nor troubles himself about me; and I have enough to do to sew my grave clothes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So the seventh and last came; and what could she do?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Why, she could tell stories, as many as you liked, on any subject.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here are my five fingers, said the old goblin; "now tell me a story for each of them."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So she took him by the wrist, and he laughed till he nearly choked; and when she came to the fourth finger, there was a gold ring on it, as if it knew there was to be a betrothal.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the old goblin said, "Hold fast what you have: this hand is yours; for I will have you for a wife myself."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the elfin girl said that the stories about the ring-finger and little Peter Playman had not yet been told.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We will hear them in the winter, said the old goblin, "and also about the fir and the birch-trees, and the ghost stories, and of the tingling frost.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You shall tell your tales, for no one over there can do it so well; and we will sit in the stone rooms, where the pine logs are burning, and drink mead out of the golden drinking-horn of the old Norwegian kings.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The water-god has given me two; and when we sit there, Nix comes to pay us a visit, and will sing you all the songs of the mountain shepherdesses.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How merry we shall be!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The salmon will be leaping in the waterfalls, and dashing against the stone walls, but he will not be able to come in.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is indeed very pleasant to live in old Norway.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But where are the lads?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Where indeed were they?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Why, running about the fields, and blowing out the will-o'-the-wisps, who so good-naturedly came and brought their torches.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What tricks have you been playing? said the old goblin.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I have taken a mother for you, and now you may take one of your aunts.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the youngsters said they would rather make a speech and drink to their good fellowship; they had no wish to marry.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they made speeches and drank toasts, and tipped their glasses, to show that they were empty.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they took off their coats, and lay down on the table to sleep; for they made themselves quite at home.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the old goblin danced about the room with his young bride, and exchanged boots with her, which is more fashionable than exchanging rings.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The cock is crowing, said the old elfin maiden who acted as housekeeper; now we must close the shutters, that the sun may not scorch us."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the hill closed up.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the lizards continued to run up and down the riven tree; and one said to the other, "Oh, how much I was pleased with the old goblin!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The boys pleased me better, said the earth-worm.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But then the poor miserable creature could not see.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: IN the midst of a garden grew a rose-tree, in full blossom, and in the prettiest of all the roses lived an elf.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was such a little wee thing, that no human eye could see him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Behind each leaf of the rose he had a sleeping chamber.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was as well formed and as beautiful as a little child could be, and had wings that reached from his shoulders to his feet.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, what sweet fragrance there was in his chambers! and how clean and beautiful were the walls! for they were the blushing leaves of the rose.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: During the whole day he enjoyed himself in the warm sunshine, flew from flower to flower, and danced on the wings of the flying butterflies.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he took it into his head to measure how many steps he would have to go through the roads and cross-roads that are on the leaf of a linden-tree.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What we call the veins on a leaf, he took for roads; ay, and very long roads they were for him; for before he had half finished his task, the sun went down: he had commenced his work too late.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It became very cold, the dew fell, and the wind blew; so he thought the best thing he could do would be to return home.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He hurried himself as much as he could; but he found the roses all closed up, and he could not get in; not a single rose stood open.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The poor little elf was very much frightened.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had never before been out at night, but had always slumbered secretly behind the warm rose-leaves.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, this would certainly be his death.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At the other end of the garden, he knew there was an arbor, overgrown with beautiful honey-suckles.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The blossoms looked like large painted horns; and he thought to himself, he would go and sleep in one of these till the morning.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He flew thither; but "hush!" two people were in the arbor,- a handsome young man and a beautiful lady.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They sat side by side, and wished that they might never be obliged to part.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They loved each other much more than the best child can love its father and mother.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But we must part, said the young man; "your brother does not like our engagement, and therefore he sends me so far away on business, over mountains and seas.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Farewell, my sweet bride; for so you are to me."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then they kissed each other, and the girl wept, and gave him a rose; but before she did so, she pressed a kiss upon it so fervently that the flower opened.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the little elf flew in, and leaned his head on the delicate, fragrant walls.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here he could plainly hear them say, "Farewell, farewell;" and he felt that the rose had been placed on the young man's breast.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, how his heart did beat!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The little elf could not go to sleep, it thumped so loudly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The young man took it out as he walked through the dark wood alone, and kissed the flower so often and so violently, that the little elf was almost crushed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He could feel through the leaf how hot the lips of the young man were, and the rose had opened, as if from the heat of the noonday sun.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There came another man, who looked gloomy and wicked.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was the wicked brother of the beautiful maiden.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He drew out a sharp knife, and while the other was kissing the rose, the wicked man stabbed him to death; then he cut off his head, and buried it with the body in the soft earth under the linden-tree.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now he is gone, and will soon be forgotten, thought the wicked brother; "he will never come back again.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was going on a long journey over mountains and seas; it is easy for a man to lose his life in such a journey.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: My sister will suppose he is dead; for he cannot come back, and she will not dare to question me about him."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he scattered the dry leaves over the light earth with his foot, and went home through the darkness; but he went not alone, as he thought,- the little elf accompanied him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He sat in a dry rolled-up linden-leaf, which had fallen from the tree on to the wicked man's head, as he was digging the grave.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The hat was on the head now, which made it very dark, and the little elf shuddered with fright and indignation at the wicked deed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was the dawn of morning before the wicked man reached home; he took off his hat, and went into his sister's room.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There lay the beautiful, blooming girl, dreaming of him whom she loved so, and who was now, she supposed, travelling far away over mountain and sea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her wicked brother stopped over her, and laughed hideously, as fiends only can laugh.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The dry leaf fell out of his hair upon the counterpane; but he did not notice it, and went to get a little sleep during the early morning hours.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the elf slipped out of the withered leaf, placed himself by the ear of the sleeping girl, and told her, as in a dream, of the horrid murder; described the place where her brother had slain her lover, and buried his body; and told her of the linden-tree, in full blossom, that stood close by.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That you may not think this is only a dream that I have told you, he said, "you will find on your bed a withered leaf."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then she awoke, and found it there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, what bitter tears she shed! and she could not open her heart to any one for relief.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The window stood open the whole day, and the little elf could easily have reached the roses, or any of the flowers; but he could not find it in his heart to leave one so afflicted.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the window stood a bush bearing monthly roses.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He seated himself in one of the flowers, and gazed on the poor girl.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her brother often came into the room, and would be quite cheerful, in spite of his base conduct; so she dare not say a word to him of her heart's grief.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As soon as night came on, she slipped out of the house, and went into the wood, to the spot where the linden-tree stood; and after removing the leaves from the earth, she turned it up, and there found him who had been murdered.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, how she wept and prayed that she also might die!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Gladly would she have taken the body home with her; but that was impossible; so she took up the poor head with the closed eyes, kissed the cold lips, and shook the mould out of the beautiful hair.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I will keep this, said she; and as soon as she had covered the body again with the earth and leaves, she took the head and a little sprig of jasmine that bloomed in the wood, near the spot where he was buried, and carried them home with her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As soon as she was in her room, she took the largest flower-pot she could find, and in this she placed the head of the dead man, covered it up with earth, and planted the twig of jasmine in it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Farewell, farewell, whispered the little elf.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He could not any longer endure to witness all this agony of grief, he therefore flew away to his own rose in the garden.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the rose was faded; only a few dry leaves still clung to the green hedge behind it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Alas! how soon all that is good and beautiful passes away, sighed the elf.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: After a while he found another rose, which became his home, for among its delicate fragrant leaves he could dwell in safety.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Every morning he flew to the window of the poor girl, and always found her weeping by the flower pot.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bitter tears fell upon the jasmine twig, and each day, as she became paler and paler, the sprig appeared to grow greener and fresher.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One shoot after another sprouted forth, and little white buds blossomed, which the poor girl fondly kissed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But her wicked brother scolded her, and asked her if she was going mad.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He could not imagine why she was weeping over that flower-pot, and it annoyed him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He did not know whose closed eyes were there, nor what red lips were fading beneath the earth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And one day she sat and leaned her head against the flower-pot, and the little elf of the rose found her asleep.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he seated himself by her ear, talked to her of that evening in the arbor, of the sweet perfume of the rose, and the loves of the elves.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Sweetly she dreamed, and while she dreamt, her life passed away calmly and gently, and her spirit was with him whom she loved, in heaven.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the jasmine opened its large white bells, and spread forth its sweet fragrance; it had no other way of showing its grief for the dead.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the wicked brother considered the beautiful blooming plant as his own property, left to him by his sister, and he placed it in his sleeping room, close by his bed, for it was very lovely in appearance, and the fragrance sweet and delightful.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The little elf of the rose followed it, and flew from flower to flower, telling each little spirit that dwelt in them the story of the murdered young man, whose head now formed part of the earth beneath them, and of the wicked brother and the poor sister.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We know it, said each little spirit in the flowers, "we know it, for have we not sprung from the eyes and lips of the murdered one.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We know it, we know it," and the flowers nodded with their heads in a peculiar manner.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The elf of the rose could not understand how they could rest so quietly in the matter, so he flew to the bees, who were gathering honey, and told them of the wicked brother.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the bees told it to their queen, who commanded that the next morning they should go and kill the murderer.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But during the night, the first after the sister's death, while the brother was sleeping in his bed, close to where he had placed the fragrant jasmine, every flower cup opened, and invisibly the little spirits stole out, armed with poisonous spears.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They placed themselves by the ear of the sleeper, told him dreadful dreams and then flew across his lips, and pricked his tongue with their poisoned spears.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now have we revenged the dead, said they, and flew back into the white bells of the jasmine flowers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When the morning came, and as soon as the window was opened, the rose elf, with the queen bee, and the whole swarm of bees, rushed in to kill him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But he was already dead.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: People were standing round the bed, and saying that the scent of the jasmine had killed him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the elf of the rose understood the revenge of the flowers, and explained it to the queen bee, and she, with the whole swarm, buzzed about the flower-pot.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bees could not be driven away.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then a man took it up to remove it, and one of the bees stung him in the hand, so that he let the flower-pot fall, and it was broken to pieces.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then every one saw the whitened skull, and they knew the dead man in the bed was a murderer.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the queen bee hummed in the air, and sang of the revenge of the flowers, and of the elf of the rose and said that behind the smallest leaf dwells One, who can discover evil deeds, and punish them also.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: MANY, many years ago lived an emperor, who thought so much of new clothes that he spent all his money in order to obtain them; his only ambition was to be always well dressed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He did not care for his soldiers, and the theatre did not amuse him; the only thing, in fact, he thought anything of was to drive out and show a new suit of clothes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had a coat for every hour of the day; and as one would say of a king "He is in his cabinet," so one could say of him, "The emperor is in his dressing-room."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The great city where he resided was very gay; every day many strangers from all parts of the globe arrived.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One day two swindlers came to this city; they made people believe that they were weavers, and declared they could manufacture the finest cloth to be imagined.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Their colours and patterns, they said, were not only exceptionally beautiful, but the clothes made of their material possessed the wonderful quality of being invisible to any man who was unfit for his office or unpardonably stupid.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That must be wonderful cloth, thought the emperor.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
If I were to be dressed in a suit made of this cloth I should be able to find out which men in my empire were unfit for their places, and I could distinguish the clever from the stupid.
8:8	H:N	H:N	I must have this cloth woven for me without delay.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And he gave a large sum of money to the swindlers, in advance, that they should set to work without any loss of time.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They set up two looms, and pretended to be very hard at work, but they did nothing whatever on the looms.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They asked for the finest silk and the most precious gold-cloth; all they got they did away with, and worked at the empty looms till late at night.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I should very much like to know how they are getting on with the cloth, thought the emperor.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But he felt rather uneasy when he remembered that he who was not fit for his office could not see it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Personally, he was of opinion that he had nothing to fear, yet he thought it advisable to send somebody else first to see how matters stood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Everybody in the town knew what a remarkable quality the stuff possessed, and all were anxious to see how bad or stupid their neighbours were.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I shall send my honest old minister to the weavers, thought the emperor.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He can judge best how the stuff looks, for he is intelligent, and nobody understands his office better than he.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The good old minister went into the room where the swindlers sat before the empty looms.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Heaven preserve us! he thought, and opened his eyes wide, "I cannot see anything at all," but he did not say so.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Both swindlers requested him to come near, and asked him if he did not admire the exquisite pattern and the beautiful colours, pointing to the empty looms.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The poor old minister tried his very best, but he could see nothing, for there was nothing to be seen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh dear, he thought, "can I be so stupid?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I should never have thought so, and nobody must know it!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Is it possible that I am not fit for my office?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No, no, I cannot say that I was unable to see the cloth."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now, have you got nothing to say? said one of the swindlers, while he pretended to be busily weaving.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, it is very pretty, exceedingly beautiful, replied the old minister looking through his glasses.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
What a beautiful pattern, what brilliant colours!
29:29	H:N	F:N	I shall tell the emperor that I like the cloth very much.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We are pleased to hear that, said the two weavers, and described to him the colours and explained the curious pattern.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The old minister listened attentively, that he might relate to the emperor what they said; and so he did.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now the swindlers asked for more money, silk and gold-cloth, which they required for weaving.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They kept everything for themselves, and not a thread came near the loom, but they continued, as hitherto, to work at the empty looms.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Soon afterwards the emperor sent another honest courtier to the weavers to see how they were getting on, and if the cloth was nearly finished.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Like the old minister, he looked and looked but could see nothing, as there was nothing to be seen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Is it not a beautiful piece of cloth? asked the two swindlers, showing and explaining the magnificent pattern, which, however, did not exist.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am not stupid, said the man.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
It is therefore my good appointment for which I am not fit.
39:39	H:N	F:N	It is very strange, but I must not let any one know it; and he praised the cloth, which he did not see, and expressed his joy at the beautiful colours and the fine pattern.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is very excellent, he said to the emperor.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Everybody in the whole town talked about the precious cloth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At last the emperor wished to see it himself, while it was still on the loom.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: With a number of courtiers, including the two who had already been there, he went to the two clever swindlers, who now worked as hard as they could, but without using any thread.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Is it not magnificent? said the two old statesmen who had been there before.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Your Majesty must admire the colours and the pattern.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then they pointed to the empty looms, for they imagined the others could see the cloth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What is this? thought the emperor, "I do not see anything at all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That is terrible!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Am I stupid?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Am I unfit to be emperor?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That would indeed be the most dreadful thing that could happen to me."

author: HCAndersen
