author: HCAndersen
sentence: After some time, the linen was taken into the house, placed under the scissors, and cut and torn into pieces, and then pricked with needles.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This certainly was not pleasant; but at last it was made into twelve garments of that kind which people do not like to name, and yet everybody should wear one.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: See, now, then, said the flax; "I have become something of importance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This was my destiny; it is quite a blessing.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now I shall be of some use in the world, as everyone ought to be; it is the only way to be happy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am now divided into twelve pieces, and yet we are all one and the same in the whole dozen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is most extraordinary good fortune."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Years passed away, and at last the linen was so worn it could scarcely hold together.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It must end very soon, said the pieces to each other; "we would gladly have held together a little longer, but it is useless to expect impossibilities."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And at length they fell into rags and tatters, and thought it was all over with them, for they were torn to shreds, and steeped in water, and made into a pulp, and dried, and they knew not what besides, till all at once they found themselves beautiful white paper.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Well, now, this is a surprise; a glorious surprise too, said the paper.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
I am now finer than ever, and I shall be written upon, and who can tell what fine things I may have written upon me.
43:43	H:Su+	H:+	This is wonderful luck!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And sure enough the most beautiful stories and poetry were written upon it, and only once was there a blot, which was very fortunate.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then people heard the stories and poetry read, and it made them wiser and better; for all that was written had a good and sensible meaning, and a great blessing was contained in the words on this paper.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I never imagined anything like this, said the paper, "when I was only a little blue flower, growing in the fields.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How could I fancy that I should ever be the means of bringing knowledge and joy to man?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I cannot understand it myself, and yet it is really so.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Heaven knows that I have done nothing myself, but what I was obliged to do with my weak powers for my own preservation; and yet I have been promoted from one joy and honor to another.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Each time I think that the song is ended; and then something higher and better begins for me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I suppose now I shall be sent on my travels about the world, so that people may read me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It cannot be otherwise; indeed, it is more than probable; for I have more splendid thoughts written upon me, than I had pretty flowers in olden times.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am happier than ever."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the paper did not go on its travels; it was sent to the printer, and all the words written upon it were set up in type, to make a book, or rather, many hundreds of books; for so many more persons could derive pleasure and profit from a printed book, than from the written paper; and if the paper had been sent around the world, it would have been worn out before it had got half through its journey.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This is certainly the wisest plan, said the written paper; "I really did not think of that.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I shall remain at home, and be held in honor, like some old grandfather, as I really am to all these new books.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They will do some good.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I could not have wandered about as they do.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am the most honored of all."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the paper was tied in a bundle with other papers, and thrown into a tub that stood in the washhouse.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: After work, it is well to rest, said the paper, "and a very good opportunity to collect one's thoughts.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now I am able, for the first time, to think of my real condition; and to know one's self is true progress.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What will be done with me now, I wonder?

author: HCAndersen

sentence: I have always progressed hitherto, as I know quite well."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now it happened one day that all the paper in the tub was taken out, and laid on the hearth to be burnt.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: People said it could not be sold at the shop, to wrap up butter and sugar, because it had been written upon.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The children in the house stood round the stove; for they wanted to see the paper burn, because it flamed up so prettily, and afterwards, among the ashes, so many red sparks could be seen running one after the other, here and there, as quick as the wind.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They called it seeing the children come out of school, and the last spark was the schoolmaster.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They often thought the last spark had come; and one would cry, "There goes the schoolmaster;" but the next moment another spark would appear, shining so beautifully.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How they would like to know where the sparks all went to!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Perhaps we shall find out some day, but we don't know now.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The whole bundle of paper had been placed on the fire, and was soon alight.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ugh, cried the paper, as it burst into a bright flame; "ugh."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was certainly not very pleasant to be burning; but when the whole was wrapped in flames, the flames mounted up into the air, higher than the flax had ever been able to raise its little blue flower, and they glistened as the white linen never could have glistened.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All the written letters became quite red in a moment, and all the words and thoughts turned to fire.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now I am mounting straight up to the sun, said a voice in the flames; and it was as if a thousand voices echoed the words; and the flames darted up through the chimney, and went out at the top.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then a number of tiny beings, as many in number as the flowers on the flax had been, and invisible to mortal eyes, floated above them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were even lighter and more delicate than the flowers from which they were born; and as the flames were extinguished, and nothing remained of the paper but black ashes, these little beings danced upon it; and whenever they touched it, bright red sparks appeared.

author: HCAndersen

sentence: Snip, snap, snurre, Basse lure: The song is ended.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THERE was once a merchant who was so rich that he could have paved the whole street with gold, and would even then have had enough for a small alley.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But he did not do so; he knew the value of money better than to use it in this way.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So clever was he, that every shilling he put out brought him a crown; and so he continued till he died.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His son inherited his wealth, and he lived a merry life with it; he went to a masquerade every night, made kites out of five pound notes, and threw pieces of gold into the sea instead of stones, making ducks and drakes of them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In this manner he soon lost all his money.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At last he had nothing left but a pair of slippers, an old dressing-gown, and four shillings.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And now all his friends deserted him, they could not walk with him in the streets; but one of them, who was very good-natured, sent him an old trunk with this message, "Pack up!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, he said, "it is all very well to say 'pack up,' "but he had nothing left to pack up, therefore he seated himself in the trunk.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a very wonderful trunk; no sooner did any one press on the lock than the trunk could fly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He shut the lid and pressed the lock, when away flew the trunk up the chimney with the merchant's son in it, right up into the clouds.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Whenever the bottom of the trunk cracked, he was in a great fright, for if the trunk fell to pieces he would have made a tremendous somerset over the trees.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: However, he got safely in his trunk to the land of Turkey.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He hid the trunk in the wood under some dry leaves, and then went into the town: he could so this very well, for the Turks always go about dressed in dressing-gowns and slippers, as he was himself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He happened to meet a nurse with a little child.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I say, you Turkish nurse, cried he, "what castle is that near the town, with the windows placed so high?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The king's daughter lives there, she replied; "it has been prophesied that she will be very unhappy about a lover, and therefore no one is allowed to visit her, unless the king and queen are present."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thank you, said the merchant's son.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So he went back to the wood, seated himself in his trunk, flew up to the roof of the castle, and crept through the window into the princess's room.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She lay on the sofa asleep, and she was so beautiful that the merchant's son could not help kissing her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then she awoke, and was very much frightened; but he told her he was a Turkish angel, who had come down through the air to see her, which pleased her very much.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He sat down by her side and talked to her: he said her eyes were like beautiful dark lakes, in which the thoughts swam about like little mermaids, and he told her that her forehead was a snowy mountain, which contained splendid halls full of pictures.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then he related to her about the stork who brings the beautiful children from the rivers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: These were delightful stories; and when he asked the princess if she would marry him, she consented immediately.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But you must come on Saturday, she said; "for then the king and queen will take tea with me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They will be very proud when they find that I am going to marry a Turkish angel; but you must think of some very pretty stories to tell them, for my parents like to hear stories better than anything.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: My mother prefers one that is deep and moral; but my father likes something funny, to make him laugh."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Very well, he replied; "I shall bring you no other marriage portion than a story," and so they parted.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the princess gave him a sword which was studded with gold coins, and these he could use.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he flew away to the town and bought a new dressing-gown, and afterwards returned to the wood, where he composed a story, so as to be ready for Saturday, which was no easy matter.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was ready however by Saturday, when he went to see the princess.

sentence: The king, and queen, and the whole court, were at tea with the princess; and he was received with great politeness.

sentence: Will you tell us a story? said the queen,- "one that is instructive and full of deep learning."

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was very natural that he should wish to know.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And what strange things people did say, to be sure! every one whom he questioned had a different tale to tell, though they all thought it very beautiful.

sentence: 'I saw the Turkish angel myself, said one; "he had eyes like glittering stars, and a head like foaming water."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THE little dwelling in which we lived was of clay, but the door-posts were columns of fluted marble, found near the spot on which it stood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The roof sloped nearly to the ground.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was at this time dark, brown, and ugly, but had originally been formed of blooming olive and laurel branches, brought from beyond the mountains.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The house was situated in a narrow gorge, whose rocky walls rose to a perpendicular height, naked and black, while round their summits clouds often hung, looking like white living figures.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Not a singing bird was ever heard there, neither did men dance to the sound of the pipe.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The spot was one sacred to olden times; even its name recalled a memory of the days when it was called "Delphi."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the summits of the dark, sacred mountains were covered with snow, and the highest, mount Parnassus, glowed longest in the red evening light.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The brook which rolled from it near our house, was also sacred.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How well I can remember every spot in that deep, sacred solitude!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A fire had been kindled in the midst of the hut, and while the hot ashes lay there red and glowing, the bread was baked in them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At times the snow would be piled so high around our hut as almost to hide it, and then my mother appeared most cheerful.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She would hold my head between her hands, and sing the songs she never sang at other times, for the Turks, our masters, would not allow it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She sang,- "On the summit of mount Olympus, in a forest of dwarf firs, lay an old stag.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His eyes were heavy with tears, and glittering with colors like dewdrops; and there came by a roebuck, and said, 'What ailest thee, that thou weepest blue and red tears?'

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the stag answered, 'The Turk has come to our city; he has wild dogs for the chase, a goodly pack.' 'I will drive them away across the islands!' cried the young roebuck; 'I will drive them away across the islands into the deep sea.'

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But before evening the roebuck was slain, and before night the hunted stag was dead."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And when my mother sang thus, her eyes would become moist; and on the long eyelashes were tears, but she concealed them and watched the black bread baking in the ashes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then I would clench my fist, and cry, "We will kill these Turks!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But she repeated the words of the song, "I will drive them across the islands to the deep sea; but before evening came the roebuck was slain, and before the night the hunted stag was dead."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We had been lonely in our hut for several days and nights when my father came home.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I knew he would bring me some shells from the gulf of Lepanto, or perhaps a knife with a shining blade.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This time he brought, under his sheep-skin cloak, a little child, a little half-naked girl.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was wrapped in a fur; but when this was taken off, and she lay in my mother's lap, three silver coins were found fastened in her dark hair; they were all her possessions.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: My father told us that the child's parents had been killed by the Turks, and he talked so much about them that I dreamed of Turks all night.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He himself had been wounded, and my mother bound up his arm.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a deep wound, and the thick sheep-skin cloak was stiff with congealed blood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The little maiden was to be my sister.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How pretty and bright she looked: even my mother's eyes were not more gentle than hers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Anastasia, as she was called, was to be my sister, because her father had been united to mine by an old custom, which we still follow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They had sworn brotherhood in their youth, and the most beautiful and virtuous maiden in the neighborhood was chosen to perform the act of consecration upon this bond of friendship.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So now this little girl was my sister.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She sat in my lap, and I brought her flowers, and feathers from the birds of the mountain.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We drank together of the waters of Parnassus, and dwelt for many years beneath the laurel roof of the hut, while, winter after winter, my mother sang her song of the stag who shed red tears.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But as yet I did not understand that the sorrows of my own countrymen were mirrored in those tears.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One day there came to our hut Franks, men from a far country, whose dress was different to ours.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They had tents and beds with them, carried by horses; and they were accompanied by more than twenty Turks, all armed with swords and muskets.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: These Franks were friends of the Pacha, and had letters from him, commanding an escort for them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They only came to see our mountain, to ascend Parnassus amid the snow and clouds, and to look at the strange black rocks which raised their steep sides near our hut.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They could not find room in the hut, nor endure the smoke that rolled along the ceiling till it found its way out at the low door; so they pitched their tents on a small space outside our dwelling.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Roasted lambs and birds were brought forth, and strong, sweet wine, of which the Turks are forbidden to partake.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When they departed, I accompanied them for some distance, carrying my little sister Anastasia, wrapped in a goat-skin, on my back.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One of the Frankish gentlemen made me stand in front of a rock, and drew us both as we stood there, so that we looked like one creature.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I did not think of it then, but Anastasia and I were really one.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was always sitting on my lap, or riding in the goat-skin on my back; and in my dreams she always appeared to me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Two nights after this, other men, armed with knives and muskets, came into our tent.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were Albanians, brave men, my mother told me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They only stayed a short time.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: My sister Anastasia sat on the knee of one of them; and when they were gone, she had not three, but two silver coins in her hair- one had disappeared.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They wrapped tobacco in strips of paper, and smoked it; and I remember they were uncertain as to the road they ought to take.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But they were obliged to go at last, and my father went with them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Soon after, we heard the sound of firing.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The noise continued, and presently soldiers rushed into our hut, and took my mother and myself and Anastasia prisoners.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They declared that we had entertained robbers, and that my father had acted as their guide, and therefore we must now go with them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The corpses of the robbers, and my father's corpse, were brought into the hut.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I saw my poor dead father, and cried till I fell asleep.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When I awoke, I found myself in a prison; but the room was not worse than our own in the hut.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They gave me onions and musty wine from a tarred cask; but we were not accustomed to much better fare at home.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How long we were kept in prison, I do not know; but many days and nights passed by.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We were set free about Easter-time.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I carried Anastasia on my back, and we walked very slowly; for my mother was very weak, and it is a long way to the sea, to the Gulf of Lepanto.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On our arrival, we entered a church, in which there were beautiful pictures in golden frames.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were pictures of angels, fair and bright; and yet our little Anastasia looked equally beautiful, as it seemed to me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the centre of the floor stood a coffin filled with roses.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: My mother told me it was the Lord Jesus Christ who was represented by these roses.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the priest announced, "Christ is risen," and all the people greeted each other.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Each one carried a burning taper in his hand, and one was given to me, as well as to little Anastasia.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The music sounded, and the people left the church hand-in-hand, with joy and gladness.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Outside, the women were roasting the paschal lamb.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We were invited to partake; and as I sat by the fire, a boy, older than myself, put his arms round my neck, and kissed me, and said, "Christ is risen."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And thus it was that for the first time I met Aphtanides.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: My mother could make fishermen's nets, for which there was a great demand here in the bay; and we lived a long time by the side of the sea, the beautiful sea, that had a taste like tears, and in its colors reminded me of the stag that wept red tears; for sometimes its waters were red, and sometimes green or blue.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Aphtanides knew how to manage our boat, and I often sat in it, with my little Anastasia, while it glided on through the water, swift as a bird flying through the air.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then, when the sun set, how beautifully, deeply blue, would be the tint on the mountains, one rising above the other in the far distance, and the summit of mount Parnassus rising above them all like a glorious crown.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Its top glittered in the evening rays like molten gold, and it seemed as if the light came from within it; for long after the sun had sunk beneath the horizon, the mountain-top would glow in the clear, blue sky.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The white aquatic birds skimmed the surface of the water in their flight, and all was calm and still as amid the black rocks at Delphi.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I lay on my back in the boat, Anastasia leaned against me, while the stars above us glittered more brightly than the lamps in our church.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were the same stars, and in the same position over me as when I used to sit in front of our hut at Delphi, and I had almost begun to fancy I was still there, when suddenly there was a splash in the water- Anastasia had fallen in; but in a moment Aphtanides has sprung in after her, and was now holding her up to me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We dried her clothes as well as we were able, and remained on the water till they were dry; for we did not wish it to be known what a fright we had had, nor the danger which our little adopted sister had incurred, in whose life Aphtanides had now a part.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The summer came, and the burning heat of the sun tinted the leaves of the trees with lines of gold.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I thought of our cool mountain-home, and the fresh water that flowed near it; my mother, too, longed for if, and one evening we wandered towards home.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How peaceful and silent it was as we walked on through the thick, wild thyme, still fragrant, though the sun had scorched the leaves.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Not a single herdsman did we meet, not a solitary hut did we pass; everything appeared lonely and deserted- only a shooting star showed that in the heavens there was yet life.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I know not whether the clear, blue atmosphere gleamed with its own light, or if the radiance came from the stars; but we could distinguish quite plainly the outline of the mountains.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: My mother lighted a fire, and roasted some roots she had brought with her, and I and my little sister slept among the bushes, without fear of the ugly smidraki, from whose throat issues fire, or of the wolf and the jackal; for my mother sat by us, and I considered her presence sufficient protection.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We reached our old home; but the cottage was in ruins, and we had to build a new one.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: With the aid of some neighbors, chiefly women, the walls were in a few days erected, and very soon covered with a roof of olive-branches.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: My mother obtained a living by making bottle-cases of bark and skins, and I kept the sheep belonging to the priests, who were sometimes peasants, while I had for my playfellows Anastasia and the turtles.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Once our beloved Aphtanides paid us a visit.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He said he had been longing to see us so much; and he remained with us two whole happy days.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A month afterwards he came again to wish us good-bye, and brought with him a large fish for my mother.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He told us he was going in a ship to Corfu and Patras, and could relate a great many stories, not only about the fishermen who lived near the gulf of Lepanto, but also of kings and heroes who had once possessed Greece, just as the Turks possess it now.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I have seen a bud on a rose-bush gradually, in the course of a few weeks, unfold its leaves till it became a rose in all its beauty; and, before I was aware of it, I beheld it blooming in rosy loveliness.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The same thing had happened to Anastasia.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Unnoticed by me, she had gradually become a beautiful maiden, and I was now also a stout, strong youth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The wolf-skins that covered the bed in which my mother and Anastasia slept, had been taken from wolves which I had myself shot.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Years had gone by when, one evening, Aphtanides came in.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had grown tall and slender as a reed, with strong limbs, and a dark, brown skin.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He kissed us all, and had so much to tell of what he had seen of the great ocean, of the fortifications at Malta, and of the marvellous sepulchres of Egypt, that I looked up to him with a kind of veneration.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His stories were as strange as the legends of the priests of olden times.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How much you know!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I exclaimed, "and what wonders you can relate?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I think what you once told me, the finest of all, he replied; "you told me of a thing that has never been out of my thoughts- of the good old custom of 'the bond of friendship,'- a custom I should like to follow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Brother, let you and I go to church, as your father and Anastasia's father once did.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Your sister Anastasia is the most beautiful and most innocent of maidens, and she shall consecrate the deed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No people have such grand old customs as we Greeks."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Anastasia blushed like a young rose, and my mother kissed Aphtanides.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At about two miles from our cottage, where the earth on the hill is sheltered by a few scattered trees, stood the little church, with a silver lamp hanging before the altar.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I put on my best clothes, and the white tunic fell in graceful folds over my hips.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The red jacket fitted tight and close, the tassel on my Fez cap was of silver, and in my girdle glittered a knife and my pistols.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Aphtanides was clad in the blue dress worn by the Greek sailors; on his breast hung a silver medal with the figure of the Virgin Mary, and his scarf was as costly as those worn by rich lords.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Every one could see that we were about to perform a solemn ceremony.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When we entered the little, unpretending church, the evening sunlight streamed through the open door on the burning lamp, and glittered on the golden picture frames.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We knelt down together on the altar steps, and Anastasia drew near and stood beside us.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A long, white garment fell in graceful folds over her delicate form, and on her white neck and bosom hung a chain entwined with old and new coins, forming a kind of collar.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her black hair was fastened into a knot, and confined by a headdress formed of gold and silver coins which had been found in an ancient temple.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No Greek girl had more beautiful ornaments than these.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her countenance glowed, and her eyes were like two stars.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We all three offered a silent prayer, and then she said to us, "Will you be friends in life and in death?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, we replied.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Will you each remember to say, whatever may happen, 'My brother is a part of myself; his secret is my secret, my happiness is his; self-sacrifice, patience, everything belongs to me as they do to him?'

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And we again answered, "Yes."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then she joined out hands and kissed us on the forehead, and we again prayed silently.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: After this a priest came through a door near the altar, and blessed us all three.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then a song was sung by other holy men behind the altar-screen, and the bond of eternal friendship was confirmed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When we arose, I saw my mother standing by the church door, weeping.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How cheerful everything seemed now in our little cottage by the Delphian springs!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On the evening before his departure, Aphtanides sat thoughtfully beside me on the slopes of the mountain.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His arm was flung around me, and mine was round his neck.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We spoke of the sorrows of Greece, and of the men of the country who could be trusted.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Every thought of our souls lay clear before us.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Presently I seized his hand: "Aphtanides," I exclaimed, "there is one thing still that you must know,- one thing that till now has been a secret between myself and Heaven.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: My whole soul is filled with love,- with a love stronger than the love I bear to my mother and to thee.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And whom do you love? asked Aphtanides.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And his face and neck grew red as fire.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I love Anastasia, I replied.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then his hand trembled in mine, and he became pale as a corpse.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I saw it, I understood the cause, and I believe my hand trembled too.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I bent towards him, I kissed his forehead, and whispered, "I have never spoken of this to her, and perhaps she does not love me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Brother, think of this; I have seen her daily, she has grown up beside me, and has become a part of my soul."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And she shall be thine, he exclaimed; "thine!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I may not wrong thee, nor will I do so.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I also love her, but tomorrow I depart.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In a year we will see each other again, but then you will be married; shall it not be so?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I have a little gold of my own, it shall be yours.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You must and shall take it."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We wandered silently homeward across the mountains.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was late in the evening when we reached my mother's door.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Anastasia held the lamp as we entered; my mother was not there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She looked at Aphtanides with a sweet but mournful expression on her face.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: To-morrow you are going to leave us, she said.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am very sorry.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Sorry! he exclaimed, and his voice was troubled with a grief as deep as my own.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I could not speak; but he seized her hand and said, "Our brother yonder loves you, and is he not dear to you?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His very silence now proves his affection."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Anastasia trembled, and burst into tears.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then I saw no one, thought of none, but her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I threw my arms round her, and pressed my lips to hers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As she flung her arms round my neck, the lamp fell to the ground, and we were in darkness, dark as the heart of poor Aphtanides.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Before daybreak he rose, kissed us all, and said "Farewell," and went away.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had given all his money to my mother for us.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Anastasia was betrothed to me, and in a few days afterwards she became my wife.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THERE was once a regular student, who lived in a garret, and had no possessions.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And there was also a regular huckster, to whom the house belonged, and who occupied the ground floor.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A goblin lived with the huckster, because at Christmas he always had a large dish full of jam, with a great piece of butter in the middle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The huckster could afford this; and therefore the goblin remained with the huckster, which was very cunning of him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One evening the student came into the shop through the back door to buy candles and cheese for himself, he had no one to send, and therefore he came himself; he obtained what he wished, and then the huckster and his wife nodded good evening to him, and she was a woman who could do more than merely nod, for she had usually plenty to say for herself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The student nodded in return as he turned to leave, then suddenly stopped, and began reading the piece of paper in which the cheese was wrapped.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a leaf torn out of an old book, a book that ought not to have been torn up, for it was full of poetry.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yonder lies some more of the same sort, said the huckster: "I gave an old woman a few coffee berries for it; you shall have the rest for sixpence, if you will."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Indeed I will, said the student; "give me the book instead of the cheese; I can eat my bread and butter without cheese.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It would be a sin to tear up a book like this.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You are a clever man; and a practical man; but you understand no more about poetry than that cask yonder."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This was a very rude speech, especially against the cask; but the huckster and the student both laughed, for it was only said in fun.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the goblin felt very angry that any man should venture to say such things to a huckster who was a householder and sold the best butter.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As soon as it was night, and the shop closed, and every one in bed except the student, the goblin stepped softly into the bedroom where the huckster's wife slept, and took away her tongue, which of course, she did not then want.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Whatever object in the room he placed his tongue upon immediately received voice and speech, and was able to express its thoughts and feelings as readily as the lady herself could do.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It could only be used by one object at a time, which was a good thing, as a number speaking at once would have caused great confusion.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The goblin laid the tongue upon the cask, in which lay a quantity of old newspapers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Is it really true, he asked, that you do not know what poetry is?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Of course I know, replied the cask: "poetry is something that always stand in the corner of a newspaper, and is sometimes cut out; and I may venture to affirm that I have more of it in me than the student has, and I am only a poor tub of the huckster's."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the goblin placed the tongue on the coffee mill; and how it did go to be sure!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he put it on the butter tub and the cash box, and they all expressed the same opinion as the waste-paper tub; and a majority must always be respected.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now I shall go and tell the student, said the goblin; and with these words he went quietly up the back stairs to the garret where the student lived.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had a candle burning still, and the goblin peeped through the keyhole and saw that he was reading in the torn book, which he had brought out of the shop.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But how light the room was!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: From the book shot forth a ray of light which grew broad and full, like the stem of a tree, from which bright rays spread upward and over the student's head.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Each leaf was fresh, and each flower was like a beautiful female head; some with dark and sparkling eyes, and others with eyes that were wonderfully blue and clear.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The fruit gleamed like stars, and the room was filled with sounds of beautiful music.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The little goblin had never imagined, much less seen or heard of, any sight so glorious as this.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He stood still on tiptoe, peeping in, till the light went out in the garret.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The student no doubt had blown out his candle and gone to bed; but the little goblin remained standing there nevertheless, and listening to the music which still sounded on, soft and beautiful, a sweet cradle-song for the student, who had lain down to rest."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This is a wonderful place, said the goblin; "I never expected such a thing.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I should like to stay here with the student;" and the little man thought it over, for he was a sensible little spirit.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At last he sighed, "but the student has no jam!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So he went down stairs again into the huckster's shop, and it was a good thing he got back when he did, for the cask had almost worn out the lady's tongue; he had given a description of all that he contained on one side, and was just about to turn himself over to the other side to describe what was there, when the goblin entered and restored the tongue to the lady.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But from that time forward, the whole shop, from the cash box down to the pinewood logs, formed their opinions from that of the cask; and they all had such confidence in him, and treated him with so much respect, that when the huckster read the criticisms on theatricals and art of an evening, they fancied it must all come from the cask.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But after what he had seen, the goblin could no longer sit and listen quietly to the wisdom and understanding down stairs; so, as soon as the evening light glimmered in the garret, he took courage, for it seemed to him as if the rays of light were strong cables, drawing him up, and obliging him to go and peep through the keyhole; and, while there, a feeling of vastness came over him such as we experience by the ever-moving sea, when the storm breaks forth; and it brought tears into his eyes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He did not himself know why he wept, yet a kind of pleasant feeling mingled with his tears.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How wonderfully glorious it would be to sit with the student under such a tree; but that was out of the question, he must be content to look through the keyhole, and be thankful for even that.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There he stood on the old landing, with the autumn wind blowing down upon him through the trap-door.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was very cold; but the little creature did not really feel it, till the light in the garret went out, and the tones of music died away.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then how he shivered, and crept down stairs again to his warm corner, where it felt home-like and comfortable.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And when Christmas came again, and brought the dish of jam and the great lump of butter, he liked the huckster best of all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Soon after, in the middle of the night, the goblin was awoke by a terrible noise and knocking against the window shutters and the house doors, and by the sound of the watchman's horn; for a great fire had broken out, and the whole street appeared full of flames.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Was it in their house, or a neighbor's?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No one could tell, for terror had seized upon all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The huckster's wife was so bewildered that she took her gold ear-rings out of her ears and put them in her pocket, that she might save something at least.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The huckster ran to get his business papers, and the servant resolved to save her blue silk mantle, which she had managed to buy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Each wished to keep the best things they had.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The goblin had the same wish; for, with one spring, he was up stairs and in the student's room, whom he found standing by the open window, and looking quite calmly at the fire, which was raging at the house of a neighbor opposite.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The goblin caught up the wonderful book which lay on the table, and popped it into his red cap, which he held tightly with both hands.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The greatest treasure in the house was saved; and he ran away with it to the roof, and seated himself on the chimney.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The flames of the burning house opposite illuminated him as he sat, both hands pressed tightly over his cap, in which the treasure lay; and then he found out what feelings really reigned in his heart, and knew exactly which way they tended.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And yet, when the fire was extinguished, and the goblin again began to reflect, he hesitated, and said at last, "I must divide myself between the two; I cannot quite give up the huckster, because of the jam."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And this is a representation of human nature.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We are like the goblin; we all go to visit the huckster "because of the jam."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THE drummer's wife went into the church.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She saw the new altar with the painted pictures and the carved angels.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Those upon the canvas and in the glory over the altar were just as beautiful as the carved ones; and they were painted and gilt into the bargain.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Their hair gleamed golden in the sunshine, lovely to behold; but the real sunshine was more beautiful still.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It shone redder, clearer through the dark trees, when the sun went down.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was lovely thus to look at the sunshine of heaven.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And she looked at the red sun, and she thought about it so deeply, and thought of the little one whom the stork was to bring, and the wife of the drummer was very cheerful, and looked and looked, and wished that the child might have a gleam of sunshine given to it, so that it might at least become like one of the shining angels over the altar.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And when she really had the little child in her arms, and held it up to its father, then it was like one of the angels in the church to behold, with hair like gold- the gleam of the setting sun was upon it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: My golden treasure, my riches, my sunshine! said the mother; and she kissed the shining locks, and it sounded like music and song in the room of the drummer; and there was joy, and life, and movement.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The drummer beat a roll- a roll of joy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the Drum said- the Fire-drum, that was beaten when there was a fire in the town: "Red hair! the little fellow has red hair!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Believe the drum, and not what your mother says!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Rub-a dub, rub-a dub!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the town repeated what the Fire-drum had said.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The boy was taken to church, the boy was christened.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There was nothing much to be said about his name; he was called Peter.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The whole town, and the Drum too, called him Peter the drummer's boy with the red hair; but his mother kissed his red hair, and called him her golden treasure.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the hollow way in the clayey bank, many had scratched their names as a remembrance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Celebrity is always something! said the drummer; and so he scratched his own name there, and his little son's name likewise.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the swallows came.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They had, on their long journey, seen more durable characters engraven on rocks, and on the walls of the temples in Hindostan, mighty deeds of great kings, immortal names, so old that no one now could read or speak them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Remarkable celebrity!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the clayey bank the martens built their nest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They bored holes in the deep declivity, and the splashing rain and the thin mist came and crumbled and washed the names away, and the drummer's name also, and that of his little son.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Peter's name will last a full year and a half longer! said the father.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Fool! thought the Fire-drum; but it only said, "Dub, dub, dub, rub-a-dub!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was a boy full of life and gladness, this drummer's son with the red hair.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had a lovely voice.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He could sing, and he sang like a bird in the woodland.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There was melody, and yet no melody.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He must become a chorister boy, said his mother.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He shall sing in the church, and stand among the beautiful gilded angels who are like him!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Fiery cat! said some of the witty ones of the town.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The Drum heard that from the neighbors' wives.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Don't go home, Peter, cried the street boys.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If you sleep in the garret, there'll be a fire in the house, and the fire-drum will have to be beaten.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Look out for the drumsticks, replied Peter; and, small as he was, he ran up boldly, and gave the foremost such a punch in the body with his fist, that the fellow lost his legs and tumbled over, and the others took their legs off with themselves very rapidly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The town musician was very genteel and fine.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was the son of the royal plate-washer.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was very fond of Peter, and would sometimes take him to his home; and he gave him a violin, and taught him to play it.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Those who sat near him, and heard what he said, looked at him in great astonishment, and one of them rose, took off his hat respectfully, and said in a very serious manner, "You must certainly be a very learned man, monsieur."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh no, replied the counsellor; "I can only discourse on topics which every one should understand."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Modestia is a beautiful virtue, said the man.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Moreover, I must add to your speech mihi secus videtur; yet in this case I would suspend my judicium.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: May I ask to whom I have the pleasure of speaking?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am a Bachelor of Divinity, said the man.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This answer satisfied the counsellor.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The title agreed with the dress.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This is surely, thought he, "an old village schoolmaster, a perfect original, such as one meets with sometimes even in Jutland."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This is not certainly a locus docendi, began the man; "still I must beg you to continue the conversation.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You must be well read in ancient lore."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh yes, replied the counsellor; "I am very fond of reading useful old books, and modern ones as well, with the exception of every-day stories, of which we really have more than enough.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Every-day stories? asked the bachelor.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, I mean the new novels that we have at the present day.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, replied the man, with a smile; "and yet they are very witty, and are much read at Court.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The king likes especially the romance of Messeurs Iffven and Gaudian, which describes King Arthur and his knights of the round table.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He has joked about it with the gentlemen of his Court."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Well, I have certainly not read that, replied the counsellor.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I suppose it is quite new, and published by Heiberg.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No, answered the man, "it is not by Heiberg; Godfred von Gehman brought it out."

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Oh, is he the publisher?
114:114	N:N	N:N	That is a very old name, said the counsellor; "was it not the name of the first publisher in Denmark?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes; and he is our first printer and publisher now, replied the scholar.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So far all had passed off very well; but now one of the citizens began to speak of a terrible pestilence which had been raging a few years before, meaning the plague of 1484.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The counsellor thought he referred to the cholera, and they could discuss this without finding out the mistake.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The war in 1490 was spoken of as quite recent.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The English pirates had taken some ships in the Channel in 1801, and the counsellor, supposing they referred to these, agreed with them in finding fault with the English.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The rest of the talk, however, was not so agreeable; every moment one contradicted the other.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The good bachelor appeared very ignorant, for the simplest remark of the counsellor seemed to him either too bold or too fantastic.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They stared at each other, and when it became worse the bachelor spoke in Latin, in the hope of being better understood; but it was all useless.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How are you now? asked the landlady, pulling the counsellor's sleeve.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then his recollection returned to him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the course of conversation he had forgotten all that had happened previously.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Goodness me! where am I? said he.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It bewildered him as he thought of it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We will have some claret, or mead, or Bremen beer, said one of the guests; "will you drink with us?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Two maids came in.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One of them had a cap on her head of two colors.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They poured out the wine, bowed their heads, and withdrew.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The counsellor felt a cold shiver run all over him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What is this? what does it mean? said he; but he was obliged to drink with them, for they overpowered the good man with their politeness.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He became at last desperate; and when one of them said he was tipsy, he did not doubt the man's word in the least- only begged them to get a droschky; and then they thought he was speaking the Muscovite language.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Never before had he been in such rough and vulgar company.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One might believe that the country was going back to heathenism, he observed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This is the most terrible moment of my life.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Just then it came into his mind that he would stoop under the table, and so creep to the door.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He tried it; but before he reached the entry, the rest discovered what he was about, and seized him by the feet, when, luckily for him, off came the goloshes, and with them vanished the whole enchantment.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The counsellor now saw quite plainly a lamp, and a large building behind it; everything looked familiar and beautiful.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was in East Street, as it now appears; he lay with his legs turned towards a porch, and just by him sat the watchman asleep.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Is it possible that I have been lying here in the street dreaming? said he.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Yes, this is East Street; how beautifully bright and gay it looks!
144:144	Su-:Su-	-:-	It is quite shocking that one glass of punch should have upset me like this.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Two minutes afterwards he sat in a droschky, which was to drive him to Christian's Haven.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He thought of all the terror and anxiety which he had undergone, and felt thankful from his heart for the reality and comfort of modern times, which, with all their errors, were far better than those in which he so lately found himself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THE WATCHMAN'S ADVENTURES

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Well, I declare, there lies a pair of goloshes, said the watchman.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
No doubt, they belong to the lieutenant who lives up stairs.
150:150	N:N	N:N	They are lying just by his door.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Gladly would the honest man have rung, and given them in, for a light was still burning, but he did not wish to disturb the other people in the house; so he let them lie.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: These things must keep the feet very warm, said he; "they are of such nice soft leather."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he tried them on, and they fitted his feet exactly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now, said he, "how droll things are in this world!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There's that man can lie down in his warm bed, but he does not do so.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There he goes pacing up and down the room.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He ought to be a happy man.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He has neither wife nor children, and he goes out into company every evening.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, I wish I were he; then I should be a happy man."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As he uttered this wish, the goloshes which he had put on took effect, and the watchman at once became the lieutenant.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There he stood in his room, holding a little piece of pink paper between his fingers, on which was a poem,- a poem written by the lieutenant himself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Who has not had, for once in his life, a moment of poetic inspiration? and at such a moment, if the thoughts are written down, they flow in poetry.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The following verses were written on the pink paper:-

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
OH WERE I RICH!
165:165	N:N	N:-	Oh were I rich!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How oft, in youth's bright hour, When youthful pleasures banish every care, I longed for riches but to gain a power, The sword and plume and uniform to wear!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The riches and the honor came for me; Yet still my greatest wealth was poverty: Ah, help and pity me!

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Once in my youthful hours, when gay and free, A maiden loved me; and her gentle kiss, Rich in its tender love and purity, Taught me, alas! too much of earthly bliss.
169:169	N:N	N:N	Dear child!
170:170	N:N	N:N	She only thought of youthful glee; She loved no wealth, but fairy tales and me.
171:171	N:Sa	N:-	Thou knowest: ah, pity me!
172:172	N:N	N:N	Oh were I rich! again is all my prayer: That child is now a woman, fair and free, As good and beautiful as angels are.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, were I rich in lovers' poetry, To tell my fairy tale, love's richest lore!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But no; I must be silent- I am poor.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ah, wilt thou pity me?

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Oh were I rich in truth and peace below, I need not then my poverty bewail.
177:177	N:N	N:S	To thee I dedicate these lines of woe; Wilt thou not understand the mournful tale?
178:178	N:N	N:S	A leaf on which my sorrows I relate- Dark story of a darker night of fate.
179:179	N:N	N:S	Ah, bless and pity me!

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Well, yes; people write poems when they are in love, but a wise man will not print them.
181:181	N:N	N:S	A lieutenant in love, and poor.
182:182	N:N	N:S	This is a triangle, or more properly speaking, the half of the broken die of fortune.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The lieutenant felt this very keenly, and therefore leaned his head against the window-frame, and sighed deeply.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The poor watchman in the street, said he, "is far happier than I am.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He knows not what I call poverty.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He has a home, a wife and children, who weep at his sorrow and rejoice at his joy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, how much happier I should be could I change my being and position with him, and pass through life with his humble expectations and hopes!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, he is indeed happier than I am."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At this moment the watchman again became a watchman; for having, through the goloshes of Fortune, passed into the existence of the lieutenant, and found himself less contented than he expected, he had preferred his former condition, and wished himself again a watchman.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That was an ugly dream, said he, "but droll enough.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It seemed to me as if I were the lieutenant up yonder, but there was no happiness for me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I missed my wife and the little ones, who are always ready to smother me with kisses."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He sat down again and nodded, but he could not get the dream out of his thoughts, and he still had the goloshes on his feet.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A falling star gleamed across the sky.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There goes one! cried he.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
However, there are quite enough left; I should very much like to examine these a little nearer, especially the moon, for that could not slip away under one's hands.

198:198	N:N	N:N	If that were true, it would be very delightful, but I don't believe it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There are certain things in the world which should be uttered very cautiously; doubly so when the speaker has on his feet the goloshes of Fortune.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now we shall hear what happened to the watchman.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Nearly every one is acquainted with the great power of steam; we have proved it by the rapidity with which we can travel, both on a railroad or in a steamship across the sea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But this speed is like the movements of the sloth, or the crawling march of the snail, when compared to the swiftness with which light travels; light flies nineteen million times faster than the fleetest race-horse, and electricity is more rapid still.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Death is an electric shock which we receive in our hearts, and on the wings of electricity the liberated soul flies away swiftly, the light from the sun travels to our earth ninety-five millions of miles in eight minutes and a few seconds; but on the wings of electricity, the mind requires only a second to accomplish the same distance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The space between the heavenly bodies is, to thought, no farther than the distance which we may have to walk from one friend's house to another in the same town; yet this electric shock obliges us to use our bodies here below, unless, like the watchman, we have on the goloshes of Fortune.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In a very few seconds the watchman had travelled more than two hundred thousand miles to the moon, which is formed of a lighter material than our earth, and may be said to be as soft as new fallen snow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He found himself on one of the circular range of mountains which we see represented in Dr. Madler's large map of the moon.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The interior had the appearance of a large hollow, bowl-shaped, with a depth about half a mile from the brim.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Within this hollow stood a large town; we may form some idea of its appearance by pouring the white of an egg into a glass of water.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The materials of which it was built seemed just as soft, and pictured forth cloudy turrets and sail-like terraces, quite transparent, and floating in the thin air.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Our earth hung over his head like a great dark red ball.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Presently he discovered a number of beings, which might certainly be called men, but were very different to ourselves.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A more fantastical imagination than Herschel's must have discovered these.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Had they been placed in groups, and painted, it might have been said, "What beautiful foliage!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They had also a language of their own.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No one could have expected the soul of the watchman to understand it, and yet he did understand it, for our souls have much greater capabilities then we are inclined to believe.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Do we not, in our dreams, show a wonderful dramatic talent? each of our acquaintance appears to us then in his own character, and with his own voice; no man could thus imitate them in his waking hours.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How clearly, too, we are reminded of persons whom we have not seen for many years; they start up suddenly to the mind's eye with all their peculiarities as living realities.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In fact, this memory of the soul is a fearful thing; every sin, every sinful thought it can bring back, and we may well ask how we are to give account of "every idle word" that may have been whispered in the heart or uttered with the lips.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The spirit of the watchman therefore understood very well the language of the inhabitants of the moon.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were disputing about our earth, and doubted whether it could be inhabited.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The atmosphere, they asserted, must be too dense for any inhabitants of the moon to exist there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They maintained that the moon alone was inhabited, and was really the heavenly body in which the old world people lived.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They likewise talked politics.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But now we will descend to East Street, and see what happened to the watchman's body.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He sat lifeless on the steps.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His staff had fallen out of his hand, and his eyes stared at the moon, about which his honest soul was wandering.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What is it o'clock, watchman? inquired a passenger.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But there was no answer from the watchman.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The man then pulled his nose gently, which caused him to lose his balance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The body fell forward, and lay at full length on the ground as one dead.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All his comrades were very much frightened, for he seemed quite dead; still they allowed him to remain after they had given notice of what had happened; and at dawn the body was carried to the hospital.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We might imagine it to be no jesting matter if the soul of the man should chance to return to him, for most probably it would seek for the body in East Street without being able to find it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We might fancy the soul inquiring of the police, or at the address office, or among the missing parcels, and then at length finding it at the hospital.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But we may comfort ourselves by the certainty that the soul, when acting upon its own impulses, is wiser than we are; it is the body that makes it stupid.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As we have said, the watchman's body had been taken to the hospital, and here it was placed in a room to be washed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Naturally, the first thing done here was to take off the goloshes, upon which the soul was instantly obliged to return, and it took the direct road to the body at once, and in a few seconds the man's life returned to him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He declared, when he quite recovered himself, that this had been the most dreadful night he had ever passed; not for a hundred pounds would he go through such feelings again.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: However, it was all over now.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The same day he was allowed to leave, but the goloshes remained at the hospital.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THE EVENTFUL MOMENT - A MOST UNUSUAL JOURNEY

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Every inhabitant of Copenhagen knows what the entrance to Frederick's Hospital is like; but as most probably a few of those who read this little tale may not reside in Copenhagen, we will give a short description of it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The hospital is separated from the street by an iron railing, in which the bars stand so wide apart that, it is said, some very slim patients have squeezed through, and gone to pay little visits in the town.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The most difficult part of the body to get through was the head; and in this case, as it often happens in the world, the small heads were the most fortunate.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This will serve as sufficient introduction to our tale.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One of the young volunteers, of whom, physically speaking, it might be said that he had a great head, was on guard that evening at the hospital.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The rain was pouring down, yet, in spite of these two obstacles, he wanted to go out just for a quarter of an hour; it was not worth while, he thought, to make a confidant of the porter, as he could easily slip through the iron railings.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There lay the goloshes, which the watchman had forgotten.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It never occurred to him that these could be goloshes of Fortune.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They would be very serviceable to him in this rainy weather, so he drew them on.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now came the question whether he could squeeze through the palings; he certainly had never tried, so he stood looking at them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I wish to goodness my head was through, said he, and instantly, though it was so thick and large, it slipped through quite easily.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The goloshes answered that purpose very well, but his body had to follow, and this was impossible.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am too fat, he said; "I thought my head would be the worst, but I cannot get my body through, that is certain."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he tried to pull his head back again, but without success; he could move his neck about easily enough, and that was all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His first feeling was one of anger, and then his spirits sank below zero.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The goloshes of Fortune had placed him in this terrible position, and unfortunately it never occurred to him to wish himself free.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No, instead of wishing he kept twisting about, yet did not stir from the spot.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The rain poured, and not a creature could be seen in the street.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The porter's bell he was unable to reach, and however was he to get loose!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He foresaw that he should have to stay there till morning, and then they must send for a smith to file away the iron bars, and that would be a work of time.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All the charity children would just be going to school: and all the sailors who inhabited that quarter of the town would be there to see him standing in the pillory.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What a crowd there would be.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ha, he cried, "the blood is rushing to my head, and I shall go mad.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I believe I am crazy already; oh, I wish I were free, then all these sensations would pass off."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This is just what he ought to have said at first.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The moment he had expressed the thought his head was free.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He started back, quite bewildered with the fright which the goloshes of Fortune had caused him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But we must not suppose it was all over; no, indeed, there was worse to come yet.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The night passed, and the whole of the following day; but no one sent for the goloshes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the evening a declamatory performance was to take place at the amateur theatre in a distant street.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The house was crowded; among the audience was the young volunteer from the hospital, who seemed to have quite forgotten his adventures of the previous evening.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had on the goloshes; they had not been sent for, and as the streets were still very dirty, they were of great service to him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A new poem, entitled "My Aunt's Spectacles," was being recited.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It described these spectacles as possessing a wonderful power; if any one put them on in a large assembly the people appeared like cards, and the future events of ensuing years could be easily foretold by them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The idea struck him that he should very much like to have such a pair of spectacles; for, if used rightly, they would perhaps enable him to see into the hearts of people, which he thought would be more interesting than to know what was going to happen next year; for future events would be sure to show themselves, but the hearts of people never.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
I can fancy what I should see in the whole row of ladies and gentlemen on the first seat, if I could only look into their hearts; that lady, I imagine, keeps a store for things of all descriptions; how my eyes would wander about in that collection; with many ladies I should no doubt find a large millinery establishment.
278:278	N:N	N:N	There is another that is perhaps empty, and would be all the better for cleaning out.
279:279	N:N	N:N	There may be some well stored with good articles.
280:280	N:N	N:N	Ah, yes, he sighed, "I know one, in which everything is solid, but a servant is there already, and that is the only thing against it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I dare say from many I should hear the words, 'Please to walk in.'

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I only wish I could slip into the hearts like a little tiny thought."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This was the word of command for the goloshes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The volunteer shrunk up together, and commenced a most unusual journey through the hearts of the spectators in the first row.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The first heart he entered was that of a lady, but he thought he must have got into one of the rooms of an orthopedic institution where plaster casts of deformed limbs were hanging on the walls, with this difference, that the casts in the institution are formed when the patient enters, but here they were formed and preserved after the good people had left.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: These were casts of the bodily and mental deformities of the lady's female friends carefully preserved.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Quickly he passed into another heart, which had the appearance of a spacious, holy church, with the white dove of innocence fluttering over the altar.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Gladly would he have fallen on his knees in such a sacred place; but he was carried on to another heart, still, however, listening to the tones of the organ, and feeling himself that he had become another and a better man.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The next heart was also a sanctuary, which he felt almost unworthy to enter; it represented a mean garret, in which lay a sick mother; but the warm sunshine streamed through the window, lovely roses bloomed in a little flowerbox on the roof, two blue birds sang of childlike joys, and the sick mother prayed for a blessing on her daughter.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Next he crept on his hands and knees through an overfilled butcher's shop; there was meat, nothing but meat, wherever he stepped; this was the heart of a rich, respectable man, whose name is doubtless in the directory.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he entered the heart of this man's wife; it was an old, tumble-down pigeon-house; the husband's portrait served as a weather-cock; it was connected with all the doors, which opened and shut just as the husband's decision turned.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The next heart was a complete cabinet of mirrors, such as can be seen in the Castle of Rosenberg.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But these mirrors magnified in an astonishing degree; in the middle of the floor sat, like the Grand Lama, the insignificant I of the owner, astonished at the contemplation of his own features.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At his next visit he fancied he must have got into a narrow needlecase, full of sharp needles: "Oh," thought he, "this must be the heart of an old maid;" but such was not the fact; it belonged to a young officer, who wore several orders, and was said to be a man of intellect and heart.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The poor volunteer came out of the last heart in the row quite bewildered.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He could not collect his thoughts, and imagined his foolish fancies had carried him away.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Good gracious! he sighed, "I must have a tendency to softening of the brain, and here it is so exceedingly hot that the blood is rushing to my head."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then suddenly recurred to him the strange event of the evening before, when his head had been fixed between the iron railings in front of the hospital.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That is the cause of it all! he exclaimed, "I must do something in time.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A Russian bath would be a very good thing to begin with.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I wish I were lying on one of the highest shelves."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Sure enough, there he lay on an upper shelf of a vapor bath, still in his evening costume, with his boots and goloshes on, and the hot drops from the ceiling falling on his face.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ho! he cried, jumping down and rushing towards the plunging bath.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The attendant stopped him with a loud cry, when he saw a man with all his clothes on.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The volunteer had, however, presence of mind enough to whisper, "It is for a wager;" but the first thing he did, when he reached his own room, was to put a large blister on his neck, and another on his back, that his crazy fit might be cured.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The next morning his back was very sore, which was all he gained by the goloshes of Fortune.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THE CLERK'S TRANSFORMATION

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The watchman, whom we of course have not forgotten, thought, after a while, of the goloshes which he had found and taken to the hospital; so he went and fetched them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But neither the lieutenant nor any one in the street could recognize them as their own, so he gave them up to the police.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They look exactly like my own goloshes, said one of the clerks, examining the unknown articles, as they stood by the side of his own.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It would require even more than the eye of a shoemaker to know one pair from the other.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Master clerk, said a servant who entered with some papers.

sentence: Oh, my poor mother! he cried, while the tears rolled down his cheeks.
