author: HCAndersen
sentence: No, indeed, it is not true, replied the old servant, raising her eyes to heaven; "she was worth a great deal; I knew it years ago, and since the last night of her life I am more certain of it than ever.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I say she was a good and worthy woman, and God, who is in heaven, knows I am speaking the truth, though the world may say, even now she was good for nothing."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: GRANDMOTHER is very old, her face is wrinkled, and her hair is quite white; but her eyes are like two stars, and they have a mild, gentle expression in them when they look at you, which does you good.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She wears a dress of heavy, rich silk, with large flowers worked on it; and it rustles when she moves.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then she can tell the most wonderful stories.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Grandmother knows a great deal, for she was alive before father and mother- that's quite certain.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She has a hymn-book with large silver clasps, in which she often reads; and in the book, between the leaves, lies a rose, quite flat and dry; it is not so pretty as the roses which are standing in the glass, and yet she smiles at it most pleasantly, and tears even come into her eyes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
I wonder why grandmother looks at the withered flower in the old book that way?
6:6	N:N	N:N	Do you know?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Why, when grandmother's tears fall upon the rose, and she is looking at it, the rose revives, and fills the room with its fragrance; the walls vanish as in a mist, and all around her is the glorious green wood, where in summer the sunlight streams through thick foliage; and grandmother, why she is young again, a charming maiden, fresh as a rose, with round, rosy cheeks, fair, bright ringlets, and a figure pretty and graceful; but the eyes, those mild, saintly eyes, are the same,- they have been left to grandmother.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At her side sits a young man, tall and strong; he gives her a rose and she smiles.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Grandmother cannot smile like that now.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, she is smiling at the memory of that day, and many thoughts and recollections of the past; but the handsome young man is gone, and the rose has withered in the old book, and grandmother is sitting there, again an old woman, looking down upon the withered rose in the book.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Grandmother is dead now.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She had been sitting in her arm-chair, telling us a long, beautiful tale; and when it was finished, she said she was tired, and leaned her head back to sleep awhile.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We could hear her gentle breathing as she slept; gradually it became quieter and calmer, and on her countenance beamed happiness and peace.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was as if lighted up with a ray of sunshine.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She smiled once more, and then people said she was dead.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was laid in a black coffin, looking mild and beautiful in the white folds of the shrouded linen, though her eyes were closed; but every wrinkle had vanished, her hair looked white and silvery, and around her mouth lingered a sweet smile.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We did not feel at all afraid to look at the corpse of her who had been such a dear, good grandmother.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The hymn-book, in which the rose still lay, was placed under her head, for so she had wished it; and then they buried grandmother.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On the grave, close by the churchyard wall, they planted a rose-tree; it was soon full of roses, and the nightingale sat among the flowers, and sang over the grave.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: From the organ in the church sounded the music and the words of the beautiful psalms, which were written in the old book under the head of the dead one.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The moon shone down upon the grave, but the dead was not there; every child could go safely, even at night, and pluck a rose from the tree by the churchyard wall.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The dead know more than we do who are living.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They know what a terror would come upon us if such a strange thing were to happen, as the appearance of a dead person among us.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They are better off than we are; the dead return no more.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The earth has been heaped on the coffin, and it is earth only that lies within it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The leaves of the hymn-book are dust; and the rose, with all its recollections, has crumbled to dust also.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But over the grave fresh roses bloom, the nightingale sings, and the organ sounds and there still lives a remembrance of old grandmother, with the loving, gentle eyes that always looked young.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Eyes can never die.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ours will once again behold dear grandmother, young and beautiful as when, for the first time, she kissed the fresh, red rose, that is now dust in the grave.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THIS story really consists of two parts.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The first part might be left out, but it gives us a few particulars, and these are useful We were staying in the country at a gentleman's seat, where it happened that the master was absent for a few days.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the meantime, there arrived from the next town a lady; she had a pug dog with her, and came, she said, to dispose of shares in her tan-yard.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She had her papers with her, and we advised her to put them in an envelope, and to write thereon the address of the proprietor of the estate, "General War-Commissary Knight," &c.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She listened to us attentively, seized the pen, paused, and begged us to repeat the direction slowly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We complied, and she wrote; but in the midst of the "General War-" she struck fast, sighed deeply, and said, "I am only a woman!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her Puggie had seated itself on the ground while she wrote, and growled; for the dog had come with her for amusement and for the sake of its health; and then the bare floor ought not to be offered to a visitor.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His outward appearance was characterized by a snub nose and a very fat back.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He doesn't bite, said the lady; "he has no teeth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He is like one of the family, faithful and grumpy; but the latter is my grandchildren's fault, for they have teased him; they play at wedding, and want to give him the part of the bridesmaid, and that's too much for him, poor old fellow."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And she delivered her papers, and took Puggie upon her arm.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And this is the first part of the story which might have been left out.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: PUGGIE DIED!!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That's the second part.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was about a week afterwards we arrived in the town, and put up at the inn.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Our windows looked into the tan-yard, which was divided into two parts by a partition of planks; in one half were many skins and hides, raw and tanned.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here was all the apparatus necessary to carry on a tannery, and it belonged to the widow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Puggie had died in the morning, and was to be buried in this part of the yard; the grandchildren of the widow (that is, of the tanner's widow, for Puggie had never been married) filled up the grave, and it was a beautiful grave- it must have been quite pleasant to lie there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The grave was bordered with pieces of flower-pots and strewn over with sand; quite at the top they had stuck up half a beer bottle, with the neck upwards, and that was not at all allegorical.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The children danced round the grave, and the eldest of the boys among them, a practical youngster of seven years, made the proposition that there should be an exhibition of Puggie's burial-place for all who lived in the lane; the price of admission was to be a trouser button, for every boy would be sure to have one, and each might also give one for a little girl.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This proposal was adopted by acclamation.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And all the children out of the lane- yes, even out of the little lane at the back- flocked to the place, and each gave a button.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Many were noticed to go about on that afternoon with only one suspender; but then they had seen Puggie's grave, and the sight was worth much more.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But in front of the tan-yard, close to the entrance, stood a little girl clothed in rags, very pretty to look at, with curly hair, and eyes so blue and clear that it was a pleasure to look into them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The child said not a word, nor did she cry; but each time the little door was opened she gave a long, long look into the yard.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She had not a button- that she knew right well, and therefore she remained standing sorrowfully outside, till all the others had seen the grave and had gone away; then she sat down, held her little brown hands before her eyes, and burst into tears; this girl alone had not seen Puggie's grave.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a grief as great to her as any grown person can experience.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We saw this from above; and looked at from above, how many a grief of our own and of others can make us smile!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That is the story, and whoever does not understand it may go and purchase a share in the tan-yard from the window.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THE largest green leaf in this country is certainly the burdock-leaf.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If you hold it in front of you, it is large enough for an apron; and if you hold it over your head, it is almost as good as an umbrella, it is so wonderfully large.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A burdock never grows alone; where it grows, there are many more, and it is a splendid sight; and all this splendor is good for snails.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The great white snails, which grand people in olden times used to have made into fricassees; and when they had eaten them, they would say, "O, what a delicious dish!" for these people really thought them good; and these snails lived on burdock-leaves, and for them the burdock was planted.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There was once an old estate where no one now lived to require snails; indeed, the owners had all died out, but the burdock still flourished; it grew over all the beds and walks of the garden- its growth had no check- till it became at last quite a forest of burdocks.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here and there stood an apple or a plum-tree; but for this, nobody would have thought the place had ever been a garden.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was burdock from one end to the other; and here lived the last two surviving snails.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They knew not themselves how old they were; but they could remember the time when there were a great many more of them, and that they were descended from a family which came from foreign lands, and that the whole forest had been planted for them and theirs.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They had never been away from the garden; but they knew that another place once existed in the world, called the Duke's Palace Castle, in which some of their relations had been boiled till they became black, and were then laid on a silver dish; but what was done afterwards they did not know.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Besides, they could not imagine exactly how it felt to be boiled and placed on a silver dish; but no doubt it was something very fine and highly genteel.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Neither the cockchafer, nor the toad, nor the earth-worm, whom they questioned about it, would give them the least information; for none of their relations had ever been cooked or served on a silver dish.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The old white snails were the most aristocratic race in the world,- they knew that.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The forest had been planted for them, and the nobleman's castle had been built entirely that they might be cooked and laid on silver dishes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They lived quite retired and very happily; and as they had no children of their own, they had adopted a little common snail, which they brought up as their own child.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The little one would not grow, for he was only a common snail; but the old people, particularly the mother-snail, declared that she could easily see how he grew; and when the father said he could not perceive it, she begged him to feel the little snail's shell, and he did so, and found that the mother was right.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One day it rained very fast.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Listen, what a drumming there is on the burdock-leaves; turn, turn, turn; turn, turn, turn, said the father-snail.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There come the drops, said the mother; "they are trickling down the stalks.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We shall have it very wet here presently.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am very glad we have such good houses, and that the little one has one of his own.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There has been really more done for us than for any other creature; it is quite plain that we are the most noble people in the world.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We have houses from our birth, and the burdock forest has been planted for us.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I should very much like to know how far it extends, and what lies beyond it."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There can be nothing better than we have here, said the father-snail; "I wish for nothing more."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, but I do, said the mother; "I should like to be taken to the palace, and boiled, and laid upon a silver dish, as was done to all our ancestors; and you may be sure it must be something very uncommon."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The nobleman's castle, perhaps, has fallen to decay, said the snail-father, or the burdock wood may have grown out.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You need not be in a hurry; you are always so impatient, and the youngster is getting just the same.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He has been three days creeping to the top of that stalk.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I feel quite giddy when I look at him."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You must not scold him, said the mother-snail; "he creeps so very carefully.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He will be the joy of our home; and we old folks have nothing else to live for.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But have you ever thought where we are to get a wife for him?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Do you think that farther out in the wood there may be others of our race?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There may be black snails, no doubt, said the old snail; "black snails without houses; but they are so vulgar and conceited too.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But we can give the ants a commission; they run here and there, as if they all had so much business to get through.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They, most likely, will know of a wife for our youngster."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I certainly know a most beautiful bride, said one of the ants; "but I fear it would not do, for she is a queen."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That does not matter, said the old snail; "has she a house?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She has a palace, replied the ant,- "a most beautiful ant-palace with seven hundred passages."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thank-you, said the mother-snail; "but our boy shall not go to live in an ant-hill.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If you know of nothing better, we will give the commission to the white gnats; they fly about in rain and sunshine; they know the burdock wood from one end to the other."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We have a wife for him, said the gnats; "a hundred man-steps from here there is a little snail with a house, sitting on a gooseberry-bush; she is quite alone, and old enough to be married.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is only a hundred man-steps from here."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then let her come to him, said the old people.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He has the whole burdock forest; she has only a bush.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So they brought the little lady-snail.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She took eight days to perform the journey; but that was just as it ought to be; for it showed her to be one of the right breeding.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then they had a wedding.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Six glow-worms gave as much light as they could; but in other respects it was all very quiet; for the old snails could not bear festivities or a crowd.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But a beautiful speech was made by the mother-snail.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The father could not speak; he was too much overcome.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they gave the whole burdock forest to the young snails as an inheritance, and repeated what they had so often said, that it was the finest place in the world, and that if they led upright and honorable lives, and their family increased, they and their children might some day be taken to the nobleman's palace, to be boiled black, and laid on a silver dish.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And when they had finished speaking, the old couple crept into their houses, and came out no more; for they slept.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The young snail pair now ruled in the forest, and had a numerous progeny.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But as the young ones were never boiled or laid in silver dishes, they concluded that the castle had fallen into decay, and that all the people in the world were dead; and as nobody contradicted them, they thought they must be right.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the rain fell upon the burdock-leaves, to play the drum for them, and the sun shone to paint colors on the burdock forest for them, and they were very happy; the whole family were entirely and perfectly happy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: HIGH up in the clear, pure air flew an angel, with a flower plucked from the garden of heaven.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As he was kissing the flower a very little leaf fell from it and sunk down into the soft earth in the middle of a wood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It immediately took root, sprouted, and sent out shoots among the other plants.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What a ridiculous little shoot! said one.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No one will recognize it; not even the thistle nor the stinging-nettle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It must be a kind of garden plant, said another; and so they sneered and despised the plant as a thing from a garden.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Where are you coming? said the tall thistles whose leaves were all armed with thorns.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is stupid nonsense to allow yourself to shoot out in this way; we are not here to support you.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Winter came, and the plant was covered with snow, but the snow glittered over it as if it had sunshine beneath as well as above.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When spring came, the plant appeared in full bloom: a more beautiful object than any other plant in the forest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And now the professor of botany presented himself, one who could explain his knowledge in black and white.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He examined and tested the plant, but it did not belong to his system of botany, nor could he possibly find out to what class it did belong.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It must be some degenerate species, said he; "I do not know it, and it is not mentioned in any system."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Not known in any system! repeated the thistles and the nettles.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The large trees which grew round it saw the plant and heard the remarks, but they said not a word either good or bad, which is the wisest plan for those who are ignorant.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There passed through the forest a poor innocent girl; her heart was pure, and her understanding increased by her faith.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her chief inheritance had been an old Bible, which she read and valued.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: From its pages she heard the voice of God speaking to her, and telling her to remember what was said of Joseph's brethren when persons wished to injure her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They imagined evil in their hearts, but God turned it to good.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If we suffer wrongfully, if we are misunderstood or despised, we must think of Him who was pure and holy, and who prayed for those who nailed Him to the cross, "Father forgive them, for they know not what they do."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The girl stood still before the wonderful plant, for the green leaves exhaled a sweet and refreshing fragrance, and the flowers glittered and sparkled in the sunshine like colored flames, and the harmony of sweet sounds lingered round them as if each concealed within itself a deep fount of melody, which thousands of years could not exhaust.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: With pious gratitude the girl looked upon this glorious work of God, and bent down over one of the branches, that she might examine the flower and inhale the sweet perfume.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then a light broke in on her mind, and her heart expanded.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Gladly would she have plucked a flower, but she could not overcome her reluctance to break one off.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She knew it would so soon fade; so she took only a single green leaf, carried it home, and laid it in her Bible, where it remained ever green, fresh, and unfading.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Between the pages of the Bible it still lay when, a few weeks afterwards, that Bible was laid under the young girl's head in her coffin.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A holy calm rested on her face, as if the earthly remains bore the impress of the truth that she now stood in the presence of God.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the forest the wonderful plant still continued to bloom till it grew and became almost a tree, and all the birds of passage bowed themselves before it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That plant is a foreigner, no doubt, said the thistles and the burdocks.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We can never conduct ourselves like that in this country.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the black forest snails actually spat at the flower.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then came the swineherd; he was collecting thistles and shrubs to burn them for the ashes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He pulled up the wonderful plant, roots and all, and placed it in his bundle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This will be as useful as any, he said; so the plant was carried away.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Not long after, the king of the country suffered from the deepest melancholy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was diligent and industrious, but employment did him no good.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They read deep and learned books to him, and then the lightest and most trifling that could be found, but all to no purpose.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they applied for advice to one of the wise men of the world, and he sent them a message to say that there was one remedy which would relieve and cure him, and that it was a plant of heavenly origin which grew in the forest in the king's own dominions.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The messenger described the flower so that is appearance could not be mistaken.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then said the swineherd, "I am afraid I carried this plant away from the forest in my bundle, and it has been burnt to ashes long ago.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But I did not know any better."

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
You did not know, any better!
42:42	A:N	A:A	Ignorance upon ignorance indeed!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The poor swineherd took these words to heart, for they were addressed to him; he knew not that there were others who were equally ignorant.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Not even a leaf of the plant could be found.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There was one, but it lay in the coffin of the dead; no one knew anything about it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the king, in his melancholy, wandered out to the spot in the wood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here is where the plant stood, he said; "it is a sacred place."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he ordered that the place should be surrounded with a golden railing, and a sentry stationed near it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The botanical professor wrote a long treatise about the heavenly plant, and for this he was loaded with gold, which improved the position of himself and his family.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And this part is really the most pleasant part of the story.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: For the plant had disappeared, and the king remained as melancholy and sad as ever, but the sentry said he had always been so.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: IN Denmark there stands an old castle named Kronenburg, close by the Sound of Elsinore, where large ships, both English, Russian, and Prussian, pass by hundreds every day.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And they salute the old castle with cannons, "Boom, boom," which is as if they said, "Good-day."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the cannons of the old castle answer "Boom," which means "Many thanks."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In winter no ships sail by, for the whole Sound is covered with ice as far as the Swedish coast, and has quite the appearance of a high-road.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The Danish and the Swedish flags wave, and Danes and Swedes say, "Good-day," and "Thank you" to each other, not with cannons, but with a friendly shake of the hand; and they exchange white bread and biscuits with each other, because foreign articles taste the best.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the most beautiful sight of all is the old castle of Kronenburg, where Holger Danske sits in the deep, dark cellar, into which no one goes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He is clad in iron and steel, and rests his head on his strong arm; his long beard hangs down upon the marble table, into which it has become firmly rooted; he sleeps and dreams, but in his dreams he sees everything that happens in Denmark.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On each Christmas-eve an angel comes to him and tells him that all he has dreamed is true, and that he may go to sleep again in peace, as Denmark is not yet in any real danger; but should danger ever come, then Holger Danske will rouse himself, and the table will burst asunder as he draws out his beard.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he will come forth in his strength, and strike a blow that shall sound in all the countries of the world.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: An old grandfather sat and told his little grandson all this about Holger Danske, and the boy knew that what his grandfather told him must be true.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As the old man related this story, he was carving an image in wood to represent Holger Danske, to be fastened to the prow of a ship; for the old grandfather was a carver in wood, that is, one who carved figures for the heads of ships, according to the names given to them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And now he had carved Holger Danske, who stood there erect and proud, with his long beard, holding in one hand his broad battle-axe, while with the other he leaned on the Danish arms.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The old grandfather told the little boy a great deal about Danish men and women who had distinguished themselves in olden times, so that he fancied he knew as much even as Holger Danske himself, who, after all, could only dream; and when the little fellow went to bed, he thought so much about it that he actually pressed his chin against the counterpane, and imagined that he had a long beard which had become rooted to it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the old grandfather remained sitting at his work and carving away at the last part of it, which was the Danish arms.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And when he had finished he looked at the whole figure, and thought of all he had heard and read, and what he had that evening related to his little grandson.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he nodded his head, wiped his spectacles and put them on, and said, "Ah, yes; Holger Danske will not appear in my lifetime, but the boy who is in bed there may very likely live to see him when the event really comes to pass."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the old grandfather nodded again; and the more he looked at Holger Danske, the more satisfied he felt that he had carved a good image of him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It seemed to glow with the color of life; the armor glittered like iron and steel.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The hearts in the Danish arms grew more and more red; while the lions, with gold crowns on their heads, were leaping up.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That is the most beautiful coat of arms in the world, said the old man.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The lions represent strength; and the hearts, gentleness and love.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And as he gazed on the uppermost lion, he thought of King Canute, who chained great England to Denmark's throne; and he looked at the second lion, and thought of Waldemar, who untied Denmark and conquered the Vandals.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The third lion reminded him of Margaret, who united Denmark, Sweden, and Norway.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But when he gazed at the red hearts, their colors glowed more deeply, even as flames, and his memory followed each in turn.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The first led him to a dark, narrow prison, in which sat a prisoner, a beautiful woman, daughter of Christian the Fourth, Eleanor Ulfeld, and the flame became a rose on her bosom, and its blossoms were not more pure than the heart of this noblest and best of all Danish women.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ah, yes; that is indeed a noble heart in the Danish arms, said the grandfather. and his spirit followed the second flame, which carried him out to sea, where cannons roared and the ships lay shrouded in smoke, and the flaming heart attached itself to the breast of Hvitfeldt in the form of the ribbon of an order, as he blew himself and his ship into the air in order to save the fleet.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the third flame led him to Greenland's wretched huts, where the preacher, Hans Egede, ruled with love in every word and action.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The flame was as a star on his breast, and added another heart to the Danish arms.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And as the old grandfather's spirit followed the next hovering flame, he knew whither it would lead him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In a peasant woman's humble room stood Frederick the Sixth, writing his name with chalk on the beam.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The flame trembled on his breast and in his heart, and it was in the peasant's room that his heart became one for the Danish arms.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The old grandfather wiped his eyes, for he had known King Frederick, with his silvery locks and his honest blue eyes, and had lived for him, and he folded his hands and remained for some time silent.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then his daughter came to him and said it was getting late, that he ought to rest for a while, and that the supper was on the table.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What you have been carving is very beautiful, grandfather, said she.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Holger Danske and the old coat of arms; it seems to me as if I have seen the face somewhere.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No, that is impossible, replied the old grandfather; "but I have seen it, and I have tried to carve it in wood, as I have retained it in my memory.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a long time ago, while the English fleet lay in the roads, on the second of April, when we showed that we were true, ancient Danes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I was on board the Denmark, in Steene Bille's squadron; I had a man by my side whom even the cannon balls seemed to fear.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He sung old songs in a merry voice, and fired and fought as if he were something more than a man.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I still remember his face, but from whence he came, or whither he went, I know not; no one knows.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I have often thought it might have been Holger Danske himself, who had swam down to us from Kronenburg to help us in the hour of danger.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That was my idea, and there stands his likeness."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The wooden figure threw a gigantic shadow on the wall, and even on part of the ceiling; it seemed as if the real Holger Danske stood behind it, for the shadow moved; but this was no doubt caused by the flame of the lamp not burning steadily.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the daughter-in-law kissed the old grandfather, and led him to a large arm-chair by the table; and she, and her husband, who was the son of the old man and the father of the little boy who lay in bed, sat down to supper with him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the old grandfather talked of the Danish lions and the Danish hearts, emblems of strength and gentleness, and explained quite clearly that there is another strength than that which lies in a sword, and he pointed to a shelf where lay a number of old books, and amongst them a collection of Holberg's plays, which are much read and are so clever and amusing that it is easy to fancy we have known the people of those days, who are described in them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He knew how to fight also, said the old man; "for he lashed the follies and prejudices of people during his whole life."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the grandfather nodded to a place above the looking-glass, where hung an almanac, with a representation of the Round Tower upon it, and said "Tycho Brahe was another of those who used a sword, but not one to cut into the flesh and bone, but to make the way of the stars of heaven clear, and plain to be understood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then he whose father belonged to my calling,- yes, he, the son of the old image-carver, he whom we ourselves have seen, with his silvery locks and his broad shoulders, whose name is known in all lands;- yes, he was a sculptor, while I am only a carver.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Holger Danske can appear in marble, so that people in all countries of the world may hear of the strength of Denmark.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now let us drink the health of Bertel."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the little boy in bed saw plainly the old castle of Kronenburg, and the Sound of Elsinore, and Holger Danske, far down in the cellar, with his beard rooted to the table, and dreaming of everything that was passing above him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And Holger Danske did dream of the little humble room in which the image-carver sat; he heard all that had been said, and he nodded in his dream, saying, "Ah, yes, remember me, you Danish people, keep me in your memory, I will come to you in the hour of need."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bright morning light shone over Kronenburg, and the wind brought the sound of the hunting-horn across from the neighboring shores.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The ships sailed by and saluted the castle with the boom of the cannon, and Kronenburg returned the salute, "Boom, boom."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the roaring cannons did not awake Holger Danske, for they meant only "Good morning," and "Thank you."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They must fire in another fashion before he awakes; but wake he will, for there is energy yet in Holger Danske.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: IN the forest that extends from the banks of the Gudenau, in North Jutland, a long way into the country, and not far from the clear stream, rises a great ridge of land, which stretches through the wood like a wall.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Westward of this ridge, and not far from the river, stands a farmhouse, surrounded by such poor land that the sandy soil shows itself between the scanty ears of rye and wheat which grow in it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Some years have passed since the people who lived here cultivated these fields; they kept three sheep, a pig, and two oxen; in fact they maintained themselves very well, they had quite enough to live upon, as people generally have who are content with their lot.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They even could have afforded to keep two horses, but it was a saying among the farmers in those parts, "The horse eats himself up;" that is to say, he eats as much as he earns.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Jeppe Jans cultivated his fields in summer, and in the winter he made wooden shoes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He also had an assistant, a lad who understood as well as he himself did how to make wooden shoes strong, but light, and in the fashion.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They carved shoes and spoons, which paid well; therefore no one could justly call Jeppe Jans and his family poor people.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Little Ib, a boy of seven years old and the only child, would sit by, watching the workmen, or cutting a stick, and sometimes his finger instead of the stick.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But one day Ib succeeded so well in his carving that he made two pieces of wood look really like two little wooden shoes, and he determined to give them as a present to Little Christina.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And who was Little Christina?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was the boatman's daughter, graceful and delicate as the child of a gentleman; had she been dressed differently, no one would have believed that she lived in a hut on the neighboring heath with her father.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was a widower, and earned his living by carrying firewood in his large boat from the forest to the eel-pond and eel-weir, on the estate of Silkborg, and sometimes even to the distant town of Randers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There was no one under whose care he could leave Little Christina; so she was almost always with him in his boat, or playing in the wood among the blossoming heath, or picking the ripe wild berries.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Sometimes, when her father had to go as far as the town, he would take Little Christina, who was a year younger than Ib, across the heath to the cottage of Jeppe Jans, and leave her there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ib and Christina agreed together in everything; they divided their bread and berries when they were hungry; they were partners in digging their little gardens; they ran, and crept, and played about everywhere.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Once they wandered a long way into the forest, and even ventured together to climb the high ridge.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Another time they found a few snipes' eggs in the wood, which was a great event.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ib had never been on the heath where Christina's father lived, nor on the river; but at last came an opportunity.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Christina's father invited him to go for a sail in his boat; and the evening before, he accompanied the boatman across the heath to his house.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The next morning early, the two children were placed on the top of a high pile of firewood in the boat, and sat eating bread and wild strawberries, while Christina's father and his man drove the boat forward with poles.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They floated on swiftly, for the tide was in their favor, passing over lakes, formed by the stream in its course; sometimes they seemed quite enclosed by reeds and water-plants, yet there was always room for them to pass out, although the old trees overhung the water and the old oaks stretched out their bare branches, as if they had turned up their sleeves and wished to show their knotty, naked arms.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Old alder-trees, whose roots were loosened from the banks, clung with their fibres to the bottom of the stream, and the tops of the branches above the water looked like little woody islands.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The water-lilies waved themselves to and fro on the river, everything made the excursion beautiful, and at last they came to the great eel-weir, where the water rushed through the flood-gates; and the children thought this a beautiful sight.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In those days there was no factory nor any town house, nothing but the great farm, with its scanty-bearing fields, in which could be seen a few herd of cattle, and one or two farm laborers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The rushing of the water through the sluices, and the scream of the wild ducks, were almost the only signs of active life at Silkborg.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: After the firewood had been unloaded, Christina's father bought a whole bundle of eels and a sucking-pig, which were all placed in a basket in the stern of the boat.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they returned again up the stream; and as the wind was favorable, two sails were hoisted, which carried the boat on as well as if two horses had been harnessed to it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As they sailed on, they came by chance to the place where the boatman's assistant lived, at a little distance from the bank of the river.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The boat was moored; and the two men, after desiring the children to sit still, both went on shore. they obeyed this order for a very short time, and then forgot it altogether.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: First they peeped into the basket containing the eels and the sucking-pig; then they must needs pull out the pig and take it in their hands, and feel it, and touch it; and as they both wanted to hold it at the same time, the consequence was that they let it fall into the water, and the pig sailed away with the stream.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here was a terrible disaster.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ib jumped ashore, and ran a little distance from the boat.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, take me with you, cried Christina; and she sprang after him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In a few minutes they found themselves deep in a thicket, and could no longer see the boat or the shore.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They ran on a little farther, and then Christina fell down, and began to cry.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ib helped her up, and said, "Never mind; follow me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yonder is the house."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the house was not yonder; and they wandered still farther, over the dry rustling leaves of the last year, and treading on fallen branches that crackled under their little feet; then they heard a loud, piercing cry, and they stood still to listen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Presently the scream of an eagle sounded through the wood; it was an ugly cry, and it frightened the children; but before them, in the thickest part of the forest, grew the most beautiful blackberries, in wonderful quantities.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They looked so inviting that the children could not help stopping; and they remained there so long eating, that their mouths and cheeks became quite black with the juice.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Presently they heard the frightful scream again, and Christina said, "We shall get into trouble about that pig."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, never mind, said Ib; "we will go home to my father's house.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is here in the wood."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So they went on, but the road led them out of the way; no house could be seen, it grew dark, and the children were afraid.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The solemn stillness that reigned around them was now and then broken by the shrill cries of the great horned owl and other birds that they knew nothing of.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At last they both lost themselves in the thicket; Christina began to cry, and then Ib cried too; and, after weeping and lamenting for some time, they stretched themselves down on the dry leaves and fell asleep.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sun was high in the heavens when the two children woke.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They felt cold; but not far from their resting-place, on a hill, the sun was shining through the trees.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They thought if they went there they should be warm, and Ib fancied he should be able to see his father's house from such a high spot.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But they were far away from home now, in quite another part of the forest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They clambered to the top of the rising ground, and found themselves on the edge of a declivity, which sloped down to a clear transparent lake.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Great quantities of fish could be seen through the clear water, sparkling in the sun's rays; they were quite surprised when they came so suddenly upon such an unexpected sight.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Close to where they stood grew a hazel-bush, covered with beautiful nuts.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They soon gathered some, cracked them, and ate the fine young kernels, which were only just ripe.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But there was another surprise and fright in store for them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Out of the thicket stepped a tall old woman, her face quite brown, and her hair of a deep shining black; the whites of her eyes glittered like a Moor's; on her back she carried a bundle, and in her hand a knotted stick.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was a gypsy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The children did not at first understand what she said.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She drew out of her pocket three large nuts, in which she told them were hidden the most beautiful and lovely things in the world, for they were wishing nuts.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ib looked at her, and as she spoke so kindly, he took courage, and asked her if she would give him the nuts; and the woman gave them to him, and then gathered some more from the bushes for herself, quite a pocket full.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ib and Christina looked at the wishing nuts with wide open eyes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Is there in this nut a carriage, with a pair of horses? asked Ib.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, there is a golden carriage, with two golden horses, replied the woman.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then give me that nut, said Christina; so Ib gave it to her, and the strange woman tied up the nut for her in her handkerchief.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ib held up another nut.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Is there, in this nut, a pretty little neckerchief like the one Christina has on her neck? asked Ib.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There are ten neckerchiefs in it, she replied, "as well as beautiful dresses, stockings, and a hat and veil."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then I will have that one also, said Christina; "and it is a pretty one too.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then Ib gave her the second nut.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The third was a little black thing.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You may keep that one, said Christina; "it is quite as pretty."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What is in it? asked Ib.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The best of all things for you, replied the gypsy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So Ib held the nut very tight.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the woman promised to lead the children to the right path, that they might find their way home: and they went forward certainly in quite another direction to the one they meant to take; therefore no one ought to speak against the woman, and say that she wanted to steal the children.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the wild wood-path they met a forester who knew Ib, and, by his help, Ib and Christina reached home, where they found every one had been very anxious about them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were pardoned and forgiven, although they really had both done wrong, and deserved to get into trouble; first, because they had let the sucking-pig fall into the water; and, secondly, because they had run away.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Christina was taken back to her father's house on the heath, and Ib remained in the farm-house on the borders of the wood, near the great land ridge.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The first thing Ib did that evening was to take out of his pocket the little black nut, in which the best thing of all was said to be enclosed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He laid it carefully between the door and the door-post, and then shut the door so that the nut cracked directly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But there was not much kernel to be seen; it was what we should call hollow or worm-eaten, and looked as if it had been filled with tobacco or rich black earth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is just what I expected! exclaimed Ib.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
How should there be room in a little nut like this for the best thing of all?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Winter came; and the new year, and indeed many years passed away; until Ib was old enough to be confirmed, and, therefore, he went during a whole winter to the clergyman of the nearest village to be prepared.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One day, about this time, the boatman paid a visit to Ib's parents, and told them that Christina was going to service, and that she had been remarkably fortunate in obtaining a good place, with most respectable people.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Only think, he said, "She is going to the rich innkeeper's, at the hotel in Herning, many miles west from here.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She is to assist the landlady in the housekeeping; and, if afterwards she behaves well and remains to be confirmed, the people will treat her as their own daughter."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So Ib and Christina took leave of each other.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: People already called them "the betrothed," and at parting the girl showed Ib the two nuts, which she had taken care of ever since the time that they lost themselves in the wood; and she told him also that the little wooden shoes he once carved for her when he was a boy, and gave her as a present, had been carefully kept in a drawer ever since.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And so they parted.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: After Ib's confirmation, he remained at home with his mother, for he had become a clever shoemaker, and in summer managed the farm for her quite alone.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His father had been dead some time, and his mother kept no farm servants.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Sometimes, but very seldom, he heard of Christina, through a postillion or eel-seller who was passing.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But she was well off with the rich innkeeper; and after being confirmed she wrote a letter to her father, in which was a kind message to Ib and his mother.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In this letter, she mentioned that her master and mistress had made her a present of a beautiful new dress, and some nice under-clothes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This was, of course, pleasant news.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One day, in the following spring, there came a knock at the door of the house where Ib's old mother lived; and when they opened it, lo and behold, in stepped the boatman and Christina.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She had come to pay them a visit, and to spend the day.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A carriage had to come from the Herning hotel to the next village, and she had taken the opportunity to see her friends once more.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She looked as elegant as a real lady, and wore a pretty dress, beautifully made on purpose for her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There she stood, in full dress, while Ib wore only his working clothes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He could not utter a word; he could only seize her hand and hold it fast in his own, but he felt too happy and glad to open his lips.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Christina, however, was quite at her ease; she talked and talked, and kissed him in the most friendly manner.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Even afterwards, when they were left alone, and she asked, "Did you know me again, Ib?" he still stood holding her hand, and said at last, "You are become quite a grand lady, Christina, and I am only a rough working man; but I have often thought of you and of old times."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they wandered up the great ridge, and looked across the stream to the heath, where the little hills were covered with the flowering broom.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ib said nothing; but before the time came for them to part, it became quite clear to him that Christina must be his wife: had they not even in childhood been called the betrothed?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: To him it seemed as if they were really engaged to each other, although not a word had been spoken on the subject.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They had only a few more hours to remain together, for Christina was obliged to return that evening to the neighboring village, to be ready for the carriage which was to start the next morning early for Herning.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ib and her father accompanied her to the village.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a fine moonlight evening; and when they arrived, Ib stood holding Christina's hand in his, as if he could not let her go.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His eyes brightened, and the words he uttered came with hesitation from his lips, but from the deepest recesses of his heart: "Christina, if you have not become too grand, and if you can be contented to live in my mother's house as my wife, we will be married some day.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But we can wait for a while."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh yes, she replied; "Let us wait a little longer, Ib.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I can trust you, for I believe that I do love you.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But let me think it over."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he kissed her lips; and so they parted.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On the way home, Ib told the boatman that he and Christina were as good as engaged to each other; and the boatman found out that he had always expected it would be so, and went home with Ib that evening, and remained the night in the farmhouse; but nothing further was said of the engagement.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: During the next year, two letters passed between Ib and Christina.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were signed, "Faithful till death;" but at the end of that time, one day the boatman came over to see Ib, with a kind greeting from Christina.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had something else to say, which made him hesitate in a strange manner.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At last it came out that Christina, who had grown a very pretty girl, was more lucky than ever.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was courted and admired by every one; but her master's son, who had been home on a visit, was so much pleased with Christina that he wished to marry her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had a very good situation in an office at Copenhagen, and as she had also taken a liking for him, his parents were not unwilling to consent.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But Christina, in her heart, often thought of Ib, and knew how much he thought of her; so she felt inclined to refuse this good fortune, added the boatman.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At first Ib said not a word, but he became as white as the wall, and shook his head gently, and then he spoke,- "Christina must not refuse this good fortune."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then will you write a few words to her? said the boatman.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ib sat down to write, but he could not get on at all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The words were not what he wished to say, so he tore up the page.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The following morning, however, a letter lay ready to be sent to Christina, and the following is what he wrote:- "The letter written by you to your father I have read, and see from it that you are prosperous in everything, and that still better fortune is in store for you.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ask your own heart, Christina, and think over carefully what awaits you if you take me for your husband, for I possess very little in the world.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Do not think of me or of my position; think only of your own welfare.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You are bound to me by no promises; and if in your heart you have given me one, I release you from it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: May every blessing and happiness be poured out upon you, Christina.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Heaven will give me the heart's consolation.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ever your sincere friend, IB."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This letter was sent, and Christina received it in due time.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the course of the following November, her banns were published in the church on the heath, and also in Copenhagen, where the bridegroom lived.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was taken to Copenhagen under the protection of her future mother-in-law, because the bridegroom could not spare time from his numerous occupations for a journey so far into Jutland.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On the journey, Christina met her father at one of the villages through which they passed, and here he took leave of her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Very little was said about the matter to Ib, and he did not refer to it; his mother, however, noticed that he had grown very silent and pensive.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thinking as he did of old times, no wonder the three nuts came into his mind which the gypsy woman had given him when a child, and of the two which he had given to Christina.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: These wishing nuts, after all, had proved true fortune-tellers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One had contained a gilded carriage and noble horses, and the other beautiful clothes; all of these Christina would now have in her new home at Copenhagen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her part had come true.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And for him the nut had contained only black earth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The gypsy woman had said it was the best for him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Perhaps it was, and this also would be fulfilled.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He understood the gypsy woman's meaning now.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The black earth- the dark grave- was the best thing for him now.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Again years passed away; not many, but they seemed long years to Ib.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The old innkeeper and his wife died one after the other; and the whole of their property, many thousand dollars, was inherited by their son.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Christina could have the golden carriage now, and plenty of fine clothes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: During the two long years which followed, no letter came from Christina to her father; and when at last her father received one from her, it did not speak of prosperity or happiness.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Poor Christina!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Neither she nor her husband understood how to economize or save, and the riches brought no blessing with them, because they had not asked for it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Years passed; and for many summers the heath was covered with bloom; in winter the snow rested upon it, and the rough winds blew across the ridge under which stood Ib's sheltered home.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One spring day the sun shone brightly, and he was guiding the plough across his field.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The ploughshare struck against something which he fancied was a firestone, and then he saw glittering in the earth a splinter of shining metal which the plough had cut from something which gleamed brightly in the furrow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He searched, and found a large golden armlet of superior workmanship, and it was evident that the plough had disturbed a Hun's grave.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He searched further, and found more valuable treasures, which Ib showed to the clergyman, who explained their value to him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he went to the magistrate, who informed the president of the museum of the discovery, and advised Ib to take the treasures himself to the president.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You have found in the earth the best thing you could find, said the magistrate.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The best thing, thought Ib; "the very best thing for me,- and found in the earth!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Well, if it really is so, then the gypsy woman was right in her prophecy."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So Ib went in the ferry-boat from Aarhus to Copenhagen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: To him who had only sailed once or twice on the river near his own home, this seemed like a voyage on the ocean; and at length he arrived at Copenhagen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The value of the gold he had found was paid to him; it was a large sum- six hundred dollars.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then Ib of the heath went out, and wandered about in the great city.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On the evening before the day he had settled to return with the captain of the passage-boat, Ib lost himself in the streets, and took quite a different turning to the one he wished to follow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He wandered on till he found himself in a poor street of the suburb called Christian's Haven.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Not a creature could be seen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At last a very little girl came out of one of the wretched-looking houses, and Ib asked her to tell him the way to the street he wanted; she looked up timidly at him, and began to cry bitterly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He asked her what was the matter; but what she said he could not understand.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So he went along the street with her; and as they passed under a lamp, the light fell on the little girl's face.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A strange sensation came over Ib, as he caught sight of it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The living, breathing embodiment of Little Christina stood before him, just as he remembered her in the days of her childhood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He followed the child to the wretched house, and ascended the narrow, crazy staircase which led to a little garret in the roof.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The air in the room was heavy and stifling, no light was burning, and from one corner came sounds of moaning and sighing.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was the mother of the child who lay there on a miserable bed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: With the help of a match, Ib struck a light, and approached her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Can I be of any service to you? he asked.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
This little girl brought me up here; but I am a stranger in this city.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he raised the head of the sick woman, and smoothed her pillow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He started as he did so.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was Christina of the heath!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No one had mentioned her name to Ib for years; it would have disturbed his peace of mind, especially as the reports respecting her were not good.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The wealth which her husband had inherited from his parents had made him proud and arrogant.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had given up his certain appointment, and travelled for six months in foreign lands, and, on his return, had lived in great style, and got into terrible debt.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

sentence: The cold hand of death had already touched the heart of Christina.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her youngest child, looked for in the midst of prosperity, had sunk into the grave when only a few weeks old; and at last Christina herself became sick unto death, and lay, forsaken and dying, in a miserable room, amid poverty she might have borne in her younger days, but which was now more painful to her from the luxuries to which she had lately been accustomed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the forest by the river Gudenau, not far from the heath, and beneath the ridge of land, stood the little farm, newly painted and whitewashed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The air was heavy and dark; there were no blossoms on the heath; the autumn winds whirled the yellow leaves towards the boatman's hut, in which strangers dwelt; but the little farm stood safely sheltered beneath the tall trees and the high ridge.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The turf blazed brightly on the hearth, and within was sunlight, the sparkling light from the sunny eyes of a child; the birdlike tones from the rosy lips ringing like the song of a lark in spring.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All was life and joy.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ib's house was well and prettily furnished; for he was a prosperous man now, while the mother of the little girl rested in the churchyard at Copenhagen, where she had died in poverty.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ib had money now- money which had come to him out of the black earth; and he had Christina for his own, after all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THE Flea, the Grasshopper, and the Skipjack once wanted to see which of them could jump highest; and they invited the whole world, and whoever else would come, to see the grand sight.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And there the three famous jumpers were met together in the room.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, I'll give my daughter to him who jumps highest, said the King, "for it would be mean to let these people jump for nothing."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The Flea stepped out first.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had very pretty manners, and bowed in all directions, for he had young ladies' blood in his veins, and was accustomed to consort only with human beings; and that was of great consequence.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then came the Grasshopper: he was certainly much heavier, but he had a good figure, and wore the green uniform that was born with him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This person, moreover, maintained that he belonged to a very old family in the land of Egypt, and that he was highly esteemed there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had just come from the field, he said, and had been put into a card house three stories high, and all made of picture cards with the figures turned inwards.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There were doors and windows in the house, cut in the body of the Queen of Hearts.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I sing so, he said, "that sixteen native crickets who have chirped from their youth up, and have never yet had a card house of their own, would become thinner than they are with envy if they were to hear me."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Both of them, the Flea and the Grasshopper, took care to announce who they were, and that they considered themselves entitled to marry a Princess.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The Skipjack said nothing, but it was said of him that he thought all the more; and directly the Yard Dog had smelt at him he was ready to assert that the Skipjack was of good family, and formed from the breastbone of an undoubted goose.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The old councillor, who had received three medals for holding his tongue, declared that the Skipjack possessed the gift of prophecy; one could tell by his bones whether there would be a severe winter or a mild one; and that's more than one can always tell from the breastbone of the man who writes the almanac.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I shall not say anything more, said the old King.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I only go on quietly, and always think the best.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now they were to take their jump.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The Flea sprang so high that no one could see him; and then they asserted that he had not jumped at all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That was very mean.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The Grasshopper only sprang half as high, but he sprang straight into the King's face, and the King declared that was horribly rude.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The Skipjack stood a long time considering; at last people thought that he could not jump at all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I only hope he's not become unwell, said the Yard Dog, and then he smelt at him again.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Tap! he sprang with a little crooked jump just into the lap of the Princess, who sat on a low golden stool.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the King said, "The highest leap was taken by him who jumped up to my daughter; for therein lies the point; but it requires head to achieve that, and the Skipjack has shown that he has a head."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And so he had the Princess.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I jumped highest, after all, said the Flea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:

author: HCAndersen
sentence: IN the forest, high up on the steep shore, and not far from the open seacoast, stood a very old oak-tree.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was just three hundred and sixty-five years old, but that long time was to the tree as the same number of days might be to us; we wake by day and sleep by night, and then we have our dreams.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is different with the tree; it is obliged to keep awake through three seasons of the year, and does not get any sleep till winter comes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Winter is its time for rest; its night after the long day of spring, summer, and autumn.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On many a warm summer, the Ephemera, the flies that exist for only a day, had fluttered about the old oak, enjoyed life and felt happy and if, for a moment, one of the tiny creatures rested on one of his large fresh leaves, the tree would always say, "Poor little creature! your whole life consists only of a single day.

sentence: How very short.

sentence: Melancholy! what do you mean? the little creature would always reply.

sentence: Everything around me is so wonderfully bright and warm, and beautiful, that it makes me joyous.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But only for one day, and then it is all over.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Are you all over too?"

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And there stood the oak, stripped of all its leaves, left to rest during the whole of a long winter, and to dream many dreams of events that had happened in its life, as in the dreams of men.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The great tree had once been small; indeed, in its cradle it had been an acorn.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: According to human computation, it was now in the fourth century of its existence.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was the largest and best tree in the forest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Its summit towered above all the other trees, and could be seen far out at sea, so that it served as a landmark to the sailors.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It had no idea how many eyes looked eagerly for it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In its topmost branches the wood-pigeon built her nest, and the cuckoo carried out his usual vocal performances, and his well-known notes echoed amid the boughs; and in autumn, when the leaves looked like beaten copper plates, the birds of passage would come and rest upon the branches before taking their flight across the sea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But now it was winter, the tree stood leafless, so that every one could see how crooked and bent were the branches that sprang forth from the trunk.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Crows and rooks came by turns and sat on them, and talked of the hard times which were beginning, and how difficult it was in winter to obtain food.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was just about holy Christmas time that the tree dreamed a dream.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The tree had, doubtless, a kind of feeling that the festive time had arrived, and in his dream fancied he heard the bells ringing from all the churches round, and yet it seemed to him to be a beautiful summer's day, mild and warm.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His mighty summits was crowned with spreading fresh green foliage; the sunbeams played among the leaves and branches, and the air was full of fragrance from herb and blossom; painted butterflies chased each other; the summer flies danced around him, as if the world had been created merely for them to dance and be merry in.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All that had happened to the tree during every year of his life seemed to pass before him, as in a festive procession.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He saw the knights of olden times and noble ladies ride by through the wood on their gallant steeds, with plumes waving in their hats, and falcons on their wrists.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The hunting horn sounded, and the dogs barked.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He saw hostile warriors, in colored dresses and glittering armor, with spear and halberd, pitching their tents, and anon striking them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The watchfires again blazed, and men sang and slept under the hospitable shelter of the tree.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He saw lovers meet in quiet happiness near him in the moonshine, and carve the initials of their names in the grayish-green bark on his trunk.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Once, but long years had intervened since then, guitars and Eolian harps had been hung on his boughs by merry travellers; now they seemed to hang there again, and he could hear their marvellous tones.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The wood-pigeons cooed as if to explain the feelings of the tree, and the cuckoo called out to tell him how many summer days he had yet to live.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then it seemed as if new life was thrilling through every fibre of root and stem and leaf, rising even to the highest branches.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The tree felt itself stretching and spreading out, while through the root beneath the earth ran the warm vigor of life.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As he grew higher and still higher, with increased strength, his topmost boughs became broader and fuller; and in proportion to his growth, so was his self-satisfaction increased, and with it arose a joyous longing to grow higher and higher, to reach even to the warm, bright sun itself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Already had his topmost branches pierced the clouds, which floated beneath them like troops of birds of passage, or large white swans; every leaf seemed gifted with sight, as if it possessed eyes to see.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The stars became visible in broad daylight, large and sparkling, like clear and gentle eyes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They recalled to the memory the well-known look in the eyes of a child, or in the eyes of lovers who had once met beneath the branches of the old oak.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: These were wonderful and happy moments for the old tree, full of peace and joy; and yet, amidst all this happiness, the tree felt a yearning, longing desire that all the other trees, bushes, herbs, and flowers beneath him, might be able also to rise higher, as he had done, and to see all this splendor, and experience the same happiness.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And this feeling of yearning trembled through every branch, through every leaf, as warmly and fervently as if they had been the fibres of a human heart.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The summit of the tree waved to and fro, and bent downwards as if in his silent longing he sought for something.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then there came to him the fragrance of thyme, followed by the more powerful scent of honeysuckle and violets; and he fancied he heard the note of the cuckoo.

author: HCAndersen

sentence: Up through the clouds came the green summits of the forest trees, and beneath him, the oak saw them rising, and growing higher and higher.

sentence: IN a village there once lived two men who had the same name.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were both called Claus.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One of them had four horses, but the other had only one; so to distinguish them, people called the owner of the four horses, "Great Claus," and he who had only one, "Little Claus."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now we shall hear what happened to them, for this is a true story.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Through the whole week, Little Claus was obliged to plough for Great Claus, and lend him his one horse; and once a week, on a Sunday, Great Claus lent him all his four horses.

author: HCAndersen

sentence: Do you remember what the flowers told you to say to me? said little Ida.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then she took a little paper box, on which were painted beautiful birds, and laid the dead flowers in it.

author: HCAndersen
