author: HCAndersen
sentence: IT was terribly cold and nearly dark on the last evening of the old year, and the snow was falling fast.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the cold and the darkness, a poor little girl, with bare head and naked feet, roamed through the streets.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is true she had on a pair of slippers when she left home, but they were not of much use.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were very large, so large, indeed, that they had belonged to her mother, and the poor little creature had lost them in running across the street to avoid two carriages that were rolling along at a terrible rate.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One of the slippers she could not find, and a boy seized upon the other and ran away with it, saying that he could use it as a cradle, when he had children of his own.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So the little girl went on with her little naked feet, which were quite red and blue with the cold.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In an old apron she carried a number of matches, and had a bundle of them in her hands.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No one had bought anything of her the whole day, nor had any one given here even a penny.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Shivering with cold and hunger, she crept along; poor little child, she looked the picture of misery.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The snowflakes fell on her long, fair hair, which hung in curls on her shoulders, but she regarded them not.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Lights were shining from every window, and there was a savory smell of roast goose, for it was New-year's eve- yes, she remembered that.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In a corner, between two houses, one of which projected beyond the other, she sank down and huddled herself together.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She had drawn her little feet under her, but she could not keep off the cold; and she dared not go home, for she had sold no matches, and could not take home even a penny of money.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her father would certainly beat her; besides, it was almost as cold at home as here, for they had only the roof to cover them, through which the wind howled, although the largest holes had been stopped up with straw and rags.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her little hands were almost frozen with the cold.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ah! perhaps a burning match might be some good, if she could draw it from the bundle and strike it against the wall, just to warm her fingers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She drew one out-"scratch!" how it sputtered as it burnt!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It gave a warm, bright light, like a little candle, as she held her hand over it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was really a wonderful light.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It seemed to the little girl that she was sitting by a large iron stove, with polished brass feet and a brass ornament.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How the fire burned! and seemed so beautifully warm that the child stretched out her feet as if to warm them, when, lo! the flame of the match went out, the stove vanished, and she had only the remains of the half-burnt match in her hand.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She rubbed another match on the wall.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It burst into a flame, and where its light fell upon the wall it became as transparent as a veil, and she could see into the room.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The table was covered with a snowy white table-cloth, on which stood a splendid dinner service, and a steaming roast goose, stuffed with apples and dried plums.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And what was still more wonderful, the goose jumped down from the dish and waddled across the floor, with a knife and fork in its breast, to the little girl.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the match went out, and there remained nothing but the thick, damp, cold wall before her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She lighted another match, and then she found herself sitting under a beautiful Christmas-tree.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was larger and more beautifully decorated than the one which she had seen through the glass door at the rich merchant's.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thousands of tapers were burning upon the green branches, and colored pictures, like those she had seen in the show-windows, looked down upon it all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The little one stretched out her hand towards them, and the match went out.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The Christmas lights rose higher and higher, till they looked to her like the stars in the sky.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then she saw a star fall, leaving behind it a bright streak of fire.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Some one is dying, thought the little girl, for her old grandmother, the only one who had ever loved her, and who was now dead, had told her that when a star falls, a soul was going up to God.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She again rubbed a match on the wall, and the light shone round her; in the brightness stood her old grandmother, clear and shining, yet mild and loving in her appearance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Grandmother, cried the little one, "O take me with you; I know you will go away when the match burns out; you will vanish like the warm stove, the roast goose, and the large, glorious Christmas-tree."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And she made haste to light the whole bundle of matches, for she wished to keep her grandmother there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the matches glowed with a light that was brighter than the noon-day, and her grandmother had never appeared so large or so beautiful.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She took the little girl in her arms, and they both flew upwards in brightness and joy far above the earth, where there was neither cold nor hunger nor pain, for they were with God.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the dawn of morning there lay the poor little one, with pale cheeks and smiling mouth, leaning against the wall; she had been frozen to death on the last evening of the year; and the New-year's sun rose and shone upon a little corpse!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The child still sat, in the stiffness of death, holding the matches in her hand, one bundle of which was burnt.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She tried to warm herself, said some.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No one imagined what beautiful things she had seen, nor into what glory she had entered with her grandmother, on New-year's day.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THERE was once a woman who wished very much to have a little child, but she could not obtain her wish.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At last she went to a fairy, and said, "I should so very much like to have a little child; can you tell me where I can find one?"

sentence: Oh, that can be easily managed, said the fairy.

sentence: Here is a barleycorn of a different kind to those which grow in the farmer's fields, and which the chickens eat; put it into a flower-pot, and see what will happen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thank you, said the woman, and she gave the fairy twelve shillings, which was the price of the barleycorn.

sentence: Within the flower, upon the green velvet stamens, sat a very delicate and graceful little maiden.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Tweet, tweet, sounded over her head suddenly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She looked up, and there was the swallow himself flying close by.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As soon as he spied Tiny, he was delighted; and then she told him how unwilling she felt to marry the ugly mole, and to live always beneath the earth, and never to see the bright sun any more.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And as she told him she wept.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Cold winter is coming, said the swallow, "and I am going to fly away into warmer countries.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Will you go with me?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You can sit on my back, and fasten yourself on with your sash.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then we can fly away from the ugly mole and his gloomy rooms,- far away, over the mountains, into warmer countries, where the sun shines more brightly- than here; where it is always summer, and the flowers bloom in greater beauty.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Fly now with me, dear little Tiny; you saved my life when I lay frozen in that dark passage."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, I will go with you, said Tiny; and she seated herself on the bird's back, with her feet on his outstretched wings, and tied her girdle to one of his strongest feathers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the swallow rose in the air, and flew over forest and over sea, high above the highest mountains, covered with eternal snow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Tiny would have been frozen in the cold air, but she crept under the bird's warm feathers, keeping her little head uncovered, so that she might admire the beautiful lands over which they passed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At length they reached the warm countries, where the sun shines brightly, and the sky seems so much higher above the earth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here, on the hedges, and by the wayside, grew purple, green, and white grapes; lemons and oranges hung from trees in the woods; and the air was fragrant with myrtles and orange blossoms.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Beautiful children ran along the country lanes, playing with large gay butterflies; and as the swallow flew farther and farther, every place appeared still more lovely.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At last they came to a blue lake, and by the side of it, shaded by trees of the deepest green, stood a palace of dazzling white marble, built in the olden times.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Vines clustered round its lofty pillars, and at the top were many swallows' nests, and one of these was the home of the swallow who carried Tiny.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This is my house, said the swallow; "but it would not do for you to live there- you would not be comfortable.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You must choose for yourself one of those lovely flowers, and I will put you down upon it, and then you shall have everything that you can wish to make you happy."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That will be delightful, she said, and clapped her little hands for joy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A large marble pillar lay on the ground, which, in falling, had been broken into three pieces.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Between these pieces grew the most beautiful large white flowers; so the swallow flew down with Tiny, and placed her on one of the broad leaves.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But how surprised she was to see in the middle of the flower, a tiny little man, as white and transparent as if he had been made of crystal!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had a gold crown on his head, and delicate wings at his shoulders, and was not much larger than Tiny herself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was the angel of the flower; for a tiny man and a tiny woman dwell in every flower; and this was the king of them all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, how beautiful he is! whispered Tiny to the swallow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The little prince was at first quite frightened at the bird, who was like a giant, compared to such a delicate little creature as himself; but when he saw Tiny, he was delighted, and thought her the prettiest little maiden he had ever seen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He took the gold crown from his head, and placed it on hers, and asked her name, and if she would be his wife, and queen over all the flowers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This certainly was a very different sort of husband to the son of a toad, or the mole, with my black velvet and fur; so she said, "Yes," to the handsome prince.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then all the flowers opened, and out of each came a little lady or a tiny lord, all so pretty it was quite a pleasure to look at them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Each of them brought Tiny a present; but the best gift was a pair of beautiful wings, which had belonged to a large white fly and they fastened them to Tiny's shoulders, so that she might fly from flower to flower.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then there was much rejoicing, and the little swallow who sat above them, in his nest, was asked to sing a wedding song, which he did as well as he could; but in his heart he felt sad for he was very fond of Tiny, and would have liked never to part from her again.

sentence: After her a man came out of the coach, who is a painter; he is the great master of colors, and is named SEPTEMBER.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The forest, on his arrival, had to change its colors when he wished it; and how beautiful are the colors he chooses!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The woods glow with hues of red and gold and brown.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This great master painter could whistle like a blackbird.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was quick in his work, and soon entwined the tendrils of the hop plant around his beer jug.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This was an ornament to the jug, and he has a great love for ornament.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There he stood with his color pot in his hand, and that was the whole of his luggage.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A land-owner followed, who in the month for sowing seed attended to the ploughing and was fond of field sports.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Squire OCTOBER brought his dog and his gun with him, and had nuts in his game bag.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Crack, crack.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had a great deal of luggage, even an English plough.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He spoke of farming, but what he said could scarcely be heard for the coughing and gasping of his neighbor.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was NOVEMBER, who coughed violently as he got out.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had a cold, which caused him to use his pocket-handkerchief continually; and yet he said he was obliged to accompany servant girls to their new places, and initiate them into their winter service.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He said he thought his cold would never leave him when he went out woodcutting, for he was a master sawyer, and had to supply wood to the whole parish.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He spent his evenings preparing wooden soles for skates, for he knew, he said, that in a few weeks these shoes would be wanted for the amusement of skating.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At length the last passenger made her appearance,- old Mother DECEMBER, with her fire-stool.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The dame was very old, but her eyes glistened like two stars.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She carried on her arm a flower-pot, in which a little fir-tree was growing.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This tree I shall guard and cherish, she said, "that it may grow large by Christmas Eve, and reach from the ground to the ceiling, to be covered and adorned with flaming candles, golden apples, and little figures.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The fire-stool will be as warm as a stove, and I shall then bring a story book out of my pocket, and read aloud till all the children in the room are quite quiet.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the little figures on the tree will become lively, and the little waxen angel at the top spread out his wings of gold-leaf, and fly down from his green perch.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He will kiss every one in the room, great and small; yes, even the poor children who stand in the passage, or out in the street singing a carol about the 'Star of Bethlehem.'"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Well, now the coach may drive away, said the sentry; "we have the whole twelve.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Let the horses be put up."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: First, let all the twelve come to me, said the captain on duty, "one after another.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The passports I will keep here.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Each of them is available for one month; when that has passed, I shall write the behavior of each on his passport.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Mr. JANUARY, have the goodness to come here."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And Mr. January stepped forward.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When a year has passed, I think I shall be able to tell you what the twelve passengers have brought to you, to me, and to all of us.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now I do not know, and probably even they don't know themselves, for we live in strange times.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: IN the city of Florence, not far from the Piazza del Granduca, runs a little street called Porta Rosa.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In this street, just in front of the market-place where vegetables are sold, stands a pig, made of brass and curiously formed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bright color has been changed by age to dark green; but clear, fresh water pours from the snout, which shines as if it had been polished, and so indeed it has, for hundreds of poor people and children seize it in their hands as they place their mouths close to the mouth of the animal, to drink.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is quite a picture to see a half-naked boy clasping the well-formed creature by the head, as he presses his rosy lips against its jaws.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Every one who visits Florence can very quickly find the place; he has only to ask the first beggar he meets for the Metal Pig, and he will be told where it is.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was late on a winter evening; the mountains were covered with snow, but the moon shone brightly, and moonlight in Italy is like a dull winter's day in the north; indeed it is better, for clear air seems to raise us above the earth, while in the north a cold, gray, leaden sky appears to press us down to earth, even as the cold damp earth shall one day press on us in the grave.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the garden of the grand duke's palace, under the roof of one of the wings, where a thousand roses bloom in winter, a little ragged boy had been sitting the whole day long; a boy, who might serve as a type of Italy, lovely and smiling, and yet still suffering.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was hungry and thirsty, yet no one gave him anything; and when it became dark, and they were about to close the gardens, the porter turned him out.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He stood a long time musing on the bridge which crosses the Arno, and looking at the glittering stars, reflected in the water which flowed between him and the elegant marble bridge Della Trinita.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He then walked away towards the Metal Pig, half knelt down, clasped it with his arms, and then put his mouth to the shining snout and drank deep draughts of the fresh water.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Close by, lay a few salad-leaves and two chestnuts, which were to serve for his supper.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No one was in the street but himself; it belonged only to him, so he boldly seated himself on the pig's back, leaned forward so that his curly head could rest on the head of the animal, and, before he was aware, he fell asleep.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was midnight.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The Metal Pig raised himself gently, and the boy heard him say quite distinctly, "Hold tight, little boy, for I am going to run;" and away he started for a most wonderful ride.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: First, they arrived at the Piazza del Granduca, and the metal horse which bears the duke's statue, neighed aloud.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The painted coats-of-arms on the old council-house shone like transparent pictures, and Michael Angelo's David tossed his sling; it was as if everything had life.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The metallic groups of figures, among which were Perseus and the Rape of the Sabines, looked like living persons, and cries of terror sounded from them all across the noble square.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: By the Palazzo degli Uffizi, in the arcade, where the nobility assemble for the carnival, the Metal Pig stopped.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Hold fast, said the animal; "hold fast, for I am going up stairs."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The little boy said not a word; he was half pleased and half afraid.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They entered a long gallery, where the boy had been before.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The walls were resplendent with paintings; here stood statues and busts, all in a clear light as if it were day.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the grandest appeared when the door of a side room opened; the little boy could remember what beautiful things he had seen there, but to-night everything shone in its brightest colors.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here stood the figure of a beautiful woman, as beautifully sculptured as possible by one of the great masters.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her graceful limbs appeared to move; dolphins sprang at her feet, and immortality shone from her eyes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The world called her the Venus de' Medici.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: By her side were statues, in which the spirit of life breathed in stone; figures of men, one of whom whetted his sword, and was named the Grinder; wrestling gladiators formed another group, the sword had been sharpened for them, and they strove for the goddess of beauty.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The boy was dazzled by so much glitter; for the walls were gleaming with bright colors, all appeared living reality.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As they passed from hall to hall, beauty everywhere showed itself; and as the Metal Pig went step by step from one picture to the other, the little boy could see it all plainly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One glory eclipsed another; yet there was one picture that fixed itself on the little boy's memory, more especially because of the happy children it represented, for these the little boy had seen in daylight.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Many pass this picture by with indifference, and yet it contains a treasure of poetic feeling; it represents Christ descending into Hades.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They are not the lost whom the spectator sees, but the heathen of olden times.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The Florentine, Angiolo Bronzino, painted this picture; most beautiful is the expression on the face of the two children, who appear to have full confidence that they shall reach heaven at last.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They are embracing each other, and one little one stretches out his hand towards another who stands below him, and points to himself, as if he were saying, "I am going to heaven."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The older people stand as if uncertain, yet hopeful, and they bow in humble adoration to the Lord Jesus.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On this picture the boy's eyes rested longer than on any other: the Metal Pig stood still before it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A low sigh was heard.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Did it come from the picture or from the animal?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The boy raised his hands towards the smiling children, and then the Pig ran off with him through the open vestibule.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thank you, thank you, you beautiful animal, said the little boy, caressing the Metal Pig as it ran down the steps.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thanks to yourself also, replied the Metal Pig; "I have helped you and you have helped me, for it is only when I have an innocent child on my back that I receive the power to run.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes; as you see, I can even venture under the rays of the lamp, in front of the picture of the Madonna, but I may not enter the church; still from without, and while you are upon my back, I may look in through the open door.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Do not get down yet, for if you do, then I shall be lifeless, as you have seen me in the Porta Rosa."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I will stay with you, my dear creature, said the little boy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So then they went on at a rapid pace through the streets of Florence, till they came to the square before the church of Santa Croce.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The folding-doors flew open, and light streamed from the altar through the church into the deserted square.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A wonderful blaze of light streamed from one of the monuments in the left-side aisle, and a thousand moving stars seemed to form a glory round it; even the coat-of-arms on the tomb-stone shone, and a red ladder on a blue field gleamed like fire.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was the grave of Galileo.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The monument is unadorned, but the red ladder is an emblem of art, signifying that the way to glory leads up a shining ladder, on which the prophets of mind rise to heaven, like Elias of old.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the right aisle of the church every statue on the richly carved sarcophagi seemed endowed with life.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here stood Michael Angelo; there Dante, with the laurel wreath round his brow; Alfieri and Machiavelli; for here side by side rest the great men- the pride of Italy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The church itself is very beautiful, even more beautiful than the marble cathedral at Florence, though not so large.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It seemed as if the carved vestments stirred, and as if the marble figures they covered raised their heads higher, to gaze upon the brightly colored glowing altar where the white-robed boys swung the golden censers, amid music and song, while the strong fragrance of incense filled the church, and streamed forth into the square.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The boy stretched forth his hands towards the light, and at the same moment the Metal Pig started again so rapidly that he was obliged to cling tightly to him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The wind whistled in his ears, he heard the church door creak on its hinges as it closed, and it seemed to him as if he had lost his senses- then a cold shudder passed over him, and he awoke.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was morning; the Metal Pig stood in its old place on the Porta Rosa, and the boy found he had slipped nearly off its back.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Fear and trembling came upon him as he thought of his mother; she had sent him out the day before to get some money, he had not done so, and now he was hungry and thirsty.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Once more he clasped the neck of his metal horse, kissed its nose, and nodded farewell to it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he wandered away into one of the narrowest streets, where there was scarcely room for a loaded donkey to pass.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A great iron-bound door stood ajar; he passed through, and climbed up a brick staircase, with dirty walls and a rope for a balustrade, till he came to an open gallery hung with rags.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: From here a flight of steps led down to a court, where from a well water was drawn up by iron rollers to the different stories of the house, and where the water-buckets hung side by side.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Sometimes the roller and the bucket danced in the air, splashing the water all over the court.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Another broken-down staircase led from the gallery, and two Russian sailors running down it almost upset the poor boy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were coming from their nightly carousal.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A woman not very young, with an unpleasant face and a quantity of black hair, followed them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What have you brought home? she asked. when she saw the boy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Don't be angry, he pleaded; "I received nothing, I have nothing at all;" and he seized his mother's dress and would have kissed it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they went into a little room.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I need not describe it, but only say that there stood in it an earthen pot with handles, made for holding fire, which in Italy is called a marito.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This pot she took in her lap, warmed her fingers, and pushed the boy with her elbow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Certainly you must have some money, she said.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The boy began to cry, and then she struck him with her foot till he cried out louder.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Will you be quiet? or I'll break your screaming head; and she swung about the fire-pot which she held in her hand, while the boy crouched to the earth and screamed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then a neighbor came in, and she had also a marito under her arm.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Felicita, she said, "what are you doing to the child?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The child is mine, she answered; "I can murder him if I like, and you too, Giannina."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then she swung about the fire-pot.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The other woman lifted up hers to defend herself, and the two pots clashed together so violently that they were dashed to pieces, and fire and ashes flew about the room.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The boy rushed out at the sight, sped across the courtyard, and fled from the house.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The poor child ran till he was quite out of breath; at last he stopped at the church, the doors of which were opened to him the night before, and went in.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here everything was bright, and the boy knelt down by the first tomb on his right, the grave of Michael Angelo, and sobbed as if his heart would break.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: People came and went, mass was performed, but no one noticed the boy, excepting an elderly citizen, who stood still and looked at him for a moment, and then went away like the rest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Hunger and thirst overpowered the child, and he became quite faint and ill.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At last he crept into a corner behind the marble monuments, and went to sleep.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Towards evening he was awakened by a pull at his sleeve; he started up, and the same old citizen stood before him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Are you ill? where do you live? have you been here all day? were some of the questions asked by the old man.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: After hearing his answers, the old man took him home to a small house close by, in a back street.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They entered a glovemaker's shop, where a woman sat sewing busily.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A little white poodle, so closely shaven that his pink skin could plainly be seen, frisked about the room, and gambolled upon the boy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Innocent souls are soon intimate, said the woman, as she caressed both the boy and the dog.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: These good people gave the child food and drink, and said he should stay with them all night, and that the next day the old man, who was called Giuseppe, would go and speak to his mother.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A little homely bed was prepared for him, but to him who had so often slept on the hard stones it was a royal couch, and he slept sweetly and dreamed of the splendid pictures and of the Metal Pig.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Giuseppe went out the next morning, and the poor child was not glad to see him go, for he knew that the old man was gone to his mother, and that, perhaps, he would have to go back.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He wept at the thought, and then he played with the little, lively dog, and kissed it, while the old woman looked kindly at him to encourage him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And what news did Giuseppe bring back?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At first the boy could not hear, for he talked a great deal to his wife, and she nodded and stroked the boy's cheek.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then she said, "He is a good lad, he shall stay with us, he may become a clever glovemaker, like you.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Look what delicate fingers he has got; Madonna intended him for a glovemaker."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So the boy stayed with them, and the woman herself taught him to sew; and he ate well, and slept well, and became very merry.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But at last he began to tease Bellissima, as the little dog was called.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This made the woman angry, and she scolded him and threatened him, which made him very unhappy, and he went and sat in his own room full of sad thoughts.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This chamber looked upon the street, in which hung skins to dry, and there were thick iron bars across his window.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That night he lay awake, thinking of the Metal Pig; indeed, it was always in his thoughts.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Suddenly he fancied he heard feet outside going pit-a-pat.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He sprung out of bed and went to the window.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Could it be the Metal Pig?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But there was nothing to be seen; whatever he had heard had passed already.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Next morning, their neighbor, the artist, passed by, carrying a paint-box and a large roll of canvas.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Help the gentleman to carry his box of colors, said the woman to the boy; and he obeyed instantly, took the box, and followed the painter.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They walked on till they reached the picture gallery, and mounted the same staircase up which he had ridden that night on the Metal Pig.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He remembered all the statues and pictures, the beautiful marble Venus, and again he looked at the Madonna with the Saviour and St. John.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They stopped before the picture by Bronzino, in which Christ is represented as standing in the lower world, with the children smiling before Him, in the sweet expectation of entering heaven; and the poor boy smiled, too, for here was his heaven.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You may go home now, said the painter, while the boy stood watching him, till he had set up his easel.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: May I see you paint? asked the boy; "may I see you put the picture on this white canvas?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am not going to paint yet, replied the artist; then he brought out a piece of chalk.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His hand moved quickly, and his eye measured the great picture; and though nothing appeared but a faint line, the figure of the Saviour was as clearly visible as in the colored picture.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Why don't you go? said the painter.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the boy wandered home silently, and seated himself on the table, and learned to sew gloves.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But all day long his thoughts were in the picture gallery; and so he pricked his fingers and was awkward.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But he did not tease Bellissima.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When evening came, and the house door stood open, he slipped out.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a bright, beautiful, starlight evening, but rather cold.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Away he went through the already-deserted streets, and soon came to the Metal Pig; he stooped down and kissed its shining nose, and then seated himself on its back.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You happy creature, he said; "how I have longed for you! we must take a ride to-night."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the Metal Pig lay motionless, while the fresh stream gushed forth from its mouth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The little boy still sat astride on its back, when he felt something pulling at his clothes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He looked down, and there was Bellissima, little smooth-shaven Bellissima, barking as if she would have said, "Here I am too; why are you sitting there?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A fiery dragon could not have frightened the little boy so much as did the little dog in this place.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Bellissima in the street, and not dressed! as the old lady called it; "what would be the end of this?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The dog never went out in winter, unless she was attired in a little lambskin coat which had been made for her; it was fastened round the little dog's neck and body with red ribbons, and was decorated with rosettes and little bells.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The dog looked almost like a little kid when she was allowed to go out in winter, and trot after her mistress.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And now here she was in the cold, and not dressed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, how would it end?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All his fancies were quickly put to flight; yet he kissed the Metal Pig once more, and then took Bellissima in his arms.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The poor little thing trembled so with cold, that the boy ran homeward as fast as he could.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What are you running away with there? asked two of the police whom he met, and at whom the dog barked.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Where have you stolen that pretty dog? they asked; and they took it away from him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, I have not stolen it; do give it to me back again, cried the boy, despairingly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If you have not stolen it, you may say at home that they can send to the watch-house for the dog.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they told him where the watch-house was, and went away with Bellissima.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here was a dreadful trouble.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The boy did not know whether he had better jump into the Arno, or go home and confess everything.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They would certainly kill him, he thought.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Well, I would gladly be killed, he reasoned; "for then I shall die, and go to heaven:" and so he went home, almost hoping for death.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The door was locked, and he could not reach the knocker.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No one was in the street; so he took up a stone, and with it made a tremendous noise at the door.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Who is there? asked somebody from within.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is I, said he.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Bellissima is gone.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then indeed there was a great panic.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Madame was so very fond of Bellissima.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She immediately looked at the wall where the dog's dress usually hung; and there was the little lambskin.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Bellissima in the watch-house! she cried.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
You bad boy! how did you entice her out?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Giuseppe went off at once, while his wife lamented, and the boy wept.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Several of the neighbors came in, and amongst them the painter.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He took the boy between his knees, and questioned him; and, in broken sentences, he soon heard the whole story, and also about the Metal Pig, and the wonderful ride to the picture-gallery, which was certainly rather incomprehensible.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The painter, however, consoled the little fellow, and tried to soften the lady's anger; but she would not be pacified till her husband returned with Bellissima, who had been with the police.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then there was great rejoicing, and the painter caressed the boy, and gave him a number of pictures.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, what beautiful pictures these were!- figures with funny heads; and, above all, the Metal Pig was there too.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, nothing could be more delightful.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: By means of a few strokes, it was made to appear on the paper; and even the house that stood behind it had been sketched in.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, if he could only draw and paint!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He who could do this could conjure all the world before him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The first leisure moment during the next day, the boy got a pencil, and on the back of one of the other drawings he attempted to copy the drawing of the Metal Pig, and he succeeded.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Certainly it was rather crooked, rather up and down, one leg thick, and another thin; still it was like the copy, and he was overjoyed at what he had done.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The pencil would not go quite as it ought,- he had found that out; but the next day he tried again.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A second pig was drawn by the side of the first, and this looked a hundred times better; and the third attempt was so good, that everybody might know what it was meant to represent.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And now the glovemaking went on but slowly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The orders given by the shops in the town were not finished quickly; for the Metal Pig had taught the boy that all objects may be drawn upon paper; and Florence is a picture-book in itself for any one who chooses to turn over its pages.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On the Piazza dell Trinita stands a slender pillar, and upon it is the goddess of Justice, blindfolded, with her scales in her hand.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was soon represented on paper, and it was the glovemaker's boy who placed her there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His collection of pictures increased; but as yet they were only copies of lifeless objects, when one day Bellissima came gambolling before him: "Stand still," cried he, "and I will draw you beautifully, to put amongst my collection."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But Bellissima would not stand still, so she must be bound fast in one position.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He tied her head and tail; but she barked and jumped, and so pulled and tightened the string, that she was nearly strangled; and just then her mistress walked in.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You wicked boy! the poor little creature! was all she could utter.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She pushed the boy from her, thrust him away with her foot, called him a most ungrateful, good-for-nothing, wicked boy, and forbade him to enter the house again.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THERE is a street in Copenhagen with a very strange name.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is called "Hysken" street.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Where the name came from, and what it means is very uncertain.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is said to be German, but that is unjust to the Germans, for it would then be called "Hauschen," not "Hysken."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Hauschen, means a little house; and for many years it consisted only of a few small houses, which were scarcely larger than the wooden booths we see in the market-places at fair time.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were perhaps a little higher, and had windows; but the panes consisted of horn or bladder-skins, for glass was then too dear to have glazed windows in every house.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This was a long time ago, so long indeed that our grandfathers, and even great-grandfathers, would speak of those days as "olden times;" indeed, many centuries have passed since then.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The rich merchants in Bremen and Lubeck, who carried on trade in Copenhagen, did not reside in the town themselves, but sent their clerks, who dwelt in the wooden booths in the Hauschen street, and sold beer and spices.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The German beer was very good, and there were many sorts- from Bremen, Prussia, and Brunswick- and quantities of all sorts of spices, saffron, aniseed, ginger, and especially pepper; indeed, pepper was almost the chief article sold here; so it happened at last that the German clerks in Denmark got their nickname of "pepper gentry."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It had been made a condition with these clerks that they should not marry; so that those who lived to be old had to take care of themselves, to attend to their own comforts, and even to light their own fires, when they had any to light.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Many of them were very aged; lonely old boys, with strange thoughts and eccentric habits.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: From this, all unmarried men, who have attained a certain age, are called, in Denmark, "pepper gentry;" and this must be remembered by all those who wish to understand the story.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: These "pepper gentlemen," or, as they are called in England, "old bachelors," are often made a butt of ridicule; they are told to put on their nightcaps, draw them over their eyes, and go to sleep.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The boys in Denmark make a song of it, thus:-

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Poor old bachelor, cut your wood, Such a nightcap was never seen; Who would think it was ever clean?
15:15	N:N	N:D	Go to sleep, it will do you good.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So they sing about the "pepper gentleman;" so do they make sport of the poor old bachelor and his nightcap, and all because they really know nothing of either.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is a cap that no one need wish for, or laugh at.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And why not?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Well, we shall hear in the story.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In olden times, Hauschen Street was not paved, and passengers would stumble out of one hole into another, as they generally do in unfrequented highways; and the street was so narrow, and the booths leaning against each other were so close together, that in the summer time a sail would be stretched across the street from one booth to another opposite.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At these times the odor of the pepper, saffron, and ginger became more powerful than ever.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Behind the counter, as a rule, there were no young men.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The clerks were almost all old boys; but they did not dress as we are accustomed to see old men represented, wearing wigs, nightcaps, and knee-breeches, and with coat and waistcoat buttoned up to the chin.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We have seen the portraits of our great-grandfathers dressed in this way; but the "pepper gentlemen" had no money to spare to have their portraits taken, though one of them would have made a very interesting picture for us now, if taken as he appeared standing behind his counter, or going to church, or on holidays.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On these occasions, they wore high-crowned, broad-brimmed hats, and sometimes a younger clerk would stick a feather in his.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The woollen shirt was concealed by a broad, linen collar; the close jacket was buttoned up to the chin, and the cloak hung loosely over it; the trousers were tucked into the broad, tipped shoes, for the clerks wore no stockings.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They generally stuck a table-knife and spoon in their girdles, as well as a larger knife, as a protection to themselves; and such a weapon was often very necessary.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: After this fashion was Anthony dressed on holidays and festivals, excepting that, instead of a high-crowned hat, he wore a kind of bonnet, and under it a knitted cap, a regular nightcap, to which he was so accustomed that it was always on his head; he had two, nightcaps I mean, not heads.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Anthony was one of the oldest of the clerks, and just the subject for a painter.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was as thin as a lath, wrinkled round the mouth and eyes, had long, bony fingers, bushy, gray eyebrows, and over his left eye hung a thick tuft of hair, which did not look handsome, but made his appearance very remarkable.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: People knew that he came from Bremen; it was not exactly his home, although his master resided there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His ancestors were from Thuringia, and had lived in the town of Eisenach, close by Wartburg.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Old Anthony seldom spoke of this place, but he thought of it all the more.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The old clerks of Hauschen Street very seldom met together; each one remained in his own booth, which was closed early enough in the evening, and then it looked dark and dismal out in the street.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Only a faint glimmer of light struggled through the horn panes in the little window on the roof, while within sat the old clerk, generally on his bed, singing his evening hymn in a low voice; or he would be moving about in his booth till late in the night, busily employed in many things.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It certainly was not a very lively existence.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: To be a stranger in a strange land is a bitter lot; no one notices you unless you happen to stand in their way.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Often, when it was dark night outside, with rain or snow falling, the place looked quite deserted and gloomy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There were no lamps in the street, excepting a very small one, which hung at one end of the street, before a picture of the Virgin, which had been painted on the wall.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The dashing of the water against the bulwarks of a neighboring castle could plainly be heard.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Such evenings are long and dreary, unless people can find something to do; and so Anthony found it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There were not always things to be packed or unpacked, nor paper bags to be made, nor the scales to be polished.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So Anthony invented employment; he mended his clothes and patched his boots, and when he at last went to bed,- his nightcap, which he had worn from habit, still remained on his head; he had only to pull it down a little farther over his forehead.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Very soon, however, it would be pushed up again to see if the light was properly put out; he would touch it, press the wick together, and at last pull his nightcap over his eyes and lie down again on the other side.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But often there would arise in his mind a doubt as to whether every coal had been quite put out in the little fire-pan in the shop below.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If even a tiny spark had remained it might set fire to something, and cause great damage.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he would rise from his bed, creep down the ladder- for it could scarcely be called a flight of stairs- and when he reached the fire-pan not a spark could be seen; so he had just to go back again to bed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But often, when he had got half way back, he would fancy the iron shutters of the door were not properly fastened, and his thin legs would carry him down again.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And when at last he crept into bed, he would be so cold that his teeth chattered in his head.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He would draw the coverlet closer round him, pull his nightcap over his eyes, and try to turn his thoughts from trade, and from the labors of the day, to olden times.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But this was scarcely an agreeable entertainment; for thoughts of olden memories raise the curtains from the past, and sometimes pierce the heart with painful recollections till the agony brings tears to the waking eyes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And so it was with Anthony; often the scalding tears, like pearly drops, would fall from his eyes to the coverlet and roll on the floor with a sound as if one of his heartstrings had broken.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Sometimes, with a lurid flame, memory would light up a picture of life which had never faded from his heart.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If he dried his eyes with his nightcap, then the tear and the picture would be crushed; but the source of the tears remained and welled up again in his heart.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The pictures did not follow one another in order, as the circumstances they represented had occurred; very often the most painful would come together, and when those came which were most full of joy, they had always the deepest shadow thrown upon them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The beech woods of Denmark are acknowledged by every one to be very beautiful, but more beautiful still in the eyes of old Anthony were the beech woods in the neighborhood of Wartburg.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: More grand and venerable to him seemed the old oaks around the proud baronial castle, where the creeping plants hung over the stony summits of the rocks; sweeter was the perfume there of the apple-blossom than in all the land of Denmark.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How vividly were represented to him, in a glittering tear that rolled down his cheek, two children at play- a boy and a girl.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The boy had rosy cheeks, golden ringlets, and clear, blue eyes; he was the son of Anthony, a rich merchant; it was himself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The little girl had brown eyes and black hair, and was clever and courageous; she was the mayor's daughter, Molly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The children were playing with an apple; they shook the apple, and heard the pips rattling in it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they cut it in two, and each of them took half.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They also divided the pips and ate all but one, which the little girl proposed should be placed in the ground.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You will see what will come out, she said; "something you don't expect.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A whole apple-tree will come out, but not directly."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they got a flower-pot, filled it with earth, and were soon both very busy and eager about it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The boy made a hole in the earth with his finger, and the little girl placed the pip in the hole, and then they both covered it over with earth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now you must not take it out to-morrow to see if it has taken root, said Molly; "no one ever should do that.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I did so with my flowers, but only twice; I wanted to see if they were growing.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I didn't know any better then, and the flowers all died."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Little Anthony kept the flower-pot, and every morning during the whole winter he looked at it, but there was nothing to be seen but black earth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At last, however, the spring came, and the sun shone warm again, and then two little green leaves sprouted forth in the pot.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They are Molly and me, said the boy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How wonderful they are, and so beautiful!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Very soon a third leaf made its appearance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Who does that stand for? thought he, and then came another and another.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Day after day, and week after week, till the plant became quite a tree.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And all this about the two children was mirrored to old Anthony in a single tear, which could soon be wiped away and disappear, but might come again from its source in the heart of the old man.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the neighborhood of Eisenach stretches a ridge of stony mountains, one of which has a rounded outline, and shows itself above the rest without tree, bush, or grass on its barren summits.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is called the "Venus Mountain," and the story goes that the "Lady Venus," one of the heathen goddesses, keeps house there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She is also called "Lady Halle," as every child round Eisenach well knows.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She it was who enticed the noble knight, Tannhauser, the minstrel, from the circle of singers at Wartburg into her mountain.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Little Molly and Anthony often stood by this mountain, and one day Molly said, "Do you dare to knock and say, 'Lady Halle, Lady Halle, open the door: Tannhauser is here!'"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But Anthony did not dare.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: IN the country of Wurtemburg, in Germany, where the acacias grow by the public road, where the apple-trees and the pear-trees in autumn bend to the earth with the weight of the precious fruit, lies the little town of Marbach.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: IT is winter-time.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The earth wears a snowy garment, and looks like marble hewn out of the rock; the air is bright and clear; the wind is sharp as a well-tempered sword, and the trees stand like branches of white coral or blooming almond twigs, and here it is keen as on the lofty Alps.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The night is splendid in the gleam of the Northern Lights, and in the glitter of innumerable twinkling stars.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But we sit in the warm room, by the hot stove, and talk about the old times.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And we listen to this story: By the open sea was a giant's grave; and on the grave-mound sat at midnight the spirit of the buried hero, who had been a king.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The golden circlet gleamed on his brow, his hair fluttered in the wind, and he was clad in steel and iron.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He bent his head mournfully, and sighed in deep sorrow, as an unquiet spirit might sigh.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And a ship came sailing by.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Presently the sailors lowered the anchor and landed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Among them was a singer, and he approached the royal spirit, and said, "Why mournest thou, and wherefore dost thou suffer thus?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the dead man answered, "No one has sung the deeds of my life; they are dead and forgotten.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Song doth not carry them forth over the lands, nor into the hearts of men; therefore I have no rest and no peace."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And he spoke of his works, and of his warlike deeds, which his contemporaries had known, but which had not been sung, because there was no singer among his companions.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the old bard struck the strings of his harp, and sang of the youthful courage of the hero, of the strength of the man, and of the greatness of his good deeds.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the face of the dead one gleamed like the margin of the cloud in the moonlight.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Gladly and of good courage, the form arose in splendor and in majesty, and vanished like the glancing of the northern light.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Nought was to be seen but the green turfy mound, with the stones on which no Runic record has been graven; but at the last sound of the harp there soared over the hill, as though he had fluttered from the harp, a little bird, a charming singing-bird, with ringing voice of the thrush, with the moving voice pathos of the human heart, with a voice that told of home, like the voice that is heard by the bird of passage.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The singing-bird soared away, over mountain and valley, over field and wood- he was the Bird of Popular Song, who never dies.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We hear his song- we hear it now in the room while the white bees are swarming without, and the storm clutches the windows.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bird sings not alone the requiem of heroes; he sings also sweet gentle songs of love, so many and so warm, of Northern fidelity and truth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He has stories in words and in tones; he has proverbs and snatches of proverbs; songs which, like Runes laid under a dead man's tongue, force him to speak; and thus Popular Song tells of the land of his birth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the old heathen days, in the times of the Vikings, the popular speech was enshrined in the harp of the bard.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the days of knightly castles, when the strongest fist held the scales of justice, when only might was right, and a peasant and a dog were of equal importance, where did the Bird of Song find shelter and protection?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Neither violence nor stupidity gave him a thought.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But in the gabled window of the knightly castle, the lady of the castle sat with the parchment roll before her, and wrote down the old recollections in song and legend, while near her stood the old woman from the wood, and the travelling peddler who went wandering through the country.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As these told their tales, there fluttered around them, with twittering and song, the Bird of Popular Song, who never dies so long as the earth has a hill upon which his foot may rest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And now he looks in upon us and sings.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Without are the night and the snow-storm.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He lays the Runes beneath our tongues, and we know the land of our home.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Heaven speaks to us in our native tongue, in the voice of the Bird of Popular Song.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The old remembrances awake, the faded colors glow with a fresh lustre, and story and song pour us a blessed draught which lifts up our minds and our thoughts, so that the evening becomes as a Christmas festival.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The snow-flakes chase each other, the ice cracks, the storm rules without, for he has the might, he is lord- but not the LORD OF ALL.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is winter time.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The wind is sharp as a two-edged sword, the snow-flakes chase each other; it seems as though it had been snowing for days and weeks, and the snow lies like a great mountain over the whole town, like a heavy dream of the winter night.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Everything on the earth is hidden away, only the golden cross of the church, the symbol of faith, arises over the snow grave, and gleams in the blue air and in the bright sunshine.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And over the buried town fly the birds of heaven, the small and the great; they twitter and they sing as best they may, each bird with his beak.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: First comes the band of sparrows: they pipe at every trifle in the streets and lanes, in the nests and the houses; they have stories to tell about the front buildings and the back buildings.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We know the buried town, they say; "everything living in it is piep! piep! piep!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The black ravens and crows flew on over the white snow.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Grub, grub! they cried.

There's something to be got down there; something to swallow, and that's most important.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The wild swans come flying on whirring pinions, and sing of the noble and the great, that will still sprout in the hearts of men, down in the town which is resting beneath its snowy veil.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No death is there- life reigns yonder; we hear it on the notes that swell onward like the tones of the church organ, which seize us like sounds from the elf-hill, like the songs of Ossian, like the rushing swoop of the wandering spirits' wings.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What harmony!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That harmony speaks to our hearts, and lifts up our souls!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is the Bird of Popular Song whom we hear.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And at this moment the warm breath of heaven blows down from the sky.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There are gaps in the snowy mountains, the sun shines into the clefts; spring is coming, the birds are returning, and new races are coming with the same home sounds in their hearts.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Hear the story of the year: "The night of the snow-storm, the heavy dream of the winter night, all shall be dissolved, all shall rise again in the beauteous notes of the Bird of Popular Song, who never dies!"
