author: HCAndersen
sentence: Our worshipful judges don't appear to have noticed this at all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Were I the sunbeam, I would give each one of them a sun stroke; but that would only make them mad, and they are mad enough already.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I only hope," continued the rose, "that peace may reign in the wood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is glorious to bloom, to be fragrant, and to live; to live in story and in song.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sunbeam will outlive us all."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What is the first prize? asked the earthworm, who had overslept the time, and only now came up.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It contains a free admission to a cabbage-garden, replied the mule.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
I proposed that as one of the prizes.
54:54	N:N	N:H	The hare most decidedly must have it; and I, as an active and thoughtful member of the committee, took especial care that the prize should be one of advantage to him; so now he is provided for.
55:55	N:N	N:H	The snail can now sit on the fence, and lick up moss and sunshine.
56:56	N:N	N:H	He has also been appointed one of the first judges of swiftness in racing.
57:57	N:N	N:H	It is worth much to know that one of the numbers is a man of talent in the thing men call a 'committee.'
58:58	N:N	N:H	I must say I expect much in the future; we have already made such a good beginning.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: ONCE upon a time there was little girl, pretty and dainty.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But in summer time she was obliged to go barefooted because she was poor, and in winter she had to wear large wooden shoes, so that her little instep grew quite red.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the middle of the village lived an old shoemaker's wife; she sat down and made, as well as she could, a pair of little shoes out of some old pieces of red cloth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were clumsy, but she meant well, for they were intended for the little girl, whose name was Karen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Karen received the shoes and wore them for the first time on the day of her mother's funeral.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were certainly not suitable for mourning; but she had no others, and so she put her bare feet into them and walked behind the humble coffin.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Just then a large old carriage came by, and in it sat an old lady; she looked at the little girl, and taking pity on her, said to the clergyman, "Look here, if you will give me the little girl, I will take care of her."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Karen believed that this was all on account of the red shoes, but the old lady thought them hideous, and so they were burnt.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Karen herself was dressed very neatly and cleanly; she was taught to read and to sew, and people said that she was pretty.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the mirror told her, "You are more than pretty- you are beautiful."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One day the Queen was travelling through that part of the country, and had her little daughter, who was a princess, with her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All the people, amongst them Karen too, streamed towards the castle, where the little princess, in fine white clothes, stood before the window and allowed herself to be stared at.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She wore neither a train nor a golden crown, but beautiful red morocco shoes; they were indeed much finer than those which the shoemaker's wife had sewn for little Karen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There is really nothing in the world that can be compared to red shoes!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Karen was now old enough to be confirmed; she received some new clothes, and she was also to have some new shoes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The rich shoemaker in the town took the measure of her little foot in his own room, in which there stood great glass cases full of pretty shoes and white slippers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It all looked very lovely, but the old lady could not see very well, and therefore did not get much pleasure out of it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Amongst the shoes stood a pair of red ones, like those which the princess had worn.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How beautiful they were! and the shoemaker said that they had been made for a count's daughter, but that they had not fitted her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I suppose they are of shiny leather? asked the old lady.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They shine so.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, they do shine, said Karen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They fitted her, and were bought.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the old lady knew nothing of their being red, for she would never have allowed Karen to be confirmed in red shoes, as she was now to be.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Everybody looked at her feet, and the whole of the way from the church door to the choir it seemed to her as if even the ancient figures on the monuments, in their stiff collars and long black robes, had their eyes fixed on her red shoes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was only of these that she thought when the clergyman laid his hand upon her head and spoke of the holy baptism, of the covenant with God, and told her that she was now to be a grown-up Christian.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The organ pealed forth solemnly, and the sweet children's voices mingled with that of their old leader; but Karen thought only of her red shoes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the afternoon the old lady heard from everybody that Karen had worn red shoes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She said that it was a shocking thing to do, that it was very improper, and that Karen was always to go to church in future in black shoes, even if they were old.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On the following Sunday there was Communion.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Karen looked first at the black shoes, then at the red ones- looked at the red ones again, and put them on.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sun was shining gloriously, so Karen and the old lady went along the footpath through the corn, where it was rather dusty.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At the church door stood an old crippled soldier leaning on a crutch; he had a wonderfully long beard, more red than white, and he bowed down to the ground and asked the old lady whether he might wipe her shoes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then Karen put out her little foot too.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Dear me, what pretty dancing-shoes! said the soldier.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Sit fast, when you dance, said he, addressing the shoes, and slapping the soles with his hand.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The old lady gave the soldier some money and then went with Karen into the church.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And all the people inside looked at Karen's red shoes, and all the figures gazed at them; when Karen knelt before the altar and put the golden goblet to her mouth, she thought only of the red shoes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It seemed to her as though they were swimming about in the goblet, and she forgot to sing the psalm, forgot to say the "Lord's Prayer."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now every one came out of church, and the old lady stepped into her carriage.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But just as Karen was lifting up her foot to get in too, the old soldier said: "Dear me, what pretty dancing shoes!" and Karen could not help it, she was obliged to dance a few steps; and when she had once begun, her legs continued to dance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It seemed as if the shoes had got power over them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She danced round the church corner, for she could not stop; the coachman had to run after her and seize her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He lifted her into the carriage, but her feet continued to dance, so that she kicked the good old lady violently.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At last they took off her shoes, and her legs were at rest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: At home the shoes were put into the cupboard, but Karen could not help looking at them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now the old lady fell ill, and it was said that she would not rise from her bed again.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She had to be nursed and waited upon, and this was no one's duty more than Karen's.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But there was a grand ball in the town, and Karen was invited.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She looked at the red shoes, saying to herself that there was no sin in doing that; she put the red shoes on, thinking there was no harm in that either; and then she went to the ball; and commenced to dance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But when she wanted to go to the right, the shoes danced to the left, and when she wanted to dance up the room, the shoes danced down the room, down the stairs through the street, and out through the gates of the town.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She danced, and was obliged to dance, far out into the dark wood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Suddenly something shone up among the trees, and she believed it was the moon, for it was a face.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But it was the old soldier with the red beard; he sat there nodding his head and said: "Dear me, what pretty dancing shoes!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was frightened, and wanted to throw the red shoes away; but they stuck fast.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She tore off her stockings, but the shoes had grown fast to her feet.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She danced and was obliged to go on dancing over field and meadow, in rain and sunshine, by night and by day- but by night it was most horrible.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She danced out into the open churchyard; but the dead there did not dance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They had something better to do than that.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She wanted to sit down on the pauper's grave where the bitter fern grows; but for her there was neither peace nor rest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And as she danced past the open church door she saw an angel there in long white robes, with wings reaching from his shoulders down to the earth; his face was stern and grave, and in his hand he held a broad shining sword.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Dance you shall, said he, "dance in your red shoes till you are pale and cold, till your skin shrivels up and you are a skeleton!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Dance you shall, from door to door, and where proud and wicked children live you shall knock, so that they may hear you and fear you!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Dance you shall, dance- !"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Mercy! cried Karen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But she did not hear what the angel answered, for the shoes carried her through the gate into the fields, along highways and byways, and unceasingly she had to dance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One morning she danced past a door that she knew well; they were singing a psalm inside, and a coffin was being carried out covered with flowers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then she knew that she was forsaken by every one and damned by the angel of God.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She danced, and was obliged to go on dancing through the dark night.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The shoes bore her away over thorns and stumps till she was all torn and bleeding; she danced away over the heath to a lonely little house.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here, she knew, lived the executioner; and she tapped with her finger at the window and said: "Come out, come out!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I cannot come in, for I must dance."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the executioner said: "I don't suppose you know who I am.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I strike off the heads of the wicked, and I notice that my axe is tingling to do so."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Don't cut off my head! said Karen, "for then I could not repent of my sin.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But cut off my feet with the red shoes."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then she confessed all her sin, and the executioner struck off her feet with the red shoes; but the shoes danced away with the little feet across the field into the deep forest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And he carved her a pair of wooden feet and some crutches, and taught her a psalm which is always sung by sinners; she kissed the hand that guided the axe, and went away over the heath.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now, I have suffered enough for the red shoes, she said; "I will go to church, so that people can see me."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And she went quickly up to the church-door; but when she came there, the red shoes were dancing before her, and she was frightened, and turned back.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: During the whole week she was sad and wept many bitter tears, but when Sunday came again she said: "Now I have suffered and striven enough.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I believe I am quite as good as many of those who sit in church and give themselves airs."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And so she went boldly on; but she had not got farther than the churchyard gate when she saw the red shoes dancing along before her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then she became terrified, and turned back and repented right heartily of her sin.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She went to the parsonage, and begged that she might be taken into service there.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She would be industrious, she said, and do everything that she could; she did not mind about the wages as long as she had a roof over her, and was with good people.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The pastor's wife had pity on her, and took her into service.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And she was industrious and thoughtful.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She sat quiet and listened when the pastor read aloud from the Bible in the evening.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All the children liked her very much, but when they spoke about dress and grandeur and beauty she would shake her head.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On the following Sunday they all went to church, and she was asked whether she wished to go too; but, with tears in her eyes, she looked sadly at her crutches.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And then the others went to hear God's Word, but she went alone into her little room; this was only large enough to hold the bed and a chair.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here she sat down with her hymn-book, and as she was reading it with a pious mind, the wind carried the notes of the organ over to her from the church, and in tears she lifted up her face and said: "O God! help me!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the sun shone so brightly, and right before her stood an angel of God in white robes; it was the same one whom she had seen that night at the church-door.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He no longer carried the sharp sword, but a beautiful green branch, full of roses; with this he touched the ceiling, which rose up very high, and where he had touched it there shone a golden star.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He touched the walls, which opened wide apart, and she saw the organ which was pealing forth; she saw the pictures of the old pastors and their wives, and the congregation sitting in the polished chairs and singing from their hymn-books.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The church itself had come to the poor girl in her narrow room, or the room had gone to the church.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She sat in the pew with the rest of the pastor's household, and when they had finished the hymn and looked up, they nodded and said, "It was right of you to come, Karen."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was mercy, said she.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The organ played and the children's voices in the choir sounded soft and lovely.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The bright warm sunshine streamed through the window into the pew where Karen sat, and her heart became so filled with it, so filled with peace and joy, that it broke.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her soul flew on the sunbeams to Heaven, and no one was there who asked after the Red Shoes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THERE was once a fine gentleman who possessed among other things a boot-jack and a hair-brush; but he had also the finest shirt-collar in the world, and of this collar we are about to hear a story.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The collar had become so old that he began to think about getting married; and one day he happened to find himself in the same washing-tub as a garter.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Upon my word, said the shirt-collar, "I have never seen anything so slim and delicate, so neat and soft before.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: May I venture to ask your name?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I shall not tell you, replied the garter.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Where do you reside when you are at home? asked the shirt-collar.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the garter was naturally shy, and did not know how to answer such a question.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I presume you are a girdle, said the shirt-collar, "a sort of under girdle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I see that you are useful, as well as ornamental, my little lady."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You must not speak to me, said the garter; "I do not think I have given you any encouragement to do so."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, when any one is as beautiful as you are, said the shirt-collar, "is not that encouragement enough?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Get away; don't come so near me, said the garter, "you appear to me quite like a man."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am a fine gentleman certainly, said the shirt-collar, "I possess a boot-jack and a hair-brush."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This was not true, for these things belonged to his master; but he was a boaster.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Don't come so near me, said the garter; "I am not accustomed to it."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Affectation! said the shirt-collar.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they were taken out of the wash-tub, starched, and hung over a chair in the sunshine, and then laid on the ironing-board.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And now came the glowing iron.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Mistress widow, said the shirt-collar, "little mistress widow, I feel quite warm.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I am changing, I am losing all my creases.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You are burning a hole in me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ugh!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I propose to you."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You old rag, said the flat-iron, driving proudly over the collar, for she fancied herself a steam-engine, which rolls over the railway and draws carriages.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You old rag! said she.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The edges of the shirt-collar were a little frayed, so the scissors were brought to cut them smooth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh! exclaimed the shirt-collar, "what a first-rate dancer you would make; you can stretch out your leg so well.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I never saw anything so charming; I am sure no human being could do the same."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I should think not, replied the scissors.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You ought to be a countess, said the shirt collar; "but all I possess consists of a fine gentleman, a boot-jack, and a comb.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I wish I had an estate for your sake."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What! is he going to propose to me? said the scissors, and she became so angry that she cut too sharply into the shirt collar, and it was obliged to be thrown by as useless.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I shall be obliged to propose to the hair-brush, thought the shirt collar; so he remarked one day, "It is wonderful what beautiful hair you have, my little lady.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Have you never thought of being engaged?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You might know I should think of it, answered the hair brush; "I am engaged to the boot-jack."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Engaged! cried the shirt collar, "now there is no one left to propose to;" and then he pretended to despise all love-making.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A long time passed, and the shirt collar was taken in a bag to the paper-mill.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here was a large company of rags, the fine ones lying by themselves, separated from the coarser, as it ought to be.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They had all many things to relate, especially the shirt collar, who was a terrible boaster.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I have had an immense number of love affairs, said the shirt collar, "no one left me any peace.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is true I was a very fine gentleman; quite stuck up.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I had a boot-jack and a brush that I never used.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You should have seen me then, when I was turned down.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I shall never forget my first love; she was a girdle, so charming, and fine, and soft, and she threw herself into a washing tub for my sake.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There was a widow too, who was warmly in love with me, but I left her alone, and she became quite black.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The next was a first-rate dancer; she gave me the wound from which I still suffer, she was so passionate.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Even my own hair-brush was in love with me, and lost all her hair through neglected love.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yes, I have had great experience of this kind, but my greatest grief was for the garter- the girdle I meant to say- that jumped into the wash-tub.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I have a great deal on my conscience, and it is really time I should be turned into white paper."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And the shirt collar came to this at last.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All the rags were made into white paper, and the shirt collar became the very identical piece of paper which we now see, and on which this story is printed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It happened as a punishment to him, for having boasted so shockingly of things which were not true.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And this is a warning to us, to be careful how we act, for we may some day find ourselves in the rag-bag, to be turned into white paper, on which our whole history may be written, even its most secret actions.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And it would not be pleasant to have to run about the world in the form of a piece of paper, telling everything we have done, like the boasting shirt collar.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: IT is so delightfully cold, said the Snow Man, "that it makes my whole body crackle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This is just the kind of wind to blow life into one.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: How that great red thing up there is staring at me!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He meant the sun, who was just setting.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
It shall not make me wink.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had two triangular pieces of tile in his head, instead of eyes; his mouth was made of an old broken rake, and was, of course, furnished with teeth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had been brought into existence amidst the joyous shouts of boys, the jingling of sleigh-bells, and the slashing of whips.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The sun went down, and the full moon rose, large, round, and clear, shining in the deep blue.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There it comes again, from the other side, said the Snow Man, who supposed the sun was showing himself once more.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Ah, I have cured him of staring, though; now he may hang up there, and shine, that I may see myself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was quite hoarse, and could not pronounce "Bow wow" properly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had once been an indoor dog, and lay by the fire, and he had been hoarse ever since.

author: HCAndersen

The sun will make you run some day.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I don't understand you, comrade, said the Snow Man.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Is that thing up yonder to teach me to run?
21:21	N:N	N:N	I saw it running itself a little while ago, and now it has come creeping up from the other side.
22:22	D:N	D:N	You know nothing at all," replied the yard-dog; "but then, you've only lately been patched up.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What you see yonder is the moon, and the one before it was the sun.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It will come again to-morrow, and most likely teach you to run down into the ditch by the well; for I think the weather is going to change.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I can feel such pricks and stabs in my left leg; I am sure there is going to be a change."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I don't understand him, said the Snow Man to himself; "but I have a feeling that he is talking of something very disagreeable.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The one who stared so just now, and whom he calls the sun, is not my friend; I can feel that too."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Away, away, barked the yard-dog, and then he turned round three times, and crept into his kennel to sleep.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There was really a change in the weather.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Towards morning, a thick fog covered the whole country round, and a keen wind arose, so that the cold seemed to freeze one's bones; but when the sun rose, the sight was splendid.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Trees and bushes were covered with hoar frost, and looked like a forest of white coral; while on every twig glittered frozen dew-drops.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The many delicate forms concealed in summer by luxuriant foliage, were now clearly defined, and looked like glittering lace-work.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: From every twig glistened a white radiance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The birch, waving in the wind, looked full of life, like trees in summer; and its appearance was wondrously beautiful.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And where the sun shone, how everything glittered and sparkled, as if diamond dust had been strewn about; while the snowy carpet of the earth appeared as if covered with diamonds, from which countless lights gleamed, whiter than even the snow itself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This is really beautiful, said a young girl, who had come into the garden with a young man; and they both stood still near the Snow Man, and contemplated the glittering scene.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Summer cannot show a more beautiful sight, she exclaimed, while her eyes sparkled.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And we can't have such a fellow as this in the summer time, replied the young man, pointing to the Snow Man; "he is capital."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The girl laughed, and nodded at the Snow Man, and then tripped away over the snow with her friend.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The snow creaked and crackled beneath her feet, as if she had been treading on starch.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Who are these two? asked the Snow Man of the yard-dog.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You have been here longer than I have; do you know them?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Of course I know them, replied the yard-dog; "she has stroked my back many times, and he has given me a bone of meat.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I never bite those two."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But what are they? asked the Snow Man.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They are lovers, he replied; "they will go and live in the same kennel by-and-by, and gnaw at the same bone.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Away, away!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Are they the same kind of beings as you and I? asked the Snow Man.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Well, they belong to the same master, retorted the yard-dog.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Certainly people who were only born yesterday know very little.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The cold is delightful, said the Snow Man; "but do tell me tell me; only you must not clank your chain so; for it jars all through me when you do that."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Away, away! barked the yard-dog; "I'll tell you; they said I was a pretty little fellow once; then I used to lie in a velvet-covered chair, up at the master's house, and sit in the mistress's lap.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They used to kiss my nose, and wipe my paws with an embroidered handkerchief, and I was called 'Ami, dear Ami, sweet Ami.'

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But after a while I grew too big for them, and they sent me away to the housekeeper's room; so I came to live on the lower story.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You can look into the room from where you stand, and see where I was master once; for I was indeed master to the housekeeper.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was certainly a smaller room than those up stairs; but I was more comfortable; for I was not being continually taken hold of and pulled about by the children as I had been.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I received quite as good food, or even better.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I had my own cushion, and there was a stove- it is the finest thing in the world at this season of the year.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I used to go under the stove, and lie down quite beneath it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ah, I still dream of that stove.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Away, away!"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Does a stove look beautiful? asked the Snow Man, "is it at all like me?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is just the reverse of you,' said the dog; it's as black as a crow, and has a long neck and a brass knob; it eats firewood, so that fire spurts out of its mouth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: We should keep on one side, or under it, to be comfortable.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You can see it through the window, from where you stand."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the Snow Man looked, and saw a bright polished thing with a brazen knob, and fire gleaming from the lower part of it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The Snow Man felt quite a strange sensation come over him; it was very odd, he knew not what it meant, and he could not account for it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But there are people who are not men of snow, who understand what it is.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: 'And why did you leave her? asked the Snow Man, for it seemed to him that the stove must be of the female sex.

sentence: But the Snow Man was no longer listening.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I might as well go, said the Snow Man, "for I think I am breaking up as it is."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: During the whole day the Snow Man stood looking in through the window, and in the twilight hour the room became still more inviting, for from the stove came a gentle glow, not like the sun or the moon; no, only the bright light which gleams from a stove when it has been well fed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When the door of the stove was opened, the flames darted out of its mouth; this is customary with all stoves.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The light of the flames fell directly on the face and breast of the Snow Man with a ruddy gleam.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I can endure it no longer, said he; "how beautiful it looks when it stretches out its tongue?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The night was long, but did not appear so to the Snow Man, who stood there enjoying his own reflections, and crackling with the cold.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the morning, the window-panes of the housekeeper's room were covered with ice.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were the most beautiful ice-flowers any Snow Man could desire, but they concealed the stove.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: These window-panes would not thaw, and he could see nothing of the stove, which he pictured to himself, as if it had been a lovely human being.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The snow crackled and the wind whistled around him; it was just the kind of frosty weather a Snow Man might thoroughly enjoy.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But he did not enjoy it; how, indeed, could he enjoy anything when he was "stove sick?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That is terrible disease for a Snow Man, said the yard-dog; "I have suffered from it myself, but I got over it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Away, away," he barked and then he added, "the weather is going to change."

author: HCAndersen

sentence: One morning he broke, and sunk down altogether; and, behold, where he had stood, something like a broomstick remained sticking up in the ground.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I MEAN to be somebody, and do something useful in the world, said the eldest of five brothers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
I don't care how humble my position is, so that I can only do some good, which will be something.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Your 'something' is not enough for me, said the second brother; "what you talk of doing is nothing at all, it is journeyman's work, or might even be done by a machine.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I should prefer to be a builder at once, there is something real in that.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A man gains a position, he becomes a citizen, has his own sign, his own house of call for his workmen: so I shall be a builder.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If all goes well, in time I shall become a master, and have my own journeymen, and my wife will be treated as a master's wife.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This is what I call something."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I call it all nothing, said the third; "not in reality any position.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There are many in a town far above a master builder in position.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You may be an upright man, but even as a master you will only be ranked among common men.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I know better what to do than that.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I will be an architect, which will place me among those who possess riches and intellect, and who speculate in art.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I shall certainly have to rise by my own endeavors from a bricklayer's laborer, or as a carpenter's apprentice- a lad wearing a paper cap, although I now wear a silk hat.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I shall have to fetch beer and spirits for the journeymen, and they will call me 'thou,' which will be an insult.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I shall endure it, however, for I shall look upon it all as a mere representation, a masquerade, a mummery, which to-morrow, that is, when I myself as a journeyman, shall have served my time, will vanish, and I shall go my way, and all that has passed will be nothing to me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then I shall enter the academy, and get instructed in drawing, and be called an architect.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I may even attain to rank, and have something placed before or after my name, and I shall build as others have done before me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: By this there will be always 'something' to make me remembered, and is not that worth living for?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Not in my opinion, said the fourth; "I will never follow the lead of others, and only imitate what they have done.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I will be a genius, and become greater than all of you together.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I will create a new style of building, and introduce a plan for erecting houses suitable to the climate, with material easily obtained in the country, and thus suit national feeling and the developments of the age, besides building a storey for my own genius."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But supposing the climate and the material are not good for much, said the fifth brother, "that would be very unfortunate for you, and have an influence over your experiments.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Nationality may assert itself until it becomes affectation, and the developments of a century may run wild, as youth often does.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I see clearly that none of you will ever really be anything worth notice, however you may now fancy it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But do as you like, I shall not imitate you.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I mean to keep clear of all these things, and criticize what you do.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And he kept his word, and became a critic.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And on that very account they thought he must be something.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You shall hear; it is quite a history.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The eldest brother, he who fabricated bricks, soon discovered that each brick, when finished, brought him in a small coin, if only a copper one; and many copper pieces, if placed one upon another, can be changed into a shining shilling; and at whatever door a person knocks, who has a number of these in his hands, whether it be the baker's, the butcher's, or the tailor's, the door flies open, and he can get all he wants.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So you see the value of bricks.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Some of the bricks, however, crumbled to pieces, or were broken, but the elder brother found a use for even these.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On the high bank of earth, which formed a dyke on the sea-coast, a poor woman named Margaret wished to build herself a house, so all the imperfect bricks were given to her, and a few whole ones with them; for the eldest brother was a kind-hearted man, although he never achieved anything higher than making bricks.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The poor woman built herself a little house- it was small and narrow, and the window was quite crooked, the door too low, and the straw roof might have been better thatched.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But still it was a shelter, and from within you could look far over the sea, which dashed wildly against the sea-wall on which the little house was built.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The salt waves sprinkled their white foam over it, but it stood firm, and remained long after he who had given the bricks to build it was dead and buried.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The second brother of course knew better how to build than poor Margaret, for he served an apprenticeship to learn it.

sentence: The sound of beautiful music came into my poor little room where I lay.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Towards evening, when the moon rose beautifully, though not yet in her full splendor, I glanced from my bed over the wide sea; and there, just where the sea and sky met, rose a curious white cloud.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I lay looking at the cloud till I observed a little black spot in the middle of it, which gradually grew larger and larger, and then I knew what it meant- I am old and experienced; and although this token is not often seen, I knew it, and a shuddering seized me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Twice in my life had I seen this same thing, and I knew that there would be an awful storm, with a spring tide, which would overwhelm the poor people who were now out on the ice, drinking, dancing, and making merry.

sentence: Young and old, the whole city, were there; who was to warn them, if no one noticed the sign, or knew what it meant as I did?

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: ON the last house in a little village the storks had built a nest, and the mother stork sat in it with her four young ones, who stretched out their necks and pointed their black beaks, which had not yet turned red like those of the parent birds.

sentence: A little way off, on the edge of the roof, stood the father stork, quite upright and stiff; not liking to be quite idle, he drew up one leg, and stood on the other, so still that it seemed almost as if he were carved in wood.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It must look very grand, thought he, "for my wife to have a sentry guarding her nest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They do not know that I am her husband; they will think I have been commanded to stand here, which is quite aristocratic;" and so he continued standing on one leg.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the street below were a number of children at play, and when they caught sight of the storks, one of the boldest amongst the boys began to sing a song about them, and very soon he was joined by the rest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The silken flag waved to and fro, on the shield itself a double eagle was displayed, and a big boot; the youngest lads carried the "welcome," and the chest of the workmen's guild, and their shirt-sleeves were adorned with red and white ribbons; the elder ones carried drawn swords, each with a lemon stuck on its point.

sentence: The builder was a man of low origin, but possessing great pride; his eyes and forehead spoke of large intellect, and Waldemar Daa was fond of listening to him, and so was Waldemar's daughter Ida, the eldest, now about fifteen years old; and while he was building the ship for the father, he was building for himself a castle in the air, in which he and Ida were to live when they were married.

sentence: This might have happened, indeed, if there had been a real castle, with stone walls, ramparts, and a moat.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But in spite of his clever head, the builder was still but a poor, inferior bird; and how can a sparrow expect to be admitted into the society of peacocks?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I passed on in my course, said the Wind, "and he passed away also.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was not allowed to remain, and little Ida got over it, because she was obliged to do so.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Proud, black horses, worth looking at, were neighing in the stable.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And they were locked up; for the admiral, who had been sent by the king to inspect the new ship, and make arrangements for its purchase, was loud in admiration of these beautiful horses.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I heard it all," said the Wind, "for I accompanied the gentlemen through the open door of the stable, and strewed stalks of straw, like bars of gold, at their feet.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Waldemar Daa wanted gold, and the admiral wished for the proud black horses; therefore he praised them so much.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the hint was not taken, and consequently the ship was not bought.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It remained on the shore covered with boards,- a Noah's ark that never got to the water- Whir-r-r-r- and that was a pity.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the winter, when the fields were covered with snow, and the water filled with large blocks of ice which I had blown up to the coast, continued the Wind, "great flocks of crows and ravens, dark and black as they usually are, came and alighted on the lonely, deserted ship.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then they croaked in harsh accents of the forest that now existed no more, of the many pretty birds' nests destroyed and the little ones left without a home; and all for the sake of that great bit of lumber, that proud ship, that never sailed forth.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I made the snowflakes whirl till the snow lay like a great lake round the ship, and drifted over it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I let it hear my voice, that it might know what the storm has to say.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Certainly I did my part towards teaching it seamanship.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
That winter passed away, and another winter and summer both passed, as they are still passing away, even as I pass away.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:

96:96	N:N	N:-	And so it was.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I twirled the weather-cock round on the summit of the tower, and it creaked like the snoring of a warder, but no warder was there; nothing but mice and rats.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Poverty laid the table-cloth; poverty sat in the wardrobe and in the larder.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The door fell off its hinges, cracks and fissures made their appearance everywhere; so that I could go in and out at pleasure, and that is how I know all about it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Amid smoke and ashes, sorrow, and sleepless nights, the hair and beard of the master of the house turned gray, and deep furrows showed themselves around his temples; his skin turned pale and yellow, while his eyes still looked eagerly for gold, the longed-for gold, and the result of his labor was debt instead of gain.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I blew the smoke and ashes into his face and beard; I moaned through the broken window-panes, and the yawning clefts in the walls; I blew into the chests and drawers belonging to his daughters, wherein lay the clothes that had become faded and threadbare, from being worn over and over again.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Such a song had not been sung, at the children's cradle as I sung now.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The lordly life had changed to a life of penury.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I was the only one who rejoiced aloud in that castle," said the Wind.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
At last I snowed them up, and they say snow keeps people warm.

114:114	N:N	S:S	Here was a life for high-born people!
115:115	D:N	D:S	'Give it up, give it up!'
116:116	D:N	D:S	But my Lord Daa would not do that.
117:117	N:N	N:N	'After winter, spring will come,' he said, 'after want, good times.
118:118	N:N	N:N	We must not lose patience, we must learn to wait.

120:120	N:N	N:-	I heard him as he thus spoke; he was looking at a spider's web, and he continued, 'Thou cunning little weaver, thou dost teach me perseverance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Let any one tear thy web, and thou wilt begin again and repair it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Let it be entirely destroyed, thou wilt resolutely begin to make another till it is completed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So ought we to do, if we wish to succeed at last.'

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
It was the morning of Easter-day.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: His coat was powdered with ashes, and there were ashes in his beard and in his tangled hair.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He stood erect, and held high in the air the brittle glass that contained his costly treasure.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: 'Found! found!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Gold! gold!' he shouted, again holding the glass aloft, that it might flash in the sunshine; but his hand trembled, and the alchymic glass fell from it, clattering to the ground, and brake in a thousand pieces.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The last bubble of his happiness had burst, with a whiz and a whir, and I rushed away from the gold-maker's house.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Late in the autumn, when the days were short, and the mist sprinkled cold drops on the berries and the leafless branches, I came back in fresh spirits, rushed through the air, swept the sky clear, and snapped off the dry twigs, which is certainly no great labor to do, yet it must be done.
139:139	N:N	N:N	There was another kind of sweeping taking place at Waldemar Daa's, in the castle of Borreby.
140:140	N:N	N:-	His enemy, Owe Ramel, of Basnas, was there, with the mortgage of the house and everything it contained, in his pocket.
141:141	N:N	N:-	I rattled the broken windows, beat against the old rotten doors, and whistled through cracks and crevices, so that Mr. Owe Ramel did not much like to remain there.

143:143	N:N	N:N	Owe Ramel offered Waldemar Daa permission to remain in the house till the end of his life.

145:145	N:N	N:-	Then I rushed against the house and the old lime-trees with such force, that one of the thickest branches, a decayed one, was broken off, and the branch fell at the entrance, and remained there.

158:158	N:N	S:S	The eldest and youngest, hand-in-hand, Went forth alone to a distant land."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: These were only two; here there were three, and their father with them also.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They walked along the high-road, where once they had driven in their splendid carriage; they went forth with their father as beggars.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They wandered across an open field to a mud hut, which they rented for a dollar and a half a year, a new home, with bare walls and empty cupboards.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Crows and magpies fluttered about them, and cried, as if in contempt, 'Caw, caw, turned out of our nest- caw, caw,' as they had done in the wood at Borreby, when the trees were felled.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Daa and his daughters could not help hearing it, so I blew about their ears to drown the noise; what use was it that they should listen?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So they went to live in the mud hut in the open field, and I wandered away, over moor and meadow, through bare bushes and leafless forests, to the open sea, to the broad shores in other lands, 'Whir-r-r, whir-r-r!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Away, away!' year after year."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And what became of Waldemar Daa and his daughters?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Listen; the Wind will tell us: "The last I saw of them was the pale hyacinth, Anna Dorothea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was old and bent then; for fifty years had passed and she had outlived them all.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She could relate the history.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Yonder, on the heath, near the town of Wiborg, in Jutland, stood the fine new house of the canon.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was built of red brick, with projecting gables.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was inhabited, for the smoke curled up thickly from the chimneys.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The canon's gentle lady and her beautiful daughters sat in the bay-window, and looked over the hawthorn hedge of the garden towards the brown heath.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What were they looking at?

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Their glances fell upon a stork's nest, which was built upon an old tumbledown hut.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The roof, as far as one existed at all, was covered with moss and lichen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The stork's nest covered the greater part of it, and that alone was in a good condition; for it was kept in order by the stork himself.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That is a house to be looked at, and not to be touched," said the Wind.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
For the sake of the stork's nest it had been allowed to remain, although it is a blot on the landscape.
180:180	N:N	N:N	They did not like to drive the stork away; therefore the old shed was left standing, and the poor woman who dwelt in it allowed to stay.
181:181	N:N	N:N	She had the Egyptian bird to thank for that; or was it perchance her reward for having once interceded for the preservation of the nest of its black brother in the forest of Borreby?
182:182	N:N	N:N	At that time she, the poor woman, was a young child, a white hyacinth in a rich garden.
183:183	N:N	N:+	She remembered that time well; for it was Anna Dorothea.
184:184	Sa:N	N:N	'O-h, o-h,' she sighed; for people can sigh like the moaning of the wind among the reeds and rushes.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: 'O-h, o-h,' she would say, 'no bell sounded at thy burial, Waldemar Daa.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The poor school-boys did not even sing a psalm when the former lord of Borreby was laid in the earth to rest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: O-h, everything has an end, even misery.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Sister Ida became the wife of a peasant; that was the hardest trial which befell our father, that the husband of his own daughter should be a miserable serf, whom his owner could place for punishment on the wooden horse.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I suppose he is under the ground now; and Ida- alas! alas! it is not ended yet; miserable that I am!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Kind Heaven, grant me that I may die.'

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
That was Anna Dorothea's prayer in the wretched hut that was left standing for the sake of the stork.
192:192	N:N	N:S	I took pity on the proudest of the sisters, said the Wind.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Her courage was like that of a man; and in man's clothes she served as a sailor on board ship.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On such another Easter morning as that on which Waldemar Daa imagined he had discovered the art of making gold, I heard the tones of a psalm under the stork's nest, and within the crumbling walls.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was Anna Dorothea's last song.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There was no window in the hut, only a hole in the wall; and the sun rose like a globe of burnished gold, and looked through.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: With what splendor he filled that dismal dwelling!

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her eyes were glazing, and her heart breaking; but so it would have been, even had the sun not shone that morning on Anna Dorothea.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The stork's nest had secured her a home till her death.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I sung over her grave; I sung at her father's grave.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I know where it lies, and where her grave is too, but nobody else knows it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
New times now; all is changed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Tell it better, any of you, if you know how," said the Wind; and he rushed away, and was gone.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: A SOLDIER came marching along the high road: "Left, right- left, right."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He had his knapsack on his back, and a sword at his side; he had been to the wars, and was now returning home.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As he walked on, he met a very frightful-looking old witch in the road.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Her under-lip hung quite down on her breast, and she stopped and said, "Good evening, soldier; you have a very fine sword, and a large knapsack, and you are a real soldier; so you shall have as much money as ever you like."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Thank you, old witch, said the soldier.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Do you see that large tree, said the witch, pointing to a tree which stood beside them.

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Well, it is quite hollow inside, and you must climb to the top, when you will see a hole, through which you can let yourself down into the tree to a great depth.
7:7	N:N	N:N	I will tie a rope round your body, so that I can pull you up again when you call out to me.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But what am I to do, down there in the tree? asked the soldier.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Get money, she replied; "for you must know that when you reach the ground under the tree, you will find yourself in a large hall, lighted up by three hundred lamps; you will then see three doors, which can be easily opened, for the keys are in all the locks.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: On entering the first of the chambers, to which these doors lead, you will see a large chest, standing in the middle of the floor, and upon it a dog seated, with a pair of eyes as large as teacups.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But you need not be at all afraid of him; I will give you my blue checked apron, which you must spread upon the floor, and then boldly seize hold of the dog, and place him upon it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You can then open the chest, and take from it as many pence as you please, they are only copper pence; but if you would rather have silver money, you must go into the second chamber.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here you will find another dog, with eyes as big as mill-wheels; but do not let that trouble you.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Place him upon my apron, and then take what money you please.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If, however, you like gold best, enter the third chamber, where there is another chest full of it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The dog who sits on this chest is very dreadful; his eyes are as big as a tower, but do not mind him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If he also is placed upon my apron, he cannot hurt you, and you may take from the chest what gold you will."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This is not a bad story, said the soldier; "but what am I to give you, you old witch? for, of course, you do not mean to tell me all this for nothing."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No, said the witch; "but I do not ask for a single penny.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Only promise to bring me an old tinder-box, which my grandmother left behind the last time she went down there."

author: HCAndersen
sentence:
Very well; I promise.
22:22	N:N	N:N	Now tie the rope round my body.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here it is, replied the witch; "and here is my blue checked apron."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: As soon as the rope was tied, the soldier climbed up the tree, and let himself down through the hollow to the ground beneath; and here he found, as the witch had told him, a large hall, in which many hundred lamps were all burning.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he opened the first door.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Ah! there sat the dog, with the eyes as large as teacups, staring at him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You're a pretty fellow, said the soldier, seizing him, and placing him on the witch's apron, while he filled his pockets from the chest with as many pieces as they would hold.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he closed the lid, seated the dog upon it again, and walked into another chamber, And, sure enough, there sat the dog with eyes as big as mill-wheels.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: You had better not look at me in that way, said the soldier; "you will make your eyes water;" and then he seated him also upon the apron, and opened the chest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But when he saw what a quantity of silver money it contained, he very quickly threw away all the coppers he had taken, and filled his pockets and his knapsack with nothing but silver.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he went into the third room, and there the dog was really hideous; his eyes were, truly, as big as towers, and they turned round and round in his head like wheels.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Good morning, said the soldier, touching his cap, for he had never seen such a dog in his life.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But after looking at him more closely, he thought he had been civil enough, so he placed him on the floor, and opened the chest.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Good gracious, what a quantity of gold there was! enough to buy all the sugar-sticks of the sweet-stuff women; all the tin soldiers, whips, and rocking-horses in the world, or even the whole town itself There was, indeed, an immense quantity.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So the soldier now threw away all the silver money he had taken, and filled his pockets and his knapsack with gold instead; and not only his pockets and his knapsack, but even his cap and boots, so that he could scarcely walk.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was really rich now; so he replaced the dog on the chest, closed the door, and called up through the tree, "Now pull me out, you old witch."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Have you got the tinder-box? asked the witch.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No; I declare I quite forgot it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So he went back and fetched the tinderbox, and then the witch drew him up out of the tree, and he stood again in the high road, with his pockets, his knapsack, his cap, and his boots full of gold.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: What are you going to do with the tinder-box? asked the soldier.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That is nothing to you, replied the witch; "you have the money, now give me the tinder-box."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I tell you what, said the soldier, "if you don't tell me what you are going to do with it, I will draw my sword and cut off your head."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No, said the witch.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The soldier immediately cut off her head, and there she lay on the ground.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he tied up all his money in her apron. and slung it on his back like a bundle, put the tinderbox in his pocket, and walked off to the nearest town.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a very nice town, and he put up at the best inn, and ordered a dinner of all his favorite dishes, for now he was rich and had plenty of money.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The servant, who cleaned his boots, thought they certainly were a shabby pair to be worn by such a rich gentleman, for he had not yet bought any new ones.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The next day, however, he procured some good clothes and proper boots, so that our soldier soon became known as a fine gentleman, and the people visited him, and told him all the wonders that were to be seen in the town, and of the king's beautiful daughter, the princess.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Where can I see her? asked the soldier.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She is not to be seen at all, they said; "she lives in a large copper castle, surrounded by walls and towers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No one but the king himself can pass in or out, for there has been a prophecy that she will marry a common soldier, and the king cannot bear to think of such a marriage."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I should like very much to see her, thought the soldier; but he could not obtain permission to do so.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: However, he passed a very pleasant time; went to the theatre, drove in the king's garden, and gave a great deal of money to the poor, which was very good of him; he remembered what it had been in olden times to be without a shilling.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now he was rich, had fine clothes, and many friends, who all declared he was a fine fellow and a real gentleman, and all this gratified him exceedingly.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But his money would not last forever; and as he spent and gave away a great deal daily, and received none, he found himself at last with only two shillings left.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So he was obliged to leave his elegant rooms, and live in a little garret under the roof, where he had to clean his own boots, and even mend them with a large needle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: None of his friends came to see him, there were too many stairs to mount up.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: One dark evening, he had not even a penny to buy a candle; then all at once he remembered that there was a piece of candle stuck in the tinder-box, which he had brought from the old tree, into which the witch had helped him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He found the tinder-box, but no sooner had he struck a few sparks from the flint and steel, than the door flew open and the dog with eyes as big as teacups, whom he had seen while down in the tree, stood before him, and said, "What orders, master?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Hallo, said the soldier; "well this is a pleasant tinderbox, if it brings me all I wish for."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Bring me some money, said he to the dog.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He was gone in a moment, and presently returned, carrying a large bag of coppers in his month.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The soldier very soon discovered after this the value of the tinder-box.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: If he struck the flint once, the dog who sat on the chest of copper money made his appearance; if twice, the dog came from the chest of silver; and if three times, the dog with eyes like towers, who watched over the gold.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The soldier had now plenty of money; he returned to his elegant rooms, and reappeared in his fine clothes, so that his friends knew him again directly, and made as much of him as before.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: After a while he began to think it was very strange that no one could get a look at the princess.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Every one says she is very beautiful, thought he to himself; "but what is the use of that if she is to be shut up in a copper castle surrounded by so many towers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Can I by any means get to see her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Stop! where is my tinder-box?"

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he struck a light, and in a moment the dog, with eyes as big as teacups, stood before him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It is midnight, said the soldier, "yet I should very much like to see the princess, if only for a moment."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The dog disappeared instantly, and before the soldier could even look round, he returned with the princess.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She was lying on the dog's back asleep, and looked so lovely, that every one who saw her would know she was a real princess.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The soldier could not help kissing her, true soldier as he was.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the dog ran back with the princess; but in the morning, while at breakfast with the king and queen, she told them what a singular dream she had had during the night, of a dog and a soldier, that she had ridden on the dog's back, and been kissed by the soldier.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That is a very pretty story, indeed, said the queen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So the next night one of the old ladies of the court was set to watch by the princess's bed, to discover whether it really was a dream, or what else it might be.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The soldier longed very much to see the princess once more, so he sent for the dog again in the night to fetch her, and to run with her as fast as ever he could.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the old lady put on water boots, and ran after him as quickly as he did, and found that he carried the princess into a large house.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She thought it would help her to remember the place if she made a large cross on the door with a piece of chalk.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then she went home to bed, and the dog presently returned with the princess.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But when he saw that a cross had been made on the door of the house, where the soldier lived, he took another piece of chalk and made crosses on all the doors in the town, so that the lady-in-waiting might not be able to find out the right door.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Early the next morning the king and queen accompanied the lady and all the officers of the household, to see where the princess had been.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Here it is, said the king, when they came to the first door with a cross on it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: No, my dear husband, it must be that one," said the queen, pointing to a second door having a cross also.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And here is one, and there is another! they all exclaimed; for there were crosses on all the doors in every direction.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So they felt it would be useless to search any farther.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the queen was a very clever woman; she could do a great deal more than merely ride in a carriage.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She took her large gold scissors, cut a piece of silk into squares, and made a neat little bag.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: This bag she filled with buckwheat flour, and tied it round the princess's neck; and then she cut a small hole in the bag, so that the flour might be scattered on the ground as the princess went along.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: During the night, the dog came again and carried the princess on his back, and ran with her to the soldier, who loved her very much, and wished that he had been a prince, so that he might have her for a wife.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The dog did not observe how the flour ran out of the bag all the way from the castle wall to the soldier's house, and even up to the window, where he had climbed with the princess.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Therefore in the morning the king and queen found out where their daughter had been, and the soldier was taken up and put in prison.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Oh, how dark and disagreeable it was as he sat there, and the people said to him, "To-morrow you will be hanged."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was not very pleasant news, and besides, he had left the tinder-box at the inn.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In the morning he could see through the iron grating of the little window how the people were hastening out of the town to see him hanged; he heard the drums beating, and saw the soldiers marching.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Every one ran out to look at them. and a shoemaker's boy, with a leather apron and slippers on, galloped by so fast, that one of his slippers flew off and struck against the wall where the soldier sat looking through the iron grating.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Hallo, you shoemaker's boy, you need not be in such a hurry, cried the soldier to him.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There will be nothing to see till I come; but if you will run to the house where I have been living, and bring me my tinder-box, you shall have four shillings, but you must put your best foot foremost.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The shoemaker's boy liked the idea of getting the four shillings, so he ran very fast and fetched the tinder-box, and gave it to the soldier.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: And now we shall see what happened.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Outside the town a large gibbet had been erected, round which stood the soldiers and several thousands of people.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The king and the queen sat on splendid thrones opposite to the judges and the whole council.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The soldier already stood on the ladder; but as they were about to place the rope around his neck, he said that an innocent request was often granted to a poor criminal before he suffered death.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He wished very much to smoke a pipe, as it would be the last pipe he should ever smoke in the world.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The king could not refuse this request, so the soldier took his tinder-box, and struck fire, once, twice, thrice,- and there in a moment stood all the dogs;- the one with eyes as big as teacups, the one with eyes as large as mill-wheels, and the third, whose eyes were like towers.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Help me now, that I may not be hanged, cried the soldier.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: I will not be touched, said the king.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: But the largest dog seized him, as well as the queen, and threw them after the others.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The princess came out of the copper castle, and became queen, which was very pleasing to her.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: THERE were once five-and-twenty tin soldiers, who were all brothers, for they had been made out of the same old tin spoon.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They shouldered arms and looked straight before them, and wore a splendid uniform, red and blue.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The first thing in the world they ever heard were the words, "Tin soldiers!" uttered by a little boy, who clapped his hands with delight when the lid of the box, in which they lay, was taken off.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: They were given him for a birthday present, and he stood at the table to set them up.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The soldiers were all exactly alike, excepting one, who had only one leg; he had been left to the last, and then there was not enough of the melted tin to finish him, so they made him to stand firmly on one leg, and this caused him to be very remarkable.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The table on which the tin soldiers stood, was covered with other playthings, but the most attractive to the eye was a pretty little paper castle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Through the small windows the rooms could be seen.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In front of the castle a number of little trees surrounded a piece of looking-glass, which was intended to represent a transparent lake.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Swans, made of wax, swam on the lake, and were reflected in it.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: All this was very pretty, but the prettiest of all was a tiny little lady, who stood at the open door of the castle; she, also, was made of paper, and she wore a dress of clear muslin, with a narrow blue ribbon over her shoulders just like a scarf.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: In front of these was fixed a glittering tinsel rose, as large as her whole face.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The little lady was a dancer, and she stretched out both her arms, and raised one of her legs so high, that the tin soldier could not see it at all, and he thought that she, like himself, had only one leg.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: That is the wife for me, he thought; "but she is too grand, and lives in a castle, while I have only a box to live in, five-and-twenty of us altogether, that is no place for her.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Still I must try and make her acquaintance."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then he laid himself at full length on the table behind a snuff-box that stood upon it, so that he could peep at the little delicate lady, who continued to stand on one leg without losing her balance.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When evening came, the other tin soldiers were all placed in the box, and the people of the house went to bed.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Then the playthings began to have their own games together, to pay visits, to have sham fights, and to give balls.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The tin soldiers rattled in their box; they wanted to get out and join the amusements, but they could not open the lid.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The nut-crackers played at leap-frog, and the pencil jumped about the table.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: There was such a noise that the canary woke up and began to talk, and in poetry too.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Only the tin soldier and the dancer remained in their places.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: She stood on tiptoe, with her legs stretched out, as firmly as he did on his one leg.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He never took his eyes from her for even a moment.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The clock struck twelve, and, with a bounce, up sprang the lid of the snuff-box; but, instead of snuff, there jumped up a little black goblin; for the snuff-box was a toy puzzle.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Tin soldier, said the goblin, "don't wish for what does not belong to you.

sentence: But the tin soldier pretended not to hear.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Very well; wait till to-morrow, then, said the goblin.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Now, whether it was the goblin who did it, or the draught, is not known, but the window flew open, and out fell the tin soldier, heels over head, from the third story, into the street beneath.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: It was a terrible fall; for he came head downwards, his helmet and his bayonet stuck in between the flagstones, and his one leg up in the air.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The servant maid and the little boy went down stairs directly to look for him; but he was nowhere to be seen, although once they nearly trod upon him.

sentence: If he had called out, "Here I am," it would have been all right, but he was too proud to cry out for help while he wore a uniform.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: Presently it began to rain, and the drops fell faster and faster, till there was a heavy shower.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: When it was over, two boys happened to pass by, and one of them said, "Look, there is a tin soldier.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: He ought to have a boat to sail in."

author: HCAndersen
sentence: So they made a boat out of a newspaper, and placed the tin soldier in it, and sent him sailing down the gutter, while the two boys ran by the side of it, and clapped their hands.

author: HCAndersen
sentence: The paper boat rocked up and down, and turned itself round sometimes so quickly that the tin soldier trembled; yet he remained firm; his countenance did not change; he looked straight before him, and shouldered his musket.
